summary: Found by residents of Bahriya at the Roman settlement of Kom el-Duwani, 1 km west of the village of el-Qamadir. The hoard consisted of 105 late Roman coins (AE 4), 102 of which were illegible.
408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.

The hoard comprised 16 silver coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-72) and was found close to a ceramic oil lamp which may have acted as a marker for the hoard. The hoard contained 10 shekels of the First Jewish Revolt: 3 Year 1, 3 Year 2, 3 Year 3, and 1 Year 5; 1 half-shekel of Year 1, 3 half-shekels of Year 2; 1 Tyrian Shekel (AD 52/3); 1 Antiochene tetradrachm.
18 denarii found together during the archaeological excavations at the Dacian fortress: Republic – Augustus (16 BC).
21 siliquae and 1 nummus, up to Honorius, AD 402.
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).

15 coins in a pot, found on Podington Wold in the early 19th century, including coins of Gallienus (AD 253-268) and Philippus Augustus (AD 244-249), a st1 described as of circular form with a hole for a winch, which sounds like a rotary quern, and fragments of pottery.
The hoard comprised 188 bronze coins from a variety of provincial mints in the Levant.
A hoard of 11 solidi (Constantius II to Arcadius) found in North Saqqarah, in a cache under a wall of 1 of the Christian houses north of the sanctuary.
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A hoard of 3 provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
27 Kentish potin and 1 Roman Republican denarius of C. Vibius Pansa (RRC 342). The Republican denarius is later in date than the potins.
The hoard comprised 371 denarii from the Republic to Domitian dating to AD 80-81. The Republican denarii are identified to 57 'families' but cannot be given RRC equivalents.
40 aurei found in a ceramic atramentarium (inkpot): Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-42).
231 denarii - republican and imperial issues - found witha an amphora at the a depth of 8m in the sea: Republic - Augustus (9 BC). In the same amphora was found a brooch spring.
2 coins: 1 Alexandrian bronze of Vespasian, 1 provincial bronze of Elagabalus found together with 6 lead tokens (produced in Memphis) during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 8 bronze coins, range: Carus - Constantinus' successors. Findspot is a Greek sanctuary. Possible, multiple votive offerings.
ca. 40 coins in a leather purse, but only 5 coins are identified: Septimius Severus (1), Postumus (4).
4127 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: c. 1261.0-5249.0 g
disposition: Musée d'Annecy, France; inv.no. 3477 (3828 coins); 400 coins dispersed

summary: 15 nummi: House of Constantine I (AD 306-361).
601 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
A hoard of Iron Age silver units dispersed in a field and discovered over a period of years. The latest addenda are not listed in de Jersey, but included here.

92 coins: 2 gold and 90 silver 1s: republican period: 1 victoriatus, 64 denarii, 3 denarii serrati, 11 quinarii; imperial period: 1 aureus, 1 gold quinarius, 10 denarii, 1 quinarius: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Museo Nazionale Romano in Palazzo Massimo alle Terme, Rome, Italy (inv.nos. 428195-428281)

summary: The hoard originally comprised 50.591 antoniniani: Gordianus III - Maximian I ( AD 293). Almost the whole hoard was acquired and now 45.873 coins are kept in the Museo di Castelvecchio, Verona. This find is ex10sively published. 168 kilos.
disposition: Verona, Museo di Castelvecchio, 45873 coins; otherwise dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 200 Roman coins, of which 62 were acquired by the Musée de Beauvais including antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus.
Unknown originally number of coins fund with a ceramic vessel. 23 antoniniani (radiates) were studied: Trebonianus Gallus - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
The hoard was found with a metal detector in 1983 'along the Sarum Road'. The 52 coins were all minted between 330 and 348.
39 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Most likely it is part of the hoard PLOURHAN 1881 (Plourhan II).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80316, 39 coins)

summary: The hoard was found during gallery constructions. It comprised c. 20 denarii from Augustus.
12 nummi found in the Roman villa. Unknown whether they were found together: House of Constantine I (AD 341-346).
Among the object found during the excavations at Haus Meer, were 9 nummi (AD 302-305) that probably belonged to a hoard.

The hoard was found in a barrel or box and comprised approximately 900 bronze coins arranged in stacks. The first account of the hoard gives the hoard as ranging from Domitian to Commodus, with coins of Hadrian and the Anto9s (with the exception of Commodus) being particularly numerous. A catalogue of 36 of the sestertii was created. In 1843 or 1844, it was noted that there were also 2 later coins in the hoard. The hoard was dispersed immediately amongst collectors, with a small number of worn coins kept by the finder. The Musée du Mans acquired some coins (which are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard).
disposition: Musée du Mans (coins are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard)

summary: The hoard comprised 254 denarii (10 serrati) from the Republic to Augustus (18 BC).

A hoard 437 coins (?), composed of 1 denarius (Maximinus) and 436 antoniniani (325: Julia Domna - Gallienus; 111: Gallic empire) to AD 263, found in excavations conducted by the curé M. Duchâtel in Noyers. Note that the catalogue only lists 324 antonininiani for the period Julia Domna - Gallienus and 109 for the Gallic Empire (i.e. 434 coins in total, and not 437).

A hoard of 14 coins, found in sector SO-XIII, in the area of the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Apsaros. The coins were 8 silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Hadrian to Caracalla) and 6 bronzes from Trapezus (Marcus Aurelius to Alexander Severus). All coins were burnt.
Uknown number of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 9 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Popovo: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Hoard of a large number of nummi. Only 9 pieces were recovered, all from the time of Constantine I.
disposition: Family of Mr. Alfredo Ayres Gouvêa Allen

summary: Few hundreds silver coins. 467 silver coins were reovered: Nero – Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further details.
disposition: Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu (420 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest (47 coins)

summary: 10 coins of unknown denomination and issuer found on the road to Hainburg. Apparently, they were minted in the 1st century AD.

The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius. The hoard was found in the north eastern corner of the Big Northern Room of a Roman building situated near the southern part of the wall in the eastern part of the lower city. It has been interpreted as an 'Emergency Hoard' with a Tpq of AD 249 (?) [RIC IV 107a]. Judging from the wear of the coins, it was desposited soon after the middle of the third century AD.
5 radiates "of Tetricus" found near the surface by a digger driver during gravel extraction at the site of the now destroyed supposed Iron Age hillfort known as "The Walls" in Nursling.
359 billon coins. Acquired by J.P. 6 together with another 2 (?) hoards, consisting in Ptolemaic bronze coins and 178 Roman folles respectively.
The coins were discovered around 1930/35. The circumstances of the find cannot be further ascertained. Nearly all of the specimens are of excellent preservation.

During the excavations of the shrine or fanum, 4 Iron Age coins (including 1 GERMANVS INDVTILLI L and 1 ROVECA) and 8 bronze of Tiberius (Caesar) depicting the altar of Lyon were recovered. There is some debate about whether these coins represent a hoard or a votive deposit.
4 aurei: Vespasian, Antoninus for Faustina I/Diva Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus. No detailed information.
3 aurei of Gallienus (AD 260-268). 2 of the coins are soldered. Traces of fire
1450 coins - possibly found with a ceramic vessel: 1 bronze Iberic, 1 as, 1 solidus, 8 antoniniani (radiates), 1440 nummi: 2nd c. BC - Honorius (AD 404-408). Together was found a golden ring.
disposition: Museo Nacional de Arte Romano, Mérida, Spain

summary: A possible scattered hoard of a Clacton type stater and quarter staters, found in the early 1980s. No further information available.
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
4 solidi: Valentinian I, Gratian, Arcadius, Theodosius II (AD 408-420); Gold w8: 17.8g;
6 Iron Age silver units, dug up at March, in Cambridgeshire, with about '40 other 1s'.

The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full ex10t is unknown. FMRD gives 3 lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 30622) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 30623) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 30624) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 30625)

300 small brass coins, mostly of Constantius and Magnentius, but a few of Constantine II and Constans were found dispersed among the soil, evidently after the cordon st1s of the tower had fallen from its top.
Circa 600 denarii, information provided on 540: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 4521); Lunds Universitets Historiska Museum, Lund (inv.no. 27544 - 3 coins), Sweden

summary: The hoard comprised 35 Iron Age coins and 1 obol from Massalia. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.062

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 100 'base silver denarii' [probably radiates]. The majority of the coins date to the period of Gordian and the Philips. According to TAF, it is possible that the closing date for the hoard is much later - Valerian I or Postumus?
The coins were in the old collections of Leroy de la Brière and E. Lambert.
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).
116 coins - 3 aurei and 113 denarii - found together during the archaeological excavations
7 coins of the first tetrarchs: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 3 nummi (AD 294-305).

391 silver coins: 287 denarii from Vespasian to Gordian III; 101 antoniniani from Gordian III to Philip I; 3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 1 provincial, 1 unidentified (AD 244-249); silver w8: 437.2-913.2 g.
Hoard of 66 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-267).
28 denarii found in the wall of the ”Domus of denarii”: Mark Antony - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.
3 coins found on surface 1 next to the other (AD 260-274).
Hoard of 80 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 232-254). 1 denarius of Severus Alexander among the coins.

Within lumps, the coins were arranged in stacks shifted sideways, 389 silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates). All coins were covered with a light green patina. There are 88 denarii: Clodius Albius to Gordian III and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Macrinus Valerian I and Gallienus).
The hoard comprised 2755 bronze coins dated between AD 348 and AD 355.

2 gold solidi were found during construction work in October 1979 in a bank of soil protecting a new housing estate at Haydon Hill, Aylesbury. They were found about 1 metre down in soil which could have come from almost anywhere on the housing estate.
disposition: British Museum (Theodosius coin); the other coin sold by Sotheby’s (15 July 1980, lot 196A)

summary: Circa 80 denarii were discovered in an amphora. They were all dispersed before being studied. 1 denarius of Augustus minted in Lugdunum in 12 BC was identified in a private collection where was displayed as a pendant.
The hoard comprised 110 coins from Hadrian to Gordian (III?) along with Roman pottery.

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
16 Iron Age potin coins, found in the woods at Castle Hill Ruffs, New Addington in 1978 and 1979.
The composition of this hoard was reconstructed by Paul Reinecke. The coins (10 denarii, ranging from Galba to Maximinus) were found in a wood belonging to the abbey at Met10, soon after 1800.

The hoard comprised an amphora containing more than 33 kilos of coins, estimated as representing more than 8000 examples. Vallier examined 'a suitcase full' of coins which included issues of Gallienus, Claudius II (rare), Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Florian, Probus and Numerian. It appears that there were also some earlier coins dating to the first or second centuries AD but the information is vague.

The hoard comprised approximately 10000 bronze coins of Diocletian, Maximian, Constantius Chlorus, Constantine I, Maximinus, Maxentius and Crispus (the presence of coins of Crispus should be treated with some caution). The hoard was quickly dispersed.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 50 coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
With 3 iberian denarii of Bolskan, 6 republican denarii and 3 denarii of Augustus (AD 19-18 BC).
Hoard of 493 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 492 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 134.9-1281.3 g.

Between 296 and 334 coins. The coins came out following the blasting activities on the Lueg Canal. G. Dembski considers as hoard these coins due to homogenous aspect of this numismatic evidence: Vesasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1258 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 1623.4-3383.4 g.
2 aurei (Nero, Vespasian), in a refuse pit by the side of the old Roman road from Colchester to Norwich.
15 gold coins: 12 solidi, 3 tremisses: Leo I - Justin I (AD 518-524); gold w8: 57.9 g.
196 nummi of Constantine I and its family (AD 335-337). Found within the temple of Hadrian.
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 1440 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Of this total, 1424 were catalogued by Chanel. Silver: 1358 coins; Silver w8: 246.9-3528.5g
Around 1000 antoniniani found with a ceramic jug: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
10000 nummi. According to Walburg: "extremely doubtful". "No details are reported, and indeed no further mention has ever been made of this hoard since Bopearachchi’s short notice quoted above.

The hoard comprised 2 separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the 2 hoards cannot be established with any certainty.

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: 307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: Unknown number of solidi found on the same field, 2 coins of Theodosius II and 1 of Zeno are known; gold w8: 13.35 g.

4 coins found on a terra sigillata dish as grave-goods with an inhumation on the Inner Relief Road site B, Colchester (St Johns Abbey). Found with a greyware jar.Further details of the grave in Crummy et al. 1993, 205ff record that this was a child's grave and also contained the cranium of a dog. The coins were in a leather pouch or purse and found stacked.
2 denarii of Augustus found in a st1 burial (S-A) during the archaeological excavation of Samtavro cemetery by I. A. Dzhavakhishvili.
Grup of 2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver w8: 5.32 g.
12 nummi: House of Constantine (Helena) - Valens (AD 364-375).

1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Julia Domna) and 78 antoniniani (radiates) (Julia Maesa to Gallienus), found in the northwest-west suburb of Kerch. 71 of these were published by N. Kunina in 1962. To these, Golenko adds a further 8 antoniniani.
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 216 coins (without doubt mostly denarii and antoniniani (radiates) and a range of silver vessels, gold and silver jewellery and a copper-alloy figurine. The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.
The coins (3rd - 4th c. AD) were found during sharding in 2007; they were corroded together and not identifiable.
At least 1772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
The hoard comprised a large ceramic vessel containing 62 sestertii of the first to third century AD.
Unknown number of denarii. 56 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Nero - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2590

summary: 20-25000 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. The latest coins belong to Honorius (AD 395-423).
disposition: Ca.mara Municipal de Paredes de Coura (5,000 coins)

summary: 14 provincial bronze coins: 13 Tomis, 1 Marcianopolis (Moesia Inferior): Pertinax - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie Constanța, Romania; Inv. nos. 78427-78440

summary: 79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

2747 bronze coins, ranging from the 4th century BC (Neandria) to Basiliscus (AD 475-476), found in a small pot during the excavations lead by G. Brunton at Qaw el-Kebir, south of Asyut. Most of the coins were late Roman nummi, with some Ptolemaic and Alexandrian bronzes and coins from Aksum. 1264 coins were barbaric imitations or casts.

In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found 4 silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: Probably circa 10000 nummi, only 2280 nummi were extracted from the bottom of the sea.

274 coins: 75 sestertii, 117 dupondii, 74 asses, 7 dupondii/asses, 1 bronze medallion: Gaius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-176). Together with the coins were found: 2 silver pans, 1 silver plate, silver wire bracelet.
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
866 bronze coins together with 4 billon coins ranging from Gordian to Hostilian.
disposition: National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sarajevo

summary: 115 nummi of Constantine I found with a ceramic vessel.
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only 6 provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
9 solidi: Honorius - Valentinian III (AD 426-455); gold w8: 40.05g.
64 nummi. Among them a coin of Constantius II ending with issues of AD 393-395.
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing a single dupondius or as of Gordian III and 60 radiates from Carus to Maximian I.
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 113-114 with 4 intruding coins.
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Philip II "and other emperors and empresses of the 3rd century".
Sometime before 1869, somewhere in the vicinity of Nantes, a hoard comprising several hundreds antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II was discovered.
Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, b1 artefacts.
Around 98 coins, of which 29 denarii, 4 bronze provincials, 65 bronze: Vitellius - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).
33 bronze coins found together in 1 insula of the former Roman city of Baetulo.

116 coins found in 1870 close to M1ybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed 2 separate hoards (1 consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
Hoard of 1000 nummi. No further information.

A hoard of 39 antoniniani (Gordian III and Philip I) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the middle of November 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on November 14, 2017. There is no additional information about the conditions of hoard find. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of more than 2000 coins of which only 47 were seen: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
54 nummi found on the floor of mosaic: Constantius II - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
6 coins, possible kept in a purse, found in a building with unknown use: 5 republican denarii, 1 aureus of Augustus (BC 9).
Unknown number of silver coins. 15 denarii of Vespasian are kept in the History Museum in Lovech, Bulgaria.
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1266-1280 (15 coins)

summary: A doubtful hoard of 3000 antoniniani (radiates) found by amateur archaeologists. Not confirmed by the "official research".
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
11 denarii: 5 republican, 6 imperial: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).
Within an ancient settlement was found a deposit of iron tools. Beneath were discovered 280 silver and bronze coins. The latest 1 from the mid-3rd century AD. No further information.
A bunch of 12 antoniniani: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
5 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Septimius Severus, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
2 denarii (Hadrian and Commodus for Crispina) and 25 solidi: Honorius - Justinian I (AD 527-565). Found together with several gold fragments and 1 piece of bronze.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 19800b ß denarii; 19130, 19310, 19536, 19800, 20214)

summary: Hoard found during construction work, supervised by archaeologists. 6 Aes coins found together, all fresh Vespasian coins of the year 71, probably the con10t of a purse. No further indication.
26 denarii found in 3 separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
The deposit was discovered over the course of several seasons of excavation at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site and comprised 27 bronze coins of Postumus.
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver w8: 880.6-5928.0 g.
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
At least 4 Gallo-Belgic E staters probably originating in a single deposit have been discovered in the mud off the south coast of Mersea Island.
3 solidi of Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 8 denarii were documented

4th century. Coins 1-2, 4-7, 5?, 9 - find spot Tr 63, 2m NW of House 1. With exception of heavily corroded & illegible No. 5, all of similar AD 330-50 Constantinian date, & occur within area of 1.5m, despite being topsoil finds. Poss. a small disturbed hoard. Nowakowski J.A. & Quinnell, H. 2011. Trevelgue Head, Cornwall. The Importance of C.K. Croft Andrew's Excavations. Cornwall County Council.Coin report by Reece pp. 245-256, fig. 101.1.

The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.
5 denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large st1s, animal b1s, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and 1 of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
The hoard comprised 11 electrum staters. It is not clear whether the hoard was found in a vessel. Collin notes links with the hoard from Denée.
(c. 400) 156 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan Decius - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Nero (AD 54-68) and Nerva (AD 96-98).

Not far from Cunetium, at the top of the Salisbury Hill, a pot was found containing a considerable number of coins, almost all British, with 1 coin of Tiberius. The coins were dispersed, although some were later given to the British Museum. It was noted that they included some small silver coins of Epaticcus. With them were some uninscribed British coins (Remic type), of the type which originally had a coin of Philip of Macedon for its pattern. -- see hoard http://chre.ashmus.ox.ac.uk/hoard/2327 as well.
At least 250 siliquae but only 20 siliquae entered museum collection: Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: National Museum of Ethnography and Natural History, Chișinău, Moldova; inv.nos. 13.415/AR 6.902-6.921

summary: The hoard comprised 294 denarii from Republican issues through to Vespasian (AD 69-79).
Hoard of over 100 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 15-16).

4600 coins dated between the end of the 3rd century and the 4th found during the excavations at the Roman villa. Most of the coins were nummi, some of them with the reverse REPARATIO REIPVB and GLORIA ROMANORVM. Fragments of linen were recovered from the coins, belonging to the bag with which the coins were kept.
disposition: Museu de Conimbriga/Câmara Municipal de Mêda, Portugal

summary: 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 931 radiates for which Bourriau provides a summary catalogue: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Atgier noted the presence of coins of Quintillus and Constantine but TAF believes this to be an error. The coins were acquired by the Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle. The jug handle is in the Musée d'Orbigny.
disposition: Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle (coins); Musée d'Orbigny (jug)

summary: 81 coins found in a ceramic vessel whilst demolishing a stable block: 65 antoniniani (radiates), 15 denarii, 1 sestertius: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-269).
21 coins found in group in the remains of a Roman building, while excavating in the cellar of the Theological Seminar.

The hoard comprised a flint nodule containing 10 silver coins attributed to the Eduens. Coutil suggests there was also a coin with the legend ATEVLA/VLATOS but this appears to be an error. The Musée des Antiquités de Rouen possesses at least 1 coin from the hoard (Scheers MGSM no. 168). Another is known from the Collection of A. Le Boucher.
The coins (9 sestertii, Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III) were found during building work on the premises of Neckarhalde.
153 silver coins found with a jug: 102 drachm, 48 didrachm, 1 Seleucid tetradrachm and 2 Seleucid didrachms.
Roll of 5 nummi found on a field near the Roman villa: Constantine I 5, Licinius I 2 (AD 316-317).
2 aurei of Constantine I minted in Treveri (AD 310-313).
Unknown initial number of coins. 82 bronze coins were studied: 81 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Titus - Gordian III (AD 240/241).
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 04 comprises 120 Iron Age coins.
4 Celtic staters.
Around 1000 gold coins found with crater: 1 solidus of Theodosius I and 2 gold pieces of Honorius and Arcadius are known; gold w8: c. 4450g.

The hoard comprised more than 500 Roman coins, which were immediately dispersed. P. Tes10oire-Lafayette identified 50 coins dating to the 4th century, which had been kept by the finder. It is thought that these coins are likely to be representative of the composition of the hoard as a whole.
A hoard of 276 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in room 2 of B. 8, east of the Agora.
214 radiates after AD 280. Found in a pit post-dating the rampart in a concreted mass. 1 official coin and 212 barbarous radiates of small module, 1 illegible coin.

Hoard of 460 coins: 446 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Gallienus, 11 denarii from Caracalla to Gordian III and 3 Provincial bronzes (Septimius Severus of Hadrianoi and Gordian III of Metropolis).
disposition: National Museum, Athens, Greece (124 coins and the list of the entire hoard)

summary: The hoard comprised 1 silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
120 denarii. 32 were donated to the History Museum in Silistra: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Apparently a small scattered hoard. 4 EISU stater and a VEP CORF stater were found successively in the same field over a period ranging from January 1986 to May 1987.
The hoard was found in small red brick 'ampoule' in a grave next to a skeleton. It comprised 307 radiates from Valerian I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270.
1 denarius, 33 antoniniani (radiates), 16 sesterti, 16 antoniniani (radiates) fragments, 4 nummi: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
7 coins: 1 denarius, 6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270). The denarius is unidentified.

A hoard of 16 antoniniani (Julia Domna - Gallienus), found in the shop II of the Stoa of Attalos, on the agora of Athens. The tpq for the hoard is given by the archaeological context, which corresponds to the the sack of Athens by the Heruls.
134 silver coins. 28 entered the National Archaeological Institute with Museum in Sofia: Republic - Vespasian/Titus (AD 69-81).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2806-2833

summary: 10 denarii, of which 3 of Tiberius, found with a small ceramic vessel.
7 denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).
The hoard comprised 1002 denarii and 2 drachms from Nero to Gordian I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1467.5g and 3140.8g.
1548 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 204); silver w8: 2788.4-4765.7 g.

Coins discovered during the excavations appeared to include 2 hoards, 1 of 7 nummi (Gatcombe I), the other of 9 nummi (Gatcombe II), found as quite distinct deposits trampled into a single occupation layer on the floor of building 3. Hoard I ends with coins of Constans, Aug., rev. VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN.
A hoard of 13 provincial coins of Athens (period VI), excavated in 1934 near a late wall, north of the Tholos. Their burial has been ascribed to the sack of Athens by the Herulians.
4teen Gallo-Belgic E staters were discovered over an area of ploughsoil, and a Clacton quarter stater was recorded as an addition to the hoard in 1992.
The hoard comprised 12 solidi of Honorius, only 1 of which was described in any detail. Gold w8: 53.4g.
Hoard of at least 167 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 1 imitation of a Macedonia Prima tetradrachm, 1 drachm of Rhoemetalces I, 161 denarii: Republic - Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: City Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria (161 coins); inv.nos . 2005 -2008)

summary: 3000 Alexandrian drachms/tetradrachms. No further details. 'Briefly menti1d (together with hoards nos. 7-8) in a letter to Milne by Dattari, who examined 2/3 of the hoard.'
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. 1 of them belongs to Faustina I and 1 to Lucilla.
3 solidi: Valentinian I, Valentinian III (2) found at different dates at the same findspot 'Hofstatt'.
disposition: Local museum, Fritzlar (inv.no. 308 - solidus of Valentinian III)

summary: 56 nummi: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 378-383).
disposition: Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: 2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver w8: 2765.1-5725.2g

Unknown originally number of gold coins. Only 7 pieces are known: 5 aurei, 2 solidi: Severus Alexander (2), Trajan Decius, Valerian I and Gallienus for Gallienus, Constantine I, Arcadius, Theodosius II; gold w8: 34.87-38.95 g.
300 silver and billon coins: 1 Augustus, 1 Vespasian, ending with Valerian I (AD 253-260).
8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and 3 silver spoons.
42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Hoard of 40 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 286-328). No further information.

Before 1889, 2 aurei of Tiberius and 1 of Claudius were found. It is not clear whether they were found together. The coins were acquired by the Musée Saint-Jean, Angers (Reg. IV, p. 144, nos. 565-566, 5.02.1889)

Coins found close to the Roman fort at Old Carlisle while metal detecting. The find comprised 1 aureus of Titus (under Vespasian) and 17 denarii ranging from Mark Antony to the reign of Septimius Severus.
A widely-scattered hoard, mostly found between 1990 and 1996, with 1 possible addition discovered in 2003.
hoard of 7 aurei and 196 denari found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Titus (AD 79-81).
460 nummi of the Tetrarchy placed directly on the ground: Diocletian - Licinius I (AD 311-312).
(c. 250) 45 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
Only 110 antoniniani (radiates) from a hoard of several hundred coins was preserved: Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 131.3g.
A hoard of 300-400 antoniniani (radiates). 336 coins were examined by Salama at the home of a dealer in Tunis on 6.5.1965: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 10 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. TAF interprets the hoard as being a purse drop.
2 Roman gold coins (Augustus) were found in the Venner Moor. A third specimen was found in the region of Venne and could well belong to the same find.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Anto9 period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
12 bronze coins of Viminacium probably issued under Gordian III and Philip I (AD 246-247)
disposition: Museum of Sofia; inv. nos. CIII and CLXVII (1936 and 1953)

summary: (c. 1000) 88 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 1251.6-2848.4 g
96 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of 42 nummi from the time of Constantine I.
4 nummi of the House of Constantine found during archaeological excavations at the Katsuren castle — a UNESCO world heritage site — which stood from the 12th to the 15th century AD.
A hoard of 62 Caesarean provincial bronze coins dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III.
The hoard was found in Burial 21 of a Roman cemetery and comprised a purse containing 32 coins of Magnentius, Valentinian, Valens and Gratian.
46 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
112 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel with 1 handle: 34 antoniniani, 78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2745

summary: 65 AR (Cistophori) found during excavations dating to between 190-53 BCE.
3 solidi of Leo I (AD 462-466); gold w8: 8.9-13.35 g.
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: Hoard of 31 denarii. Only 1 denarius of Antoninus Pius is known.

At the beginning of 1884, a mass grave dating to the 1793 war was found south of the Hammermühle in Wiesbaden-Biebrich. At the same place was also found a hoard of ca. 30 Roman denarii, ranging from the Republic to Elagabalus. FMRD lists 32 coins. The composition of the hoard is highly unusual and FMRD considers the last 3 coins (Antoninus Pius and Elagabalus) as po10tial intruders. If that was the case, the hoard would end with Titus.

During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
c. 20 denarii: Vitellius - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.

In 1732 a hoard was found in "Herrenwäldchen" near Schloßborn, whose con10t was soon afterwards identified as "heydnische müntz," which was at the time definitely a description for Roman coins. The coins, described as 'white', were melted down, totalling a w8 of 3044.446 g, which would correspond to 700 antoniniani or 1000 denarii.

In Room 15, part of 'Central Group' of villa rooms, there was a semi-circular pit 1.22m wide & c. 0.80m deep, dug through an earlier concrete op. sig. floor. In pit was a large Alice Holt storage jar at angle of 30°, with top broken away & wedged in place with a brick; & major part of a colour-coated Gaulish bowl. 20 coins in pit scattered throughout fill, but with some conc. between the 2 ceramic vessels. Coins from Constantine I to Constans Augustus, with 1 minim; of AD 330-350. Also a bronze 'lion mask' axle cap, an iron padlock & chain, frags. of 4 glass beakers & a glass bowl, a mortarium, & 2 metallic-glazed, rouletted Castor-ware box lids.
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 700 Roman Republican denarii.
31 coins: 29 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii found together: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Around 20 provincial bronze coins are known. 7 pieces were documented: Septimius Severus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
122 Iron Age coins, found in a field. No precise information on their context in known.
The hoard comprised 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Allectus and was found in a Gallo-Roman cemetery.
A hoard of 200 silver and bronze coins was dispersed: 44 provincial coins of Antioch (Pisidia) and 13 nummi of the period of AD 306-366).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (57 coins; inv.no. 2593)

summary: A large hoard of 2218 coins: Vespasian - Commodus. No further information.

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
1 solidus of Valentinian I, found in 1838, certainly associated with 4 nordic bracteates (6th c.), found in 1858. All were found close to Landegge, on the edge of the sand dune 10ge in the moor.
72 denarii of Augustus. No further details.
12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 16-26.8 g.

The hoard containing over 193 specimens dated from Tiberius to Caracalla was found in 1992. It included slashed coins, coins transformed into ornaments, and an unknown number of imitations. Unfortunately, the find was never published.
2 aurei Vespasian and Titus (AD 79-81) together with gold jewelry: 2 necklaces, 1 pair of earrings and a "Mercury".
disposition: Museum of Vienne, France, since 1946 (only jewelry)

summary: 520 imperial and provincial bronze coins: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). The bulk of the coins consists in issues of Marcianopolis (249+ ex.), followed by coins from Odessus, Tomis, Anchialus, Mesembria, Dionysopolis and Bizya.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (450 coins)

summary: 20 nummi of Constantine I for Constantine II (Caesra) minted in Londinium (AD 318).
The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.

In Room 15, part of 'Central Group' of villa rooms, there was a small, very shallow subcircular grave 0.43m long and 0.38m wide, cut into earlier concrete floor. This contained skeleton of a neonate, disturbed & mostly removed at later date, accompanied by 4 minims, 2 minimi, a bronze vessel frag., a pot sherd & a small amount of carbonised wheat grains. In same room there was also a small hoard of ingots (composition 60% copper and 40% lead) and a casting, placed in a small pit together with a pottery vessel.

A hoard of 180 denarii, ranging from Nero to Commodus. 9 denarii (Otho-Commodus) were found in 1938, on Lord Clyde's estate of Briglands, Rumbling Bridge. Subsequent discoveries at the same place were made in 1948-57, 2-thirds of the way up the steep left (east) bank of the River Devon, after a coin was found at the opening of a rabbit hole. 1 further coin was reported in 1972.
2115 nummi were discovered of which only 1671 survive: House of Theodosius - Anastasius (AD 491-518).
It comprised 3000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
The first (Δα) of 2 hoards found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street). It contained 6 nummi from the time of Constantine I.

A hoard of 103 Roman imperial denarii: Otho – Caracalla (AD 211-217) was discovered by 2 treasure hunters in the mid-October 2009 in the Kyiv region. The first report about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on October 26, 2009, and on October 29, November 2 and 23 photos of the coins were published. According to 1 of the finders, initially, not far from the unexcavated earlier pits from other treasure hunters, 71 coins were found on an area of 5x5 meters with a depth of 15-20 cm. At a later time, on the findspot was made sondage and the next 19 coins were found, and later – a further 13. The coins were cleaned by finders. The preservation of the coins is mostly good to very good. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates).
1900 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 294-306).
15 coins found in the rubble of floor of Roman edifice: Claudius II - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-383).
2 solidi of Theodosius II (AD 430-440), 1 is pierced; gold w8: 8.9 g.
20 silver and 1 gold coin, said to be of the upper and lower Empire, found by workmen making the railway from Prestatyn Station to the foot of Cwm Mountain.
8een aurei were found in a local earthenware pot. Some of them were pierced.
List of recorded coins in the catalog of coins under the find spot Stephanstraße. Of the 76 coins there are 6 specimens of a different provenance.
15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to NUMIS they are dated around AD 270. No further information.
116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
2 Gallo-Belgic Ca staters thought to be from the same deposit.
ca. 308 Iron Age potin coins, among which many fragments. No full report yet available.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins of which 13 were kept and including issues of Trajan to Postumus.
Coins from Trajan to Septimius Severus found with a ceramic vessel.
A hoard of 14 Republican denarii and 1 quinarius (Augustus) found in Stühlingen, were Roman buildings were found.
The hoard comprised 24 nummi dating to the period AD 351 to 378. They were found in the northern part of the area sacra at building XV.
5 solidi: Theodosius II, Leo I 2, Zeno, Anastasius (AD 491-518); gold w8: 21.78 g.
4 denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.

Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.
A hoard of 1005 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Tiberius to Nero), found during excavations in 1967 in Karanis, though no details about the exact findspot are known.
19 denarii found by metal detecting: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
1100 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1426

summary: The excavation of an inhumation grave uncovered a hoard of 31 very damaged/corroded imitation nummi measuring between 6 and 8mm in diameter.
119 coins: 1 denarius, 118 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259).
A hoard of 202 late Roman bronze coins (c. AD 270 - 4th/5th century AD), found during the excavations at Kellia, a Christian monastic community, 40 miles south of Alexandria.
A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.
The hoard comprised 10 coins and 61 debitage fragments from 125 BC- 4 BC.

In 1919 a farmer found more than 1000 Roman small bronze coins, ranging from Claudius II to Constantine I, in an amalgamated compact mass. Only a cursory description of the coins exist, and they are now lost.
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver w8: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: 45 nummi: Diocletian - Theodosius II (AD 408-423).
992 coins: 14 denarii, 900 antoniniani, 1 sestertius: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 259); and jewelry of precious metal
The coins were found on the st1 floor of a heating system in a trench dug at Förster/Karthause. The specimens lay in the doorway to the hypocaust heating room at the lower floor.
186 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Severus Alexander, found compacted together during building work on the Augustusplatz. A few coins were lost.

2 staters found about 60 m apart, at a depth of c.8 cm, in March 2000. Approximately 30 late Roman bronzes, and first or second century AD brooches, were also reported from the site. Not certainly a hoard.
The listed coins lay together under the label "railway 1914 N 46" in a box. All are deeply sintered.
The hoard was found in 1886, in "La Grange Rouge". It comprised 250 bronze coins of the Late Empire.
Unknown number of coins. 11 bronze coins have been noticed: Rhometalces I - Nero (AD 54-68).
A small urn found by a workman stubbing gravel. It contained 30 coins of the Lower Empire, 1 gold and 20-9 silver, in very fine preservation.

The Snettisham hoard F consisted principally of 9.2 kg of broken metalwork contained within a bronze vessel (Stead 1991, 447): fragments from at least 50 torques, at least 70 ingot rings/bracelets and 3 straight ingots, as well as 9 coins. 5 of the coins were contained within a piece of tubular torc. 7 more coins have been associated with this hoard, as they may be scatters from hoard F. The British Museum excavation conducted after the initial discovery revealed a further 27 Iron Age coins and further metal detecting revealed 11 more coins.
170 provincial coins: Nicopolis ad Istrum 77, Marcianopolis 69, Hadrianopolis 6, Odessos 4, Anchialus 9, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard consisted of an unknown number of Roman coins, only 10 of them had a basic description.
In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).

A hoard of ca. 2570 (?) coins (3 Ptolemaic or provincial Alexandrian coins; 2307 imperial coins; 260 Egyptian casts imitations), found in Meidum during the excavations of the University of Pennsylvania, in a house (ANS 99) made of mud bricks. The list given here is the 1 found in Noeske 2000, after MacIsaac. A slightly different account is given in Lease 1998.
disposition: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology (part) and the Egyptian Government (part)

summary: 3 nummi of Valentinian II found during metal detectation (AD 375-392).

The hoard comprised a vessel (or vessels) containing 7kg of coins, equating to approximately 2500 silver Republican coins and base-gold and silver Iron Age coins. In 1876, an excavation of the findspot revealed a further 60 coins which are likely to be part of the same assemblage. The number of Republican coins known from the site total 1298 plus a further 30 found in 1876. The Iron Age coins known from the site total approximately 1160 plus a further 30 in 1876.
The deposit was found during the demolition of Roman bridge piles and comprised approximately 4000 Roman Republican and Imperial coins, with the most recent being of Domitian.
2 boar/horse B silver units stuck together.
Unknown number of Roman coins. 5 denarii were placed in a liturgical cup in Limanowa!
13 coins found in a tomb: 6 Ptolemaic, 2 Alexandria provincial coins: Augustus, Tiberius. 5 tesserae.
8 bronze coins - 7 sestertii, 1 as - range: Galba- Trajan (AD 103-111) found in a ditch on the area of the Roman cemetery.
(4-5 kg) 280 silver coins: 75 denarii, 205 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver w8: 367.8-888.5 g.
651 silver coins: 435 denarii, 216 cistophori found with a jug: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of st1s and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).
Around 160 denarii of which 148 preserved, found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - augustus (-2 BC - AD 14).
disposition: National Museum in Kielce, Poland, inv. No. MNKi/A/2353/1-147; Regional Museum in Sandomierz (Muzeum Okręgowe w Sandomierzu), inv. No. MS-585/h

summary: 16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.
810 silver coins: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 1014.2-2363.7 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just 1 hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
1500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in 2 small pots in an underground room during excavations of a house.
Hoard of 50 denarii found in the Dacian necropolis. 36 were studied: Republic – Augustus (2 BC – AD 4). Found together with jewelry.
disposition: Eastern Carpathian Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (33 coins)

summary: 25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alerxander (AD 222-235). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: 1312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 249.3g.
19 nummi found close to each other on a floor, in a sealed quake context: Constantius II - House of Valentinian (AD 367-383).
116 silver coins: 4 denarii, 112 antoniniani: Caracalla-Diocletian (AD 292).
The hoard comprised nearly 1500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus to Probus, with coins of Probus being the most numerous. Only 1 coin of Gallienus' sole reign was described (RIC 599).
The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
28 coins found in the Dionysos House: 1 sestertius, 22 provincial coins, 5 undocumented coins: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Several poorly-recorded finds made over a period of 4teen years or more. The earliest discoveries seem to be those made in October 1986: 5 silver staters, 1 silver quarter stater and 1 struck bronze staters, all of the Durotriges. They were found within an area of approximately 50 m2, apparently with 2 small silver ingots. In March 1987 another silver stater was found in the same area, 4 staters are found "in the vicinity", in November 1987, and 2 silver staters are found in 1994.
2827 nummi and 1 Naimana imitation found with a ceramic vessel: House of Constantine I - Theodosius II/Marcian (Ad 425-457). "Only 276 coins could be identified; nothing is said about the rest."
disposition: Archaeological Department in Colombo, Sri lanka (Inv: EC/C/37) (2,547 coins); National Museum, Colombo, Sri Lanka (276 coins)..

summary: A hoard (or part of a hoard?) of 37 4th century nummi, known through a lot of 29 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (art market, Athens) and 8 further nummi presenting the same patina, confiscated from a dealer in Delphi in 1962. Mints represented are mainly the 1s from Italy, which is curious for Greece and might be explained by the fact that this hoard could be a purse loss of an Italian visiting Greece.
261 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard was found in a heap of st1s without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of st1s with no obvious container.

find_spot_name: TRIER - CHAPEL WEST CORNER TEMPELS AREA
summary: "The coins were found together in the trench Förster I, in a 60cm deep layer; to judge according to the composition, the coins probably were originally a hoard find."
(c. 1500) 64 antoniniani (radiates): 8 genuine, 56 copies: Valerian I (Salonina) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: c. 390.0 g.
3 solidi of Glycerius minted in Ravenna (AD 473-474). 2 of the coins are presumed to be exactly the same type of the third 1. Part of the Hoard PLOUŽNICE 2003?
disposition: Fridrich Götz (Jeweler) Collection, Mimon, missing today.

summary: Over 28 aurei, of which 8 are bearing the portrait of Claudius I. No further details.
The hoard comprised a large bronze vessel with a handle, filled with approximately 3000 'medium and small' bronze coins (nummi) of the Tetrarchy to Constantius II and Magnentius.
54 coins found spread close to each other in a layer of ashes: Domitian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
A hoard of 8 late Roman gold solidi was found 1990 by a man using a metal detector at Butterfield Down.

Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of 4 Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."
About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing 821 antoniniani (radiates). The catalogue made by Blanchet is not accurate. Aubin published a lot of 21 radiates in 1981 which probably came from the hoard. However, it is not clear whether these are additions or whether they were included in the original numbers. The hoard was found by a farmer. Silver: 821 coins; Silver w8: 222.6-1025.3 g.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie Nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (copper-alloy vessel, inv.no. 50253)

summary: In 1888 while digging in the garden of the Sandmeier farm in the parish Alswede, 180 denarii were found caked together. Later in 1891, a further 40 were found at the same place. 160 of these 220 denarii (ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus) were published in 1889-1891. The remaining portion of the hoard appear to have come into the possession of the Osnabrück museum. Compared with other hoards from Westphalia, LASHORST I has a higher percentage of barbarous imitations. - see the LATZEN hoard as well, showing that 2nd c. denarii circulated until the middle of the 4th c. AD.

2 groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinst1 Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as 1 find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.

The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.

The 3 coins found are likely to represent a portion of a larger hoard. The denarius of Balbinus was given to Desjobert; the second was given to the Mans Museum and the third to M. Nepveu of Bellefille.
disposition: Musée de Mans., France; Mr. Nepveu of Bellefille.

summary: The hoard comprised 42 coins including 2 sestertii of Commodus and Balbinus and a silver coin of Attila(sic).
20-1 coins were recovered, all from the topsoil, during a controlled search of an area of about half a hectare.
The hoard comprised bronze coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-70).
14 coins: 11 Roman Republican denarii, 1 Republican bronze, 1 denarius of king Juba and 1 Augustan denarius. The particularity of this hoard are the graffiti on the coins.
108 antoniniani (radiates)Ș Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).

A purse hoard recorded by Penhallurick as being found during Radford's excavations in 1955 of the Great Ditch below the Lower Ward's outer bank on the mainland part of the Castle. The purse was not recognised as such until later on and is thought to have been a leather draw string purse which contained 10 coins.
5 bronze coins found in room 42 of the 'Gordian's Palace': Antoninus Pius 1 sestertius, Faustina II 1 sestertius, 1 as/dupondius, Gordian III 2 sestertii.
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.
The hoard comprised 19 bronze coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 67-68).
A hoard of 7 bronze coins from the Severan time (after AD 192), found in grave 21 in the western cemetery of Pella.

A find of 10 or 12 gold coins of Constantine I, found near Holyhead. For a single gold coin of Constantine found in the same area in 1820, see HOLYHEAD MOUNTAIN 1825. All could be from the same find, but records are confused.

1200-1300 bronze coins, found in a vessel south of the Roman fort, together with a silver ring. The coins were dispersed. 25 of them were described, and 11 further coins are still preserved in the museum Landshut (therefore, 36 are listed in FMRD, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander).
237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver w8: 87.1-137.5 g
Survey and archaeological excavation of a ford uncovered when the river Seine was low, revealed a collection of more than 100 Iron Age and Roman coins from the Republic to Honorius.
The hoard comprised 94 provincial bronze coins dated between AD 49/50 and 252/3.
7 coins: 3 antoniniani (radiates), 4 radiate fractions: Gallienus (sole) - Tetrarchy (AD 303). Found together in the Roman villa.
disposition: Museu dos Condes de Castro Guimarães, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 2000 coins of 'copper, silver alloy and silver'. In the report compiled by P. Ilarregui the hoard contained pieces of the emperors: Pius Gordianus, Philip, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Gallienus, Saloninus (Caesar), Saloninus (Emperor) and Postumus. A small selection of 10 coins was sent to the Real Academia de la Historia.
disposition: Real Academia de la Historia, Madrid, Spain (10 coins)

summary: 17000 antoniniani (radiates). The hoard was split. The first results after the cleaning part of the hoard indicate the following issuers: Gallienus (sole reign), Claudius II, Victorinus, Tétricus I, Tetricus II (AD 271-274).
disposition: Musée d'Arras, France (part of the hoard)

summary: A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in 1 pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
2 antoniniani (radiates) of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
145 denarii: Republic – Augustus (27 BC – AD 14). Today, lost.
30 antoninianii, ranging from Gordian III to Volusian, were unearthed at the Roman fort Biriciana, on the via principalis near the porta dextra during excavations in 1892.
7 sestertii of Nero found during excavations at the Roman fort of Albaniana.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a copper-alloy finger ring, 2 gold finger rings, 1 with an engraved intaglio setting and 2334 denarii and radiates from Antoninus Pius to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 702.5g to 6042.8g.

3 Roman hoards found in St1a. This hoard comprises 37 denarii ranging up to Gordian III and was found with Iron Age coins seen as a separate group (St1a Grange I group I). Part of the group was detected from site prior to excavation.
250 coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 247 sestertii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 213-217); silver w8: 7.4-8.5 g.
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
320 nummi found in the Baths of the Months. 283 coins issued for Maxentius (AD 312).
242 antoniniani: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
(?) 112 silver coins: 17 denarii, 95 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258); silver w8: c. 875.6-1818.9 g
disposition: Town Museum Marienmont, Morlanwelz-Marienmont, Belgium (109 coins)

summary: 6 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (6 coins).

summary: The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.

Over 3000 antoniniani (radiates) (8 kg) found with a amphora-like vessel. The largest number of coins belongs to Postumus. Other issuers: Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina. An Alexander is menti1d among issuers, Severus Alexander (?).

Over 90 coins: antoniniani, provincial bronze medallions, provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (Ad 238-244). Provincial coins were minted in: Pautalia, Serdica, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Deultum, Anchialus.

Since at least 1969, an uncertain number of water-worn Iron Age staters have been recovered from the beach at Barton-on-Sea, mostly just to the west of the small stream which runs onto the beach at Beckton Bunny. They have presumably come from a hoard eroded out of the low cliff.

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
85 nummi closing with issues of Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
Unknown number of coins. 46 coins of Nerva and 31 of Hadrian were in possession of the antiquarian Fornier.
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a m1y-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel covered with a tile containing 2300 nummi of the Tetrarchy.
The hoard, found in a temple box, comprised 207 bronzes of the 3rd c. AD.
500-600 nummi of the tetrarchs (AD 294-305).
Hoard found during ploughing, 200 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
(c. 230) 206 coins: 140 antoniniani and 66 nummi: Valerian I/Gallienus - Constantine I/Maxentius (AD 309-312)

Both coins are Iron Age gold coins produced between Caesar's invasions of Britain (55/54 BC) and the Roman Conquest in AD 43. They belong to the so-called 'Western series', which is of10 attributed to the Dobunni. (PAS).

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). 8 coins have been lost.

494 coins found with a bronze vessel: 2 gold medallions, 6 aurei, 486 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold w8: 63.6 g.; silver w8: 133.8-1515.2 g. The hoard was found by a farmer. The multiple of Gallienus was acquired by the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.
956 nummi: Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 406-408).
86 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 15-37).

An important site lying on high ground on the southern edge of the Downs, roughly in the centre-east of the Isle of Wight. The Iron Age coins were found over an area of at least 1 hectare, with "little clear evidence of clustering although the 2 quarter staters of Tincomaros [sic] were found no more than 3 metres apart"; other material (including almost 400 Roman coins, 8 finger rings, 6 pins and 33 copper alloy brooches) was found over a wider area of some 2.5 ha. This may be consis10t with a ritual site frequented over a longer period.
(1900) 1898 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256-257); silver w8: 1324.4-2705.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. no. 923 1-248

summary: A hoard of 2 gold coins (Arcadius and Constantine III), found in the county of West Betuwe at Tiel in 1994, 50 cm apart from each other.
79 denarii and antoniniani were found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
179 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 forgeries (antoniniani): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, dated between AD 244-253.
13 asses found as a foundation offering: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 50-54).

In 1983, workmen digging footings trenches discovered a hoard comprising 610 bronze coins - 484 regular issues of AD 320-48 and 126 irregular copies of types of AD 330-48. Some coins might have been lost while the coins were removed from the site.
disposition: Hampshire County Council Museums Service (part); Unknown (part)

summary: The hoard comprised more than 230 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta and Julia Domna) - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 288.1-596.9 g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (198 coins; inv.nos. III 2099-2102); Musée d'Avranches (32 coins)

summary: In 1854, 300 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi were discovered, probably within the bath-house at Divonne-les-Bains. TAF interprets the assemblage as a votive deposit.
Unknown initial number of coins. 24 provincial bronze coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of Iron Age and Roman coins, found in an urn, ploughing in a field known as the 11 Acres. Sir John Evans succeeded in examining 249 of the coins: 10 gold coins of the Dobunni, 232 silver coins of the Dobunni, 3 Roman denarii, and 4 bronze coins.
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are menti1d), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.
3 gold coins (1 solidus of Justinian, before 538; 2 tremissis of Athalaric, in the name of Justinian, 526-534) found together with 2 gold bars.
14 small Roman coins (Gallienus - AD 347/8), found by field workers together in a field in Striesen near Dresden.

The hoard comprised 1094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver w8: 208.4-798.1 g.
The hoard comprised 1 tetradrachm and 22 bronze coins of Tyre, deposited after 74 BC.
23 coins found in 3 piles found near a wall: 22 antoniniani (radiates).

In 1993-4, several rare types of South Thames coinage began to appear in some numbers in the trade. Various possible findspots were suggested, including Clanfield, Butser Hill and "near Petersfield", but the true location seems to have been about half way between Clanfield and Hambledon. Precise figures are impossible to establish.
11 Celtic staters. The hoard was found when an old tree was uprooted.
3 coins published in BNJ 57 (1987), pl. 1.16-18, presumably forming a small hoard.
28 Late Roman coins (Constantine I - Constantius II) forming probably a small hoard.

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: 63 coins: 9 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Found in the baths.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 743-782

summary: A hoard of ca. 80 bronze coins, ranging from Diocletian to the time of Constantine I, found in Ludwigstraße in 1922.
see EMMERSWEILER A (ID 16729) for details.
4 Roman AE coins and 1 Iron Age silver unit, found in a barrow, in which were found human b1s as well.
Originally, there were 300 denarii. Only 128 were available for study: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
The hoard comprised 2109 antoniniani (radiates) and 'aureliani' dated between AD 247-293.
About 2000 antoniniani and 4 aurei up to AD 270.
The hoard comprised 335 antoniniani (radiates) dating between the reigns of Valerian and Claudius II.
disposition: Dispersed in trade. Recorded at the British Museum.

summary: The hoard comprised 99 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 270-275 and AD 284-305.
The hoard comprised a radiate of Divus Claudius II and 14 nummi of the House of Constantine with a tpq of AD 347 to 348. It was found during the excavation of Insula 20 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana.
11 denarii piled together found in a kitchen of the hillfort: Republic - Augustus (15-13 BC).
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: 6 uncertain imperial coins (Vespasian-Aurelian).
745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).

Preliminary record of a small hoard of Gallo-Belgic E staters found in October 2010. The classifications given on the PAS record vary slightly from the assessment by John Sills which is given in de Jersey.
4 solidi: Theodosius II - Majorian (AD 457-461); gold w8: 17.8 g. Found at different times on the same field.

A hoard of 353 Roman copper alloy coins discovered in 1990 and declared as Po10tial Treasure Trove. The coins are believed to be nummi, and 1 has been identified as an AE 3/4 of Constantine II (317 - 340 AD). They were found in a ceramic vessel; a black burnished ware pot now in 20 pieces glued together. The coins do not appear to have been catalogued.The hoard was acquired by Clifton Park Museum, Rotherham on the 29th September 1990.Other PAS records associated with this hoard: SWYOR-78C8E4
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 6 gold coins and 29 silver coins of the Roman emperors. No further information.
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
79 denarii found en ruleau while digging a ditch: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223). Some coins may be intruders.
disposition: Collection of the public grammar school in Kalmar

summary: 23 coins (sestertii and dupondii of Trajan and Hadrian) found in Athens in the Academia Platonos area. No further information available.
The hoard comprised a broken earthenware vessel containing 50 'middle bronzes' of Augustus, including 1 with a reverse type depicting the Altar of Lyon
Circa hundreds of nummi found while digging a ditch. 12 coins were seen, among issuers: Theodosius I, Honorius, Arcadius.
16 coins found together in a Roman house: 1 denarius, 15 nummi: Severus Alexander - Valens (AD 367-375).

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 1000 and 2000 Roman silver and billon coins, assumed to be radiates and nummi. 300 were examined by Pottier and 80 by Billiard. Found by a labourer in a quarry
103 nummi found in a fire layer from a domestic building: Claudius II (Divus) - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Convento dos Lóios, Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 33 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 1970.1.33/1 to 33
Hoard either of 98 or 40 denarii. Some of Augustus, the others of Tiberius (AD 14-37).

3000 antoniniani (ranging from Trajan Decius to Tetricus, several of which are imitations) fund in a vessel close to Nieder-Ingelheim. 1174 specimens reached the museum Wiesbaden, the other coins are lost.

Unknown originally number of denarii. 199 denarii were examined and identified: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4). Found somewhere in the Vratsa/Montana/Pleven regions. Seized by the custom authorities at Sofia Airport in November 2000 during an illicit export attempt. Unpublished (Paunov 2021, 31-32).

A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as menti1d in Noe).
2 silver units found "on top of each other" at a depth of 15 - 20 cm.
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
4 coins on PAS database centered to village - possibly a hoard or addenda to 1 of the previous hoards?Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-531F17
265 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228).

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious st1s; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a st1 statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
The hoard comprised 53 bronze coins dated between AD 69 and AD 247-249.
