Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

Found during excavations in a Gallo-Roman "Vierecktempel" on a hilltop, above a cliff. Among many single finds a depot of 66 antoniniani (latest coin Diocletian, AD 293), found in the cella of the temple.
(211) 207 denarii in a ceramic vessel: 88 republican, 109 imperial: Republic - Titus (AD 79-81).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv. no. M III 5135-5334 (203 coins) - stolen in 2003

summary: The coins were found in a purse close to the head in Burial 160 and comprised 26 coins from Claudius II to Julian II (Caesar) along with 22 bronze and lead alloy rings. A nummus of Magnentius was found in the left hand of the burial and 2 coins of Magnentius were placed in the eye sockets of the skeleton.

2 hoards (Kilkis A and B) were acquired by the museum of Thessaloniki in 1966 after having been found by some villagers in the areas of the Prefecture of Kilkis. Kilkis B comprised 11 4th century nummi.

A small hoard seen by a private collector, which was said to have contained 3 Durotrigan staters and between 5 and 7 Gallo-Belgic E staters. The only coin of which an image is available is described as gold, and is evidently very early in the Durotrigan series. — The coin in question is described as base gold but probably higher in silver?

At least 9 parcels of coins have been recovered on this site, apparently originating from a single hoard. de Jersey includes coins from trade which are more or less reliably said to be from the Driffield hoard, but are not included in Treasure cases.
131 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto.'

summary: 50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: 4 denarii (2 Republic, 1 Tiberius, 1 Trajan) to Trajan and 4 IA gold staters
4 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Septimius Severus, Caracalla.
69 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 68 nummi found in a presumptive funerary environment of a Roman villa. Probably were placed in an organic bag, which disintegrated during centuries.

The find comprised 3 aurei each mounted in a gold 'opus interrasile' hexagonal setting, mounted with loops, clearly originally part of a necklace. The find was made during the excavations of Théodose Bonnin. The aureus of Elagabalus was acquired by the Musée d'Évreux (Inv. 7253). The aureus of Caracalla entered the collection of General Gazan and the aureus of Macrinus, the collection of Dr Verville. Both were later bought by the Cabinet des Médailles (BN Inv. 1161 & 1215 = Monuments d'or et d'argent Nos. 154-155) without any mention of their findspot.
disposition: Musée d'Évreux (Inv. 7253); General Gazan collection, later in Cabinet des Médailles (BN Inv. 1161 and 1215 = Monuments d'or et d'argent Nos. 154-155), Paris

summary: 25 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, found together in a lump, on the site of the vicus of the Roman fort Dambach.
Hoard of circa 2000 nummi (5 kilos). Some of the coins are from the Time of Constantine I and his sons up to Valentinian I and Valens (AD 364-378).
Unknown originally number of coins. There was an information on 5 gold coins, unknown issuers. Possible, that silver and bronze coins were part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.
A hoard of 4 aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and 2 drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
An unsatisfactory record of a small hoard of north-eastern gold staters.
At least 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 92 were studied: Nero - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 193-217).
23 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of several years.
39 silver coins found near the castle of Millière: 35 Celtic, 4 republican denarii.
7 bronze coins found in 1 spot near a house. Among issues: Constantine I (Crispus Caesar), Constantine I (Constantius II Caesar)/Constantius II (AD 324-361).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (inv.no. H 215/1924)

summary: 151 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Local museum Govora, Vâlcea County, Romania (1966); Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (101 coins spread through the coin collection)

summary: The hoard comprised 2394 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses Galba to Gordian III (AD 238-239).

HER entry on Heritage Gateway (no.11781) reads: "From Journal of William Woodman metal detector: 'Things I handled as a dealer and didn't declare' - from near Willingham Cambs, 976 siliqua all unclipped, 65 miliarense, 3 solidii plus an aureus of Carausius with Pax on reverse. All in a greyware pot. Only 4 Emperors: Julian II, Valentinian I, Gratian and Valentinian II. Found in 1993. No further location information known therefore no grid reference given."
22 denarii of Augustus found in 1 layer during archaeological excavations at the site of Bagineti.
7 solidi found within the Vandal necropolis: Honorius 4, Valentinian III 1, Theodosius I 1, Leo I 1 (AD 457-474).
3500 coins found at/near the Roman villa: 3rd century AD - House of Theodosius I (AD 395).
disposition: Instituto de Arqueologia - Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 46 coins, with the latest coin dating between AD 346-350.
The hoard comprised 68-72 bronze coins of the First Jewish Revolt.
The hoard, discovered during excavations with MAGNY-COURS 2009, comprised 497 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 496 nummii of the first Tetrarchy (tpq AD 303).
20 antoniniani of Aurelian part of a larger hoard.
7 sestertii found together in a very good state of preservation inside an urban villa: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
3 coins of odd combination found corroded into a single lump in June 1983, in the garden of 39 King's Lane.

110 coins: 61 aurei (Caligula to Vespasian); 49 denarii (32 Republican, 11 M. Antonius, 1 triumviral, 5 imperial, including 1 Augustus, 1 Nero, 2 Vespasian, 1 Titus under Vespasian; 2 AE of Irnthi and Dyrrhachium, the last thought to be intrusive: Republic - Vespasian (AD 78-79). Together with the coins were found: a silver mirror, 4 silver cups and various jewelry.

summary: 11 prutahs found together while demolishing a wall of a Roman domestic building: Augustus - Nero (AD 59).

A great number of Roman coins, both gold and silver, found in an urn, close to Stratford. This includes a coin of Magnus Maximus. A gold coin of Valens, said to have been found at Stratford, may belong to this hoard.
336 antoniniani (radiates) found in Szeskszárd at an uncertain location: Valerian I and Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270)..
A hoard of ca. 100 silver Iron Age coins found near Portsmouth. The records about the hoard are quite confused. 9 coins in the British Museum are ticketed as "found at Portsmouth in 1830".
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only 1 bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 74 denarii (232g) were analysed by the Archaeological Commission: Vespasian Septimius Severus. 4 coins were described in detail.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg (1891), Russia; Podillya Antiquities Museum, Kamyanets-Podilsky, Ukraine (4 coins)

65 solidi, 11 survive: Gratian - Theodosius (AD 394-395).
A hoard of 50 solidi, found in the excavations at Qau, in the area of 'Cemetery 400', in a little flask, placed in a Roman pot.
disposition: British Museum; Hull, Ashmolean; Bristol; Brussels

summary: 74 (FMRO VI/1), around 60 bronze coins (Dembski 1977) were found in a Roman well. No certainty whether these coins belonged to a hoard or they were single finds as votive offerings. The coins minted segment: Tiberius - Numerian.

Originally the hoard had 150 silver coins and possibly 2 bronze. A full list was published in 1850 but the museum was only able to identify 50 silver coins (radiates and denarii). Silver: 15, 35 coins; Silver w8: 65.2-117.1g
At least 130 Iron Age staters, discovered near Sibsey in the early 1990s.
441 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any 1 took the trouble to pick them up."
219 nummi: Constantius II - Arcadius (AD 402-408). Although are menti1d 228 nummi, only 219 are catalogued.
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologica di Roma, Gabinetto Numismatico del Museo Nazionale Romano, Italy (inv. nos. 123676-123710)

summary: (180) 141 silver coins: 140 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm dating from the Republic to Trajan.
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (141 coins)

summary: 863 Roman silver coins (Republic - Severus Alexander) found in a leather bag contained in an earthenware vessel on the royal estate of Einsiedel in 1859, in a drainage ditch.
50-6 nummi found with a burned wooden box: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Städtischen Gustav-Lübcke-Museum Hamm, Germany (3 coins lost during the WWII)

summary: Unpublished hoard of 3 denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.
The hoard comprised a large number of silver denarii of Clodius Albinus (approximately 15 pounds in w8 or 2000 pieces).
25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
7 imitations of silver denominations; silver w8: 151.4-695.3 g.
39 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-256). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: The hoard was found in a vessel and contained between 200 and 300 coins of Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip, Otacilla, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Hostilian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian, Valerian II, Mariniana and Salonina.
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: Probably, a hoard of over a thousand coins. Only 484 coins were documented: Tetricus I - Honorius (AD 402-408).
435 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 434 nummi: Victorinus - Constantius II (AD 355-361). Found in a pit/trench while excavating an archaeological site dated from Neolithic to Middle Age.

A substantial hoard, mostly of Durotrigan silver, which seems to have been discovered between Shapwick and Badbury Rings - possibly about half a mile south-west of the hillfort, in the direction of Shapwick - although parcels of coins were given a variety of different provenances within this general area. Van Arsdell (1989b) examined about 180 coins in the mid-1980s, which he took to represent about 1 quarter of the hoard, and on that basis estimated that it had originally contained c.850 coins, predominantly Durotrigan silver and a small amount of gold. A wholly accurate reconstruction of the Badbury/Shapwick hoard is unlikely. In the meantime a total of c.850 coins, as suggested by Van Arsdell, is not unrealistic, and circumstantial evidence allows us to be fairly confident that the bulk of the c.627 coins identified in the CCI are correctly attributed to this find.

A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated 1) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.
Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: A number of late Roman coins, found by railroad workers in the vicinity of Bischleben during gravel quarrying. In doing so most of the coins were scattered and lost, and only the listed 6 specimens were salvaged.
5 clipped and 4 pierced solidi (more than 3 holes) found in a grave dated in AD 575: Leo I, Justin I, Justin I and Justinian I (2), Justinian I.
Around 560 gold coins. Only 4 or so were seen; latest coins of Valentinian III (AD c. 440?).
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 520 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov and 468 described: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1962/1-30 (30 coins)

summary: 3 denarii (1 of Trajan and 2 of Septimius Severus that share the same obverse die) from the same context (C/26/34), that may represent a small hoard, found at Kifrin, a large fortified settlement with Parthian and Roman phases of the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, on the east bank of the Euphrates.
32 bronze coins: 32 sestertii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 230)
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: 39 aurei, of which 38 were documented (Augustus–Trajan), found underwater, 100 m from the shoreline.

The hoard comprised a vessel 'containing 800 Roman bronze coins of various sizes…The abbot Simon noted the presence of 30 coins of Constantine with very small module size, raising the possibility that there were coins dating to the period AD 335/337 in the hoard. However, this hypothesis cannot be substantiated.'
16 siliquae of Constantius II (AD 351-355) found numerous silver jewelry; silver w8: 33.2-50.0 g.
4 coins (2 denarii and 2 antoniniani, Septimius Severus - Gallienus), apparently found together around 1845 on a field between Stegelitz and Fehlitz.
The only data published on this hoard indicates that it comprised 800 antoniniani (radiates) dating from the reigns of Gordian III to Gallienus (AD 260-268).
15 radiates (Gallienus to the Tetrici) from a larger hoard of unknown size discovered while ploughing a field somewhere outside Fishguard. No further details are available.
2 staters of Addedomaros, found c. April 1993. No trace of a container; no other details recorded.

The hoard comprised 97 nummi of a small module size (AE 3 and AE 4), ranging from Constans to the time of Theodosius I. Coins and 5 pieces of small sculpture in marble lay together within a small area in the fill of rubble construction in 1 of the buildings immediately east of the temple of Poseidon. The hoard has been interpreted as being deposited when Alaric invaded the Peloponnese in AD 396.

A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.
55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver w8: 69.9-128.8 g.
The coins were found together with pieces of carbonized wood adhering to them: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).
39 nummi, probably, part of a larger hoard, found by metal detecting: 3rd century - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
680 nummi found with ceramic vessel: Claudius II - Theodosius II/Valentinian III (AD 425-450). There were other circa 1000 small bronze disks (blanks?) with irregular edges.
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologica di Roma, Gabinetto Numismatico del Museo Nazionale Romano, Italy (inv. nos. 123711-123771)

summary: 20 bronze coins found with metal vessel in a wall. After cleaning only 1 coin of Trajan was noted.

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
Unknown initial number of coins. 17 solidi: Valentinian I (inc. ‘RESTITVTOR’ type) - Honorius (AD 404-423); gold w8: 75.65g+.
Large number of silver coins. 14 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 253-270.
219 sestertii: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) found in a cooking pot covered with a bronze sheet.
20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information
26 bronze coins of various denominations of both Roman and Byzantine denominations covering a 500 years: Augustus - Justinian I (AD 540-541).
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
500 coins of which only 16 were seen have been found on the canabae area: Tiberius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing 2 aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: (550) 67 denarii seen by T. Gerasimov: Nero - Trajan (AD 98-117).
The hoard originally comprised 20 solidi: Honorius-Valentinianus III (402-449 AD). Only 13 coins are recorded. Gold w8: 89.0 g.

At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.
The hoard comprised 7.5 kg of antoniniani (radiates)of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus and Probus. 2000 coins are identified.
Over 1000 nummi (c. 1 kilo) found with a ceramic vessel. Only 27 coins survived: Constans and Constantius II - Valentinian I and Valeens (AD 364-3367).
disposition: Câmara Municipal de Vila Pouca de Aguiar, Portugal

summary: Preliminary record of a small hoard of flat linear potins. 16 coins were found in 2008 and 1 additional coin in 2009. A second single coin (cut in half) addendum is not included in de Jersey but is included here.

Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had 2 large concentrations (2 hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)

Preliminary record for the material derived from recent Treasure cases from 2003 to 2007. This includes a mixture of Iron Age and Roman coins and artefacts and presumably includes several hoards within the group. de Jersey gives the following account: ‘at least 2 distinct, scattered coin hoards’ were found by a metal detectorist in May/June 2003. These were said to consist of 1) ‘a group of 12 cast ‘Thurrock type’ coins’, and 2) ‘a group of 25 struck silver coins of types traditionally attributed to the Iceni’
2 aurei (Nero and Vitellius), c. 100 Republican denarii, and 15 uncertain AE found in regio VI, insula 2, building 2 (house).
45 denari: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2

summary: The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Meth1: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

A large hoard of c. 22500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.
Hoard with 20 aes provincial coinage of Hispania. Iulia Traducta and Colonia Patricia mints.
64 nummi found with a ceramic vessel within a Paleo-Christian basilica: Constantine I - Valentinian I and Valens (AD 364-375).
6 gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 06 comprises 208 Iron Age coins and 1 Roman denarius.

(16-20 kg) (8-900) 501 bronze coins: 459 sestertii, 2 dupondii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Town museum, Kortrijk, Belgium (240 coins); Collection Heritiers Adriaen (212 coins); Collection Ms. Depoorter (5 coins)

summary: 72 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) (AD 203); silver w8: 133.5-256.7g
The hoard is described as being 32 small bronze coins (radiates?). There are 20 coins of Gallienus and 12 of Claudius II.
356 coins found southward of mausoleum B: 352 imitations of antoniniani (radiates), 4 nummi of Constantine I/his sons as Caesars (AD 310-337).
Unknown originally number of coins. 15 pieces were recorded: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
2239 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 2181 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 1 as, 47 cast sestertii: Republic - Valerian and Gallienus (AD 254-256); circa 50 kilos.
disposition: Gabinetto Numismatico di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M.0.9.22769-M.0.9.25007)

(ca. 900) 889 denarii: 46 republican, 843 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Found in 2 vessels.

summary: A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, 3 further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.

Heap of 90 nummi with a tpq in the second half of the 4th century AD

summary: Hoard of around 200 denarii. Among the issuers Vespasian and Titus. The hoard was dispersed.

disposition: Before World War II some of the coins from the hoard were kept in the collections of the St. Elisabeth Gymnasium in Wrocław (Sankt Elisabet- Gymnasium in Breslau). Lost

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in 2 by the finder. 1 part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of 1 known as Lusigny A.
3760 silver coins, only 10 are available for study: Vitellius - Commodus (AD 180)

summary: 4 staters and a gold droplet found near Saxilby in October 2007.
The hoard was found in Burial 21 of a Late Roman cemetery. It comprised a purse containing 15 4th century nummi ending with issues of Gratian.

Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely 1 owner.
Hoard of circa 60 antoniniani (radiates) with coins from Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised 123 nummi, 10 of which were dated between the 4th and 6th centuries AD.
30 siliquae: Constantius II - Valens (AD 2364-367); silver w8: 59.2-91.6 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest (30 coins) 1974

summary: A hoard of 52 bronze antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus) found in the quarry of Weisenau in 1910.
A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling 2 tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
Grup of 3 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
The hoard comprised at least 414 coins from the first part of the 5th century AD.

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver w8: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!
290 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLV

summary: The hoard comprised a 'very large number' of Celtic Iron Age coins, of which only 24 were studied. They were accompanied by a thin bronze disc.
109 coins: 105 bronze coins, 4 silver denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163). Also part of the deposit were the head of a hair pin and a ring. Considered as a votive offering.
246 denarii found while ploughing: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 202)
Around 1000 antoniniani (radiates) found with an amphora. Among coins, issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Between 3000 and 6000 denarii were found with a wooden box in a peat bog. For 16 coins are known the issuers: Trajan - Septimius Severus.

4 imperial As, 3 imperial Dupondii, 1 imperial AE (Augustus to Vespasian) and 1 uncertain imperial As, 29 uncertain imperial AE found with a female skeleton with golden jewelry in regio IX, insula 8, inner corridor to cubiculum with erotic scenes of building 3 (house).
157 coins found in a ceramic vessel: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
A hoard of 88 Iron Age silver coins found associated with a vessel dating to the period after AD 200.

This set of coins found in the Hispanic Roman city of Torrepared1s (Baena, Córdoba), which has been identified as Virtus Iulia ltuci, a city referred to by Pliny as a colonia immune of the Conventus Astigitanus. Though not quantitatively significant, the set is notable for its homogeneity and the rarity of its coins: it is composed of 6 dupondii and 1 as of the Nero period, which were all minted in Lugdunum in 66-67 AD. Its exceptional state of conservation and it is being discovered in the aerarium of the Curia, suggests that these coins were part of a consignment from the Imperial administration to the city of ltuci yet they were never circulated.
Unknown number of denarii. 199 entered the museum collection in Silistra: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 217).
288 denarii found in a ceramic vessel within the Carpic settlement: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
13 aurei: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander and silver coins of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 43 tetradrachms and 95 radiates dating to the third century AD.
2 solidi, Theodosius II and Marcian, found in a vineyard.
The hoard originally comprised 6 nummi of Maxentius discovered with a small glass vessel. Coins are now missing.
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: Around 50-60000 of silver and bronze coins (92 kilos) of the Late Empire found with an embossed copper cauldron. some issuers were identified as: Constantine I, Constantius II, Constants and Valens.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Nacional de Madrid (4,000 coins); 2,000 divided between the museums of Rotterdam, Cluny, Marsella, Lugo, Oviedo and private collectors

summary: 226 Celtic coins.
The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver w8: 133.5-237.1 g.
The hoard comprised a small casket or box containing silver and copper-alloy coins from Vespasian, Antoninus Pius and Trebonianus Gallus.
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: At least 42 solidi (Valentinian II - Valentinian III, AD 439-455) found over a period of more than a century at the same spot. The first coin was found in 1842, during agricultural work. More followed in 1846, and 1906. In the 2010s, further coins (31) were discovered using a metal detector, documented on PAN. Archaeological field research was also carried out in 2016.
A large hoard of republican and imperial denari. Only 20 pieces were seen. apparently, the latest coin belong to Tiberius (AD 14-37).
More than 1500 denarii and antoniniani. 344 pieces are menti1d in V. Varbanov dataset (2017): M. Antony to Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 193-217); silver w8: 2746.5-4979.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of Shumen, Bulgaria; 345 coins seen by T. Gerasimov as part of the private collection of late Dr. V. Haralanov.

summary: 188 silver and bronze coins: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

A scattered hoard of Durotrigan coinage, mostly rather poorly recorded, recovered over several years. The alloy of some of the Durotrigan material is uncertain and thus the division into silver and bronze staters should be treated with some caution.
(c. 230) 145 gold coins: 1 medallion, 144 aurei: Trajan - Galerius (AD 305-306); gold w8: c. 1625g+;
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna; National Hungarian Museum Budapest; formerly Ivan Nepomuk Labaš de Blaškovec collection

summary: The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii: Domitian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222 ). Only 42 coins are now available.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
20 provincial bronze coins minted in Pautalia. No further information.
Circa 700 antoniniani (radiates), 371 recovered; silver w8: c.190.0-874.0 g.
646 denarii, Republican to after 12 BC.
A leather bag full of coins was found ca. 1920 on the Oberer Zahlbacher Weg. 160 coins got into private hands and could be recorded.
9 coins of unknown denomination: Tiberius - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard was found in Burial 12, in the late Roman cemetery of Abbeville. It comprised a purse filled with 12 late Roman nummi. There was also a siliqua of Valens placed inside the mouth of the deceased.
The hoard comprised 21 late Roman bronze coins: Constantius II-Honorius (348-403 AD).

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest 6 coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: 2 copper coins (Constantine I and Valentinian I), found in Kelston Manor House, now demolished, in 1676. Probably not a hoard.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer menti1d these coins in particular: 1 of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and 1 of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
8 bronze coins. According to Boersma 1967, no. 164, they are dated around 16 BC - AD 14. No further information.
The hoard probably comprised more than 889 late Roman bronze coins: Probus - Honorius (276-395 AD).
disposition: Sala Consiliare di Brendola; Soprintendenza Archeologica del Veneto, Padova; Museo Civico G.Zannato, Montecchio Maggiore; private collection

summary: The find comprised 37 coins including 3 radiates and 34 nummi. 25 coins are in the Stiftsbibliothek St. Gallen, with 12 additional donated to the Swiss National Museum in 1847 given a provenance of 'Näfels'. It is possible that this assemblage is not a hoard but a collection of single finds (see Bertolaccini/Zäch 2008).
disposition: Stifsbibliothek St. Gallen (25 coins); Swiss National Museum (12 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 hundred of Roman coins from Maximian, Aurelianus, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carus, Numerian and Diocletian.

The hoard was found in a small square cairn created with Roman tiles stuck together with red Roman cement and was surrounded by numerous st1 sarcophagi. It comprised 87 sestertii from Vespasian to Gordian III and an oculist's stamp inscribed with the name C. TITTIVS BALBINVS.
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 119 gold coins, consisting of 102 aurei and 17 multiples, dating between the reigns of Probus and Constantine.
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. 6 denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: A hoard of few thousands coins found in unknown circumstances. 800 coins were seen by E. Couturier in Tunis: Severus Alexander, Probus, Diocletian, Maximian I, Constantius I, Galerius, Galeria Valeria, Severus II, Maximinus II, Licinius I, Constantine I, Maxentius (large number), Romulus Augustulus (?). Mints: Ostia, Aquileia, Arelate, Lugdunum, Carthage, Antioch, Alexandria.
The surviving part of the hoard consists of 613 silver denarii ranging from 157-156 BC to the reign of Claudius (51-52 AD).
disposition: Padua, Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto

summary: 495 silver coins: 1 denarius, 488 antoniniani (radiates): Augustus, Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 135.3-612.6 g.
The hoard was found in 1880. It comprised 150 radiates, from Gordian III to Postumus. Only 123 are now recorded.
76 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Celtoiberic coins - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museo Histórico-Arqueológico de Doña Mencía, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 150 antoniniani (radiates), of which 129 survive from Philip I to Claudius II/Victorinus. This is 1 of 4 hoards from the site. Silver w8: 31.3-233.2g.
2 'denarii' of Constantine I menti1d as having been found in a pot along with others.
The hoard of 15 gold coins of the Late Empire was found in a hollow flint.

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average w8 of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: 355 nummi found with an amphora, during the archaeological excavations in sector 6D: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 367-375).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.
A hoard of 3 large gold medallions, 23 aurei, 4 gold bars, 2 gold tintinnabula and several amulets of gold and lapis lazuli, probably deposited in the reign of Gordian III or Philip the Arab.
disposition: BNF, Paris (Alexander Medaillions); G. de Demetrio (Gold Objects)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 150 nummi from the Constantinian dynasty.
40 denarii: 25 republican, 15 imperial denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - 12 AD).
Hoard of 15 coins - no information on the denomination. Among issuers Vespasian and Trajan.
381 coins: 1 antoninianus, 380 nummi: Probus - Gratian (AD 367-375)
(3000) 2873 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest, Hungary (6 coins), in 1865

summary: 214 denarii, 202 studied, 12 lost: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
Over 16000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Probus (AD 276-382). Found placed in 2 amphoras together with jewelry and silverware.
disposition: Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (4,159 coins)

summary: A certain amount of late Roman nummi was found in 1885 during work on the canalisation in Willigisstraße. Of these, 49 nummi (all from the tretrarchy) were described. These coins are now lost.
52 denarii, 51 antoniniani (radiates), 1 quinarius: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
191 coins: antoniniani (radiates), nummi and imitations: Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (Arcadius, Honorius) (AD 388-402).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
11 coins of 1st-3rd cents. AD in remains of amphora
4418 tetradrachms of Alexandria and 3 bronze coin: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus). 3 large amphorae, filled with coins, dug out of the cellar of a house.
disposition: Type set of 519 coins in Oxford. 114 in London. 80 billon coins, presented to Glasgow in 1902 by the Egypt Exploration Fund and now among the duplicates, probably belong to this hoard. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 200 antoniniani, most of them belonging to Gordian III, were found beneath a collapsed roof within an ancient settlement.
The hoard comprised 10 denarii from Hadrian to Otacilla Severa and 179 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Valerian I.
The hoard comprised 120 sestertii from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
IARCH record for 2 silver Iron Age coins found together.
The hoard comprised 20 aurei of Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
Iron Age gold, silver and copper alloy units, as well as a Republican denarius and 1 Roman as of Augustus, found from 2008 to 2010 by several people.
A hoard of 94 silver coins, comprising 78 tetradrachms (dated between AD 69 and AD 219-222), 16 denarii, and 1 antoninianus (radiate).

The surviving part of the hoard includes 164 denari and 118 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasianus to Philip I (AD 72-248). 221 coins are now kept in the Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale, 61 in different private collections. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the 2 findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be 2 sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.
disposition: Pordenone, Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale

summary: (c. 150) 118 silver coins: 108 denarii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver w8: c.188.8-387.2 g.
North-west of the cemetery of Palencia, a hoard of more than 400 coins of the 4th century AD was found. No further information.
20 coins: 6 republican denarii, 14 imperial coins: 1 dupondius, 13 asses: Republic - Claudius I (AD 50-54).
872 silver coins: 45 denarii, 10 denarii plated, 381 antoniniani, 434 antoniniani plated, 1 quinarius, 1 drachm: Commodus - Gallienus (AD 260-268)
7 coins found by pupils and brought to their teacher: Alexandria provincial coins: 2, Alexandria nummi: 3. Uncertain mint 2.

The hoard comprised numerous Roman silver and bronze coins. According to Tardieu and Boyer, the coins were found in 3 small vessels. The hoard was found in a field and given to the Musée de Guéret. Only 2 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian).
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: Few dozens of denarii of the Anto9 dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.
A hoard of 26 AR coins of Ariobarzanes II, Ariobarzanes III and Ariarathes X found in a vase during excavations at Tepe Bağları Cami.
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and 2 dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
200 denarii found with a glass vessel. Some of them, issues of Augustus.
The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.

Around 1600 of which 1168 identified: 1 Republican denarius of Mark Antony from 32–31 BC from the legionary series; 1259 imperial denarii, 1 drachm, 5 imitations of imperial denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218). Together with the coins was found a gold pendant.
126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Stadt Museum Villach, Austria. (73 coins)

summary: Around 100 coins found on a beach. Among them: 1 denarius, 98 antoniniani (radiates), 1 radiate fraction: Severus Alexander - Maximian I (AD 297-298). There were many debates on the original findspot and the number of coins.

74 coins found with a Roman bronze jug: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 256-257). Together were found: an Almgren 157 fibula, 5 bracelets, a pendant and 2 silver ingots on silver. The discovery has been interpreted as a silver craftsman hoard.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, ploiești, Romania (inv.nos. 72696-72766)

summary: A series bronze coins (Vespasian - Maximinus Thrax), found by farm workers close to Landwehr; a further 3 coins are reported to have been found close to Landwehr or at the Nordostseekanal. Not belonging to the find is a cast provincial coins of Samos (Trajan Decius).
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: 363 silver coins which were first placed in a bag and then in a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2205

summary: 32 aurei of Augustus (AD 27 BC - AD 14). No further information.

The hoard comprised 15 denarii and radiates from Nerva to Valerian and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257 to 258. The exact findspot of the hoard is not known, beyond the fact that it was found on the site of Colonia Ulpia Traiana. This ensemble could have been part of a larger hoard. The date of the find is described as several decades before 2010, when the hoard was published by Reuter.
10 denarii and 1 sestertius: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 15.6-28g.
90 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 blank flan: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised an iron pot filled with several hundred denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: 9 solidi: Honorius - Leo I (AD 457-474); Gold w8: 40.05 g.
11 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard of 35-40 nummi found inside the Roman fort at Mainz-Kastel between 1895 and 1900. 27 coins have been preserved and they belong to the Tetrarchy (AD 293-305).
22 nummi with a tpq post AD 375.

In 1816 an earthenware container was found with approximately 550 coins (mostly silver, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander), close to the SE corner of the Roman fort during the construction of the national road. Most of the coins were integrated in the collections of the Landgraf in Homburg. By the time they eventually reached the Saalburgmuseum, they had been mixed up with coins from the 1897 hoard.
2 coins: solidus of Anastasius (AD 491-518), denarius of Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) found on a site of an old dwelling.
4500 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tacitus (AD 276).
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: 11 silver coins: Nerva – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 4007/1-11)

summary: Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only 2 coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with 2 silver vessels embedded each other.
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2821 coins and 11 illegible 1s, including 1 AE of Seleucus III, 1 tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).
6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

16 radiates (Philip I to the Tetrici) and 1 nummus of Constantine I (thought by Robertson to be an intruder), found at some point before October 1855. The location and circumstances of their discovery are unknown.
disposition: National Museum Cardiff (10 coins); National Roman Legion Museum, Caerleon (7)

summary: The hoard comprised 493 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Valerian and Gallienus.
(346) 216 coins, but only 157 studied: 1 denarius, 7 antoniniani (radiates), 79 nummi, 70 imitations: Severus Alexander - Arcadius (AD 383-408).
disposition: Collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (1965), 216 coins

summary: 269 sestertii found with an urn: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
12 nummi (Constans, Constantius II, and Magnentius), including a number of contemporary copies, found in a well in the area of the fort's eastern rampart.

The hoard comprised a total of 259 coins from Augustus to Probus including mostly sestertii, a few asses and 1 radiate. Most of the coins are from the 3rd c. AD and well preserved. The hoard was found between Agia Galini and Kokkinos Pyrgos, in the sea on the site of a shipwreck.

At the end of 1852, the Musée d'Angers acquired 12 coins found in the environs of Combrée. A letter between Godard-Faultrier and A. de Barthélémy attributed the coins to the Namnètes. Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers, 1st Register of entrys, p. 97, no. 362

ca. 1200 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with a bronze vessel, but only 390 are identified: 72 denarii, 318 antoniniani (radiates). Found by metal detecting The hoard contains coins from Pertinax to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown originally number of coins. 34 bronze coins: 21 sestertii, 13 dupondii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
A hoard of 7 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Nero) found in a grave in the region of Serres, placed in a vase.
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: The remnants of a large residential premises might have been surveyed in 1901 during excavation of an ice cellar in Haus Martinerfeld for the branch store of Bitburger Simon brewery. The coins were found in the building rubble.
42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether 3 antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
The hoard comprised 9 antoniniani (radiates). The emperors represented include Gordian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salonina. There is no catalogue.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 67 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Diocletian (AD 284-293).
At least 13 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 196-211).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (5 coins); Münzkabinett Berlin, Germany (2 coins); Museum Szczecin, Poland (until 1944)

summary: 53 antoniniani (radiates) were found on Hosenstraße 4-5. They were purchased in 1903. "The coin series is so unified that it seems reasonable to accept it as a small hoard; the state of preservation is especially uniform."
Total amount of coins is unknown. The hoard contains 1 denarius and 236 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
(951) 14 unknown denomination: Maximinus II Daia - Valens (AD 364-378).
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 coins were documented: Vespasian - Elagabalus (Julia Soaemias) (AD 218-222).
5000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 59 coins were recorded: 46 Augustus, 13 Tiberius.
The hoard comprised approximately 15-20 tetradrachms and 70-80 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Museum Botacin in Padova bought 16 republican denarii of the same purple tint. Latest issue from 42 BC.
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
2165 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268); silver w8: 203.5-1011.5g.
disposition: Museo d'Antichità di Torino, Italy (1,355 coins); 810 coins were bought by a junk dealer.

summary: A scatter of coins from the hoard were found by a farmer. A systematic investigation of the findspot by Mr. Pioger and Térouanne recoverd a further scatter of 800 coins as well as excavating 3 vessels containing 3600 coins (radiates and copies): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282). A catalogue of 1941 coins was prepared by R. Boissel. In addition, there were 2500 imitations and minimi. The coins were dispersed in June 1976, although some of the imitations were preserved in particular collections. A small portion of the hoard was found by a farmer. Following its discovery, there was a systematic investigation of the site. Silver: c.3600 (1941) coins; Silver w8: c.271.1-1874.1g

142 coins were recovered from an area of approximately 2 square metres during a metal detecting rally in early September 2004. 2 other coins were found "a few yards" away (TAR 2004, 169 no. 418). The 144 coins declared included 2 Roman bronzes of the third century AD which were regarded as unassociated with the hoard. In addition to the coins, 2 copper alloy fragments, an iron object, 3 flints and 23 pottery sherds were reported. The pottery included 3 handmade Iron Age sherds, black burnished ware and the base of a Roman colour coat vessel; n1 of these sherds had any signs of contact with coinage, and n1 of them joined, suggesting that n1 of them had formed the hoard container.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
75 siliquae and 10 nummi to AD 402.

A hoard of 161 Roman Imperial denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2020. Photos of the coins were published on the Violity treasure hunting forum on March 10, 2020. The conditions and circumstances of the find, as well as the fate of the hoard, are unknown.
7 coins: 2 republican quinarii, 1 imperial denarius, 1 dupondius, 3 asses: Republic - Augustus (AD 12-14).

12 denarii, of which 10 plated, were found with a ceramic vessel in a garbage pit: Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 3, Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) 2, Marcus Aurelius 1, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1 (post AD 173-174).

Hoard of gold and silver coins of circa 6 kilos: 3.85 silver, 2.26 gold. The gold coins were wrapped in leather and together with most of the silver 1s they were distributed among the finders. 14 antoniniani (radiates) have been studied so far: Gordian III 8, and Philip I for Otacilia Severa 3, Gallienus 1, Claudius II 2.
5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).

A hoard was found in Chassenon at some time in the 9teenth century AD and comprised 10 coins from Maximinus I Thrax to Aemilian. Some of the coins were kept by the family and can be identified by M. Dhénin. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 12.6-22.9 g.
The hoard comprised 8 aurei of Augustus.
The hoard of 63 aurei, found with an earthen vessel: Tiberius - Nerva (AD 96-98).
disposition: 28 coins from the hoard are in the Madras Museum.

summary: The coins were lifted en masse and when treated in the conservation lab at the BM some were found to be fused together in rolls with remains of cloth and string preserved in the corrosion products; good physical evidence that they were buried together in antiquity.
From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
2043 AR: Galba/Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 2555.4-6392.7 g
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
1310 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-259) coins; silver w8: 1496-3124.7 g.
A group of at least 4 Constantinian nummi melted and fused together, recorded by C. Barclay at the Yorkshire Museum in 1998 (details from A. Woods, hard copy of report in Yorkshire Museum). 8.62g
The hoard was discovered in 1859 on the 'Schänzle' in Waldkirch. It comprised 18 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: Coins, jewelry, lamps and pot. 1 solidus Vetranio; 3 nummi: Divus Maximianus, Constantius II. Clay pot, 3 lamps, 1 cameo hanging on a gold chain, 3 bracelets, 2 earrings, 1 ring, 1 gold necklace, 1 silver belt buckle
53 bronze nummi to AD 317, no further information on this find.

The hoard was found with 'an urn and comprised 'approximately 1500 bronzes coins of the House of Constantine [nummi]. 1 had the mintmark ESIS - Siscia' The hoard was discovered in the forest of Eu, close to the hamlet of Romensil.

942 coins: 1 aureus (Caracalla) mounted in a necklace, 939 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian to Philip I, and 2 bronze coins (missing today). The hoard comprised gold (600 g) as well and silver jewellery (400 g), a shallow silver dish and a silver salt box.

25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).

Hoard of at least 52 coins, part of a deposit of 61 coins recovered from the backfill of a well in Victoria Road, Winchester (F1093) during archaeological excavations in the 1970s. No evidence for a container was found.

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction st1s, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.
The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only 2 coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.

Metal detector find of a large hoard of Icenian silver coins, along with ceramic sherds and fragments of textile. Subsequently excavated by the Norfolk Archaeological Unit. Further batches were found after this date.
Found during excavations, early medieval cemetery. Tomb 476: inhumation, female; among grave goods 4 Aes coins, part of the "Gehänge"
(1567) 1559 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 1960.1-4072.8 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: 4 asses found together in a deep layer: Augustus for Tiberius, Lugdunum (2 coins) and 2 unidentified 1st century coins.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 07 comprises 137 Iron Age coins and 1 Roman denarius.

4 gilded forgeries of base metal coins (Diocletian to Constantine I), found as a group stuck together with remnants of linen material between them. Each coin has been gilded at 1 time, possibly as forgeries.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL XI
summary: The coins came into the possession of H.J. Lückger. Variants and features of this collection were published in 1902. Since only particular specimens were made known in the menti1d publication, it is believed that this only represents a small part. It is unknown how many coins from the hoard actually made it into the possession of Lückger.
The hoard comprised 258 nummi.
20 antoniniani found in a small ceramic vessel. Some of the coins belong to Philip I.

The Lengerich II find is the second of a set of 3 finds, made underneath 3 large st1s during the construction of the road Freren - Lengerich. It consisted of gold jewellery, a 10 solidi (time of Constantine I). The coins had been placed underneath a number of smaller st1s, artificially piled together.
A hoard of 866 Late Roman coins, found by lieu10ant v. Levetzau in Hawara. ca. 40 coins were accessi1d by the Berlin museum, the rest was disposed off, being illegible.

A farmer from Unter-Horgen found a hoard while fertilizing a marshy pasture. During this work he saw a number of coins laying next to a vessel in a ditch. The hoard comprised possibly up to 600 coins. The list given in FMRD encompasses 274 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Marius.
5 bronze coins: 1 as, 4 semisses of Claudius I (AD 51-54).
99 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
18 denarii: 5 Iberian, 9 republican, 4 of Augustus found together in a taberna: Iberian - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Museu d’Arqueologia de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: The hoard was found in the aqueduct supplying Lugdunum. 252 coins: 1 republican denarius, 251 nummi: Republic, House of Constantine I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-375).
Around 800 denarii and amber pieces found with a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Three private collections; Museum of Prehistory, Poznan.

summary: Accounts vary concerning the composition of this hoard, but 2 suggest that 18 ingots were found, alongside a large number of gold coins. Mowat (1902) suggested that approximately 600 aurei were found and c. 20 gold medallions, with emperors represented from Severus Alexander to Constantius I. Hobbs estimates a precious metal w8 of 1029.2g+;
disposition: Münzkabinett der Staatlichen Museen, Berlin, Germany; Museum Calouste Gulbenkian, Lisbon, Portugal; Walters Art Museum, Baltimore, USA; Archaeological Museum, Thessalonika, Greece

summary: Hoard of around 1081 bronze coins: Republic - Septimius Severus found with a ceramic vessel. The Soprain10deza has considered as a discovery of 'nessun valore' and retuned it to the finder. 1 sestertius of Didia Clara was kept in Museo Bottacin.
Unknown originally number of aurei. 40-5 coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. 7teen coins were studied in detail. 9 coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
A hoard composed of 130 + AR Lycian hemidrachms, including 60 from Cragus and 7 from Masicytus, dating to c. 25 BCE.
13 solidi found wrapped in a lead sheet and placed in a hole in the floor: Honorius 1, Valentinian III 11, Petronius Maximus 1 (AD 455).

A hoard of 15 clipped siliquae from the Artillery Folley area of Colchester (an area used as a cemetery in the Roman perid). Crummy (1987, 71) states that the latest issues are of Arcadius and Honorius. However, Radford and Gascoyne (2013) describe this as 15 siliquae of Constantine III (apparently a mis-reading of Crummy 1987's comments).
2191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver w8: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO A)
summary: Hoard in grave, 114 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Unknown originally number of coins. 88 pieces were available for study: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). I. Pereira Rodriguez suggests that this hoard is 1 and the same with a poorly recorded hoard known only as coming from 'Serra, Portugal'.
disposition: Museu Municipal de Santiago do Cacém (Sintra), Portugal

summary: A number of coins was found in graves in Bori: 2 drachms minted in Olbia; 2 gold imitations of Alexander's stater; 5 Parthian drachms: Phraates IV - 1 and Gotarzes II 4; 12 denarii: Augustus, Gaius, Trajan, Faustina II, Julia Domna.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg, Russia. Mention of Georgian National Museum in Tsotselia 2010.

summary: The hoard comprised 81 asses, 1 uncia, including 1 as of Claudius I.
99 denarii: Otho - Commodus (AD 182-183).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Ancona, Italy (inv. nos. 7395/22336 - 7493/22434)

summary: 322 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 aureus, 302 denarii, 18 bronze pieces. Only 242 coins were recovered: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

During the excavation of a Gallo-Roman sanctuary in 1974, 1975, 1978 and 1979 more than 100 gold, silver and bronze coins were recovered. They were coins of Marseille, the Celts, the Roman Republic and of Augustus. They are likely to represent successive votive deposits disturbed during the construction of a building in the 2nd century AD.

The hoard comprises 16 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No. 76-395 and 76.396
Around 8000 nummi." This ‘hoard’ is only menti1d once by Bopearachchi and then never again; neither by him nor by any other author." No further information.
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: 9 coins: 5 denarii, 4 sestertii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: The hoard was found in a burial in a Roman inhumation cemetery and comprised 10 nummi of Gratian to Theodosius I.
13 solidi found with a Late Roman helmet with Chi-Rho badge: Valentinian I and Valens - Constantine III (AD 408-411). A ritual offering.
The hoard comprised 'some 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which only 20 were examined' Found at the ancient port in unknown circumstances.
Some silver coins found in a garden. Only 1 denarius of Hadrian and 1 of Commodus were documented.
4 gold coins (Antoninus Pius to Caracalla), found by a farmer from the village of Umm Qeis (anc. Gadara), and seen by the archaeologist Paul Ilton.

More than 1000 pieces were found, of which nearly 700 were brought to the museum. Due to corrosion products on the coins, only about 100 of the coins were identified. There were problems of identification and classification and therefore it is not possible to date the latest coin in the hoard. However, several coins had the legend GALLIENVS AVG suggesting a date range of AD 260 to 268.
10 Alexandria tetradrachms: Probus-Maximianus I (AD 284-285).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Regionale "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 51795-51804

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 422 sestertii and 4 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus with a tpq of AD 253. An anonymous catalogue gives details of 409 coins.
The hoard comprised 341 bronze coins dating to the 4th century AD.
The hoard comprised 15 gold coins dated between AD 350-355 and AD 527-565.

Approx. 650 nummi found with a small ceramic vessel in the courtyard I of the temple at Qasr Douch. The coins run from Constantine I to Arcadius and Honorius. A small number of coins were barbarous (but no further details are given on that question).
15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

An aureus of Trebonianus Gallus and a gold barbarous imitation of a Roman coin were bought in 1855 by the Coin Cabinet of the Museum in Berlin from a local from Jelenia Góra. No certainity whether the coins were actually found in this town.
disposition: Sammlung des Münzkabinetts in Berlin (17551-[1] coin und 17552-[2] Barbarous imitation. Unknown nowadays location.

summary: The hoard comprised 1104 radiates from Valerian and Gallienus to Quintillus. 740 have been studied by Salama. (AD 270)

Originally a hoard of 68 coins but 1 went astray. From the 67 remaining coins (62 dupondii and 5 asses), 23 are completely illegible. The coins are heavily worn, suggested a much later burial than the latest coin.
4887 antoniniani radiates found in a jug in a st1 quarry: Elagabalus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
10 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 4 sestertii, 5 nummi: Vespasian - Valens (AD 364-378).
Hoard of 127 denarii found during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus (13 BC).
The hoard consists in 10 drachms of Polemon II found in a ceramic jug.
(1000-1200) 113 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tetrarchy (AD 293-294); silver w8: 217.1-1499.1 g.

The hoard comprised a large quantity of coins, although only 11 were identified. They included issues of Gordian III, Gallienus and Salonina. It seems likely that this is the same hoard as 1 menti1d by M. Faujas de Saint-Fond in 1810 which comprised 'a very large number of medium and small bronze Roman coins from Gallienus to the House of Constantine'.
17533 antoniniani (59 kg) found in a bronze vessel: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus) (AD 249-251)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 932

summary: 157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: 2 denarii of Commodus (AD 186); silver w8: 4.66 g.

The hoard comprised 2077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: 3 Roman hoards found in St1a. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.

100 solidi: 89 solidi: Theodosius II - Zeno (AD 476-491); 11 solidi uncertain; gold w8: c. 445 g; (c. 200) 199 silver coins: 158 uncertain, 41 denarii: Republic - Caracalla (AD 211-217), 1 siliqua Constantius II Jewelry and weapons
disposition: Bibliotheque National, Paris; Tyroler Landesmuseum, Innsbrück

summary: In 1864 reportedly more than 300 Roman coins were dug out at a field behind the Zorn'schen machine factory (on Landshuter street between Richard-Wagner street and Stobäusplatz). Descriptions of only 56 coins (1 denarius and 55 antoniniani, ranging from Julia Domna to Numerian) exist today. The coin of Numerian might not belong to this hoard.

The hoard "consists of 109 pieces of silverware, as well as gold jewellery (necklaces, bracelets and earrings) and over 1100 gold coins. Items from the hoard vary in date from the 4th century BC to the 1st century AD. Many of the silver items from the treasure are considered masterpieces of Roman art that could only have belonged to the very elite sections of society. A few objects also seem to be family heirlooms passed down the generations. Parts of the hoard are inscribed with the name Maxima who were perhaps the original owner." Most of the coins are aurei of Nero. The database presents 117 types mainly based on Tameanko and Blanchet.
disposition: Louvre Museum, Paris, France (since 1896). Donation Edmond James de Rothschild

summary: Hoard of 100 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

322 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 181-182). The hoard also includes silver and gold jewelry. Gold: 1 bracelet, 1 ring. Silver: 1 patera, 1 chain, 2 brooches, 1 necklace, 1 bracelet, 2 cups. All items were placed in a silver casket.

In 1909, a jeweller showed Breuillac some coins from a hoard recently found in Béceleuf. He had bought approximately 3kg of coins which constituted half the hoard. Breuillac assessed approximately 2400 coins and published a list of 135 cleaned pieces from Philip I to Tetricus I. The hoard was acquired by a jeweller and showed to Breuillac. The circumstances of discovery and the exact findspot are unknown. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 649.0-2999.0g.
166 bronze coins: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: A large hoard of denarii and a few bronze coins was found during construction works in 1957. Only 139 coins (Vespasian-Marcus Aurelius, 70-180 AD) were recovered but subsequently stolen in 1972-1973.
16 bronze coins found in a destruction layer scattered on a very small area: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-244).

The hoard comprised 1 Hellenistic coin of Thessalonica, 1 plated denarius of Septimius Severus and 28 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella and Stobi, Augustus - Gordian III). It was brought from Macedonia by a soldier who had found them while digging trenches.
192 denarii: Nerva - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
10 coins (antoniniani and nummi) found while ploughing: Victorinus - Valentinian II (AD 378-383).
8 Iron Age silver units and 1 denarius of Augustus. Declared Treasure in 1982 with St1a Grange I group II but considered a separate hoard. Part of group detected from site prior to excavation.
The hoard comprised 1 aureus, 30 Republican denarii and 35 denarii from Augustus to Nero. It was found within a dwelling.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 2 vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 313 silver coins went to the Museum of History in Silistra, Bulgaria: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria (313 coins); inv.nos. 5584-5896

summary: 2 detectorists found 9teen Chute staters in an area of about 1.7 m diameter, at a depth of 5-10 cm, between 12-14 May 1987 (Cowell et al. 1987, 6-7). Examination of the site by Andover Museum located "a pit nearby with a charcoal layer at the bottom", but it is not clear if it had any definite relationship with the hoard.

4 large gold pieces, and imbedded in clay 40-50 more, found in 1787-8 on land belonging to Haverhill Place. This hoard was thought by Robertson to be late empire but seems to be Iron Age according to additional information found by P de Jersey (2015).
500 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 243 were published: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Hoard of 223 coins: 6 aurei, 217 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold w8: 27.1-30.0g.; silver w8: 59.8-315.7g. Together was found a ring (metal not specified).
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins from the First Jewish Revolt, year 2 (AD 67-68).

Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, 2 gold pendants slightly different in size, 2 belt buckles: 1 silver and 1 bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.

The hoard (4 coins, Republic - Faustina I/II) was found with around 20 coins in 1772 during the digging of a draw well in front of the castle. - not sure which castle is meant, as there are 3 of them in Jagsthausen.
Small group of denarii and radiates and a finger ring found together, possible purse hoard.
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Ruse: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 1-43

summary: 36 denari: 24 republican, 12 imperial: Republic - Titus (AD 80).
disposition: Muzeul Național de Istorie a României, Cabinetul Numismatic, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 75 denarii and 3 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III (AD 241-243).

A hoard of 47 coins (5 uncertain coins; 3 Roman Imperial coins and 39 Roman Provincial coins: Edessa, Pella, Koinon of Macedonia, Thessalonica), found in a grave in Sindos in 1981, ending with coins of Philip.
691 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 284-293). No further details.
Around 500 denarii. Only 3 are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: A small hoard (or part of a larger 1?) of 4 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Julia Domna) found between the 2 southern walls of the horreum (grain warehouse) of the military fort of Mil10berg-Altstadt.

407 silver coins found in 2 glass bottles. 1 bottle contained 130 coins, the other 277 pieces: 86 denarii, 321 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Victorinus (AD 269-271). In 1 of the bottles were also found a pendant medallion (with a denarius of Antoninus Pius) and a silver finger ring.
disposition: Service Régional de l’Archéologie, Ile-de- Franceté; Centre Michel de Boüard – Centre de recherches archéologiques et historiques anciennes et médiévales, Caen

summary: 31 bronze coins: 1 as, 1 sestertius, denarius, 2 antoniniani, 20 nummi, 7 provincials (Vespasian-Theodosius I) (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology Constanța, Romania (1971)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1 silver coin and an unknown number of copper-alloy coins of Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Julia Mamaea.

The hoard was found in a cave and comprised 60 Roman coin copies as well as numerous fragments of copper-alloy bar with Roman coin flans stamped on them. The hoard was interpreted as belonging to a forger.
A pile of coins was found wrapped in a wide weave cloth bag in the vicinity of the skeleton. 409 coins: 2 aurei, 189 denarii, 59 sestertii, 39 dupondii, 118 asses, 2 Greek coins.
3 aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.

The excavation of the well was concluded in 1966. It was 99ft deep and its diameter below the weathering c1 average 9ft to within 6ft of the bottom. 2 radiate coins of late 3rd C. and iron fittings of several buckets found within bottom 6 ft thick silts, along with large group of late 3rd and early 4th C. ceramics, at approx. 95 ft depth. In layer between 81ft and 85ft were masses of broken Huntcliff vessels & 3 Valentinianic coins - matching sherds of pot throughout this dump imply it was a single event.The coins, by P. Curnow in I.M. Stead ed. 1980 p.128.
2 denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
Partial record of a small group of early Corieltavian staters. No further information.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
(4000+) 2569 coins: 1 denarius, 2 antoniniani (radiates), 1346 nummi, 1220 uncertain denomination: Caracalla/Julia Domna - Honorius (AD 393-423)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (34 coins); Town museum Turnhout, Belgium (512 coins); 6 private collections (2199 coins), in 1960

find_spot_name: JERUSALEM - WESTERN AND SOUTHERN WALLS 1975 B
summary: The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, deposited during the First Jewish Revolt.
2 aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.
Hoard of 18 solidi of Honorius, Theodosis II, Leo and Zeno (c.480) Gold: 18 coins; Gold w8: 80.1g;
42 bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (42 coins), in 1808

summary: In 1846 6 Roman gold coins (Tiberius - Nero) and a ring were found by a workman in 10sfelderau during the digging of a small earth mound, located on a paddock along the river 10sfelde Au.
