A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only 3 coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard

The hoard comprised 'approximately 60 sestertii, mostly illegible. 10 identifiable examples were of Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II), Commodus and perhaps, Didius Julianus' Archives of Musée de Rouen. Communication by Mme. Aubin (28.11.1982)
IARCH record for hoard of 2 Iron Age gold coins.
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.

10 bronze coins from cremation burial 317 in King Harry Lane late Iron Age cemetery (Stead and Rigby 1989, 354). The grave goods consisted of 3 pots and a brooch as well as the 10 coins, 3 of which were found on a platter. The bodies were identified as 1 adult and 1 immature. De Jersey (2015) notes the dating of Phase 1 burials from the site to AD 1-40.
1447 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximianus I (AD 293-294).
The hoard comprised a considerable number of Continental Iron Age silver coins, which were quickly dispersed or melted down.
Few hundreds denarii. 14 pieces entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: Faustina II 1, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Domna 2, Geta 2, Caracalla 3, Maximinus I Thrax 1.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3520-3525

summary: A hoard of 55 solidi, ranging from Theodosius II to Zeno, discovered outside the walls of ancient Nicomedia while laying the groundwork for a paper and cardboard factory.
Group of 38 bronze coins: 28 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 7 asses: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-268).

15 AE nummi to AD375 (or possibly a Magnentian hoard with a stray nummus of Gratian), found with a (unrelated?) first century brooch and a sherd of greyware. The grey ware was not thought to form a container due to the small amount found. Addenda of 7 more coins and 5 more greyware sherds, which could perhaps suggest that this constituted a container.
The hoard comprised 59 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Aurelian or Tetricus I and was perhaps incomplete.
236 coins: 6 denarii, 224 antoniniani (radiates), 6 sestertii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Found together with jewellery: 1 gold ring, 1 glass ring, 1 bronze brooch.
5864 coins found in 2 vessels: 5283 antoniniani (radiates), 10 denarii and 571 nummi: Severus Alexander - Tetrarchy (AD 302-303).
Solidus of Theodosius II (with 2 suspension loops), 2 clipped solidi of Justin I with Justinian I found in the tomb of female Li Xizong passed away in AD 576 (North Qi period).
4128 coins found in 2 vessels: 3 denarii, 4125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).
195 silver coins: 102 denarii, 93 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip (AD 246); silver w8: 232.3-420.8 g.
disposition: County Museum Gorj, Tg. Jiu, Romania; Ion Luben collection, Bucharest (3 coins)

summary: It comprised c. 250 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 75 are recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
6 coins (Tetricus - Gratian) were found during the demolition of a building located next to the cemetery (under the foundations of the house or possibly, next to the chimney).
The hoard comprised more than 2000 nummi from Constantine I to Gratian (AD 375-383).

The hoard was found in Tomb 687 of the Gallo-Roman and Merovingian necropolis in Maule. It comprised 29 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiate), 27 nummi and imitations: Postumus to Magnentius with a tpq of AD 351 to 361.
disposition: Camping Club de France et le Groupe d'archéologie antique du Touring Club de France

summary: Hoard of around 20 denarii from the time of Trajan found on the bank of the Sluch River.
15 kg of silver coins, 12 gold coins and 2 gold bracelets. No further information.

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of 5 coins, 3 of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, 1 cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
100 solidi of Honorius type RIC 35c Mediolanum; gold w8: c.445.0g.
1 aureus of Tacitus, 1 gold barbarous imitation of an aureus, 4 drachms Hadrian, 1 denarius Septimius Severus were found in a grave together with jewelry.
Over 20 denarii. No further information.
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.

A hoard of ca. 1100 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the town of Turbiv in the Vinnytsia region. The coins had a strong degree of wear. This information cannot be verified, as neither the coins themselves nor their photographs are available. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A large hoard of at least 990 base silver staters of the Durotriges, found in and around the base and lower body of an Iron Age or Roman pot.

According to the finders, the hoard was found with the help of a metal detector in a ploughed field between the villages of Buzhany and Rzhyshchiv. It contained 265 denarii, 2 silver fibulae, a ring-shaped silver pendant, an iron axe and several fragments of other (unidentified) objects. The main part of the hoard - coins, axe and brooch - was in the lower part of the clay pot, of which, in general, only a few fragments have survived. Other items from the treasure were spotted 3-4 meters away. They were probably contained in the upper part of the same vessel, broken by a tractor plough. That is, the pot was at a depth of only 35-40 cm and was destroyed during the cultivation of the land by the modern method of deep ploughing. Today the hoard is in a private collection.
The hoard comprised 60 Osismii billon staters found with a ceramic vessel (60-20 BC).
300 nummi of the House of Constantine I (AD 306-361) found during construction activities.

540 coins found with an amphora: 1 solidus, 8 multiple of siliqua, 4 heavy miliarenses, 86 light mililiarenses, 441 siliquae. Gold w8: 4.45g; Silver: 1300.6g. Issuers: Costans, Costantius II, Valentinian I, Valens, Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius I, Arcadius (AD 337-387). Mints: Aquileia, Siscia, Treveri, Sirmium.
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia della Lombardia, Milano, Italy

summary: 25 nummi found in the prafurnium channel: Constantine - Constans/Constantius II (AD 348-350).

The hoard and its context are discussed in detail by Edwards and Dennis; a summary of the find is in TAR 1997-98. Most of the hoard was recovered in August 1998, with the exception of 1 stater of Cunobelin found during a subsequent archaeological excavation (December 1998). (PAS).
2 denarii and 436 radiates (Septimius Severus to the Tetrici), 2 silver finger rings, and 1 small silver ingot found beneath a st1 by workers widening a road between Amlwch and Bull Bay.
826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
Hoard of 1348 coins. Only 53 are documented: Hadrian - Septimius Severus Silver (AD 193-211).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (until 1917); private collection (2 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 13 silver coins including tetradrachms, drachms and denarii, dating between the reigns of Nero and Trajan.
Unknown number of denarii found in 2 small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from 1 of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: 85 nummi dispersed by excavator: Constans - Eugenius (AD 392-394).
76 coins: 48 antoniniani (radiates), 28 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1938. Stolen

summary: The hoard comprised 57 nummi dated between AD 337-341 and AD 474-491, and 1 Nabataean coin.

Over 300 denarii, only 8 coins were seen: Antoninus Pius 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II), Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1759 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 404.6g.
HER record of 8 radiates found "below st1 bridge".
"Hoard of 22 "small bronze Roman coins", some, 11 mm in diameter, only 1 was identifiable: Theodosius II(?), AE IV, 408/450".
disposition: Museum of Litoměřice, Czech Republic (possible inv.no. 172)

summary: 230 provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Galba (AD 68-69). Found in a jar during excavations of a house.
58 denarii found with jug, shell and iron wedge. Coins from Republic to Augustus (1st century BC).

The hoard comprised bronze coins with the legend PIXTILOS, 100 bronze Carnutes eagle coins and a variety of eagle potins. The Cabinet des Médailles some bronze Carnutes coins (BN 6108-6180) which had been in the Saulcy and Luynes Collections.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Biblioteque Nationale, Paris

summary: A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and 1 Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), 1 Lycian drachm of Trajan and 1 contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel on the area of an a ancient settlement. 85 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2237

summary: 82 solidi: Honorius – Justin I (AD 518-527) found with remains of a sack. 2 coins bear the monograms of the Ostrogoth Theodoric and the Burgundian Gundobad (Fagerlie 1967, 92).

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, 2 of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.
A rather confused record of finds relating to 28 Iron Age potin coins.
The hoard comprised more than 120 nummi of Constantine I and Licinius I. Only 47 coins, probably representing a third of the hoard were not dispersed.
(c. 18 kg, 4062) 1590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 5078.8-10559.8 g.

During the excavation of a monumental temple site, numerous votive offerings and coins were discovered. The total number of coins varies according to publication but was between 359 and 385 Iron Age coins and between 17 and 19 Roman coins. The Roman coins were not examined in any detail in the publication but appear to have been Roman Republican and Imperial denarii. The latest coin was an issue of Nerva.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel with a capacity of approximately 2 litres. It was filled with grey sand (perhaps mixed with cremated human b1) which contained fragments of an ivory or b1 bracelet and 20 Roman bronze coins including 2 asses of Claudius, 1 of Domitian and 1 of Trajan. Although the other coins were not identified, they were said to be of the same date.
IARCH record for a small Magnentian hoard of 16 nummi and a copper alloy bracelet. For full details and images see LANCUM-33EBC3. Unpublished catalogue by David Shotter and Stuart Noon.

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).
Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
101 coins: 96 sestertii, 3 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260); silver w8: 3.5-6.2 g.
disposition: Local museum, Petigny, Belgium (82 coins); private collection (11 coins), in 1960; Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (8 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a burial chamber and comprised 3 silver coins (tetradrachms) and 3 bronze coins dated between AD 40-70 and AD 70-106.
The hoard comprised approximately 70 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). 40-4 coins are catalogued.

The hoard was found in a tomb and comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 75 (or 78) radiates, 17 surgical implements and 5 tinned or silvered containers, which probably originally contained ointment: Victorinus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Coins were found by 2 detectorists between 6 May and 16 July 1979, apparently scattered across a wide area (up to 900 m2) within an earthwork.
The hoard was placed next to the skull of a skeleton in an inhumation grave and comprised 33 small bronzes antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and 3 bronze basins were also found.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: 65 solidi menti1d to be discovered but only 64 based on evidence by P. Salama: Theodosius II - Zeno/Basiliscus (c.490) found while levelling the place for the church square.
A hoard of 42 denarii, 294 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 provincial coins, found during excavation at the 'podium temple' in Alexandria Troas. Coins range from Septimius Severus to AD 260.
13 aurei: Tiberius - Vespasian (AD 78-79).
Hoard of 212 nummi: Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
384 nummi: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 367-383).
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
46 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of the Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274)and unidentified onject (button?).

The assemblage comprised 2 discrete hoards (SOUTH WEST NORFOLK I - II). The first consisted of Iron Age 6 staters and perhaps the bronze unit which was found at the centre of this scatter. As it included only uninscribed coins, it could have been deposited anytime after c. AD 20. (PAS).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: 20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised 24 Iron Age coins and 4 Republican denarii. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.943.1 to 28

13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.

The hoard was purchased in Antalya in 1956 by Konrad Kraft for Staatliche Münzsammlung in Munich. According to the information given by the seller, it was found in Antalya (anc. Attaleia) in Pamphylia. The hoard consists of 335 coins dated AD 294-313.
The hoard comprised 8 nummi from the 4th century AD.
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
The hoard(?) comprised 696 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC), which may have been derived from smaller hoards.
Hoard of 230 coins of the Bosporan kings (AD 286-341).
Recorded by the Somerset Levels Project. Hoard comprised just 3 radiates, found during peat digging. No archaeological context.

find_spot_name: MONTE DO CRASTO - ABOIM DAS CHOÇAS
summary: Hoard of circa 1000 nummi found with a ceramic vessel of 4 liters: Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 388-408). Some authors consider 2 hoards with similar composition to be found here.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 900 and 1200 gold Continental Iron Age staters. 3 examples from this hoard can be found in the Museé de Rouen (Inv. 382/2, 382/3 and 409/2).
Over 2000 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); gold w8: c. 12801.4-15598.6g.
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: The assemblage comprised 20 'small bronzes' (Tacitus and Probus) assumed to be antoniniani (radiates) dating to the end of the third century AD. Blanchet considered the find to be a small hoard. TAF suggests it might be a purse hoard. The hoard was found during demolition of an old building.
Hoard of 759 bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). Uncertain whether is part of MORSHANSKOYE 1838 hoard (?) or a separate 1.
15 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 20

summary: A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
7 Roman imperial coins: 1 denarius, 3 antoniniani (radiates), 3 nummi: Marcus Aurelius - Valentinian I (AD 364-375).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of small radiates (officials or imitations?), from Victorinus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised approximately 100 shekels of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73) with an engraved gem-seal.
disposition: 24 coins: T. Drake (England); 76 coins: M. Ganneau

summary: 869 antoniniani (radiates), barbarous imitations: Divus Claudius II and Tetrici (AD 271-274).
disposition: Thermenmuseum Heerlen; Koninklijk Penningkabinet, The Hague, Netherlands

summary: A large hoard of silver coins was discovered by Bulgarian soldiers. 6 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Gordian III 5, Trajan Decius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2735

summary: Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 50 coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22 092-22 141 (50 coins)

summary: Unknown silver coins. 45 coins were bought by the museum in Traismauer. 1 of the coins is an anotninianus of Probus.

4 coins found on 28 August 2003, recorded by de Jersey and listed here. A fifth coin (a quarter stater of Verica, ABC 1208) was discovered about 700 m distant, but is not included here, nor is the the as of Claudius from the PAS list (stray find).

The Wiggensbach hoard was discovered in 1889 in Waldegg. The hoard consists of jewellery, the quantity and typology of which is not described by FMRD, and silver coins, mostly denarii and at least 4 antoniniani, with coins ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander. 384 of them were bought by the Heimatmuseum in Kemp10. 25 remained in a private collection. A list of them exists, but it gives only the name of the emperor. FMRD speaks of 407 denarii, but lists only 401 coins among which a few antoniniani.
disposition: Allgäuer Heimatmuseum, Kempten, 25 specimens in private collections.

summary: A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaer1a.
32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Hoard of 108 Roman denarii and 2 silver pendants. Coin w8: 297.5g.

A man uncovered the coins on the south side of the hospital vineyard located in front of Heidenkopf during demolition works. 12 Roman coins were found during the digging-up of the wreckage. These are labelled as 'Kollektivfund?' in FMRD.

The hoard comprised numerous fragments of silvered copper-alloy tableware accompanied by 21 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 244-249). TAF interprets it as a deposit of scrap metal in10ding for recycling.
Originally were 447 coins. Only 168 pieces survived: Valerian I - House of Constantine I for Constantine I (Divus) (AD 337-340).

Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (1 Arabian drachm; 3 drachms of Cyrenaica and 1 hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
2997 coins: 2986 antoniniani (radiates), 11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
Hoard of unknown number of Celtic gold and silver coins of type ABYDOS, Togirix of Caletes and Santons. Together were found republican denarii.
(488) 168 silver coins: Commodus - Quintillius (AD 270)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXVII (75 coins)

summary: 14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
2 solidi from hoard also containing ring gold and 3 gold bracteates. Both coins are imitiations.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica), found in grave Θ in Ierissos.
51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.
The hoard comprised c. 700 coins including 200 sestertii and 500 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Claudius II.
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).

The hoard comprised an unknown number of 4th-century nummi which was immediately dispersed on discovery. Bertrand catalogued 292 coins which were being sold by a dealer in Vichy and other collectors. They date from the Tetrarchy to Constantine I with a tpq of AD 309. The latest coins are issue from Lyon mint (RIC 287/289 and 295).

About 1638, 16 (or 8?) gold coins, and ca. 800 silver coins, containing the 'whole history of the Roman Empire, from Julius Caesar till Constantine the Great', found while digging a cellar. The coins are thought to be siliqua and solidi.
A hoard of approximate 835 gold coins with the latest issue being a coin of Leontius dating to AD 484 to 488. Hobbs estimates a precious metal w8 of approximately 3715.75g.

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in 2 piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.
Hoard of 41 silver coins: 15 denarii, with 2 didrachms, 23 drachms, and 1 hemidrachm minted in Caesarea in Cappadocia: Tiberius – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.

A small hoard of 25 Roman aurei and their imitations. This hoard was never published, however, according to Berghaus it contained 2 genuine issues and 23 cast imitations of Roman aurei, which prototypes can be dated from Lucius Verus to Septimius Severus. More than a half of them show evidence that they were made of the same moulds.
The hoard comprised 119 nummi (AE 3) of Constantine I, Constantine II and Constantius II.
1745 coins: 1742 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285); silver w8: 318.0-439.9 g.

A hoard of 21+ Republican and early imperial coins (mostly denarii and a few bronze coins), found in 1863 at Soltborg under a clay layer in a depth of 7 feet. These coins lay loosely separated without a container. The coins were sold in 1930/1. Soltborg is in the vicinity of the Roman camp of Bentumersiel.
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks 3 bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 2 silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: The hoard comprised almost 600 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations. Sauvage examined 2 lots of 120 and 12 pieces, some of which were acquired by the Musée de Boulogne. A further lot was found in the Musée de Boulogne by Seillier and Leclercq. The rest of the hoard probably comprised barbarous radiates which the museum decided not to acquire: Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).

230 antoniniani (radiates) were originally described and were thought to represent approximately 1/3rd of the hoard; however, Hiernard increased the number to 230 and argued that this portion was part of a hoard of approximately 1000 coins. Sagredo San Eustaquio gives the number of coins as 231. The latest coin in the hoard is also the subject of some discussion. Originally a coin of Postumus (AD 260 to 268) with a HERCVLI DEVSONENSI reverse was stated to be the last coin. However, with Hiernard's revisions, 3 radiates of Salonina dating to the period AD 263 to 264 were stated to be the last. Furthermore, Balil basing his observations on Mateu y Llopis, gives the latest coins in the hoard as an issue of Gallienus (RIC 280) and 1 of Salonina (RIC 5).

Various unsubstantiated reports of coins found at St1a Camp including: 1) a hoard with gold coins of Cunobelin and silver coins of the Coritani/Coieltauvi [St1a II] and 2) a hoard of silver coins of the Iceni along with some denarii [St1a III]. de Jersey lists both St1a II and III under 1 entry (de Jersey 19.1), restricting his list to 37 Icenian coins.
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which 1 coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of 2 Roman querns.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel. Preliminary study suggests that 10% are of Gallienus, 60% Postumus and some coins of Tetricus I and II.

Initially, circa 2050 coins. Only 1938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
The hoard comprised 20 nummi dating to the period AD 351-354 and AD 395-408.
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.

A small hoard of possibly 800 coins was unearthed in a bronze jar close to the railway bridge on the right bank of the Iller. Coins were mixed up with a similar hoard from Öschlesee. Coins were 'silvered bronzes' and reportedly 6 aurei. FMRD gives a summary list of 33 coins.

Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprin10denza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
28 sestertii: 15 Severus Alexander, 13 Gordian III found in the Dominican convent area.

Coin hoard discovered during the construction of the airfield in Erding, south-east of Langengeisling. Close to the find spot ground walls of a villa rusticate were excavated in 1912. The hoard originally comprised ca. 300 denarii, of which only 96 could be traced (Hadrian - Maximinus I).
The 4 coins appeared together in the west corner, belonging to a room structure erected with walls of opus vittatum.

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD

Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel within a necropolis. Together with the cois a scarbee gem was found in the same vessel. Only 3 coins were identified: Faustina II, Septimius Severus, Elagabalus.
253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 10 (or 12) denarii concealed in a hollowed out flint. The hoard was found while breaking st1s from Etrimont.
16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: 1233 silver coins: 2 denarii, 1231 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 258).
3 coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.

4 republican Denarii, 10 imperial Denarii (Vitellius and Vespasian), 2 uncertain AR and 2 uncertain AE found in a burnt wooden box in regio IX, insula 7, south of peristyle of building 14-15 (uncertain structure).

A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: 50 radiates, mainly of the Gallic Empire and terminating with Carausius, found near Conwy shortly after 1945. No more specific information on the find spot is available.
149 bronze coins of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia. 132 studied: Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255). Mints: Viminacium 120, Provincia Dacia 12.
disposition: National Museum of History, Vranje, Serbia (132 coins).

summary: (400) 359 silver coins: Commodus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 494.8-899.6 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 3110-3468

summary: 11 coins (3 imperial bronzes, 8 provincial coins), ranging from Claudius to Vespasian, found in grave T38 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 44 provincial coins have been noticed from mints of Lower Moesia and Thrace: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 193-2244).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLXXXII (7 coins)

summary: 12 aurei: Galba - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold w8: 73.8-98.7+g.
527 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Tiberius - Galba (AD 68-69). 'Presented to the Antiquities Service by Daira Sanieh.'
disposition: 'Formed the beginning of the numismatic collection in the Giza Museum. This collection was transferred 1896 to Alexandria'

summary: Hoard of 225 coins: 1 imperial denarius, 8 gold stateri, 216 bronze staters of Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus Rhescuporis V, dated between AD 80 and AD 251.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel in a layer of fire. 28 denarii survived: Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Gordian III (AD 241-243; silver w8: 44.4-85.4 g.
3500 Alexandrian bronze coins, 1st-3rd c. AD. 'Briefly menti1d (together with hoards nos. 8 and 77) in a letter to Milne by Dattari, who bought the hoard.'
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel filled with 250 (or 1250) large Roman bronzes. It is likely that these coins were sestertii, or possibly nummi (folles).
Trajan to Septimius Severus. The total number of coins is an estimate and there are thought to have been more than 1000. Found during ploughing
Unknown number of silver coins. 31 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 541.0-2499.1g.
23 siliquae found in unknown circumstances in the area of Girona: Gratian 4, Horius 4, Maximus of Barcelona 15 (AD 410-411).
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii and dupondii from the first century AD to Gordian III, found in a large pithos. They might have been be part of a larger hoard.
10 bronze coins minted in Deultum: Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Otacilia Severa.
37 denarii most likely kept in a textile bag: Republic – Nero (AD 65-66).
5 solidi: Theodosius II 2, Libius Severus 1, Anthemius 2 (AD 467-472).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Gdańsk, (4 coins), High-School, Gdańsk (1 coin) in 1898

summary: The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questi1d whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). 2 or 4 coins are missing.
1456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 394.1-1819.1g.

Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only 1 was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which 6teen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver w8: 5.57 g.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
A scattered group of 7 Iron Age coins recorded on the PAS database in 2009 and recorded as a hoard in the Suffolk HER.
Hoard of 33 gold coins. 1 solidus of Anthemius was known.
272 nummi of Constantine I (AD 316-317).

A large vessel of 4th century coins recorded in Pastscape. 133 coins of the younger Constantinus, Constans and Magnentius. British Museum Add MSS 53717 ff.310-2 sketches etc. (Rev. John Skinner, 7.5.1830).
60 solidi in a lead vessel: Marcian - Zeno (c. AD 490); gold w8: 267g.

The hoard comprised a large ceramic pot containing 15kg of 4th century nummi, approximately 5000 coins. The coins appeared to have been arranged in piles. The hoard was dispersed but Chaurand was able to study 1037 coins which had been kept by the finder's family. With the exception of 2 SOLI INVICTO COMITI issues struck in London and Arles in AD 315 to 316, the hoard comprised coins issued between AD 318 to 326. The hoard was found in a vineyard. Mints: 77 Londinium, 77 Lugdunum, 464 Treveri, 141 Arelate, 30 Roma, 90 Ticinum, 19 Aquileia, 46 Siscia, 2 Sirmium, 22 Thessalonica, 2 Nicomedia, 1 Cyzicus; uncertain 66.
3 denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1

A group of coins 124 coins and 3 fragments (Constantine I - Constans – FMRD gives a list of 125 coins), recorded during archaeological investigations in the southern half of the east crypt of the cathedral in Trier; in addition, a small cube, a token, a bronze ring, and other small pieces were found. These coins were found in a layer of 'black soil' and might have fallen through gaps in a wooden floor.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 600 (or 1200?) bronze coins (radiates and nummi) of Claudius (II), Diocletian, Maximian I and Galerius, Constantius Chlorus, Severus II, Constantine I etc. all very well preserved. Found in a field named 'Champ d'Argent' by Mr. Alexandre of Illiers-l'Évêque while labouring.
49 nummi: Constantius II - Arcadius (AD 383-388)
93 nummi found while investigating within the fort. 88 coins were studied, all of the Constantine's I family (AD333-337).
272 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). 6 coins have been lost.
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
32 Roman imperial coins: at least 1 antoninianus (radiate): Augustus - Maximian I (AD 286-310). Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
250 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 10 coins have been seen by T. Gerasimov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 12 Roman coins, of which 8 were identified by H. Desaye: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 7.5 g.
138 nummi found next to a wall south west of the market at street level: House of Constantine - Valens (AD 364-378).

2 denarii found during construction of a local railroad in 1880. 4 gold objects (2 bars, 1 ring and 1 bracelet), were reportedly found with the denarii. A st1 with a portrait was also said to be found with the menti1d items but is an obvious modern fake of unknown origin.
190 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 189 nummi: Claudius II (Divus) - Theodosius I/Honorius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: 4 radiates foundfused together.

Unknown originally number of coins and artefacts. 40 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus, 10 coins of Constans (?), 3 solidi of Gratian. Together were found: a silver brooch, 2 silver bracelets, 2 silver buckles, a strap tongue made of silver, 2 silver rings, 3 crescent-shaped pendants made of gold.
disposition: Szekely Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (brooch, 2 bracelets, 2 buckles, 1 strap pin, 2 rings, 6 denarii, 1 solidus Gratian)

summary: 1551 coins, 7 antoniniani (radiates), 1544 nummi: 3rd century AD - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: Unknown Initial number of coins. 1509 silver coins: 1486 denarii, 6 plated denarii, 17 antoniniani (radiates) Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 244). Silver w8: 4710 g. Around 30 coins are still missing
disposition: Muzeul Regiunii Porților de Fier, Drobeta-Turnu Severin (1,502 coins); Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova (7 coins), Romania

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 300 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Circa 54 nummi. Only 8 coins are in the Museum of Sczeczin: Tetrarchy (AD 310313).

16 copper alloy coins from a pit on the same site as the Snodland hoard, found during archaeological excavation. All 16 coins were nummi, mostly of the House of Constantine dated to AD 330-335 but the latest coin identified was a slightly worn coin of Magnentius, AD 350-353.

Unknown originally number of coins. Approximately 108000 nummi (c. 600 kg) were recovered and prepared for documentation: Tetrarchy to Constantine I (AD 330-333). The hoard was found stored in jars and large Tripolitanian amphorae in a domestic building. At the moment, 82713 have been attributed by mints and periods: AD 294-307; AD 307-313; AD 313-318; AD 318-324; AD 324-330; AD 330-333.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum (El Khoms) of Leptis Magna, Libya

summary: Evans (1864, 109) notes that he has "2 others of these Sussex coins [Ashdown Forest silver units, ABC 662], said to have been found at Pevensey". Bean (2000, 268 no. 11) seemingly interprets this to mean 2 others in addition to Evans's plate coin (Plate F, no. 11), but the drawing appears to be of 1 of the coins (BMC 585) actually found in the Ashdown Forest hoard (254). No further information is available and these 2 coins cannot necessarily be regarded as originating in a hoard.
5 antoniniani of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2475

summary: Circa 180 nummi found in a ceramic vessel. Sold before it could be studied.
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: 56 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2069

summary: A lager hoard. 210 denarii entered the museum collection in Sofia. No further information.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (210 coins)

summary: 81 coins of different denominations (sestertius, dupondius, as, and 1 denarius): Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
33 gold coins: 6 solidi multiples and 27 solidi, 1 gold earring: Constantine I with sons. 160.53 g.
3137 coins: 600 denarii, 2137 antoniniani (radiates), 400 sestertii; silver w8: 552.3-5293.9 g.
It comprised 600 antoniniani (radiates) coins of Claudius II. No further details.

43 coins found between 2009 and 2018. They include 16 Roman Republican denarii, 17 Iron Age silver units and 9 Roman denarii up to Claudius, plus possibly 1 denarius of Trajan (but this coud be a stray find).
A hoard of 751 AE radiates, & 1 AE denarius and pottery to AD 286 in a black burnished ware jar. Unpublished coin report by R. Abdy.
289 Icenian and Roman silver coins up to Nero were recovered from a building site at Scole House, Scole.
2060 silver coins: 1849 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 209 antoniniani (radiates), 1 drachm: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-252).
disposition: History and Archaeology Museum Constanța, Romania

summary: A multilayered Roman st1 wall was unearthed during excavation work for the construction of a public utility on Weberbach Strasse. Shards and 79 bronze coins from the 4th century AD to Theodosius stemmed from the last Roman burnt layer.
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).

Unknown initial number of silver coins. 6 coins are known in the collection of the Salzburger Museum Carolino Augusteum: Septimius Severus 2, Julia Domna 1, Caracalla 1, Maximinus I Thrax 1, Gordian III 1.

A hoard of 255 Icenian and 72 Roman silver coins found in early 1972 on a building site at Lord's Walk, Eriswell, Suffolk. The condition of the latest Icenian coins in the hoard is worse than that of the latest Roman, and suggest that the minting of Icenian silver ceased well before 60, perhaps even in 43.
9 aurei: Tiberius - Vespasian (AD 71).
The hoard comprised 100 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised 12 nummi dated between AD 341-346 and AD 383-395.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.

The details of the hoard are not well known. Found in 1871 it passed possession multiple times and was eventually split. Originally 387 silver coins were found, and 1 gold piece, along with several urns. Only 12 pieces are described: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla Augusta).

The hoard comprised a white ceramic vessel containing 84 or 85 worn sestertii of Augustus to Trajan Decius. In 1901, a further 5 dupondii and asses of Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian and Faustina I were found, as well as a worn sestertius and a potin Iron Age coin depicting a horse surmounted by lyre. It is likely that these coins formed part of the earlier hoard.
The hoard comprised 225 sestertii from Trajan to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).

In 1885, 6 Roman gold coins and a golden clasp were dug up during digging works in the Main at Thüngersheim. In 1886 2 further gold coins were found at the same location. Coins range from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.
8 nummi: Valentinian I - Theodosius (AD 388-393).
81 bronze coins: 80 sestertii, 1 as: Hadrian - Aemilianus (AD 253).
The hoard was found in 1947 in an earthen vase. It comprised many coins. Only 10 antoniniani were recorded, from Gallienus to Diocletian.

In 1854 at Ritsch, 900 m from the Elbdeich, an old German earthenware container with 20 Roman nummi (Theodosius I - Arcadius), human remains and glass pearls was found. The find position lay in the area of a small hill. It certainly was a female burial within a migration period burial ground.
46 bronze coins: 45 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2287-2326

summary: Hoard of circa 500 silver coins. Only 14 were basically identified:
The hoard comprised 800 bronze coins of the Nabataeans.
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: 3 aurei were found in unknown circumstances: Hadrian, Commodus, Septimius Severus.

A number of coins were found during archaeological investigations in a karst st1 cave in 1977. Among these, a group of maiorinae of Magnentius could have been deposited together, but all other coins are single finds.
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 20 gold coins ranging from Valentinian I to Constantius III (?), most probably Constantine III, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.
33 coins: 1 denarius, 32 antoniniani (radiate) found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma': Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
276 denarii including 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
The hoard comprised 5 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Septimius Severus, 1 Julia Domna, 1 Elagabalus, 1 pseudo-autonomous), Edessa (1 Gordian III), found in a grave.

127 aurei, ranging from Tiberius to Vespasian, found in a field in Shillington parish. 117 were discovered first, then another 6 and finally another 4. A scatter of 18 silver denarii was found in the same area, see Shillington B hoard.
1522 nummi found with a bucket: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Museo Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 20 nummi were found in 1901 during excavation works on Fleischstrasse.

Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal st1 font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal b1, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a st1 cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins
(304) 294 coins: 123 antoniniani (radiates), 1 argenteus, 170 nummi: Caracalla - Constantine I (AD 306-337). Mints: Londinium, Lugdunum, Arelate, Treveri, Roma, Carthago, Siscia.
32 kilos found with a large ceramic vessel. Only 14.315 kilos recovered - 9372 coins: Gallienus - Honorius (AD 383-423). 6656 coins were studied by J.P. Barbosa.
disposition: Museu Abade de Baçal, Bragança, Portugal

summary: 488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).

summary: 61 denarii found with a ceramic vessel at the Dacian fortress: Republic – Augustus (13 BC).

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. Based on the diameter it is assumed they were sestertii. 51 coins were examined: Hadrian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Hoard of circa 40 solidi only 2 are known today: Honorius and Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
disposition: Münzkabinett Berlin Germany; Museum of Szczecin, Poland (until 1944)

summary: A hoard of solidi menti1d in a private letter by Mr. Thurston: Theodosius II - Justin I.
11 silver coins: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 605 (11 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 119 silver coins: 89 antoniniani (radiates), 27 denarii and 3 uncertain silver denomination: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 149.4-301.7 g.
78 coins: Claudius II (Divus) - Constantius II (AD 355-361).

summary: 523 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in a jar, hidden in a hole dug out beneath the floor of underground room H, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 507 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a bronze statuette of Mercury. 34 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 21 denarii, 12 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Galerius (Caesar) with a tpq of AD 293 to 294. It was found during the excavation of the Roman amphitheatre.
The hoard comprised a small greyware vessel containing 50 silver and billon Roman coins ending in issues of Postumus. It was found not far from TAF VIII/2.1 (Oise) (CHRE 3546).
Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: 104 gold coins: 36 solidi, 68 tremisses “mostly barbarous”: Leo I - Justin I (c. AD 525); gold w8: 262.2g. Together were found a chalice and a golden plate.

Hoard found over a period of period of several months, with a first coin found in 2007 already. In 2009, the con10t was listed (treasure case 2009 T465) as 5 solidi (all Honorius), 12 siliquae (Julian to Honorius), 1 nummus (Constantine II Caesar) and 1 gold finger ring. A further 1 denarius, 2 solidi, and 19 siliquae were found in 2010 (2010 T670).
Hoard of 227 coins of the Bosporan kings dated (AD 276-341). No further information.
The hoard, incomplete, comprised 6 antoniniani (radiates) of Diocletian.
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
5 denarii found together: Augustus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.
2 solidi of Jovian and Theodosius I (AD 388-392) minted in Constantinople and Treveri.
disposition: Frisian Museum, Lcenturyarden (collection Quaestius nos. FML 359, 360)

summary: The hoard was concealed under a tile and comprised 10 silver or billon coins dating to the late third or early 4th century AD. It is not clear whether the Tetrarchic issues are radiates or nummi. Silver w8: 4.3-11.9 g.
5 denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.

The coins listed here are those reported and declared Treasure at various inquests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The findspot became public and coins were being regularly found at the site. Their findspot was no longer reported accurately and so the coins should probably be considered together (with caution) as a scattered hoard. It is possible that some of these coins are addenda to hoards 496 and 2634. These 2 hoards do appear to have been spatially separate, found above and below the Crags respectively, but it has been suggested that a hoard may have been disturbed and spilled over the Crags.

Coins belonging to 3 different hoards are now kept together in the museum and it is not any more possible to attribute them to the original hoards, which is why FMRD lists all coins together. This list is longer than the original number of coins and therefore also includes some other coins. Patina and conservation are however very similar, so it is likely that these coins were also found in Trier, possibly close to the hoards. The 3 hoards are: 1) Feldstraße (summer 1885). 240 small bronzes, found while installing a canalisation; 2) Pfützenstraße (mid-1886): a hoard of 513+ coins, found during foundation work. 513 were acquired by the museum, the others dispersed. 3) Trier-Euren (autumn 1859): an earthenware vessel containing 1 denarius of Geta and 114 badly preserved small bronzes, found in association with a building that had a mosaic floor. The list given here is the 1 given in FMRD.
26 coins: 24 sestertii, 2 denarii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235); silver w8: 4.75 g.
disposition: Collection Ms. Ausselet, Charleroi, Belgium (26 coins and the lid)

summary: Several Freckenham staters were recorded in the trade with this provenance and seem likely to have originated in a hoard. No further details are available.

101 coins: 21 denarii, 74 antoniniani, 6 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: The hoard comprised several hundred coins (mostly Constantinian nummi) of which only 6 were recorded in any detail. It was found in rubble associated with a large and rich Gallo-Roman villa.
28 denarii found during archaeological excavations together with jewelry: Republic – Domitian (AD 81).
2 gold coins - 1 Valentinian I, 1 unidentified - were found in the vicinity of skeleton. The coin of Valentinian was dated in AD 368 (!). No description.
Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.

Towards the end of October 1878 3 aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A 4th aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
4942 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 222).

summary: 523 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

The hoard was found in a hollow st1 and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

summary: In 1904, numerous coins were discovered in Landrais and catalogued by Arnaud and Bourriau. In October 1913, a 'certain number' (perhaps 300 according to Bourriau) of coins were discovered at the same findspot, along with numerous sherds of black coarseware pottery. The coins were dispersed.

summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (12) Hoard 6. 16 coins from Tetricus I to House of Constantine, incl. 3 corroded & illegible & 2 4th C. copies.
94 denarii: 76 republican, 18 imperial: Anonymous - Augustus (15-13 BC).

Coins discovered during the excavations appeared to include 2 hoards, 1 of 7 nummi (Gatcombe I), the other of 9 nummi (Gatcombe II), found as quite distinct deposits trampled into a single occupation layer on the floor of building 3. Hoard II ends with coins of Magnentius and Decentius, rev. VICTORIAE DD NN AVG ET CAE(S).
Probably a funerary find, containing circa 20 nummi of Constantine I and Constantius II (AD 337-361?).
95 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
A purse containing 7 gold coins (solidi and tremissi), minted between AD 424 - 468 CE by the eastern Roman emperors in Constantinopolis, found 20 km south-west of anc. Meli10e.
4 radiates & 9 nummi to AD 350. This small Fel Temp Hoard includes some earlier Constantinian pieces as well as debased radiates.
3 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel: Julia Domna 1, Severus Alexander 1, Julia Mamaea 1 (AD 222-235).

summary: 112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).

In 1912, during the excavation of a Romano-British homestead at Hambledon Valley, a hoard was found, comprising 294 coins: 8 antoniniani and 287 AE (folles), ranging from Tetricus to Constantine II Caesar. Cathy King has assigned 1 ant. listed above under Tetricus II, to Tetricus I (b.?), and has identified 4 coins of Constantine I as fractions. The total no. of coins of Maximinus is given as 11, that of Constantine I as 207, that of Licinius I as 34, and that of Constantine II as 12.

148 Roman coins and silver and brass jewelry. 126 coins: 6 silver coins, 116 sestertii and 4 dupondii/asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249)

25 Roman nummi. These coins were transferred from Colombo to the Jaffna Museum for exhibition on 29th November 1945. No further information.

summary: The first coin of this small hoard of Gallo-Belgic gold was discovered on 23 March 1998, followed about a month later by 3 more (TAR 1997-98, 24 no. 106; Roy and Dunn 1998), then 2 more in November 1998 (TAR 1998-99, 98 no. 259). Sills (2003, 357 no. 13) suggests that the coin illustrated as TAR 1998-99, fig. 259.1 - supposedly 1 of the 2 November 1998 finds - is a repeat of a coin published in TH, January 1998, p. 13 no. 12, as a coin from Great Leighs, Essex. 7426 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271); silver w8: 1783.8-13513.7 g.. It is not clear whether this hoard was part of the deposit found on the site in the 9teenth century, or whether it represents a separate hoard on the same site. The hoard was found during rescue excavations by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques des Pays de la Loire after an individual found coins scattered on the ground surface on several occasions on the site of a Gallo-Roman villa.
(c.100) 34 coins: 27 antoniniani (radiates), 7 nummi: Gallienus - Valens (AD 364-378).
32 antoniniani (radiates) belonging to a purse: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of 14 clipped siliquae YORYM-F6AE88 (2014 T45). All the coins were worn and heavily clipped.

A hoard of ca. 500 (?) Roman imperial denarii was discovered by treasure hunters in February 2014 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and a general photo of 2 part of the coins was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on December 27, 2014. According to the finders, the coins were found in a field, on an area of 5x5 meters, together with a silver buckle (only the frame of the buckle is preserved). The search for the coins lasted for 2 days. This field, according to the informants, was quite popular among local treasure hunters. Some of the coins from the hoard found on the second day were stuck together. There are 2 general photos of the coins: 1 shows at least 60 denarii, the other at least 71 (there are also photos of this part of the hoard on a scale, together with the silver buckle: 336.5 g). These photos were published by different treasure hunters, so they most likely represent different parts of the hoard. I managed to identify only a small part of the coins in the photos: 13 coins in the first photo and 13 coins in the second photo. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
69 sestertii and 5 dupondii ranging from Domitian to Septimius Severus.
13 coins examined of 14 originally: Theodosius I - Honorius/Constantine III; gold w8: 51.95g. Together was found a gold ring.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo; Museo Arqueológico Nacional, Madrid, Spain

summary: 9 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 5 asses: Augustus (AD 12-14).
12000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
4 aurei of Vespasian (AD 71-79). Found in the praetorium/principia of the auxiliary fort.
446 "bronze" coins - most likely, among them, antoniniani (radiates) and nummi: 1 Carthaginian, 45 Roman. The Roman coins: Tiberius - Constantius II (AD 337-361).

An entry in the diary of Sir Simonds D'Ewes, for 12 November 1646 reads: 12 Nov Postquam pranseram lustravi octo Numismata aurea, et ultra 500 argentea Romana nuper in agro Varnice'si Neronis, Vitellij, Vespasiani Traiani (BL Harleian MS 484, f. 130v). After I had dined I looked at 8 Roman gold coins and a further 500 silver recently found in a field near Warwick, of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Trajan.
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
The hoard comprised c. 1500 coins from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 2 silver drachms of the Koinon of Crete (Caligula, given to Gortyn? in RPC I), found in Grave 12 of the Roman cemetery of Agios Nikolaos.
Circa 2000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.
141 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of several years.
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.

The hoard comprised 214 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Gordian III which are today lost. Also found in the excavations as isolated finds were a denarius of Septimius Severus, and 2 bronzes of Severus Alexander. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 313.3-487.1g
6 gold Gallo-Belgic E staters, found in 2 groups of 3.

A small group of bronze staters donated to Somerset County Museum in 1992 (Somerset Archaeology and Natural History 136 (1992), 208). The coins were found following an archaeological watching brief on the Bowden Reservoir Link Pipeline, which had revealed 3 ditches and 1 pit containing a few Iron Age and Roman sherds (Somerset HER 55106).
Hoard of 36 coins of the Bosporan kings, of Theothorses, Rhadamsades, Rhescuporis VI (AD 295-327).
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 3 "aurei" in the name of Aelia Verina, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.

A hoard of ca. 500 nummi, found in 1 of the Graeco-Roman houses built within the perimeter of the first courtyard of the Pharaonic temple. This hoard is similar in its composition to EL KAB 1946. Coins of Constantius II, Julian and Valens are noted.

In a small Roman urn found in the bank of a pit at Wishaw (which adjoins Wig-ings-hill and Cat's Hill) were several Roman coins - 7 Gallienus, 2 Victorinus, 5 Tetricus 6 Claudius and several uncertain.
4 bronze coins, 3 sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel which was broken. It comprised 546 bronze and 'billon' Roman coins from the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD. It was a mixed hoard of Anto9 bronzes and later radiates. M. Lepel-Cointet of Jumièges owns the remains of the vessel and some coins.

36 gold and silver Iron Age coins had been handed in to the Russell-Cotes Museum, Bournemouth, in October 1980, and said to have been found at a depth of c.75 cm "buried beneath a flat st1". There are persis10t suggestions in the published and unpublished reports of the find that a) it was much larger than the declared portion, and b) it was found somewhere other than the given location. A large quantity of Roman bronze - up to 200 coins, mostly of the second to 4th centuries AD, of which "over 100" were donated to Dorset County Museum - was reported to have come from the same location; there were also 2 Durotrigan bronze staters from the site, but apparently not associated with the hoard.
41 coins: 39 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 57.5-75.2g.
Hundreds of coins. Recovered 4 coins: 1 antoninianus, 2 denarii, 1 nummus: Caracalla, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I, Constantius II
disposition: Collection Ormós Zsigmond; Muzeul Banatului, Timișoara, Romania

summary: 35 nummi of the Tetrarchy.
Hoard of circa 600-700 denarii. 433 pieces were studied: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Hoard of 216 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A group of 13 coins, thought to have possibly been contained in a bag or pouch. Found in Colchester Lion Walk site R (between insulae 29 and 37/388a) in a post-Roman pit.

A hoard of at least 125 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was found by 2 treasure hunters in early April 2020 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the 105 coins were published by user Sergej Ovsijchuk (Сергій Овсійчук) in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on April 3, 2020. In the comments to his post he informed that the hoard was found in a field (in a pasture), at a depth of between 30 and 70 cm in clay soil. No pottery fragments were found. Additional photos to the post show that the finders made a probing (about 2x1m) at the site, up to 1m deep. Some of the coins had bronze oxides. The photos of the coins published in the post are of rather poor quality, besides many coins had contaminations, so only a part of the deposit coins is defined. The hoard was divided into 2 parts: most of the hoard (105 coins) belonged to the author of the post, the other part (at least 20 coins) belonged to the second treasure hunter. The further fate of the hoard is unknown coins.

A small hoard consisting of approx. 30 Roman imperial denarii, a Constantius II solid with a loop and a gold pendant (or several pendants?), was discovered in the late 2010s near the village of Pohrebysche in the Vinnytsia region. Photos of the coins have not been preserved. The information is difficult to verify, so it is not quite clear whether we are talking about a hoard with accompanying items or about a hoard and items found separately at a neighboring settlement.

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus (AD 260-269).
Denarius hoard consisting of 114 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Otho to Caracalla. 119 fragments in total.

In the Fanum Voltumnae with a st1 container 221 coins: 185 republican asses, 2 republican denarii, 1 republican quinarius, 18 imitations of issue "Divus Iulius" (RRC 535/1), 15 imperial asses of the IIIviri series (AD 15 BC).
25 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1780 1-25

summary: 24 nummi, part of a larger hoard, coming from a private collection: Constans - Julian II (AD 361-363).

A Whaddon Chase stater is "said to have been found, together with 4 other British coins, near Thetford". The coin is almost certainly BMC 310 (Chadburn 2006, hoard 8), which matches the w8 given by Evans. Haselgrove (1987, 328 no. 73) acknowledges that it could be a bona fide small hoard, but also suggests it could be a parcel from Whaddon Chase (CHRE 15390).
Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver w8: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: Large number of silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. The minting period run from 91 BC to AD 254. Only 69 coins are preserved: 1 aureus, 66 denarii, 2 drachms: Republic to Hadrian (AD 119-122).
25 solidi found, 12 preserved: Honorius - Anthemius (c. AD 470); gold w8: 111.25g.
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, collection Brera (inv.nos. M.0.9.14234-14245).

summary: 5 republican denarii found by metal detector (77 BC).

Lafaurie dates the deposition of this hoard to the beginning of the fifth century, before the menace of the Vandals (letter of 28.06.1962). Circa 200 siliquae; Silver w8: c. 254.7-339.6 g. According to Kent: 'perhaps 'Vandal', probably Visigothic GLORIA'.
Unknown originally number of coins. According to I. Mira there are 2842 coins known, all antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo del Seminario de Santiago, Braga, Portugal (68 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy jug containing more than 1800 coins, mostly of Diocletian and Maximian. According to Derriaz, there were a few issues from the mint of Rome, with the remainder being mint of Lyon issues. The jug was acquired by the Musée de la Civilisation gallo-romaine, Lyon (Inv. Br. 208)

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 203 coins. These included 17 denarii from Trajan to Commodus, 103 radiates from Claudius II to Maximian, 4 argentei from Maximian to Galerius and 80 nummi from Diocletian to Constantius I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 64.9g and 88.7g.

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins. However, only 268 coins were catalogued: . The rest were sold: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian /Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Instituto Arqueologia de la Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal (200 coins); Mário de Castro Hipólito collection (68 coins)

summary: 2042 Roman bronze coins. Confirmation required. No further information.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 275 sestertii and dupondii or asses, arranged in piles from Domitian to Gordian III. 2 thirds of the hoard were unidentifable because of a thick layer of corrosion products. The hoard was found in a wood on the Tesnières wood in the roots of an oak tree. Fragments of the ceramic vessel and part of the hoard were acquired by the Musée du Mans
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).

The hoard comprised 57 radiates recovered by excavators from the Touring Club de France in 1966. To these it is possible to add another 40 coins of the same date found at the same findspot in 1899 and likely to be part of the hoard. The hoard was found on 2 separate occasions. The first coins were found in 1899. The circumstances of their discovery are unknown. A second group of coins were then discovered during an archaeological excavation in 1966. Silver: 9, 48 coins; Silver w8: 2.7
The hoard comprised an urn containing approximately 700 base-silver coins, which were not described in any detail. TAF suggests that this was a hoard of antoniniani (radiates).
928 (589) denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole reign) (AD 267).
disposition: Nikšić Heritage Museum (575 coins), Montenegro; the National Museum of Herceg-Novi (125 coins), Monetnegro; Museum of Titograd = Podgorica City Museum (Muzej grada Podgorice) (225 coins), Montenegro - 1981

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 6 denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.
A hoard of around 50 sestertii dating to the Anto9 period were found in a ceramic vessel within an urban bath-house complex.
Described as a third century hoard, including a number of aurei, 'including issues of Faustina I/II (as Diva) and Julia Maesa'.
At least 88 denarii: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
50-8 staters discovered between 28 August and 11 September 1998, within the grounds of the Jealotts Hill Research Station north of Bracknell.
33 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 28 dupondii. No further details.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
The hoard comprised over 2 silver coins and an unknown quantity of bronze provincial Judaean coins.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins: 10 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Commodus - Philip I (244-249 AD).
The hoard comprised at least 583 nummi of the Tetrarchy to Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 313-316).
33 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD14-37). Possible part of PALERMO? 1893-a
disposition: Museo Nazionale di Palermo, Italy; inv. no. 1721 (in 1893)

summary: 7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
Originally, 274 nummi, 119 coins available for study dated between AD 335 and AD 361.
Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).
176 coins: 3 medallions, 58 sestertii, 115 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Gallienus (AD 260); silver w8: 145.4-337.5 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (171 coins); private collection (2 coins), in 1961

summary: The hoard was recovered from the site of a Gallo-Roman vicus during illegal excavations and comprised a denarius of Septimius Severus and 561 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus (ad 193-211).
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: 26 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
310 nummi found during the excavations at the archaeological site. Among them issues of Constantine I, Constantine I (Fausta), Constans, Constantius II.
38 bronze coins: 2 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 28 asse, 4 dupondii or asses: Titus - Commodus (AD 192).
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.

2 solidi in the name of Decentius (AD 351-352), reported in 2015 independently by 2 different finders, but probably coming from the same field. 2 further solidi were reported in 2020 (Constantinus) and 2021 (Constans).

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in 3 textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
100 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
3 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), but this is not certain. Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
