With 4 denarii republicans and 280 imperial of Augustus.
HER record of an unrecorded late third-century hoard found by a metal-detectorist along with pottery sherds, a bracelet and a finger ring "with opposed dolphins".
Hoard 345 coins found on a wall from the Roman vicus: Tiberius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.
6 coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
The hoard comprised 401 antoniniani (radiates) terminating in an issue of Postumus (AD 260-269).
47 coins - 1 antoninianus (radiate), 45 sestertii, 1 as - found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman villa: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
The hoard comprised 22 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Gallienus and Claudius II (AD 268-270).
8 sestertii of Tiberius found in a ceramic vessel. All of the same type RIC 48 (Rome, AD 22-23).
Hoard of 2000 coins: Bosporan kings (Rhescuporis III, Sauromates IV, Teiranes, Thothorses, Rhadamsades, Rhescuporis VI and Tetrarchy up to Licinius I and Constantine I (nummi).
disposition: Old collection A. Kh. Steven (528 coins); Museum of Fine Art, Moscow, Russia (15 coins a cquired in 1947)

summary: The hoard comprises 1931 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Philip I, as well as a single drachm of Geta from Caesarea in Cappadocia. Found with a ceramic vessel.
Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).

3432 late Roman bronze coins - nummi - ranging in date from Constantine I to Marcian. Of these only 342 were deemed in a suitable condition to be recorded in the museum inventory. The w8 of each coin in this sample varies between 1- 2.5g, with the majority being around 2g.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilizations, Ankara, Turkey

summary: Hoard of circa 1200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,
40 nummi of Justinian I. Highly unlikely as a hoard- possibly a garbled account of 1 40-nummia piece?
A hoard of 29 nummi (Gratian - Arcadius for the coins that could be identified, with also a 5th century monogram type), discovered in sector D (inv. 79D/18) of Tell Atrib.
The hoard comprised 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I, Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver w8: 166.1-340.8 g.
972 republican coins: 888 denarii, 58 denarii serrati, 25 quinarii, 1 victoriatus (32 BC). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a golden bracelet.

165 coins: Celtic, Greek - Augustus (27 BC - AD 14). It seems, that the coins from hoard were mixed with the single finds from the excavation of 1955 and thy are no longer identifiable. Also, some pieces are considered lost.

The hoard comprised 20 asses ending in issues of Claudius I and has been interpreted as he con10ts of a purse. Found during excavations, in a quarter to the north of the antique settlement. Found in tomb 1, a cremation burial. 20 asses, Tiberius to Claudius I; 13 coins corroded by fire.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: 50 uncertain gold and silver coins. Issuers menti1d from Otho to Postumus (AD 260-269)?

Roman coin hoard found in 1936. Discrepancy in location of findspot. HER reports that 18 coins, including an AE of Constantine the Great, were found in 1936 in Hadfield's Quarry in Pindale near a cottage called the Black Rabbit.
Some time before 1885, an aureus of Vespasian was discovered in Coudert. In 1947, a further aureus of Vespasian was found, suggesting the presence of a dispersed hoard.

49 coins: 2 denarii, 7 antoniniani, 40 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); 28 provincial bronze coins of Marcianopolis and Nicopolis ad Istrum: Septimius Severus - Gordian III; silver w8: 12.1-19.7 g.

The hoard comprised more than 1000 antoniniani (radiates) of which 1038 were acquired by the Musée des Antiquités de Rouen' 'Une pelleteuse heurta' hit the vessel in which the hoard was buried: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 281.2-1296.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: A hoard of 169 bronze coins (K.2387) found at Kish in Mesopotamia, east of Babylon, in the Sasanian levels. The coins were badly preserved and only ⅔ of the coins could be identified. These are 1 chalcus of Seleucus I (N.B. The opening year of the hoard does not include this coin), 98 Late Roman bronzes (House of Constantine: 2; House of Valentinian; House of Theodosius: 69; uncertain: 23), 9 Sasanian bronzes (badly struck, only 1 could be identified: Bahram V).
disposition: Ashmolean Museum, Heberden Coin room (accessioned on 20.9.1933)

summary: 1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not 1 hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.
52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a st1 building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: A hoard of 21 nummi found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, niveau de fréquentation. Ritual deposit, 21 aes coins in the lower part of a broken pot, placed next to the north-eastern basis of the arc above the cult relief.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: 4 aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
Urn containing 1500 Roman coins, found by a man ditching in a field. Undated.
(c. 1550) 1512 coins: 1022 antoniniani (radiates), 490 nummi: Valerian I - Tetrarchy (AD 306).
disposition: Collection Müller, 31 coins. The rest of hoard is lost.

summary: 7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver w8: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: Unknown number of denarii. 3 coins are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Mark Antony 1, Tiberius 2.
disposition: Russe Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1635-1637

summary: Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Groups of single finds consisting in 6 gold imitations of Alexander's stater, 3 drachms of Gotarzes II and 3 (or 4?) denarii of Augustus discovered in burial no. 4 during excavations.

A small scattered hoard of 6 or 8 coins, said to have been found in the area of Leominster and Bromyard, in north-east Herefordshire, in or before May 2008. Only 2 of the coins have so far been recorded.
40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
The hoard comprised approximately 2000 coins ending with issues of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins from Gallienus to Postumus. Found during flint extraction.
87 coins - antoninianus (radiate), sestertii and nummi: Philip I - Valens (AD 364-378).
19 nummi: Constantius II - Arcadius (AD 388-402)
A hoard of 1153 denarii (Republic to Nero, AD 64), found in a field in 2008 (1121 specimens), with 5 additional coins found in 2012, and 2 more in 2013.
The hoard comprised 24 sestertii, asses and antoniniani (radiates) from Augustus to Probus and was found in the courtyard garden of a house during excavations of the Roman town of Clunia.
13 Iron Age gold staters, found in a flint container in 1827.
381 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.
163 antoniniani (radiates) found with a storage jar: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard was discovered by chance in a field and was in part immediately dispersed. With these coins was a small gold bar formed by a metal rod of circular section and decreasing in thickness. This rod is coiled on itself in the form of a snake.

A hoard of 486 antoniniani, of which at least 467 are imitations of coins of Tetricus I or Tetricus II, Victorinus and Divus Claudius II Gothicus, probably buried AD 290. The hoard was found on a field between Welldorf and Jülich while metal detecting and the surrounding area was then excavated.

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
The hoard comprised 17 silver shekels of Years 2-5 from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73) and 2 silver flans.
872 Iron Age silver units in a pot.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 1300 and 1500 copper-alloy coins from Antoninus Pius to Tetricus I.
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
17 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. Only 3 coins are known: Claudius II 1, Aurelian 2 (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 100 Continental Iron Age silver coins.
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
Unknown initial number of coins. 3 denarii: Vespasian - Titus (AD 79).
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia; 1 coin; dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 109 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus and was found in the corner of a Roman building uncovered during ploughing. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 30.4g and 135.3g.
A hoard of 6 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica and Pella) ranging from Julia Domna to Philip I, found in the remains of a Roman building.

In 1976 2 workmen found a small hoard of Roman 4th century 53 silver siliquae in a trench on a building site at Hillgrounds, Kempston, Bedfordshire. Coins range from Constantius II to Magnus Maximus, covering the period from about AD 360 to 388.
(c. 3 kg, c. 900 coins) 196 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A hoard of Norfolk Wolf and Snettisham type staters.

1 denarius (Severus Alexander), 2 gold coins (Libius Severus, pseudo-imperial solidus; Julius Nepos, pseudo-imperial tremissis) found at Oxborough, where an Anglo-Saxon cemetery is known. The Libius Severus coin is set in a pendant.
3942 nummi (3.40 kilos): pre-Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
Over 2897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: 19 AE sestertii and fractions to AD 242

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel filled with 15 Roman silver coins and 600 small bronzes of the same module (radiates). The reverse of 1 coin is given as MARTI PACIFERO, A/-. It appears to be an issue of Gallienus (RIC V/1 236?)
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: 63 coins found in a grave: Claudius II - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
10 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of 87 coins of the mid-4th century was found near West Wycombe. The pieces were scattered in a field, but they almost certainly belong to a single find. Most of the pieces were in very poor condition with the result that although the reverse types could be identified in most instance, some of the obverses and many of the mint marks were either illegible or only partly legible. All of the coins except 1 (an imitation of a VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN type of AD 347-8) either were minted after the reform in 348 and before 353 or copied official types of these years.
"1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: The hoard comprised 197 nummi dating to the 4th century AD.
A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.
Around 3000 nummi of Constantine I and his family (AD 324-337).

3 gold solidi and 6 silver siliquae (1 being a contemporary counterfeit) found scattered over an area of several hundred square feet, ranging from Constantius II (issued c.AD 353-55) to Honorius, AD 402-06. The 4 of the officially issued siliquae are badly clipped, suggesting a date of deposit for those coins of AD 410 or slightly later. A further gold solidus of Honorius had been found on the same site in 1834, which suggests that the coins may well represent survivors from a hoard which had been initially disturbed by 1834.
(c. 200) 40 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver w8: 46.4-91.3 g.
Hoard of 11 denarii ending with Tiberius (AD 14-37).

4 uninscribed copper alloy Iron Age staters of the 'Hod Hill' type, found on the site of the Roman city Clausentum (Bitterne) near Southampton, together with bronze coins of the Roman Emperors Claudius I and Nero.
77 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large st1 building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).

29 Roman silver coins found at Chew Stoke, ranging from Republican denarii to the 3rd century AD. This may be the hoard menti1d by Rahtz (1957, 114) as having been found on Pagan's Hill by its then owner Mr Gray in 1870, though 40-50 silver coins were found. Very wide date spread, which may indicate a shrine or temple in use for a long time rather than a specific hoard (EG).

find_spot_name: ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, A (1) HOARD 2
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, A (1) Hoard 2. 19 coins from Constantine II to House of Theodosius, also incl. 2 radiates. Deposit AD 388-420

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river 2 miles from the estuary. The 6 preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
128 sestertii found with an Amphora: Claudius I 108, Drusus 13, 7 uncertain (AD 41-54).
54 from the 600 coins are known. All are antoniniani (radiates); silver w8: c.162g.
255 solidi: Arcadius - Basiliscus (c. AD 480); gold w8: 1134.75g.

A hoard of 125 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in a forest in the Poltava region (without exact location) in March 2019. According to the finder, the hoard was in a clay jug, of which only fragments remained. The maximum depth at which the coins were found, "1 and a half shovel blade", that is, up to 40 cm. On 31 March 2019, photos and information about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian forum of treasure hunters Violity. 1 forum member has determined that the hoard contains coins from Trajan and Hadrian (including a coin with a portrait of Aelius) to Septimius Severus, including 1 with a portrait of Julia Domna, and possibly 1 barbarian imitation. However, on 4 April 2019, in a Facebook group, photos of 65 coins from the hoard were posted (120 coins were reported to have been found). In April 2019, the hoard was sold at the Violity auction in 1 lot. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
60-70 silver coins of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD. No further information.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: The hoard comprised 104 small bronzes [antoniniani (radiates)]of Tetricus I. Of 97 examined by Bizeul, 76 were illegible and 27 difficult to recognise because their legends were incomplete, their reverses were barbarous or their flans were too small to strike. It is clear these coins were all barbarous radiates.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
600 silver coins. N. Moushmov have seen 387 coins: Republic - Nerva (AD 96-98).
2 Dobunnic silver units were found at the same location, 1 in March 2008 and 1 (PAS WILT-60F026) in October 2008.
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
165 coins (163 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Domitian to Alexander Severus), found with 2 silver bracelets ca. 3 km east of the Römerstraße. The coins were destroyed during the war.
disposition: Staatliche Münzsammlung München (lost during WWII; one bracelet survived)

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 31 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M VI 9663-9693 (31 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 2 denarii are known: Republic, Augustus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 17 silver coins entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: 2 denarii, 15 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 245-247); silver w8: 22.0-42.3 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 3240-3246

summary: The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a st1 figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular st1 pediment and some carbonised cereals.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in 4 ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.
60 antoniniani (radiates) found with remains from a textile bag: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270) in a doctor house.
A hoard of 299 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Elagabalus) and denarii (Domitian - Severus Alexander) from Dura Europos, found in J 7 W.

During archaeological excavations. 8 coins were found in a layer of ashes: 2 Hellenistic (Mar1a and Enos), 1 uncertain - provincial bronzes and minted in Anchialus: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1 and Geta 1.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: 29 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Tetrarchy - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Museu D. Diego de Sousa, Braga, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised a whiteware jug containing between 800 and 900 coins (or 2000 according to De Closmadeuc): Philip I - Tacitus (Ad 275-276).
disposition: Musée départemental d'archéologie , Nantes, France (900 coins and sherds from the vessel)

summary: 21 denarii found by metal detecting: Trajan - Septimius Severus.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 14 denarii of Augustus minted in Lugdunum, all of type RIC 207 (2 BC - AD 4).
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 19 pieces have been noticed: Rhometalces I 4, Rhometalces II and Tiberius 14,
disposition: Once in a private collection, Plovdiv, lost?

summary: Around circa 1000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Claudius II (AD 268-270) and some Gallic usurpers. Coins were split between the finder, the field owner, and the local museum.
11 nummi found under the burned floor of a building from the Late Roman fort: Constantius II - Valens (AD 364-378).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel (amphora?). 38 denarii were avalable for study: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I Diva) - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
200 Roman coins. No further information
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
All are imitations: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 116.4-203.9g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: The hoard comprised 'half a dozen small bronzes of Diocletian, Maximian I and Constantine,' The hoard was found in a natural fissure in the rock while quarrying limest1 on the îlot de la Dive.
A hoard of 20+ Roman silver coins (i.e. certainly denarii), found while digging out peat on the Dörpstedter Moor.

A letter from M. Bréjouneau announced the discovery of 3 ceramic funerary urns and a 4th in st1 which contained cremation burials. 32 copper coins were also discovered at the same time. At least 7 were bronzes of the second century AD.
9 coins found near a broken m1y-box: 5 antoniniani, 2 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 unidentified denomination: Septimius Severus/Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.

The hoard was found as the result of deep-ploughing which brought 126 small Roman bronzes to the surface which were collected by farmers. An archaeological excavation then revealed a greyware vessel filled with more radiates and a further pink ceramic vessel containing 1276 coins. 2 containers, 1 with 988 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Domna to Postumus, the other 1437 from Valerian to Tetricus II Silver: 2425 coins; silver w8: 730.8-3581.8g.
6 silver coins found close to each other: 1 denarius, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 4 siliquae: Commodus (1), Gordian III (1), Constantius II (4).

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing several 100 bronze Iron Age coins. Chauvet catalogued 377. Although the tpq was originally fixed at 12-10 BC, the presence of a semis from Lyon may suggest a date between AD 10 and 14. The hoard was found by a farmer cutting hay.
disposition: Sold to B. Ledain, Daerocq and Rollin et Feuardent, the big coin dealers i Paris; the Lot Ledain in the municipal library in Poitiers (Roman coins); Musee Grandes Ecoles, Poitiers, France

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).
185 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1 solidus, 180 nummi: Gallienus (sole) - Honorius (AD 408-423). Together was found a scale w8.

The hoard was found during the excavation of the Roman town of Baelo and comprised 13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II with a tpq of AD 269-270. The coins were stacked 1 on top of the other next to a piece of limest1.

A hoard of 538 bronze nummi ranging to AD 316 and discovered in a field to the north of Downside Abbey, Stratton on the Fosse. The site lies approximately 400 metres to the west of the Fosse Way in an area that has produced other Romano-British material. The list includes 4 coins "found in the close vicinity of the hoard".

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The 3 denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 94 denarii recovered: Republic – Augustus (16 BC).
The hoard was found with several fragments of a red-orange ceramic vessel which presumably was its original container.

The hoard comprised a very large quantity of 'medals of middle bronze'. A hundred were studied in more detail with Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius, Lucilla, Commodus and Septimius Severus represented.
90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver w8: 114.7-196.4 g.
(?) 51 sestertii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
The hoard comprised 50 electrum coins.
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
39 nummi found together with a gilded silver helmet. 1 nummus of Constantine I (AD 313-320).

A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
191 silver coins: 132 denarii, 57 antoniniani (radiates), 2 imitations of antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
52 denarii of Hadrian of only 3 RIC types: RIC 119, 256, 339 (AD 134-138). Found together with some bits of amber.
The hoard comprised 7 middle bronzes of Vitellius stacked in a hole.
The hoard comprised 12 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Salonina, Saloninus and Postumus.
Hoard of around 2000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

2 solidi (Julian II, Valentinian I), found in 1684 and 1910. It seems most likely that these 2 coins come from the same findspot: New Downs, where the coin of Valentinian was found in 1684 is to the north of St Agnes Beacon, where the Julian was found 226 years later, and, given the fact that they were struck within at most 7 years of each other, the probability must be that they are from a small hoard.
disposition: St Agnes Museum has an impression of these solidus of Julian II.

summary: 65 billon Alexandrian tetradrahms: Nero - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 292-293). 'Presented to the owner by Felix Cary in Marseilles and reported to have been found in Upper Egypt in 1760.'
disposition: 'Probably now in Gotha as the rest of Schachmann's collection'

summary: 23 nummi: Constans - Constantius II (AD 355-361). Uncertain whether they were found together, although the composition may suggest so.
disposition: Museo Civico "F. L. Belgiorno", Modica, Italy (inv.nos. 1475-1497)

summary: 28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver w8: 35.0g.

A building of the Roman period lay on the premises of a wine dealer on Nikolausstrasse 113. In the cellar of the building, a hoard of approx. 50 bronze coins from the time of the Tetrarchy was found in 1887, surrounded by ash.
8 nummi: Theodosius I - Honorius (AD 383-423).
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
Flint containing 14 Iron Age staters.

539 nummi found with textile rests in a room destroyed by fire, located on the right side of the fort's prae10tura/principia? of the legionary fortress: Constantine I - Arcadius-Honorius (AD 402-408). Together with the coins were found: 1 melted silver item, 1 small ceramic pitcher, 1 lamp, 1 fragment from a cross-bow brooch, 2 knives, 1 iron key, 1 b1 hair comb.
disposition: Historische Museum der Stadt Wien, Austria

summary: At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Around 100 coins from Vitellius to Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, B (1A) HOARD 1
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1a) Hoard 1. 23 coins from Constantine II to House of Theodosius, deposit AD 390-420.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Quietus (AD 260-261).
37 coins: antoniniani (radiates), nummi: Claudius II - Constantine I (AD 306-337).

A group of 13 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus), found in Wehde, which is the location of a Saxon urn burial ground (2nd - 5th c. AD). It is uncertain whether the coins lay together in an urn or whether they were spread out in different urns. In 1886 the coins were purchased by LM Han. from a private owner. Addressed as Hoard?/Gave find? in FMRD.

Approx. 80 small bronze coins, of which 13 are imitations of Tetricus I, found on a brickyard located between the Lehmstrasse and Am Schlütershof. Apparently, they were contained in a small metal box.
Unknown initian number of coins. 32 nummi of the House of Constantine from AD 348 to AD 354 were studied in a private collection.

The hoard comprised 9000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver w8: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.
Hoard of circa 2000 coins. Only 129 pieces were recovered they were all issues of the Bosporan kings: Sauromatess II, Rhescuporis II and Cotys III (AD 228-234).
disposition: Former military museum of Kuban (129 coins).

summary: Circa 100 silver coins of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD were found in a ceramic vessel. Scattered.
18 silver coins entered the museum collection in Nova Zagora: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1159

summary: The hoard comprised at least 49 bronze coins from the reign of Herod (37-4 BC).
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: 2266 antoniniani (radiates) found in a bronze vessel: Septimius Severus - Probus (AD 277).
31 nummi, range: Constans/Constantius II - House of Theodosius (AD 379-423). Possible, part of the hoard Termini Imerse 1984 A.
disposition: Museo Civico "B. Romano" Comune di Termini Imerese

summary: 60 antoniniani of Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 75 g.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, D (11) HOARD 4
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (11) Hoard 4. 6 coins from Constantine I to House of Valentinian, deposit AD 368-385.
2 denarii of Hadrian
A small set of coins that were glued together to form a small cylinder were found next to a corpse.

A grave found in the peribolos of the west cemetery of ancient Rhodes (reused in late Roman times) contained a hoard comprising 4 Roman bronze coins: 1 of Aemilianus (in the mouth of the deceased), 1 of the first to second century AD, 1 of Caracalla and 1 of Alexander Severus (beside the head).
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only 2 are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.

Unknown number of argentei of the Tetrarchy found somewhere around Milano. 200 coins were offered for sale in Milano. The coins were minted during the Tetrarchy I: Diocletian, Maximian I, Galerius, Constantius I.
Hoard of 1 Roman aureus - Tiberius - and 14 imitations depicting portraits ranking from Trajan to Septimius Severus-Caracalla.
The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing '300 billon coins (radiates) dating to the 3rd century AD.
54 coins: 5 aurei, 45 denarii, 3 quinarii, 1 drachm of Apollonia: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).

The find was unearthed in 1820 and comprises only Late Roman bronze coins (Constantine I - Constantius II). Some scholars have believed it was part of the same find as IMSBACH 1846, but this does not seem to be the case.
9 coins: 2 sestertius, 4 antoniniani (radiates), 3 nummi: Trajan - Constans (AD 347-348).
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). W8: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: 8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
403 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 319-320).
disposition: Section historique de l'lnstitut Grand-Ducat de Luxembourg, Luxemburg National Museum (205 coins)

summary: A scattered hoard of 39 Iron Age staters.
Unknown number of coins, including 3 solidi: Theodosius II 2, Majorian (AD 457); gold w8: 13.35 g.
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 3695 staters and imitations of Bosporan kings found with a jug in the eastern necropolis of Phanagoria: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes, Thothorses (AD 308). 2-thirds are billon staters and the res are copper 1s.
The hoard comprised 19 Provincial bronzes of Severus Alexander issued in Caesarea Maritima.

De Jersey (2015) gives a full account of this discovery and its implications. This was probably the largest Iron Age coin hoard found in Britain, but it was illegally detected and then dispersed, before a complete record could be made. The hoard appears to have been contained in a metal bowl and was associated with further gold coins, ingots and torc fragments buried above and below it. Estimates range from between 6000 and 8000 silver coins.
The hoard comprised between 500 and 600 Roman coins. The coins were bought by M. de Bois-Robert, a collector from Montreuil at the end of the 18th century or the beginning of the 19th.

A hoard of 387 silver coins, including a large quantity of posthumous Philip Philadelphus (121, year 19 to 32, i.e. 31-18 BC), Roman denarii (141, up to AD 207), Syrian tetradrachms (29), Arabian didrachms (Trajan, 3 coins), as well as Parthian drachms (92 up to Artabanus IV, 213-227). The later coins of Severus and the members of his family are in mint state. Found in the 9veh excavations in the 1929-30 season.
disposition: British Museum (154 coins); the Birmingham City Art Gallery (17 coins); Sir Charles Hyde (25 coins); Bagdad museum (196)

summary: 52 silver coins were discovered in the modern suburbs of the city: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2320 /1-52

summary: On the jaws of a skeleton near the previous 1 were 7 well-preserved coins: 1 silver by Caracalla; another pure silver by Alessandro Severo; 3 of Aureliano and 1 of Caro, covered with silver, and 1 of copper belonging to Probus.
28 bronze coins (Nero - Antoninus Pius or even later) that could be a hoard, found together in a garden. No further details given in FMRD.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2500 well-preserved nummi, mostly GENIO POPVLI ROMANI reverse types.
(117) 115 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus; silver w8: 215.2-340.5 g.
52 nummi found in a grave: Maximian I - Constantin I (AD 317).
Of those seen (934), were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Sverus to Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 1364.0-1708.8g.
104 denarii: 71 Republic, 21 legionary series, 12 imperial: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
A scattered hoard of Chute staters, found in the same field as the Chute I (1927) find.
99 nummi found in the old collection of the Archaeological Museum of Granada under the label "Tesoro Granada 1868": Maximinus II Daza - Licinius I (AD 316).

Several finds have been made 1932 in the course of digging flints for road making on the Downs between Eastbourne and East Dean. Not far from Birling Manor 5 small contemporary forgeries of Ancient British gold coins occurred. They are copper, thinly plated with gold, and they represent uninscribed coins and 1 of Dubnovellaunus
Between 50 and 200 Iron Age gold coins, found in 1749 in the middle of the ridge of Karn-brê-hill.
An imitation of Alexander III's stater and aureus of Augustus (27 BC - 14 AD).
disposition: private purchase by Ivan Stepapovich Ter-Asaturov

summary: The hoard comprises 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I with a tpq of AD 274.
3 denarii (Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
3 uniface Atrebatic staters, all from the same reverse die and reportedly found together.
2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.
20 Iron Age bronze coins were found on the shore of the Lac de Grand-Lieu (or according to Hucher, on a jetty in the lake).
40 silver coins: 5 denarii, 35 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259).
Circa 80000 republican aurei minted between 46 and 38 BC, found with a vessel. Gold w8 650 kg.
(700) 607 antoniniani: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 153.8-706.5 g.
disposition: History Museum, Targivishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 352 (597 coins); History Museum, Omurtag, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4-14 (12 coins)

summary: 1 (possibly 2) gold iron Age staters, found on New Chetney Island with a Republican denarius.
14 sestertii found in a house: Nerva - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Concreted group of about 15 small copper alloy coins or coin blanks, found by D'Arcy Hunt, identified by Moorhead (2000, 57 no. 79) as a hoard. Found among a group of detector finds from an unknown site in Lacock parish. The collection of D'Arcy Hunt is now in the Wiltshire Museum, Devizes.
The hoard comprised at least 558 coins of the Gallic Iron Age.
Hoard of aurei and jewelry: 94 aurei: Nero - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold w8: 648.8g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.

A hoard of more than 212 coins (Valerian I - Postumus) came into view in 1969 on Saarstrasse 135 during building work; it was dispersed. The RLMT bought 91 coins, 121 further coins were seen in private collections.
4 Durotrigan base silver staters, which may perhaps have come from a hoard, confiscated from metal detectorists.
40 similar coins (1 is described: Constantine I), found together during building work 1963 and kept in private possession.

32 coins found placed in a leather bag (fragments survived): 28 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 as, 1 fragment of a bronze coin: Titus - Commodus (AD 192) and 1 solidus od Theodosius II (AD 430-440). Beside coins, the leather bag contains: 2 pearls, 19 fragments of mol10 brooches and 6 buckles, some of which were melted and damaged, some of which were not quite ready to use, bronze pieces, bronze ingots, fragments of a bronze vessel. A fibula was not quite finished, probably the casting was unsuccessful. The treasure also includes a tool, a piece of leather and lumps of bronze.
disposition: Museum in Frombork (Frauenburg) until WWII. Today, lost

summary: 168 Alexandrian provincial bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149). Found in the ground. All drachms, only briefly described. Oldest Vespasian, among the other coins are menti1d "interesting types of Antinous, Sabina, Aurelius Caesar, also some of the rare 'nome' types and few of the famous zodiacal series struck in the 8h year of Antoninus Pius."

A hoard of 551 coins, found in a drainage ditch on farmland half a mile from Llanarmon Dyffryn Geiriog, Denbighshire. Of these, 507 coins (502 denarii and 5 antoninianii, ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander) are now in the British Museum. 3 further coins were reported in 1929, but the remaining 1s are lost.
800 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Valentinian I, Gratian, Theodosius I and Honorius.
In a bronze vessel, 1272 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I to Carinus (AD 283-284), also Gallic Empire coins from Postumus to Tetricus I and imitations; silver w8: 230.0-1588.9 g.
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.

According to the catalogue prepared by P. Fustier, the hoard comprised 280 denarii and 847 antoniniani (radiates). However, this total must be considered as approximate as Fustier identified numerous coins as being radiates of Plautilla, a combination that does not exist. The hoard was found by a quarry worker called Rodriquez. It was almost completely dispersed although the Musée de Roanne did acquire 4 denarii of Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla and Plautilla. Silver w8: 2064.9-4044.9g.
Unknown original number of nummi. Only 19 coins are documented: Constantius II - Gratian (AD 378-383).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. antoniniani recovered: 1 Gordian III, 3 Tranquilina (AD 238-241).
11 provincial bronze coins found in the barracks: Severus Alexander issued at the mints of Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 33 4th century nummi of the House of Constantine.
Unknown number of gold coins and jewelry: Severus Alexander - Claudius II (AD 2680270)? Together were found silver and gold jewelry, 1 gold diadem and 2 gold ingots.
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

The hoard comprised a jug containing an agglomeration of 1454 Roman coins found with a small ceramic vessel. Gallia states that 1458 coins were found, but only 1454 were detailed. TAF suggests that a further 4 unidentified coins could be added: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: c.248.3-1144.0g.
190 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 170 provincials: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 211-257

summary: About 13 lbs. (c. 5.8 kg) of Roman bronze coins. „Found in 1896 on the little islet of Perumamarakkaladuwa in the Madu Gaoga. Allegedly, the hoard contained gold and silver coins as well but n1 was ever seen. Based on the average w8s of the Roman coins he had examined himself, Still calculated a total of approximately 5800 coins. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissi1r, was able to secure some 250 pieces from this hoard. The list of identifiable coins is based on Still’s examination and description of these pieces.” The coin types are: House of Constantine I: gloria exercitus (1 standard); Constantine I (Divus) (quadriga); vot xx mult xxx; fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Theodosius: vot x mult xx; vot x mult xx; vot v; salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); concordia augg; urbs roma felix; gloria romanorum (3 emperors).
29 denarii: 28 republican, 1 imperial: Republic - Augustus (15-13 BC).
disposition: Collection unknown. About three quarters of the treasure was already melted down in 1870 by a goldsmith in Nordhorn.

summary: A poor record of a small hoard of continental cast bronze, purportedly found near Penzance in the late 9teenth century. The coins entered the British Museum from 2 different sources and Allen (1960a, 280) notes that the 2 groups are not necessarily from the same hoard. In the absence of any further information the record cannot be regarded as particularly reliable
127 silver coins: 86 denarii, 41 antoniniani: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 174.4-359 g.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).
HER record of "7 worn minims, presumably a hoard" found by a metal detectorist in Aston Clinton in 1993.
Group of 15 first and second century copper alloy coins metal-detected from the same field over a period of years between 1990 and 1998.
25 republican silver coins: 1 quadrigatus (225-31 BC).
12 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together surrounded by some organic remaines froma leather bag: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
The hoard comprises 17 asses from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 117-138).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver w8: c.812.3-7797.7g.

A hoard of 1074 AE. The coins were found in a broken pot during excavations by the University of Michigan in the filling of Room D (House 137) at floor level. The hoard comprised 2 Greek coins, 2 Roman provincial coins, 777 late Roman imperial coins, 112 barbarous imitations, and 181 cast imitations. The hoard was published twice: by Milne in 1926 and by Haatvedt et al. in 1964. The list given here follows Noeske 2000, pp. 260-270 (after Milne 1926).
disposition: Kelsey Museum, Ann Arbor (937 coins); Egypt (11 coins); unknown (126 coins)

summary: 27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

12 Iron Age coins were found on the Thames foreshore near Putney between October 2010 and December 2011. The location of the find suggests a link with the 'Putney Bridge Hoard' which appeared sporadically during the 1980s and 1990s. The coins are all so-called 'Flat Linear I potin'; a type of cast tin-bronze coin that appears to have been produced and used in northern Kent and close to the River Thames in Greater London during the late Iron Age. They can be dated to the late second century BC and early first century BC. (PAS).
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
36 bronze coins ranging from Augustus to Vespasian found in a grave.
disposition: Museum of Croatian Archaeological Monuments in Split

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 104 Iberian bronzes and provincial coinage of Hispania have been documented.
(250) 180 silver coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 314.1-710.9g.
disposition: Museum of Slavonia Osijek, Croatia (250 coins) - 1981

summary: 68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). W8: 156 g.

The hoard comprised a whiteware vessel containing approximately 2000 'small bronzes.' These are considered to have been antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus). The latest coins (E332334 and 336) were struck in Cologne in AD 263. Archives of Musée des Antiquités de Rouen: Inventory III, p. 78, no. 2316 (12.06.1912)
50 nummi: Maximinus II Daia - Constantine I (post 317)
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Ibiza y Formentera, Ibiza, Spain

summary: The hoard was found at the summit of Puy-de-Dôme amongst sherds of 1 or more ceramic vessels. It comprised approximately 800 bronze coins dating to the first century AD. Giard studied 212 coins, which equated to approximately 1 quarter of the hoard. These coins ranged in date from Augustus to Titus. The earliest coins was an as of Augustus (C. Asinius Gallus) struck in 14 BC. Numerous coins were counter-marked. TAF suggests that these were offerings (stips) to a mountain deity, which were later gathered together in a vessel.
The hoard comprised around 200 tetradrachms and 1000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of copper-alloy coins from Antoninus Pius to Septimius Severus.
Over 56 aurei and argenterei of the Tetrarchy found in a ceramic vessel; 22 coins of Diocletian and 10 argentei of Galerius were known (AD 305).
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
200 denarii, 36 recovered: Titus – Septimius Severus.
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)

About 250 coins (initially described as denarii) were found on the line of the Great Western Railway, somewhere between Bath and Bristol. 150 coins of Valens, Gratian, and Magnus Maximus are menti1d in NC 1840, p. 144. In 1910, Dr. (later Sir) Arthur Evans presented 35 siliquae "From a hoard found between Bath and Bristol 'many years ago'" to the British Museum. The account in NC of 150 coins "entirely" of Valens, Gratian and Magnus Maximus is at odds with the sample presented to BM.

10 coins (denarii and bronze coins, ranging from Galba to Trajan) found by private persons in a burnt layer, inside the Steinkastell in Nida. It is still not unequivocal, whether the discovered coins form a hoard.
The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL IV
summary: The Cologne origin of this set seems assured. Its affiliation to the hoard Maria im Kapitol can be presumed as very likely based on the characteristic composition.

The hoard comprised around 1500 silver coins (532 known). The known pieces belong to Trebonianus Gallus (518) and Volusianus (14). The coins had been acquired in Antakya and were said to be a local find.
126 nummi of the period of AD 378-423 found in a sewer of a Roman house part of the later Euphrasian Basilica.

HER record of a hoard of 548 coins excavated in 1991 in a badger sett by the Dean Archaeologial Group. 521 coins were dated AD 348-64. The badgers had burrowed under a wall thought to be of Roman date.

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised 8 to 9 kilos of coins. Magaud catalogued 2406 coins: 1 denarius, 2405 antoniniani (radiates) and in 1910, the abbot Angot added another 43 coins which Magaud incorporated into the hoard. The hoard was found by a farm labourer in a field: Maximian I Thrax - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 651.7-5724.2g.
631 Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan (Plotina) - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
5 silver units of the Iceni found in March 2006 .
Originally, a hoard of 400-500 denarii, only 40 allowed for examination: Republic - Augustus (15 BC).

A hoard of at least 98 antoniniani (the publication is not numbered, but states that the hoard is preserved in its entirety), found by a farmer on the site of ancient Aspledon, on the northern bank of the Copaïs Lake. Acquired by the art historian E. Basserman-Jordan (Munich).
4 Danubian tetradrachms and 4 Iron Age staters found in Portland in 1720. De Jersey considers it unlikely that the British coin was deposited with the Danubian tetradrachms.

All of the coins are of types produced in the Hampshire-Dorset-Wiltshire area in the late Iron Age. 5 (2012 T82b-f) are uninscribed gold staters of the so-called "Chute/Cheriton Transition" type (ABC 752). These coins date to about 80-60 BC. The 6th coin is an uninscribed silver stater of the "Cranborne Chase" type (ABC 2157); struck a little after the gold coins, in about 60-20 BC. 3 more coins found in 2015 and 2016 (PAS).
The hoard comprised 17 gold coins dated between the reigns of Valens and Anastasius.
642 BI radiates to AD 282. Addenda of 100 coins found in 2015.

According to Liger, the hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 62 coins of the Early Empire. However, according to Barbe, there were 15 coins discovered in the vessel including 1 of Claudius II. TAF notes that Liger of10 exaggerated his descriptions of hoards.
1545 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I (Constantine II Caesar) - Arcadius/Honorius (AD 395-423).
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
152 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217). Circumstances of find not known.
Around 300 coins, of which 103 are preserved: House of Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 402-408).
disposition: Asociación de Amigos de la Historia de Calahorra, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 48 coins from the Republic to Domitian (AD 90) as well as '2 rings.'

A hoard of 1290 nummi (aes 3), from the reign of Constantine I (AD 306-337) with the latest coins dating from AD 332-335, found near Bubendorf, in the forest in the vicinity of Castle Wildenstein. The coins were found in a pot and a piece of leather divided the coins into 2 parts.
A hoard of at least 29 solidi (Constantius II - Valens), found in the vicinity of Karanis in 1974. Most coins date to between 364 to 367.
disposition: Museum of Kom Ushim, Egypt; Photothèque of the French School at Athens (photos)

summary: A large hoard of 10 kilos of coins found with a ceramic lagoena. Only 161 pieces are available for study: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Instituto de Antropologia «Dr. Mendes Corrêa», Porto, Portugal

summary: 68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)

An assemblage of nummi of the House of Constantine spread in the upper and lower fills of a midden with second to third century pottery. Possibly a dispersed hoard. 3 coins found stacked together suggestive of a purse hoard.
The hoard comprised 2 ceramic vessels containing between 6000 and 7000 copper- alloy coins from Macrinus, Severus Alexander, Maximian, Gordian III and Philip I.
132 denarii: Republican through to Augustus C CAES AVG F. Notable for absence of legionary denarii
disposition: Museum of Municipium Bucharest, Romania (122 coins); Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania (10 coins)

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 10 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N 0056 /1-10/

summary: 93 siliquae (1 imitation) of Constantius II (AD 351-355).
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum, Ukraine (93 coins inv.nos. 53879-53971)

summary: Hoard of circa 100 denarii, only 4 coins are known: Republic 3, Augustus.
704 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 683 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 10 asses: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254).
1400-1500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 479 coins were available for study: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Carnac (in 1893, 460 coins); Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80315, 18 coins)

summary: Hoard of 518 denarii, (368 coins documented) found close to the Dacian settlement: Republic – Augustus (2 BC – AD 4): 503 denari, 1 coin Juba I, 14 imitations. The coins show traces of fire.
disposition: Municipal Museum, Bucharest, Romania ( the 14 imitations)

summary: 2 solidi of Theodosius I for Arcadius minted in Constantinople (AD 394-395).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga

summary: "interesting find of 3 gold Roman coins struck under Diocletian".
disposition: Sold in Prague via the director Ed. Bittner, now missing

summary: At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a 10nis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that 1 of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, n1 of which were recovered. 4 further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.

Coin Hoards records 39 denarii, ranging from Nero to Nerva. However, Carradice 'Coinage and Finances in the reign of Domitian AD 81-96', p. 173, no. 1 adds notice of 3 more coins, without further information.
1126 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 190 coins found with a pot: Gordian III - Carinus (AD 283-285).
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: 24 gold coins of Arcadius and Honorius; gold w8: 106.8 g.
167 coins of the 3rd-4th centuries AD well preserved. No further information.

The hoard comprised an urn containing 1200 coins, mostly thought to be dupondii ('moyens bronzes'), but with some asses ('petits bronzes') and denarii. The coins range from issues of Vespasian to Severus Alexander.
1243 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius from Caracalla to Valerian I.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, B (1) HOARD 3
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1) Hoard 3. 117 coins from Claudius II to House of Theodosius, with 47 of latter; & incl. 33 illegible 4th C. coins.
The circumstances of discovery are unknown, but may partially or totally be the result of excavation.
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers, 5th Register of entries, p. 188, no. 1088 (=12535)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
44 coins found in a grave in Lefkohori, Langada in 1970. The coins included 1 denarius (Marcus Aurelius) and 43 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa, Dium, Pella, Stobi, koinon of Macedonia).
9 siliquae: Constantius II - Gratian (AD 375-378); silver w8: 24.76 g.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: Originally, 1500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 3924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
The hoard comprised 28 nummi dated between AD 383-392 and AD 457-474.
A group of 19 siliquae coming from a private collection, possible found in Trier: Constantine III - Iovinus (AD 411-413).
Group of 5 nummi: Julian II - Jovian (AD 364).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia, inv.no. 18649-18651; private collection

summary: The hoard was found in the south-eastern corner of Ulpia Traiana, south of the city walls and close to the Roman port. It comprised 46 sestertii, denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 268.
Gold and silver coins found together with tableware, 2 gold bracelets and rings in a lead chest. At least 2 aurei of Philip and Gallienus. Gold: 2+ coins; Gold w8: 10.2g+;
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised a cooking pot containing 15 Tyrian Shekels dated between 38-10 BC.

The hoard comprised a glass bottle containining more than 146 denarii from Nero to Elagabalus. The glass bottle, which acted as the container for the hoard, is preserved by the Musée de Mans (Inv. V. 62)
Over 130 nummi of the 4th-5th centuries AD.
A hoard of 41 nummi (Constantine I - Arcadius, with some 5th century cross in wreath types), found in sector D (inv. 80D/89 and 80/D94) of Tell Atrib.
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.
Unknown initial number of coins. 1481 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 453-1933

summary: 5 solidi in hoard with spiral finger-ring, gold bracteate with Runic inscription, electron ingot.

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to 2 other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All 3 hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
The hoard comprised 72 bronze coins dated between 37-4 BC and AD 330-335.
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

Approximately 10000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: 76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: 4 aurei and jewelrey: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (sole) found with a copper vessel. Some of the objects were taken by the finder. According to the finder, Near the vessel was a st1 in a vertical position.
disposition: Institut d'Archéologie de Bucarest; Musée National d'Histoire de Bucarest; dispersed

summary: 2 solidi of Constantius II and Constantius III Gallus (Caesar) and a gold foils with a stamp from a solidus of Valentinian II were found in a vault.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (inv.no. 1820/8350837)

summary: A small flint filled with 11 Iron Age coins.
14 nummi found together: Constans - Theodosius II (AD 402-408).
3071 bronze coins: Hellenistic - Valentinian III (AD 455).
The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.
7 coins found in a m1y-box: 1 denarius, 1 plated denarius, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Nerva - Philip I (Marcia Otacilia Severa) (AD 246-247).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.nos. M 29)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: 7 aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, 4 treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by 3 treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

A hoard of 50-60 antoniniani, ranging from Gallienus to Maximian I, uncovered in 1961 at the construction of a garage. Further particulars about the find circumstances are unknown. Only 40 coins have been described.
400 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carus (AD 282-283).
disposition: Museo Civico di Legnago (16 coins); Museo Civico di Gallarate (239 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 160(?) silver shekels, 89 of which were published. These coins date between 258 BC and AD 68/69.
40 coins: 4 imitations of antoniniani (radiates), 36 nummi: Tetricus I - House of Theodosius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: 26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre d'entrée, II, p. 230, no. 12.428

summary: Group of 2 coins found with an urn: Maximinus I Thrax bronze, Gordian III antoninianus (radiate) (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked 1 on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least 5 pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
6 gold coins found in a grave during archaeological excavations: 1 solidus, 1 multiple of 1 1/2 solidus, 2 plated imitations of solidi, 1 blank: Constantine I and Constantius II (AD 347-355).
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 235 nummi: Constans/Constantius II - TheodosiusI/Arcadius.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 42664-42669: 5 pcs.

summary: 100 denarii found in a small ceramic vessel with traces of a textile bag. Coins of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna have been seen.

The hoard comprised originally ca. 2400 coins (2384 coins were menti1d in 1960), of which a small proportion has been lost. The coins were found in a copper-alloy vessel. 2 denarii and 2302 radiates (incl. 7 imitations) ranging from Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian have now been published. Tpq is AD 293.
3 denarii: Titus, Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 148-149); silver w8: 7.90 g.
3501 antoniniani: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard was found during the excavation of a villa and comprised 105 nummi dating to the 4th and fifth centuries AD.
Not a hoard but a collection of coins and artefacts found in a spring and stream bed. Not declared Treasure.
Before 1856, 5 nummi of Maximian Herculeus were found in Nantes and acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. This assemblage was interpreted as possibly a hoard or a purse loss.
33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: 1100 or 1000 coins found with a bronze vessel. and gold coins from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised more than 4000 Roman coins. This hoard is frequently confused with ÉTAPLES 1842
The hoard comprised 5 tetradrachms (Trajan-Caracalla) and 1 denarius (Faustina II).
100 provincial bronze coins found in a bronze vessel. 39 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12089 (39 coins)

summary: Hoard of 50 denarii: Republic - Tiberius. Only 3 denarii were available for study, based on a photo
68 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.

In 1960, a farmer found 36 Republican denarii while working in a field. In 1962, his plough hit and broke an already damaged ceramic vessel containing 424 denarii which were studied by Giard. A later article by Gambier gave details of a further 12 denarii (8 of which were not seen by Giard and 4 which were found later). A farmer, F. Joyeux found 36 Republican denarii in a field, close to the hamlet of Grande Bernegoue, approximately 80 metres from the marshland. 2 years later, his ploughshare broke an already damaged pottery vessel from which the coins came. The hoard was acquired by the Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale (Inventory no. 1981-347 = 453 coins of which 424 were studied by Giard with an extra 29 examples).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: 142 coins found with pot. 132 were studied: Republic – Honorius (AD 395-401).
The hoard comprised 8864 antoniniani (radiates) Valerian I - Carinus (tpq AD 283, Numerian). Silver w8: 1596.1-6470.3 g.
Found during excavations, at the border of the road south of Insula 18. 10 asses, of which 5 were halved.
The hoard was found during the excavation of a taberna in the forum and comprised 20 aurei from Nero to Nerva.
Sabina (wife of Hadrian) to Valens. 3 coins were pierced, 10 had suspension loops. Together were found fragments from a golden chain and small gold ingots
43 kg = +8000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)

“Possibly 200 (Roman bronze?) coins. Confirmation required. This information is only recorded by Weerakkody, based on personal information from Bopearachchi. The latter repeatedly mentions without detail, “several hundreds of unpublished Roman and Indo-Roman coins from Bentota, Kalutara and Negombo”.
The hoard comprised c. 40 nummi dating between the 4th and fifth centuries AD.
These 22 bronze coins, ranging from Augustus to Gratian, were reportedly discovered as a hoard in 1834 near Pödeldorf, yet the find arguably in no case involves a hoard.
40 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
Unknown originally number of coins: "a large quantity of Roman coins". Only 10 nummi of the first Tetrarchy.
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 66 g to 270.3g.
Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: The hoard comprises a small greyware vessel containing 12 denarii of 1 of the Faustinas.
116 nummi: Constantine - Constantius II (AD 341-346).

A hoard of 2821 nummi, found in a vessel in the remains of a late Roman building (a monastery?) in El Kab. 143 of these were imitations. Other coins were partly illegible (obverse: 1147; reverse: 92). Most of the coins date from the period AD 364-383, ending with coins of Gratian, ca. AD 370.

Hoard was found at a brickworks called Les Caves du Roi, between the road from Paris to Calais and Estrées and on the route of the trainline towards Berck. 3 sestertii were overstruck upon pieces of Antoninus Pius (1) and Marcus Aurelius (2). Together wuth These coins were found: a coin-die (!); a pickaxe (dolabra); a spearhead.
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to 2 greyware ceramic vessels.
Found during excavations (Fouille C [b/6], layer II), around st1s that probably were part of a dirt floor.
2 pierced Iron Age coins on a string of beads from an Anglo-Saxon grave dating to the 7th century AD (probably).
A find of 4 Late Roman nummi (and 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius), made in 1888 in Benstrup. Nothing further is known about the circumstances of this find.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 1200 Roman coins, which the finder distributed amongst his friends and acquaintances. Later investigation of the findspot recovered some pottery sherds and a certain number of coins that were identified by the Cabinet des Médailles, Paris by H. Huvelin.
The hoard comprised 40 nummi dated between AD 311/312 and AD 351-361.
175 denarii: Republic – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
294 found with a black coarse ceramic vessel: Republic – Gaius (AD 37).
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. 4nier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
1000 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms 'Acquired by Dattari, who sold it to Milne.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 50 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Nero (AD 55-56), found in a small jar in a corner of a room at floor level during excavations.
The hoard comprised silver denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 254.
258 nummi: Valentinian II - Zeno (AD 474-491). Found in the basilica.
The hoard comprised 3 asses of Tiberius. No evidence that they were part of a hoard.
Over 1000 denarii. Only 13 coins were described: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Faustina I Diva) (AD post AD 141).
47 solidi: Valentinian III – Anastasius (AD 491-518). Found with a gold ring.
62 provincial bronze coins, issues of the mints from Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
194 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of anamur, Turkey (coins); Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, France (moulds)

summary: The hoard comprised 1 dupondius of Nero and 5 quadrantes of Domitian dating to the period AD 66 to 96. The coins were found during the excavation of the archaeological park at the site of Colonia Ulpia Traiana. However, no further information is given regarding their findspot or circumstances of discovery.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry st1s. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised 2676 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Quietus, Postumus, Laelian, Victorinus, Marius, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius Gothicus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian I.

The hoard comprised 113 Roman silver coins of different sizes, bearing the portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Aemilian, Valerian I and Gallienus. Apparently, this list is not exhaustive. The hoard is probably 1 of antoniniani (radiates), although perhaps some denarii were present.
10 Valens coins were located on the mosaic floor.

The hoard was found under 2 st1s which formed a small niche and comprised some pottery vessels and a wooden box containing approximately 150 (or 340) scyphate bronzes and a dupondius of Titus. The Continental Iron Age coins are of 2 module sizes (12-13mm and 14/15mm), with the bigger coins depicting a horse's head. the smaller a horse surrounded by rouelles and an S. On the reverse of both types were branches and foliage. This description suggests the coins are anepigraphic staters attributed to the Suessi1s.

4th century. 8 coins of AD 310-317, an unusual group Reece considers to be a small hoard, &/or from a purse. The Snow's Farm/HAD III shrine complex was an octagonal shrine within a sub-square enclosure, built on top of a BA round barrow. Investigated by Bromwich in 1950s, then fully excav. in 1983. Evans and Hodder2006, pp. 352-363. Coin report by Reece.
89 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).
30 coins of Constans (FEL TEMP REPARATIO) were found rolled together on a surface strewn with brick.
The hoard comprised 192 coins of the first century AD, the majority of which date to the First Jewish Revolt.
30 provincial bronze coins minted in the 3rd century AD found by metal detecting within the area of an ancient settlement.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded 3 hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All 3, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken A contains 157 of the 217 denarii.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 03 comprises 141 coins: Iron Age, Roman Republican and Roman Imperial.

Roman bronze hoard found in a pot, no numbers menti1d. 6 coins were given to the Historisches Museum Solothurn, 3 of them are still preserved today (Kantonsarchäologie Solothurn). 1 Tiberius, 1 Gaius, 1st/2nd cent. (1 coin), 1 Nero and 2 Vespasian.

There are conventionally thought to have been at least 3 separate finds of Iron Age coinage at South Ferriby, on the south bank of the Humber, in the first decade of the twentieth century. 2 of them are described in some detail by Roth, and the third is included by Allen in his Sylloge volume on the Coritani and in a short paper for Hull Museum. In total almost 170 coins can still be securely associated with this find (de Jersey, no. 172).

At least 2 gold coins of Augustus discovered between 1830 and 1838 were included by the FMRD as single finds. The same findspot, the similar date of finding, and the ambiguity of the first source mentioning "a quantity of coins" suggest that these gold coins may have been part of a hoard.
339 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).

Hoard of 1 silver coin and 21 Aes coins: 1 denarius (Domitian), 13 Asses (1 Lugdunum I, 1 Divus Augustus PROVIDENT, 6 Flavian, 4 Nerva, 1 Trajan); 6 dupondii (3 Flavian, 1 Nerva, 2 Trajan); 2 sestertii (Titus and Trajan).
8 prutot of years 2(7 coins) and 3 (1 coin) of the First Jewish Revolt.
(1430) 976 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Found together with silverware and jewelry.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (976 coins)

summary: In 1912 a find of 36 denarii in a pot was made by workers during excavations for the construction of a Tietz department store on Hohen street, between Schildergasse in the north and Cäcilienstraße in the south.
