It was acquired by J. Hagen from art-dealing for the museum of Bonn, from where it was delivered to the Roman-Germanic museum of Cologne in 1942. Found with a ceramic cooking pot.

Between December 1988 and January 1989 a third deposit (Hoard III) was located about 500 m to the south-west. This deposit consisted of 7 Iron Age staters (2 Gallo-Belgic E and 5 Chute). –– Probably part of the same deposit as hoards I and II.

A letter in the British Museum from M. Foreman of Kingston-Upon-Hull Museum in 2000 reads "We have 9 other 4th to 5th century coins listed as an 'Ulrome Hoard. These are not the same as the 9 coins from a cliff-fall" (ie hoard 2426). In fact, from the details given there would appear to be 26 coins (under 9 headings) ie those menti1d as being found before 1961 in correspondence in the file.

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.

ca. 40-50 solidi (40 of which listed by emperor), silver coins (the coins were badly preserved, and some might have been bronze coins), 2 gold rings' gold bracelet and a silver ingot (?) found in 1781 while cleaning a ditch.
IARCH record for a hoard of 5 "Chute" or "British B" type staters.

A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install ph1 cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.
disposition: Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, Monnaies et Médailles, Lausanne

summary: The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.
Grave goods: aurei of Elagabalus, 2 denarii Augustus, 2 drachms Gotarzes.

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).

302 nummi and 1 gold finger ring discovered inside an earthenware container near a steam on Bodlywydd-uchaf farm. Most of the coins were observed to be of Constantine and his sons, including a number of GLORIA EXERCITVS and city commemorative types, but the majority of the hoard was dispersed by the finder soon after its discovery. In light of this, it cannot be known whether the opening and closing dates given for this hoard are correct. 2 further nummi were found in the same area by metal detectorists in 1987.
113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.
225 nummi of the Tetrarchy found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 pieces have been recovered (AD 305-37).
136 large imperial bronzes (sestertii?), well-preserved: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
c. 400 of antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Town museum, Oudenaarde, Belgium (some coins and the vessel); collection C.A. Serrure, in 1861

summary: Hoard 141 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). W8: 484.16g.

A small hoard of 6 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about 2 years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in 2 years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as 1 deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
Silver: (c.3500) 1100 silver coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: c.4377.3-12562.7 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (3 coins); Collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (147 coins)

summary: 1 Republican denarius, 1 Augustan denarius, 16 Imperial AE found in regio VI, insula 16, building 32 (house and thermopolium)

Deposit of 3 clipped siliquae. An important number of clavi caligarii, i.e. iron hobnails, were also found in their immediate vicinity. This discovery is probably the first material evidence in a military context of the famous invasion of Hispania by the usurper ‘Constantinus III’.

46 (or 47?) sestertii ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius (or Mariniani, AD 253-260?), from a hoard found in Scarminga in the west of the Peloponnese (at Skarmingas, Pylia, near Maniaki according to Touratsoglou).
A small hoard of Cunobelin staters, apparently found near Westerham in 2002.
114 nummi found by chance: Constantine II - Gratian (AD 367-383).
Hoard of 207 denarii, 89 identified. From Vespasian to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Bought by a dealer in Belgrade; dispersed

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 7 coins are known: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver w8: 3.1-7.8 gr.
A hoard of 2 solidi of the emperor Valens (364-378), found by a metal detectorist on agricultural land in the municipality of Buren (province of Gelderland).

The hoard was found during construction work. The coins were covered by a small pot (smashed and lost). The coins were first dispersed, but later retrieved, and the assemblage is now probably close to complete. The hoard comprised 49 denarii ranging from the Republic to Vespanian (AD 70), including 1 denarius of Juba (SNG Cop 523), 32 denarii and 1 quinarius of the Roman Republic, and 15 denarii of the Roman Empire, Augustus (9), Claudius (1), Nero (1), Otho (1), Vespasian (3). 2 additional coins were discovered close by after the initial hoard was found (1 as of Vespasian, and 1 sestertius of Marcus Aurelius). These were not part of the hoard.
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver w8: 1463.8-3029.0 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during main10ance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique st1 floor.
unknown initial number of coins. 154 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2447-2561 (154 coins) - stolen

summary: Hoard of 140 Naimana imitations and 1 Roman coin - nummus (AE4) (AD 380-470) was found at a Buddhist site (Gal Vihara).

A hoard of 5+ Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica: 1; Amphipolis: 4, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus), found in a grave in Amphipolis (Grave 1) in 1953. Archives in the Ephorate mention 18 further coins, but these could not be traced any more.

IARCH record for a fused hoard of coins and jewellery found in Colchester during excavations by Colchester Archaeological Trust. Full details are not yet available due to ongoing conservation work. The latest coins fully identified are denarii of Augustus but the hoard contains copper alloy coins thought to be Claudian in date.N. Crummy writes: "The objects consist of gold and silver bracelets, a silver chain, gold finger-rings, gold and pearl earrings, a lidded wooden box covered with thin silver sheet and set on ivory legs, a copper-alloy pendant, a glass intaglio, and about 22 silver and 3-4 copper-alloy coins (precise number still uncertain). Some of the objects had been in the box when buried, and most of the coins had been buried in a leather or cloth bag or purse. 2 iron nail fragments found with the objects may be residual or associated in some way with the scooping out of the hole." (Unpublished cor1r's report by N. Crummy 2014 T577)
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
12 siliquae of Valentinian I, Gratian and Theodosius I.; silver w8: c. 24.0 g. Found together with jewelry: 2 bracelets, 2 ear-rings, 1 ring.

21 bronze coins,found with 2 pebbles and a bronze ring in the fill of the outer fort ditch. Found concreted together and later separated, probably a purse hoard although no traces of a container survived.
330 bronze nummi to AD 356 in a pot. Multiple addenda: 15 nummi (1994-5); 54 nummi (1996-2003); 4 nummi (2006 T8).
615 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 185.4-767.8g.

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.

The hoard comprised a broken vessel containing more than 850 radiates (the total is estimated at approximately 1000 coins). The hoard was buried in a cemetery, not far from the village. The hoard was discovered by chance.
214 AV and AR Republican and Imperial issues found in regio VI, insula 17, building 42 (house).

The hoard comprised 64 'bronze' coins from Caracalla to Gallienus. The denominational composition of the hoard is not given. It was found in the South Stoa. In front of shop XX was a strosis covered with a thick layer of burned debris. In this charred stratum, within the storeroom, were found the iron fittings of a m1y box containing the hoard.
The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
48 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) (AD 138-161).
disposition: History and Art Museum, Bacău, Romania

summary: 300 denarii. Only 32 recorded: Republican - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal (11 coins)

summary: (110) 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - ValerianI-Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 137.5-160.6 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 161-176 (15 coins)

summary: Unknown number of solidi. 3 solidi of Valentinian I, Valens, Arcadius, tpq c. 400; gold w8: 13.35g

Record of 3 silver coins found in a garden (or possibly 1 (of Trajan) found in the garden and the others nearby). Referred to by Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1820 in record for another hoard, see IARCH-DFE96C.
106 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 63 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

The hoard comprised approximately 60 Republican denarii The coins were stolen and presumably melted down soon after their discovery according to Madame Malva Vincent, Director of Excavations at Portus Magnus.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing 110 Iron Age gold coins which were sold or dispersed.

The hoard was found in a sandst1 or earthenware vessel hidden in a wall and covered by a large st1. It comprised 19 kg of corroded silver, billon and bronze coins, equating to approximately 3600 coins. No certainty, that the latest coins belong to Postumus.
116 sestertii: 106 Viminacium, 10 Provincia Dacia: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253)
disposition: Museum of Sremska Mitrovica, Serbia (117 coins) - 1966

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
Hoard of 44 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-252).
45 nummi found in a garden: Licinius I - House of Constantine (AD 340).
The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
24 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius, 6 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 12 asses: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) – Florian (AD 276)

In 1844, numerous skeletons were found, buried 1 on top of the other. 1 wearing an iron mail shirt, also possessed 'un coeur en bronze doré', 17 denarii and 4 bronze coins. Like TAF V. 33, the assemblage has been interpreted as representing the savings of a soldier killed in the battle between Septimius Severus and Clodius Albinus in AD 197.
A potful of Roman silver coins. Only 5 coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.
38 silver coins ranking from Trajan to Valentinian (AD 364-375); silver w8: 61.5-118.2g.
21 coins discovered within the ruins of a Roman settlement. 11 pieces in the museum of Targovishte: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a 15th century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver w8: 31.5-140.3g.
4 Iron Age silver units. Addenda of 3 units 2012.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing '60 Roman coins of the 3rd and 4th century AD'. Found together with another ceramic vessel decorated and bearing the inscription ASSVTA.

A hoard of 19 provincial coins, found in grave T7 in the roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. pl. 18-19. They comprised 3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, 15 coins of Amphipolis from the Anto9 period and 1 that remains to be identified.

1051 radiates of the later third century (Valerian to Tetricus I) found at a quarry. According to Lee (1862), the coins were in a "covered pot or pan of common black ware which was unfortunately broken."
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)
over 13 kg, c. 6000 siliquae: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 367-383); silver w8: + 13 kg
disposition: Largely dispersed; 39 siliquae in the Coin Room of the Library of the Romanian Academy

summary: 22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: 697 bronze coins were found in 1927 during preparation for a road leading to a quarry in the Gemeindewald, at Leubrücke between Faha and Wei10. The coins were lost during the war, but their inventory was kept, so that 688 coins could be identified. They range from Galba to Septimius Severus (Julia Domna).
The hoard comprised 'more than 8100 antoniniani (radiates), weighing approximately 30 kilos: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (172 coins; Inv. II nos. 606 and 680), France

summary: 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation.
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
32 or 42 solidi of Theodosius I or Theodosius II.

The finders show to Abbe Moreau c. 6700 antoniniani (radiates). The workers discovered the hoard in 3 vessels and shared the coins. V. Huguenot studied few coins of this hoard, from Antoninus Pius (probably Elagabalus) to Postumus (AD 260-269).

A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the 4 coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier 1s appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, w8 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
The hoard comprised a huge number of Roman billon coins (radiates). It was noted that the composition of the hoard was almost identical to that found on Rue Beauvoisine (TAF IV. 61).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France (36 coins). Inv.no: II, p. 79, no. 845-6 (1853)

summary: (c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).

In 1873 a hoard was found during peat digging in the Burgau moss. It comprised 7 bronze jars, 3 golden rings, and 40 coins, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins except 1 were antoniniani. This was probably not the entirety of the hoard.
40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 34 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: A hoard of 26 provincial bronze coins (Cnossos, Koinon of Crete) found in Agios Nikolaos, ranging from Claudius to Hadrian. The first report of the hoard menti1d approx. 30 coins of the Koinon of Crete struck under Trajan.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 18 comprises 180 silver Iron Age coins and 3 Roman denarii.

About 800 denarii (Mark Antony to Caracalla) and fragments of a possible ceramic container found by workmen digging a ditch near Bron-y-Berllan farm. The original size of the find is uncertain; Davies (1929) records that the workmen who made the find pocketed an unknown number of coins, and that the remainder of the hoard was split between the British Museum (18 coins) and the Verney family of Bodelwyddan Castle, Anglesey. The size and condition of the hoard cannot be accounted for until 1918, when only 333 coins were transferred from Bodelwyddan to the Bangor museum. Robertson's examinations of the hoard in 1937 and 1948 identified 350 coins split between Bangor and the British Museum; the whereabouts of the remainder are unknown.
disposition: Storiel Museum, Bangor (c. 300 coins); British Museum (18 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised between 450 and 500 coins of which only 46 were identified. The coins come from the mints of Rome and Cologne. Found during building work during the German occupation of 1914-1917. The hoard was found a couple of 100 meters from the hoard at Noyelles-Godault (TAF II.57) Silver: 450-500 (45, 1) coins; Silver w8: 129.2-592.8 g.
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
(c. 60) 27 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 71).
disposition: Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova (21 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania (6 coins, inv.no. 742/1945)

summary: (150) 109 coins: 18 denarii, 19 antoniniani, 2 sestertii, 70 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 42.3-83.4 g.
disposition: History Museum, Kazanlak, Bulgaria (20 coins); Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1566-1672 (106 coins)

summary: Found during construction work, supervised by archaeologists. Among other coins ca. 30 poorly preserved radiates, probably a purse (?), mainly imitations of the Gallic Empire (Tetricus I), plus 1 Divo Claudio II (altar, cf. RIC V.1, p. 233, no 261 (bust K).
17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 5.6-20.3g.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 5 pieces were examined: Caracalla - Elagabalus.

c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
Hoard of 187 coins, antoniniani and nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (AD 379-395).

The hoard was concealed in a hollow flint nodule and comprised 26 coins. Found by a roadworker. The coins were melted down with the exception of the 1 half-stater and the bronze which passed into the Loustau Collection in 1884.
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).

Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.
Hoard of 17 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37) found by metal detecting in a lump of an earth.
Apparently a large hoard of Iron Age potin coins, of which only the 4 coins in the British Museum are preserved.
Ca. 600 potin coins found digging a trench in a garden, in 1853, apparently packed in a box shaped receptacle. The bulk of the hoard - at least 509 coins - remained at Quex.
99 nummi recovered from the sea: tpq AD 313.
88 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
380 nummi: Quintillus - Gratian (AD 367-383).

Found by chance while removing st1s in a slope, close to a large st1 ca. 40-50 cm deep ("kaum 1 1/2 Fuss in der Erde"); Hoard of 81 coins and other objects: 2 bronze bells, 2 bowls, silver fibula, silver bracelet, and a blue glass perl. The coins and the jewellery were placed in a large bronze bowl, together with a smaller bowl containing the 2 bronze bells. Coins: 1 aureus, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I. (rv. PVELLAE FAVSTINIANAE = RIC III, p. 74-75, no 397-398), and 80 silver denarii: Otho (2), Vespasian (3), Domitian (7), Trajan (12), Hadrian (12), Hadrian for Sabina (1), Antoninus Pius (21), for (Diva?) Faustina I. (5), Marcus Aurelius (11), for (Diva?) Faustina II. (2), Commodus (1), Septimius Severus (3). - Half the hoard got into private hands (Bregenz), the other half was sold to England.
Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised a block of billon coins, many of which had been cut in half or into quarters. Most of the coins were issues from Nîmes, 4 Continental Iron Age coins, 2 small bronzes, 1 of Tiberius and 1 of Constantine (sic) and 2 dupondii of Claudius I and Titus. TAF suggests that the hoard is a votive deposit.
1 radiate and 19 nummi to AD 317-324.
98 coins: antoniniani (radiates), argentei, siliquae, nummi: Claudius II - Julian II AD 361-363); silver w8: c.197.2-312.4 g.
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: A hoard of 40 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB, VB/C, VC and VI), found among brocken crockery on the floor of the kitchen of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by 7 treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the 7 treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of 1 of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

In approximately 1834, Benjamin Bréchard de Fon10ay acquired 100 radiate copies of Tetricus I in mint condition along with some pieces of Constantine I and Constans, found in Château-d'Olonne. Are the coins of Constantine I and Costans part of the same hoard?

11 antoniniani (radiates) found with a small ceramic vessel in a well: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). The hoard was found together with a brooch and/or a Gold ring (according to Dembski).

"In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including 1 of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. 2 of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
(209) 176 nummi: Constantius I - Theodosius I (AD 388-395).
disposition: Coin Room, National Museum, Belgarde, Serbia; Inv. no. 566

summary: 12 nummi: House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402). Found near a fireplace in a Roman house.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel covered with a copper-alloy plate and comprised approximately 10000 radiates of Tetricus I, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus. Only 18 coins were preserved.

The hoard, considered to be the con10ts of a purse comprised 17 'AE3 and 4's of the House of Constantine with a tpq of AD 337 to 341. The deposit was found during the excavation of Burial 16 in the Gallo-Roman necropolis.
513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: 271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).
Unknown original number of coins. Thre is some scarce information on 23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
1700 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
74 coins: 1 antoninianus, 73 nummi: Gallienus - Honorius (AD 395-423).

More than 100 bronze coins have been found. 68 were seen: Commodus - Gordian III - minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum 35, Marcianopolis 27, Hadrianopolis 3, Anchialus 2, Serdica. 19 are kept in the museum collection in Lyaskovets.
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), 2 unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".
403 antoniniani (radiates) and 34 imitations: Valerian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
8 coins found inside a sarcophagus: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
2 solidi: Julius Nepos, Romulus Augustulus; gold w8: 8.84 g. Found in same field at different times.
45 bronze coins - antoniniani (radiates) and nummi - presumably found together south of the Ritona temple.
20 nummi found together: Constans - Theodosius I (AD 388-393). Possible a purse/pocket-m1y
Circa 700 nummi of Maxentius and other contemporary emperors.
73 nummi of Constantine I and his sons found in the bath-house complex. A hypothetic tpq of AD 335.
268 'copper coins' from the end of the 3rd century AD to the House of Valentinian. Most of the coins belong to the House of Constantine.
More than 500 nummi found in a Roman building. Only 179 were recovered: Costantius II - Gratianus (AD 375-383).
disposition: Historische Museum der Stadt Wien, Austria

summary: 1545 coins: 1 denarius, 1544 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Tetricus I (AD 271-273).
The hoard comprised 9 Republican denarii and a denarius of Augustus dating to AD 14. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 3.7g and 11.5g.
24 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1676-1699 (24 coins)

summary: 102 silver coins spilled across the floor of the room in 1 of the rooms in the principia of the legionary fort at Viminacium
(1616) 971 bronze: 2 antoniniani, 1 plated denarius, 1 as, 1 imitation, 966 nummi: Trajan - Arcadius (AD 388-393)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie, Etnografie și Artă Plastică, Lugoj, Romania

summary: The hoard of 79 denarii (1 Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and 1 Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
The hoard comprised 10 silver Iron Age coins. The coins passed into the Lecomte Collection without being described, but BN 4460 coins could come from this deposit.
The hoard comprised 4 Republican denarii.
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 25 heavily worn denarii of the Roman Republic (140-42 BC) and 2 aurei (Tiberius and Nero).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 solidi of Honorius are known; gold w8: 13.35g.
5 Iron Age gold coins, found between 2005 and 2016
38 nummi ending with a coin of Honorius (AD 393-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 23 gold coins were recovered: 16 solidi, 7 Aksumite gold coins: Constantius II - Kaleb (AD 510-530). No details if the hoard was found in a container, and have no information about any archaeological context.

Hoard of 170 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: Thassian tetradrachm, Thassian tetradrachm imitations 39, republican denarii 124, 2 denarius imitations, and imperial denarii 4: C. Renius - Augustus (29-27 BC).
The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
133 nummi: House of Constantine - Valens (AD 364-378). Unpublished.
disposition: Coin Room, Museum of National History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.

The coins were found amongst fragments of ceramic building material (brick). As coins were very rare finds on this site, it is likely that they represent a small purse hoard or a portion of a larger deposit. 7 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 4.2-15.9g.
108 antoniniani radiates: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museo Archeologico del Territorio di Farini, Gropallo, Italy

summary: 28 solidi of Honorius and Arcadius (AD 402-408); gold w8: 124.6g.
1333 silver coins from Vespasian to Gordian III (AD 238-244). No description of coins.
disposition: Biblioteca Academiei, Cabinetul Numismatic, Bucharest, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
42 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 6 dupondii, 35 asses: Augustus - Trajan (AD 98-99).
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.
3 coins which were described as "virtual surface finds" in a ploughed field, within 35 feet (11 m) of 1 another.
762 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in underground room H during excavations of a house.

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).
61 bronze coins minted in Tyras found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Severus alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 111 nummi from Diocletian to Constantine I and Licinius I with a tpq of AD 309. All coins came from the mints of Trier or London but unfortunately, TAF does not elaborate on the mint distribution by emperor.
A hoard of Roman aurei and denarii as well as punch-marked coins. This is the only hoard from India which definitely contained coins of 2 metals. Some of denari are broken.
The hoard comprised 84 tetradrachms dated between AD 211-217/8.
Group of 6 denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
62 coins: 2 denarii, 1 dupondius, 59 asses: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-54).
32 antoniniani ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: The hoard comprised 132 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 12 coins from Volusian to Salonina, found together in a single mass.
11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-246).
Hoard of 1500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found in several amphoras: Clodius Albinus - Gallienus (AD 260-268). Found together with a gold chain.
460 coins: 444 solidi, 16 imitation siliquae: Constantine I - Constantine III (AD 407-411). Found with a ceramic vessel.
The hoard comprised 15 nummi dated between AD 355-360 and AD 450-550.
IARCH record for a hoard of 33 copper alloy nummi of the House of Constantine. For full details and images see WMID-778A93.
52 nummi: Constans - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

Hoard(?) of a very diverse composition: Greek coins, billon provincial coins of Alexandria, imperial denarii, nummi. Reported to have been found in a dining set during ploughing. Most likely a private collection.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12359/1-36 (36 coins)

summary: 235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).

At least 2 British O quarter staters, found about 3 metres apart. A stater, described as bearing a "disjointed horse", was found about 400 m distant in 1996, but is unlikely to have been associated with the quarters .
(+200) 126 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 38.8-156.5 g.
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
8 aurei, all found "within a few meters of each other, indicating a coin purse was likely dropped to the ground in the course of fighting, or in10tionally hidden."

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 600 coins, apparently antoniniani (radiates). A further 9 coins were recovered from the bed of a small stream that ran into the pond. These coins were of the same emperors as those contained in the hoard.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1100 and 1500 silver and bronze coins, weighing 2.5kg. Desjobert who saw a small number of the coins, detailed that the coins included issues of Caracalla, Plautilla, Severus Alexander to Claudius II. When the hoard was dispersed, Drouet bought 27 radiates for the Musée du Mans including 7 Gallienus, 4 Claudius II, 4 Postumus, 3 Victorinus The hoard was found by a worker cleaning a fountain.

The Bjørnebanke Hoard consists of 3 solidi and the remains of large Late Roman silver platter cut to minute pieces. A 4th solidus found in the same general area in the 19th century may belong to the same deposition
ca. 50 antoniniani (radiates), but only 28 coins are identified: Valerian I - Quintillus (AD 270).

In 1821 an urn with approx. 600 bronze coins (Licinius - Gratian) was found in Gu10brunnen. The coins were lost, but 305 coins that entered the museum of Speyer with find place 'Wörschweiler Klosterberg' certainly belonged to the same find. 291 of these could be found in the Speyer museum and are listed in FMRD.
80 bronze coins of the Late Empire, presumably nummi.
55 coins: 4 gold medallions, 5 aurei and 46 silver coins: Only 17 coins are studied: 4 medallions, 5 aurei, 8 argentei: Numerianus - Constantius I (AD 294).
disposition: National Hungarian Museum (Inv.no. 104.1885 - gold pieces only), Budapest, Hungary; private collections F. Trau (Vienna) and A. Bachofen von Echt (Nussdorf, Vienna)

summary: 12 bronze coins found stuck together, in a barrow: 5 dupondii, 7 asses: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: National History and Archaeology Museum, Constanța, Romania (inv.nos. 81602-81613)

summary: 6000 nummi found with ceramic vessel: Diocletian and Constantius I (Caesar) (AD 295-305). 3000 coins were minted in Ticinum, 6 in Alexandria.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 'close to 24' Roman coins, which were not further described. It is possible that 'close to 80' coins were actually found and that the numbers 'vingt-quatre' and 'quatre-vingt' were transposed.
Hoard of 7 siliquae and iron key found in build- up behind Roman Fort rampart during archaeological excavation, not found to be treasure trove.
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest 1 is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

A hoard containing 1 gold finger–ring, 2 solidi of Valentinian II and Honorius and 1091 siliquae of emperors from Constantius II to Honorius in a field between September 1991 and 1993. The coins were found widely scattered over a 15–acre field, mostly about 3 inches below ground level. Many of the coins were clipped and the date of deposition is thus not likely to have been before c. AD 410.
2 solidi: Theodosius I, Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388). The Theodosius I solidus is mounted. The coins were found in different years (1922 – Theodosius I; 1904 – Magnus Maximus) at the same spot.
disposition: National museum, Prague, Prehistoric Collection (inv.no. H1-42.629); Town museum, Nový Bydžo, Czech Republic (inv.no. N 1268)

summary: 10 bronze coins dating from the end of the 1st c. AD (Trajan?), found in a grave inside Tumulus 3D near Potamoi.
The hoard comprised 43 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus. It was found in the same area as Oštra Luka II.
(Circa 20) 17 silver coins: Elagabalus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1832 1-17

summary: 109 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus (Saloninus Caesar) - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).

Listed on the website of the Penrith and Eden Museum (accessed 10.10.2014): "Roman and Romano-Alexandrian coins found in the vicinity of Low Borrow Bridge Roman Fort near Tebay, Cumbria.The coins were recently donated to Penrith Museum by the great granddaughter of James Day, who was a Railway Engineer on the stretch of the Lancaster to Carlisle Railway, which runs through the upper Lune Gorge and over Shap Fell.They were found by workmen operating in the area adjacent to the Roman Fort at Low Borrow Bridge.The coins consist of 4teen Constantinian issues of the AD 330s, which, because of the homogeneity of the wear and general condition almost certainly constitute the whole or part of a savings-hoard; the remainder are all aes-issues from the mint at Rome or the city-mint at Alexandria. Some of these may safely be regarded as casual losses of the Roman period."
The hoard comprised between 31 and 34 bronze coins primarily dating to the mid-4th century AD. It was found deposited in a pit close to a water feature (possibly a latrine) within a Roman fort.

A hoard of 7 as from a grave. Cemetery, mainly inhumations, from Late Iron Age (from LT C) to Roman times. Tomb 422: 7 coins, Augustus, all minted in Rome. - Tomb described as "Ensemble problématique du point de vue de la documentation".
The hoard comprised 280 Roman coins - antoniniani (radiates) and nummi - of Trebonian Gallus, Postumus, Claudius II, Tetricus, Aurelian, Probus, Galerius and Constantine (?) in a vessel.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. Y. Youroukova examined 9 pieces: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.
58 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: 107.3-170.0g

Unknown number of coins. Few coins are mention in the collection of Reydet de la Vulpillière, which indicate a large diversity of coins, denarii, antoninaini, sestertii, from Republic to Tacitus (AD 276)

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In 1 corner of the room, there were 4 coins, including 1 of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.
The hoard comprised more than 36000 coins, probably all antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
1293 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms confiscated by the police from a gold and silversmith in the town. Together with 8 silver bracelets and 2 silver ingots
disposition: "the Alexandria Museum and partly to the Salle de Vente."

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1200 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Aurelian. 2 catalogues exist for 181 and 178 of the coins respectively. They do not match. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 325g and 1499g.
78 sestertii including 2 imitations, Vespasian to Commodus with 1 Severus Alexander
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
Circa 2000 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
± 1500 nummi: Constantine I - Honorius (AD 395-423).
Hoard of 1000 coins, only 20 nummi survived: Constantine I 1, Crispus 19.
The hoard comprised 54 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus with a FELICITAS AVGVSTI reverse type. The hoard was found 20 meters from the deposit found in 1865 at Fontaine Saint-Aubin.
The hoard comprised 654 coins of which a total of 444 were recorded. These included 442 denarii from the Republic to Severus Alexander and 2 antoniniani of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
5 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius and 72 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Aurelian (AD 270-275) found with a bronze vessel.
276 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver w8: 387.6-713.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (3 coins); May 1967, 273 coins and the vessel

summary: The hoard comprised 13 Theodosian nummi with a tpq of AD 395 to 402.
The hoard comprised 7 gold coins
Unknown number of denarii found in a ceramic vessel. 214 pieces entered museum collection in Shumen: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 213

summary: The hoard was found in a burial of the Late Empire and comprised a purse containing 25 nummi of Licinius, Crispus, Constantius II, Valentinian I, Valens and Valentinian II.
38 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 37 nummi: Antoninus Pius - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: ROB, Amersfoort > Historical and Archaeological Foundation (H.A.S.)ROB, Amersfoort

summary: There is debate over the number of coins found. Jennepin states the total as being 100; Bernier 300: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: c.41.5-186.5g.
3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver w8: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: Outside of Room 7 in House XI, to the east a hoard of some 250 minimi was found. The present hoard may perhaps be dated with some certainty to the period AD 370-450.
Unknown initial number of coins. 70 pieces are kept in the museum of Lovech: 12 denarii, 29 antoniniani, 29 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1675-1676

summary: 81 provincial bronze coins discovered in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17 096-17 176

summary: The hoard was found in an earthen pot in the forest. It comprised 33 denarii from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-236). Only 29 are now recorded.
Unknown originally number of coins. 40 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
2 solidi: Theodosius II, Zeno (AD 476-491). With a frame of twisted gold- thread in a loop, ornamented by filigree-work.

Among the 162 coins listed for Lehmbach in FMRD, 150 (Gallienus - Gratian) come from an excavation made in 1957 and look like a hoard, even if they were not reported as such at the time. They were found below a medieval layer. Lemberg was located on a Roman road.

Hoard of 651 coins found in several ceramic vessels and a textile cloth. 570 coins were studied: 16 denarii, 96 antoniniani (radiates), 458 bronzes: Galba - Postumus (AD 263); silver w8: 134.0-1792.9g. 1 of the Postumus double sestertius is overstruck on a Marcus Aurelius sestertius of the type VICTORIAE AVG S C.
Hoard consisting of 29 solidi and 1 silver-mixed gold ingot (w. 299.73 g), found 1882 as a small stack below a side st1 in a st1 age dolmen. 5 coins pierced. Included imitations as well.

A concentration of 23 later Roman coins (Constantine I - Constantius II) found during excavations made before the construction of a new Merkur store Am Spielhof. These coins were viewed as a small collective find.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 40 'middle bronzes' of the 4th and fifth centuries AD.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded 3 hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All 3, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains 7 of the 217 denarii.
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 162 provincial coins of Athens (period V and VI), 1 sestertius (Trebonianus Gallus) and 34 antoniniani (Valerianus - Gallienus), found in a cave in the hills between Porto Rafti and Brauron.

2 aurei of Vespasian (AD 69-79) and an aureus of Domitian (81-96). Uncertain whether they were found together. However, the chronological segment, the close vicinity of findspots and the absence of any other Roman artefact found in this area may suggest a hoard.
Aurei found in a Germanic princess grave. 3 of the coins, pierced, where part of a necklace: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius(2). 1 in the mouth: Gallienus. Rich funerary inventory.
disposition: Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens, Weimar, Germany (inv. nos. 16-19)

summary: A hoard comprising 3 bronze coins of Augustus and Tiberius next to metal scraps (?) (Metalhortfund), found in the north wing of the Roman villa rustica at the location of Alt-Inden (act. Tagebau Inden).

A hoard of 208 gold coins (mostly solidi), found on the Menzeler Heide in an earthenware vessel. The coins were dispersed, but a list of them was made. Coins range from the late Republic to the early 5th c., with the majority belonging to the 4th c.
33 coins - 5 antoniniani (radiates), 28 nummi - found together leaning against the wall: Gallienus (sole) - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museo Monográfico de Itálica, Santiponce, Spain

summary: Found during excavations in the Roman villa rustica of Hüttwilen-Stutheien, in the north-western corner of room VIII. A group of 5 coins, 2 sestertii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 3 antoniniani (Gordian III). Possibly a purse.

(1982) 1981 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 300-301); silver w8: 267.6-1850.2g. Almost all of the treasure, 1982 pieces, was acquired by the Section history of the Grand-Ducal Institute. Many "duplicate" copies were used for exchange purposes, so that the State Museum's Medal Cabinet, where the Historical Section's medalist is kept, has only 1192 specimens left.
Over 1000 denarii and antoniniani. 1192 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0545/1-1193

summary: 21 silver coins: 8 republican denarii, 5 republican quinarii, 5 imperial denarii, 3 imperial quinarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Found together with 20 lead m1tary blank flans.
The hoard comprises 102 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Museu de la Porciúncula, Palma, Spain

summary: 700 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Probus, Carus, Numerian, Nigrinianus (AD 283-285).
The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.
91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
A hoard of approx. 5500 denarii (Nero to Septimius Severus), 15 kilos, found in Oberhausen, Augsburg.
30 aurei and several hundred denarii and antoniniani up to mid-3rd century. The coins were found together with 4 golden rings with gems and a gold ingot.
135 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
172 nummi (Tetrarchy to Licinius I, AD 316/7) found in a bronze vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 3604 small module radiate copies, known as 'minimi' [antoniniani (radiates)]. The hoard was found in an amphora covered by a tile while digging foundations for a building
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Natiobnale de France (in 1937)

summary: It is not clear whether this hoard forms part of the hoard found within the well in 1869 (See 5528). The vessel contained between 141 and 144 bronze coins from Augustus to Postumus.

111 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius, ranging from Hadrian to Trebonianus Gallus (Hostilian). The coins that make up this hoard were found a ceramic beaker, which was found in a pit in the northwest corner of a house that contained a metal workshop for bronze. Fragments of a 1:1 bronze statue (possibly an imperial statue) were found close to where the beaker with the coins was discovered.
81 nummi entered in the collection Traun without any certainty that they were found as a hoard: Constantius - Gratian (AD 367-378).

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
A small hoard of 38 copper alloy coins dating to the 370s AD, was recovered from a pit beside a pond near the Wootton Fields Roman villa (Chapman and Thorne 2004).
17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Hoard of 300 kilos, circa 180000 coins. Only 3647 coins divided into few lots are documented: 1341, 478, 63, 1760 pieces: Hieron II - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

A number of rare and unusual Iron Age coins, including a variety of continental types, have been recorded from 2 fields near Freshwater Bay. Possibly several distinct deposits, rather than a dispersed hoard?
The hoard comprised 1100 nummi, dating to the first part of the 4th century AD.
disposition: The Institute of Archaeology of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem

summary: 5 solidi found in a lead box in a burial: Leo I 1, Zeno 3, Anastasius 1.
A hoard of 30 coins, ranging from Gallienus to the time of Constantine I, found in Mainz-Bretzenheim.
On the basis of their condition and inventory numbers the coins perhaps also belong to the complex of the Keplerstraße hoard, see CHRE ID 3713.

A hoard of 155 bronze coins (2 hellenistic coins, 34 Roman imperial coins including 2 denarii, 12 provincial coins, 107 provincial coins from Gerasa), found within a linen purse close to the podium of the temple of Zeus, in a layer of reused material dated from the early 3rd c. AD.

5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. 1 interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.

A letter in the BM from the Potteries Museum and Gallery records a hoard of 68 bronze late third century coins in poor condition reported to the museum in 2000 but found in 1992 and so not Treasure. No further details other than findspot.
Unknown originally number of coins. 97 nummi: Maxentius - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
18 denarii found in unknown circumstances: 17 Republican denarii, 1 denarius of Augustus (9 BC).

summary: At least 38 Icenian silver units.

IARCH record for a hoard of 24 nummi. The coins were in poor condition and could not be fully identified. For further details and photos see WMID-C6D2A6.Unpublished catalogue by Riccardo Caravello & Teresa Gilmore.
It comprised 820 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

In 1983/4 a hoard of silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Vespasian to Gallienus, joint reign) was found scattered in a field, in the German-Dutch border area, close to Aachen-Richterich, on the site of a villa rustica. The hoard was dispersed. The total number of coins was estimated at more than 650 specimens. Some coins were sold, some others are now in the Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn. FMRD lists 747 coins.
Unknown originally number of coins. 176 silver coins. Today lost.
3 aurei of Hadrian. Only 1 was seen.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL III
summary: 145 coins of the Constantinian period were inventoried in 1934; preservation, conditions, and patina indicate that they involve a cohesive find, most likely part the hoard.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1500 and 2000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver w8: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: 2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the 1 Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).

A flint nodule containing 7 uniface (British Qb) staters was uncovered during landscaping work to create a golf course near Kingsclere. There appears to have been some pottery found nearby and possibly Roman roof tile and tesserae, although the accuracy of these observations is open to doubt.
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: The hoard was found during the excavation of a human skeleton and horse skeleton and comprised 8 nummi of the House of Constantine I.

The hoard comprised 10 individual textile bags of coins, stored in a wooden box. Although only fragments of the textile bags survive, the way the coins have settled and corroded into 10 blocks makes it clear that they were originally stored in this way. The largest of the blocks of coins weighed 68 kilos before cleaning (and 55kg after cleaning) and the assemblage as a whole weighed 340kg after cleaning. It is estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard is 110000. Found during the construction of the new Hôtel de Ville, in the area where the flight of steps up to the building were being constructed. The hoard was deposited (in its entirety?) in the Musée d’Évreux. Several portions of the assemblage have now been lost, but the remainder of the assemblage has been cleaned and conserved, with the exception of a single block of coins which has been preserved in its original state. TAF states that the hoard has now been deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles and a new catalogue is being produced.
94 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
1 imperial AE (Galba) and 2 imperial AE found with 4 skeletons in regio IX, insula 4, building 5 (bath house).
The hoard comprised 7 Celtic Iron Age coins. No further information was given regarding the composition of the hoard.

The Winchester hoard, a find of Iron Age / early Roman gold jewellery and 5 denari (now in the British Museum).BM collections online: "The Winchester hoard objects did not come from a grave, settlement or temple, but had been buried on their own on top of a small hill that might have been covered with trees. They may have been buried for safekeeping or as a religious offering.The hoard has 2 sets of gold jewellery, each comprising a necklace torc and 2 gold brooches held together by a chain. There are also 2 gold bracelets. A total of 1160 grams of very pure gold was used to make the objects. 1 of the torcs is bigger than the other, possibly because 1 was made for a man and the other for a woman".TAR 2000 pps. 16-18, no. 8; TAR 2001 91, p.181.

Unknown number of coins found in the vineyard, on an ancient settlement area. 30 coins of Gordian III are known: 15 antoniniani for Gordian III, 15 provincial bronzes minted in Deultum for Tranquilina.

summary: 339 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Silver: 254, 85 coins; silver w8: 69.6-316.5g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 4000 plated coins. The hoard was found by workmen digging ditches on the ancient route from Mans to Paris.

A group of 15 SC imitative coinages made in Hatra (14 small denominations, eagle type, Slocum series 2; 1 large denomination, unidentified). These were acquired at Hatra from local people during the Assur excavations, 1903–1913, of the Deutsche Orient-Gesellchaft. It is not sure these really represent a hoard, but rather an assemblage of local coins.

The second (Δβ) of 2 hoards found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street). It contained 11 nummi

The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).

Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1938. The hoard comprised 303 late Roman coins, 43 cast imitations and 2 Byzantine coins.

Serpieri-Averof in 1929. The Attica hoard (IGCH 343, 44 similar coins) from 1927 might well belong to the same depot.

The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 Roman coins and fragments of copper-alloy ornaments or instruments, all broken. 50 years after the discovery, Sayn (1925) suggested that the coins dated to the second century AD. The hoard was found by a young man in unknown circumstances.

A hoard of Roman coins, found in Western Crete without any known find spot and handed over by Chatzigrigorakis. Reports on its con10t diverge (see bibliography): it comprised either 143 coins (Augustus - Gallienus) or 206 (Hadrian - Maximinus). Most of these were sestertii, with very few provincial coins (Syria and Koinon of Crete or Alexandria and 1 unknown mint). The report given by Vlachogianni has been followed here.

11 nummi of the Tetrachy.
385 antoniniani (radiates found in a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 274); silver w8: 90.9-998.6 g.

summary: 698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

A hoard of 310 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) and their barbarian imitations was discovered by treasure hunters in November 2017 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and the first 104 coins were published on November 29, 2017, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity, followed by the next 117 coins on December 6, 2017. The hoard was discovered by 4 treasure hunters in a ploughed field and appears to have been partially ploughed (the coins were collected from a relatively large area). A total of 310 coins were found, which were divided among the finders (2 of the treasure hunters did not publish photos of their coins). The coins were in a hand-made vessel, a significant part of which has been preserved. A silver buckle, a bronze brooch, an iron knife with a b1 handle and a “spinning wheel-like thing” (probably a knife tip?) were also found with the coins (all artefacts are specific for the Chernyakhiv culture). The coins are very poorly preserved (heavily worn). 1 of the coins was pierced, another had a plugged hole. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 600 and 700 radiates of Gordian III to Postumus. The hoard was immediately dispersed, although subsequently 2 lots of coins were recovered for study.
27 coins: 1 antoninianus, 26 nummi: Claudius II - Valens (AD 364-367).
1325 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 239.6-1655.3g.

Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 51.2-99.8 g.

summary: 45 silver coins: 3 denarii, 42 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver w8: 57.1-113.3 g

summary: 5 antoniniani without any certainty that they were part of a hoard: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).

48 antoniani found as a roll in a destruction layer at the eastern gate of the Roman fort: Claudius II - Carinus (AD 283-284).

17 Celtic staters.
'Some kilos' of coins were found of which J.Gricourt saw 1 group of 19 coins, which were all of the House of Constantine.
(10.000+/-) 1112 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: c.1351.0-6249.0g

summary: Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 44 pieces enetered the museum collection in Popovo: Traian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.

The find comprised 'an important hoard of coins, dishes and cult statues, 2 in silver and 6 in bronze, from a sanctuary. There were approximately 40 silver coins which were melted down immediately by a goldsmith.'
12 nummi found together in the area of the baths in the Roman villa: Licinius I - Constantine I (AD 324-328).
(62) 10 denarii of Tajan (AD 112-114)

A hoard of 44 bronze coins mainly Valentinianic, was found in July 1984 during observation of redevelopment work on Hay's Wharf by the Museum of London's Department of Greater London Archaeology. Since the hoard came from the edge of a machine-dug trench, some coins may have been lost when the trench was dug. However, the size and shape of the depression suggests that at least half of the hoard was probably recovered. The latest coin in the hoard dated to 378-83. However, of the 36 Valentinianic coins identified, 21 (including most of the latest coins in the hoard) were in a state of wear which suggested that they had been in circulation for some period.
150 denarii. 145 coins entered the History Museum in Svishtov: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150); silver w8 of c. 275.8-468.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1614-1735 (145 coins)

summary: 4 bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235). Found together with an iron scale, a bronze weigh and scale pan fragments. Most likely ot a set for weighing.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Earthen jar containing 1600 pieces of the small brass of the Roman empire, found in Guilthwaite Common. Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD
312 denarii, range: Republican (211-210 BC) - Augustus (2 BC/AD 4). Large number countermarked.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "A. Salinas", Palermo: inv. 16037-96; 16103-79; 16181-89; 16190-363

summary: (200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: 68 nummi: Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 395-402).

The hoard was unearthed in the sector named Kaya Odası at Zeugma (southern part of Villa Danae, a residential area from the 5th - 7th c. AD) in the 2009 excavation season. It consist 424 bronze coins and coin fragments which are dated 4th and 5th century AD. The coins were poorly preserved due to corrosion and only 164 of them could be identified. 144 coins and 116 broken coin fragments could not be identified
A hoard (or 2 hoards?) of ca. 25000 coins dating mostly from the period AD 313-317, found in 2 earthenware vessels in the vicinity of the burgus (fort) of Mittelstrimmig.

A possible small hoard of 30 coins given to Alton Museum in 1953. An accompanying label stated that they were dug up "more than a century ago" at Hartley Mauditt. HER record states that they "include 9 of Claudius II, 20 of Gallienus and 1 of Valerian".

The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) 2 ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
5 aurei: Augustus 1 Tiberius 1, Claudius I 3 (AD 46-47).
Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).
108 denarii ranging from the Republic to the reign of Domitian, +AV and AR jewelry and vessels Roman republican (19); Roman imperial: Augustus; Tiberius; Nero to Domitianus.

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
14 denarii: Claudius I – Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (11 coins)

summary: Iron age staters from the trade which all seem to have originated from the same source, and have probably formed all or part of an undeclared hoard. It combine an unusual and poorly understood uninscribed type - the W1rsh stater (ABC 527) - with staters of Commios, and with the rarest type of Tincomarus (ABC 1052). The list of con10ts provided here should be treated with some caution given the lack of reliable information (de Jersey).

A hoard of about 500 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by a treasure hunter somewhere near the Dniester, on the borderland of the Ternopil and Ivano-Frankivsk region. The hoard was found in a pot (a few fragments are preserved). Several coins were glued to the fragments of the vessel. The coins are quite well preserved (minimal wear). Deposit was not published on Violity, and was immediately sold to 1 of the collectors. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
c. 400 nummi, 172 saved for the museum in Zagreb (1883): Constantius I, Constantius III Gallus, Julian (AD 355-363).
The hoard comprised 80 solidi from Honorius to Zeno with a tpq of c. AD 476. Gold w8: 356.0 g. The coins from these 7 separate finds have been mixed together.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 coins (although Ledru states the total was more than 1400 coins - an error?). Hucher compiled an inventory of 260 sestertii which were bought by the Musée du Mans Found in a field on the Villeneuve farm. Hollard gives a total number of 280 coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique du Mans, France (1892) - 260 coins

summary: 6 coins: 4 AE and 2 AR; Trajan-Elagabalus, with no further details currently available.
6 Roman coins, 3 of gold and 3 of bronze accidentally found in NE corner of [Southwark] Cathedral.
1141 silver coins: 546 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

summary: (c. 300) 143 described denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: c. 550.3-937.7 g

summary: 92 bronze coins: 1 as, 91 nummi (6 imitations): Nero - House of Theodosius (AD 388-402).

353 coins, among 1 aureus of Septimius Severus, found with 2 bronze vessels: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260). Together were found 2 gold rings and a silver necklace.
128 nummi: Constantine I - Theodius I/Honorius (AD 388-402).

summary: 10 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 2630-269); Silver w8: 3.7-11.5 g.

The hoard comprised 2 small urns containing more than 1000 poorly preserved radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised about 50 kg antoniniani (radiates) of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Divo Claudio, Quintillus, Aurelian and Tacitus. 2226 coins and 1 blank have been studied.

disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; inv.no. 2470 (1153 coins)

summary: A group of coins and artefacts reported to the HER that was subsequently identified as a possible scattered hoard.

The hoard comprised 19 amphorae filled with approximately 600 kg 53000 coins) of early 4th century nummi with the majority apparently coming from eastern mints. The coins were not worn and the amphorae appear to have been made specifically to accommodate the coins. At the moment, "The 5899 pieces that were analyzed were minted under the emperors Diocletian, Maximian, Constantius, Galerius, Constantine, Severus, Maximinus, Licinius and Maxentius. They came from the mints of Rome, Carthage, Aquileia, Treveri, Ticinum, Lugdunum, Londinium, Siscia and Ostia. A smaller number of coins came from Alexandria, Cyzicus, Thessaloniki, Heraklea, Nicomedia and Antiochi. The emperor whose name appears on the highest number of coins is Diocletian, and the mint, Carthage."
disposition: Provincial Archaeology Museum of Seville, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 20 Tyrian shekels (AD 8/9- AD 60/3) and 7 tetradrachms of Nero (AD 54-68).
1058 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 71 silver coins and 85 bronze coins from a Roman shipwreck.
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?
A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
Hoard of 35 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations. 34 are studied: Republic – Augustus (25-23 BC).
86 siliquae, divided into 3 parts (70, 10, 6 coins): Constantius II - Valentinian I (AD 364-367). Unknown conditions of discovery.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze prutot dating to the reign of Mattathias Antigonus (40-37 BC) and was probably concealed in a cloth bag.

(195) 180 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 245.1-503.7 g.
A small scattered hoard of Gallo-Belgic E staters, found between October 1998 and March 2003 in several batches up to 30m apart.
3 denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).
The hoard was found during excavations and comprised 2 piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.
(?) 39 antoniniani: Claudius II -Diocletian (AD 293-294); silver w8: 7.1-12.5 g.
The hoard comprised 3 aurei of Augustus, found between the city walls ('mur d'enceinte') of Aventicum and Villarepos.

216 coins: 1 aureus, circa 200 silver and 13 bronze pieces: Galba to Valerian I (AD 253-260) found with a copper vessel, and inside was an envelope made up of 2 silver foils joined by very numerous and very small silver studs. Together were were found jewelry and tableware. Aurei including 1 of Galba. AR coins run from Vespasian to Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260).

summary: Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel or a small square pot and contained more than 100 gold Iron Age coins. The exact total is not known with any certainty. 111 (Godard), 120 (Parenteau), 150 (Martin). The hoard was found by the son of the landowner and a servant in a field on the land of M. Gardais. 1 coin was aquired by the Cabinet des Médailles (BN 6723). The Musée Saint-Jean, Angers acquired 2 staters which were stolen in March 1885 (Reg. II, p. 10, no. 23, December 1860). The Musée départemental d'Archéologie, Nantes acquired 1 stater
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Paris (1 coin, BN 6723); Musée Saint-Jean, Angers (2 staters, stolen in 1885); Musée Départemental d'Archéologie, Nantes (1 stater); M. Gardais

summary: 6 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II (AD 145-175).
The hoard comprised 89 nummi dated between AD 341-346 and AD 498.

In the vicus located at the Roman In the vicus located at the Roman crossroads near the La Mône a vessel of 40 kg (8-10000 bronze and billon coins) was found. The sestertii run from Augustus to Postumus, while the denarii and antoniniani (radiates from Antoninus Pius to Macrinus and Quietus (AD 270).
10 aurei (Nero, Vitellius, and Vespasian), 88 uncertain denarii, and 9 uncertain AE found in the Villa Diomede.

A farm laborer found a Roman coin hoard in a plot of a field in Lochhausen, 10 cm below the surface. The hoard contained approx. 1700 antonianini, of which 1675 specimens could be recorded. Part of the hoard was housed in the coin collection at Munich, but lost during the years of war. The list given in FMRD is based on the publication of hoard by M. Bernhardt in 1911. Unfortunately, this publication contains many mistakes and it is not any more possible to give an exact description of the con10t.

43 coins (Constantine I - Zeno, including 1 cast imitation), found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a small leather bag and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1938.
A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver w8: 36.8-65.2 g.
5 staters and 290 Iron Age silver coins

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO C)
summary: Hoard in grave, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.

Around a skeleton, orientated eastwards, 'a large number' of Roman coins - estimated to 50 pieces: Jovian - Valentinian III (AD 426-430). The majority belonged to Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian. Most of the coins were sold in Vrsac (Serbia) and Timisoara (Romania). 23 coins entered the Ormos Zsigmond collection, which was later transferred to the National Museum of Banat. 2 solidi of Valentinian I minted in Treveri are still kept in the collection of the museum.
disposition: Muzeul Național al Banatului, Timișoara, Romania (inv.no. 59-60)

summary: Hoard of 51 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) found by metal detecting.
A hoard of late Roman bronze coins from the time of Constantine I, of which only 7 specimens were acquired by the Altertumsmuseum. The coins are now lost.
51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.

A very large hoard of denarii of Juba II found in Banasa (and not in Ksar el-Kebir as initially thought), comprising several thousand coins (4'000 or possibly more) ending in AD 17/18 (regnal year 42). The coins are said to have been found in 3 large jars. The find was rapidly dispersed, but a number of coins were bought by international numismatic museums.

The hoard comprised 44 nummi (378-383) of Valentinian I, Gratian and Theodosius I of the type REPARATIO REIPVB (Emperor raising kneeling turreted woman and holding victory on globe), found in Gortyn, at the Megali Porta bath complex. The mints were occidental and from the Balkans (no details given). This hoard seems to be linked to an inscription (IG IV, 285, dated AD 381) mentioning the distribution of gold and silver coins in Crete.
Around 30 coins found with ceramic vessel. 16 were recovered: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar)/Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy

summary: 67 antoniniani (radiates): 57 Gallienus (sole), 10 Salonina (AD 260-268).
