summary: 62 coins found when the water level went extremely low at the present dam: Claudius II (Divus) - Julian II (AD 361-363).
The hoard comprised c. 24 silver coins, only 8 tetradrachms recorded: 101/0 BC - 73-63 BC.

Around 300 coins of various periods and denominations: Carthaginian 2 ; republican and early empire 51; late empire 120; uncertain (imperial) 50; asses 23; fragmentary 55. Issuers: Augustus, Claudius I, Nero, Galba, Vitellius, Domitian, Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of 14 denarii of Augustus. The latest 1 minted in AD 13-14.

A hoard of 8 Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Edessa; Caracalla to Philip), found at the sanctuary of Zeus Ammon in Kallithea. This sanctuary was located on the territory of the Roman colony of Cassandrea.
The hoard comprised 15 sestertii from Titus to Julia Domna, found in Gonousa, close to Sicyon.

(c. 5000) gold coins from Aurelian to Heraclius Constantius (AD 610-641). 7 solidi are preserved in the collection of the National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania: Theodosius II, Valentinian III, Marcian, Leo I (4).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania; inv.no. N 13851, 13919, 13923, 13925, 13926, 14194, 14221

summary: Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 49 nummi of Constantius II are in kept in the Melk Convent.
895 denarii and antoniniani
disposition: Possible that 753 coins are in the National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXXX

summary: 1014 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

6 radiates and nummi found at various times at Breiddin hill fort. In 1875, 4 coins, thought to have been found near quarry workings on the western side of the hill fort about 10 years before, were donated to Powysland Museum. These were since lost among the museum's collections, but it is probable they included a radiate of Victorinus and 2 Constantinian nummi of GLORIA EXERCITVS (2 soldiers) and Constantinopolis types still in the museum's possession. These were followed in 1910 by around 12 more coins that were apparently found in the same area. Only 2 of these can now be identified among the museum's collections: 1 Constantinian nummus from Ticinum and 1 billon coin of Alexandria struck for Aurelian. The Alexandrian coin's association with the hoard is dubious, given the scarcity of such coins in British contexts.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 122 silver denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
19 aurei: Tiberius - Claudius I (AD 50-51).
3 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
The hoard comprised 1 denarii and 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Victorinus. The coins were stuck together with corrosion products.
The hoard comprised a vessel filled with 76 antoniniani (radiates) from Balbinus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
115 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv.no. 54015-54020

summary: 189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: Over 1054 coins were found, most of them oxidized together. Only 120 have been recorded to the level of the coin. Some 12 coins may have been lost (loose from the bulk of the hoard). Silver: 1054 (1, 127) coins; Silver w8: 285.7-2505.4g.
508 silver coins: 19 denarii, 489 denarii: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
52 gold coins found with a ceramic vessel. 41 coins were recovered and studied: Theodosius II - Marcian (AD 450-457); gold w8: 182.45g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 412 pieces are documented: Claudius II (Divus) - Valentinian III (AD 430-455).
disposition: Instituto de Antropologia «Dr. Mendes Corrêa» Oporto, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 'a handful of black coins.' 9 of the coins were recorded by Merle and included 2 electrum staters of hand under head type, 4 silver 'drachms' depicting a horseman jumping above a trilobate fleuron and 3 bronze coins. The hoard was found close to the abattoir and Vieux-Cimetière, not far from the ancient fortifications of the city and the Château.
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).
A hoard of 10 republican denarii. According to the finder, they all have the name PANSA inscribed.
A hoard containing 3000 coins from Gallienus to Constantine was found at Cervon before 1838.
Circa 500 coins, among which: 468 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
17 coins: 16 denarii, 1 dupondius: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241); silver w8: 23.9-44.2 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruzelles, Belgium (1 coin); Collection H. Verlooy of Vilvoorde (16 coins), in 1967

summary: 27 coins. 26 denarii. 1 possible barbarian imitation: Septimus Severus- Severus Alexander (ca. AD 235.)

During the excavation of the signal station at Carr Naze, Filey, 2 hoards of small brass coins were found, 1 of 110 coins, the other of 22 coins, ranging from Carausius to Arcadius and Honorius. This is hoard A, comprising 110 nummi up to AD 402. Robertson lists 110 coins but as few reverse types are given, Craster's list has been used here.
8 solidi, ranging from Valentinian II to Honorius, AD 406.
126 denarii: Galba – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 1524)

summary: The hoard comprised about 4000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be 2 hoards.
Circa 100 coins. 12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were 2 ceramic vessels buried at 2 m 1 from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: 17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
2 Iron Age East Anglian silver units of pattern-horse types, the reverse sides of which were found accreted together.
2 aurei of Trajan (AD 98-117). No further details.
71 nummi were found in a pilgrim flask, in a pit under a tile floor in a domestic quarter dating to the fifth century AD: House of Theodosius I - Zeno (AD 474-491).

This find can only be traced on paper, as it is only available as a manuscript by Christian Friedrich Hoffmann. It is stated that Hoffmann led excavations in the fort in the years 1791, 1800, 1804 and 1813-1815. His ex10sive manuscript was found in the Princely Wied archive in Neuwied in 1811. In 1991 the con10t was revised in Frankfurt am Main. Hoffmann describes 256 coins that are said to have been found “in a yellow metal chalice”. Thanks to Hoffmann's detailed description, almost all coins could be assigned. These are 213 denarii and 43 antoniniani (radiate). Most date from the reigns of Septimius Severus, Elagabalus, and Severus Alexander. The final coin, minted in AD 259.

A hoard of 180 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Septimius Severus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in April 2017 in Sumy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on April 18, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the coins were discovered on a ploughed field, near the river. On the same field in other parts of it were found single finds of denarii, many fragments of pottery, late Roman time bronze fibulae (i.e. material characteristic of the settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture – K.M.). The coins were in a hand-made pot, of which only the bottom was preserved, found at a depth of 40 cm. The finder assumed that the upper part of the pot (i.e., hoard) had been cut by a plough, as some of the coins were on fragments of this vessel or within a meter of it. Early medieval material (Kievan Rus) was also found in the same field. The further fate of the hoard coins is unknown.
2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver w8: 5.06 g.
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Found during years 1864, 1876, 1893, 1940, 25 solidi: Honorius - Anastasius (AD 491-518).
disposition: National Museum Szczecin, Poland; Museum of Cultural History Straslund, Germany; Pistorius collection; private colletions

summary: This find comprised 2 hoards, found several days apart in neighbouring fields. The first, comprised a grey coarseware vessel containing approximately 2300 antoniniani (radiates). The second comprised a red ceramic jug containing at least 32 antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 622 and 2874g.

3494 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi, 16835 kilos: Probus to Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 313-316). Distribution of coins by mints: 1470 Trier, 1527 London, 366 Lyon, 50 Rome, 36 Ticinum, 10 Aquileia, 8 Siscia, 4 Cyzicus, 13 Carthage, 2 Arles, 23 Ostia, 1 Heraclea.

The hoard comprised an unknown quantity of coins. D. Guillony gave a portion of the hoard to the Musée de la Ville. It consisted of 31 very small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, which were for the most part unidentifiable with the exception of some coins of Tetricus. They are likely to be imitations. The hoard was found 'by chance'.

142 coins in 2 vessels containing 71 sestertii from Titus to Septimius Severus and 71 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus. Only 54 were recovered and studied: 30 sestertii, 24 antoniniani (radiates).
Found with a ceramic m1y-box. 1 bronze coin serve as a lid: 285 denarii, 1 as: Republic - Augustus (7 BC).
The hoard comprised small module copper-alloy coins of the House of Constantine (with GLORIA EXERCITVS reverses etc). 50 of these coins were acquired by a regional collector.
At least 50 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), but only 5 are identified: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
57 nummi of the House of Constantine I (AD 322-325) found in the floor in a Roman villa.
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 125 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 121 nummi: Gallienus/Claudius II - Valens (AD 364-367) or Valentinian II/Arcadius (AD 383-408) (Pinto 2007, p. 156).
A small group of "irregular Dobunnic" or East Wiltshire silver units, found within an area of approximately 20 m2.

Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).
The hoard comprised 10320-10500 silver denarii and tetradrachms, ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found in a bronze jar.
13482 nummi: Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 425-435).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France Paris, France

summary: More than 1500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 69 comprises 12 Iron Age coins.
Unknown number of silver coins. Dr. Harlanov examined 23 pieces: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-219); silver w8: 41.3-66.1 g.
(?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
6 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and 1 imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: 633 coins found with shreds from the container: 1 denarius, 2 antoniniani (radiates), 630 nummi: Severus Alexander - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg (628 coins), Austria

summary: 79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of 4 provincial coins (3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, with head of Tyche / ethnic - this series ex10ds from Commodus to Philip?. The coin illustrated fig. 8-9 belongs to the latest issue; 1 Pella), found in the demolition layer of the courtyard (room ΣΤ), of a large urban Roman building.

'A Find of 265 Early British Coins, with a very crude design of a head on 1 side and a horse on the other; found at Brentford about 1860, many varieties' –– Sotheby 8 December 1915, lot 280. This was sold to Baldwin’s, who seem to have made quite leisurely progress in selling on the coins, and indeed almost 6ty years later they provided the CCI with photographs of 71 still in their possession.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 15 comprises 59 silver Iron Age coins and 2 Roman Republican denarii.
236 nummi found with a jug: Tetrarchy - Constantine I and Licinius (AD 310-313).
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel with a lid containing between 1800 and 2000 radiates. No further information about the composition of the hoard was given.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including 1 plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
Hoard of 99 electrum and silver stateri of the Bosporan Kings, Cotys III and Sauromates III (AD 232-233).
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
Hoatrd of 501 nummi re-discovered in the museum collections: Claudius Ii - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 331 coins : 322 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 8 uncertain sestertii: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 232).

A hoard of more than 3000 coins was found opposite the church in Baarlo in 1830. More than 3000 coins (32 gold and the rest in silver) remained with banker Wolters. Further data is missing. Description is known for 5 coins. The first publication, in 1838, mention coins from Augustus to the Antoninians.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold w8: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.
3 fused coins, 1 of which was identifiable as a radiate of Probus and therefore a possible hoard, though the other coins could not be identified.
(+?) 6 solidi Theodosius II (AD 430-440); gold w8: 26.7g+;
Hoard of around 1000 silver coins. 29 coins are kept in the Joanneum, Graz. According to G. Dembski the coins may rank from Severus Alexander to Gallienus.
The hoard comprised 41 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian and 16 barbarous copies; silver w8 of 12.1-50.3g.
107 coins. 65 coins: Victorinus - Theodosius I. No further information. 42 coins were found in 1995 at the same findspot.
4 2nd c. AD coins were found during sharding in Flurdistrikt above the Geybach river.
The hoard comprised 73 aurei from Augustus to Domitian found with an earthenware.
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
287 Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) found under a slab: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
19 solidi: Theodosius II - Zeno (AD 480-491); gold w8: 84.55 g.
disposition: Coin Room of the Capitoline Museum, Rome Italy

summary: A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on 1 of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen
10585 nummi: House of Constantine (AD 313-333)

1 denarius, 7 radiates, and 63 nummi (Commodus - Valentinian I), probably found in 1890 during construction work for the Busdorfschule. The coins were lost in 1945, but, except for 3, were found again in 1970.
41 denarii: Republican - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

A group of 36 coins (13 antoniniani and 23 nummi, Victorinus to House of Valentinian), in a box with the label 'The Dreghorn Hoard, July, 1897', among the collections of the Grosvenor Museum (Chester).

The hoard was found during the demolition of the praefurnium by M. Plessis. It comprised 4625 coins weighing 12kg. Hucher compiled a catalogue of 4518 coins (14 worn bronzes; 4504 radiates and imitations). Imitations account for approximately 44% of the coins in the hoard of which 2.8% were minimi. Silver w8: 1219.4-16076.0 g.
The hoard comprised 114 coins of the First Jewish Revolt from Year 4 (AD 69/70).
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
A group of 8 coins (Armenian, Parthian, and Roman), ranging from 62 to 31 BC, was discovered in 1955.
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).

The hoard comprised an unknown number of sestertii from Augustus to Septimius Severus. Blanchet compiled a catalogue of the 45 coins which he saw. He noted that the coins of Antoninus Pius were very worn.
A hoard of 45 Roman denarii, ranging from 115 BC to AD 78, found during excavations of the Elginhaugh Roman fort.
200 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 86).
A hoard of 119 antoniniani (radiates) was found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Together were found a silver anchor type brooch and a glass vessel.
Few coins found with a ceramic vessel. Unreliable information on the circumstances of discovery. The nummus of Licinius I was found later, in 1966.
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 36 siliquae and 1 (stray?) nummus found with a metal detector. The site was later investigated by test-pitting but no features were found. 2 ceramic sherds were found during this work but it is not certain if they relate to a container for the hoard. See LVPL-B38AFC for details and images.Unpublished catalogue by Vanessa Oakden, David Shotter and Richard Abdy.
A hoard of 7 nummi (AD 311-318) found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street).
(100) 32 coins, 1 aureus, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; 29 coins; inv.no. LVII; History Museum, Lovech; 2 coins; inv.no. 1784 1-2

summary: 1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagst1s at the south-eastern end of the basilica.

16 coins found with a ceramic vessel during archaeological excavations in a Carpic settlement. The coin of Antoninus Pius could be an intruder, otherwise 16 denarii: Mark Antony 8, Mark Antony 1 imitation, Augustus 1, Vespasian 5, 1 barbarous imitation.

Initially the hoard contained 202 coins and fragments found with a ceramic vessel. Nowadays, there are 191 silver coins kept i the coin collection in the Museum of archaeology in Firenze: 166 denarii, 25 quinarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC).
"A thousand coins hoard coins found with a ceramic pot". 874 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: Fund 'Il Castello", inventory list; the hoard was probably sold on market

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 176 denarii are known, but only 68 studied: Republic – Augustus (11-9 BC). Together were found silver (and gold?) jewelry of Dacian manufacture.
disposition: Banat Museum, Timișoara, Romania (inv.nos. IMBN II 543, 1905, 916, 917; Hungarian National Museum, Budapest (jewelry)

summary: The Lengerich III find is the third of a set of 3 finds, made underneath 3 large st1s during the construction of the road Freren - Lengerich. It consisted of late Roman silver coins of the ursuper Magnentius (of which 1 is preserved), a medallion of Constantius and possibly siliquae of Constantine I. The coins had been covered by a fragmented flat silver plate.

The 15 (lost) coins, "mostly poorly preserved middle bronzes from Augustus to Trebonianus Gallus", were found in 1913/14 during earthworks on the edge of a ravine near the Bühren estate. "The coins were scattered over 100 m, 1 m deep."
Hoard of 114 denarii: Republic - Nero (AD 64-68).
3150 coins: 9 antoniniani (radiates), 3141 nummi: AD 260-293 - Theososius I and his sons (AD 388-395) found with a ceramic vessel.At the same place with Balboa B.
The hoard comprised '400 gold coins found under a st1 including issues of Diocletian, Maximian and other emperors'. Gold w8: c.1768.1-1799.2g.
45 nummi (AD 320-33) found on Twyn Bwmbegan in 1997.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised 1875 silver coins found with an amphora: 1811 republican denarii, 51 denarii serrati, 13 republican quinarii, 1 hemidrachm of Dyrrhachium (with a tpq 45 BC).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel filled with 10 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
2 aurei found during agricultural works: Nero, Vespasian for Domitian (Caesar). Uncertain, whether they were found together.
disposition: National Székely Museum, Sf. Gheorghe, Romania (inv. no. 11115, vanished in 1944)

summary: Hoard of 3000 nummi, fresh minted, found with an amphora: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 306-337).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 751.3g and 1558.7g
Silver: 3 denarii, 208 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Diocletian/Galerius (Caesar) (AD 293); silver w8: 43.8-497.0g.
disposition: Landesmuseum Niederösterreich, St. Pölten (in 1977 in Wien), Austria

summary: 17 denarii to Tiberius, 68 IA silver units and 1 IA bronze coin. The denarii are described as 17 denarii from worn Republican to fresh Tiberius/Livia seated. Uncertain if all these coins belong to the same deposit.
The hoard comprised a 'large quantity of Roman bronze coins.' The hoard was discovered by a farmer on the land of M. de Fleuriot.
1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
300 denarii, found with a ceramic vessel 237 coins were recovered: Otho – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (227 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (10 coins; inv.no. 361)

summary: Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
284 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
370 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Marius (AD 269); silver w8: 102.2-959.7 g.
5 solidi: Valentinian I - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).

7 antoniniani (radiates), all of Postumus from a single collection. The coins could be part of a hoard, or form a hoard in themselves. No information regarding the circumstances of their discovery are known.
4 solidi found in 1869 with a fragment of a gold bracteate, a spiral ring, 2 partly spirali-formed gold bars et al., at the major Iron Age settlement of Sandegård.
Unknown number of silver coins. 23 silver coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 18.2-34.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Karnobat (12 coins); Regional History Museum, Burgas, Bulgaria (inv.no. XVI)

summary: The hoard was found under a st1 slab. It comprised 3 red ceramic vessels, placed in a triangle. The vessels contained 13936 denarii. The earliest Republican denarii dated to the 2nd century BC and most recent to the period of the Civil Wars of the second Triumvirate. Notably there are issues of Julius Caesar, of Pompey (RRC 446), Brutus (RRC 501; 502/2), Cassius (RRC 500/5), Sextus Pompey ( RRC 511/3), Q. Labienus (RRC 524/2, 40), eastern issues of Mark Antony (RRC 543; RRC 546/1, issue by Pinarius Scarpus in Cyrene; legionary denarii). There was also 1 Numidian silver coin of Juba, 1 Mauretanian silver coin, and 80 varieties of Augustan denarii. The hoard was found by workmen during the construction of a gymnasium at a school. The hoard was divided between the city of Le Mans and the finders and was sold in October 1850. Hucher bought a selection of denarii for the Musée du Mans and in 1894 the museum possessed 600 denarii.
400 imperial denarii and 1 aureus of Domitian. No further information.
Solidi of Constantine II (AD 337-340) and Constantius II (AD 337-361) from the excavations under the dome. No description.
16 coins: 4 republican denarii, 12 asses: Republic - Augustus (15 BC).
87 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 85 provincial: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3635 (87 coins)

summary: A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
Large quantity of Roman provincial bronze coins. 50 coins were minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis, Anchialus and Tomis.
The hoard comprised 311 nummi dated between the reigns of Constantius II and Honorius/Arcadius.
13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: In 1831, 4 Republican denarii were found and then another in 1835. It is not clear whether they represent a hoard.
A hoard of 1314 late Roman coins (1 aureus, 5 argentei and 1308 nummi ranging from Diocletian to Constantine I) that appear to have been buried in a wooden box.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 144 nummi deposited around AD 395-408.
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Hoard of 43 nummi found during archaeological excavations: Constans - Julian II (AD 361-363). Mints: Sirmium, Siscia, Cyzicus, Alexandria, Aquileia, Thessalonica, Heraclea. The coins were not separated by mints.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia

summary: The hoard comprised 300 coins from the Roman period.

43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between 2 large st1s.
The hoard comprised 215 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 268.
disposition: Brodsko Posavlje Museum, Slavonski Brod, Croatia

summary: 317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, 10 meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
More than 1000 silver coins (Trajan - Postumus), found while establishing a water ditch on a field. The composition of the hoard is difficult to reconstruct, see FMRD for details.
36 coins: 34 denarii, 2 asses: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
6 solidi: Theodosius II - Leo I (AD 457-474); gold w8: 26.7 g. Found at different times but in same field.
The hoard comprised 17 bronze coins dated between AD 317-320 and AD 351-361.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing carbonised wood, a gold finger ring with a st1 setting, a gold earring, a copper-alloy earring, a copper-alloy bell, a pewter spoon and 12 coins of the Late Empire.
The hoard comprised 75 tetradrachms (Nero-Trebonianus Gallus), found in the vicinity of Jerusalem.
disposition: Dispersed, Formerly owned by Dr. Schalit (Jerusalem)

summary: The hoard comprised 100 nummi dated between AD 346-361 and AD 450-457. 1 nummus of Justinian I is most likely an intruder.

A hoard of at least 121 denarii and antoniniani (Septimius Severus - Valerian I), found by 2 metal detectors in 2006. Some coins were preserved in fragmentary form and these fragments could account for another 1-3 specimens.
51 bronze coins, probably, kept in an organic container (carbonised traces): Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).

6 denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
(200+) 103 silver coins: 78 denarii, 25 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 246)
117000 ”bronze coins of the 3rd century”, weighing about 38 kg, buried in a pit sealed by tiles. Probably, they were in10ded for re-minting.
disposition: Institut national de recherche archéologique préventive

summary: Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.
150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.

Originally found by a farmer and then the subject of an archaeological excavation, the hoard comprised 12 solidi accompanied by 11 silver objects weighing 163g, including a bracelet fragment, ingot and cut plate (hacksilber) and 1 gold ring. Survey suggests the hoard was buried in an isolated location: Valentinian I - Constantine III (AD 408-411).
500 antoniniani (radiates): Probus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
9 bronze coins found together near the Roman amphitheater: 1 Trajan, 8 nummi Constantius II (AD 337-361)
376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: The coins are said to have been found (in the 19th c.) by children on the "Hetzheide" approx. 1.5 km northwest from the site. Further particulars do not survive. Doubtful as a hoard, given the large time spam and the composition.

A narrow-necked jar with 2000 bronze coins (antoniniani, Gallienus - Tetricus) of mostly good condition were found to the left of the road going towards Reimsbach ('auf der Hir10wiese'), along a Roman road. Only 78 coins were examined.
A substantial hoard of Durotrigan silver. Many of the coins were in good silver, weighing 5 g or more. The size of the hoard is unknown, but it almost certainly contained more than 500 coins.

On 9 July 1962 a hoard of 4th century coins was found during excavations in a 4th century building site which ran along and to the South of Watling Street adjacent to Magiovinium. The coins were probably originally contained in a bag. There were approximately 251 loose coins and a conglomerate of perhaps 400 more. The general condition of the coins was very poor - many were totally illegible. It was suggested that the coins may have been originally fused together as a result of fire. This hoard is composed almost entirely of ancient copies to which a few of the very common coins of 330 to 348 were added. All the coins are of the lowest possible value. 306 AE coins were catalogued.
2 burnt and fused silver denarii of Roman date. Both coins are distorted and have been rendered illegible. Diameter: 18.7mm; Thickness: 6.1mm; W8: 8.9g.
Hoard of 10 nummi found by metal detecting: Constantius II - Arcadius for Honorius (AD 406-408).
disposition: State Museum-Reserve Kulikovo Field, Tula, Russia

summary: It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and 1 of the Faustinas.
4 solidi of Gratian minted in Treveri (AD 375-378); Gold w8: 17.8g.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and 2 asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
The hoard was found between "le Champ de Navarre" and Jean-Ernest Darbot avenue. It comprised an uncertain number of aurei, maybe between 21 and 50. Only 12 are now recorded.
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as 1 block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD
A scattered hoard of 31 staters of Cunobelin, found on 3 occasions between 7 October and 2 November 1990, including 9 linear type, 13 wild, 5 plastic and 4 classic.
(70) 16 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).
42 nummi: Costantine I - Valens (AD 364-378).
155 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 216.6-451.6 g.
690 denarii found in a black ceramic vessel: 532 republican, 158 imperial: Republic - Augustus (17-16 BC).
15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: Con10ts of a little purse. 7 denarii: Nero - Trajan.

A hoard of 1702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
64 bronze coins, (residual): Siculo-Punic - Valentinian III? (AD 425-455).
5 denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.
86 nummi found on a floor in a building: Constantine I - Constantius II and Constans (AD 347-348).
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.
The hoard comprised 14 Republican denarii. It was interpreted as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations.
The hoard comprised 61 nummi found during the excavation at the entrance hall of the Odeion: House of Constantine I (AD 340-348).
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
304 Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations. All of Vespasian and his family.

The 1970 Sardes Hoard (420 coins) was found southeast of the entrance to the Synagogue in 1970. Most of these coins are dated to the 4th and fifth centuries AD. The coins had not been sealed by a container, so some of the coins listed here probably do not belong to the original hoard (see Buttrey et al., p. 123).

The hoard comprised 801 sestertii from Vespasian or Titus to Maximinus I Thrax with a tpq of AD 236. Although no trace of a container was recovered, the coins were found stacked, as if they had been stored in rolls in a box.

6263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.
Provincial coinage of Hispania (Gades, Colonia Patricia & Italica) for Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
Silver coins, Celtic 1s of Sequani, obols of Marseille and Antipolis.
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.
In a grave 8 nummi were found: Valentinian I 4, Valens 4 (AD 364-378)
The hoard comprised 11 Tyrian tetradrachms, dated between 142-29 BC.

10 Iron Age silver units and 4 denarii to Tiberius, found by 5 metal detectorists at a rally held between 24 and 26 August 1996; another detectorist found the second batch, of c. 369 coins (sources don't agree on exact figure), on 26 July 1997, at a depth of c. 30 cm. 7teen body sherds of a wheelmade vessel in a sandy, micaceous fabric were found nearby, possibly from a globular beaker and perhaps the container for the hoard (Chadburn 2006, hoard 54).
1094 antoniani: Valerian I - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292). It was found during dredging works in the River Danube. Apparently, the hoard was originally packed as rolls of coins.
49 nummi found in a cave beside other votive offerings: Constans - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
3 solidi found at different times before 1857: Valentinian III, Julius Nepos, Anastasius (AD 491-518)
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised '20 denarii [actually, antoniniani (radiates)] of Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian (?), Gallienus and Postumus.
The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.

A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing '30 silver and bronze coins, including 1 of Nero. It is possible that this hoard is the same as the hoard of large and medium bronzes of Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Gordian III which were examined by Deville.
During the archaeological excavations at the Roman villa of 'Los Cipreses' a set of 5 jugs was found. 1 of them contained 52 nummi: Constantine I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-378).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Jerónimo Molina, Jumilla, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 12 coins of Gallienus and Tetricus I.
30-40 denarii and antoniniani hoard. No further information.
134 sestertii: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only 4 coins were provided with some information.
38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).
The deposit was found in the 'galerie de circulation' of the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 2 coins, 1 of Tiberius and the other illegible.
The hoard comprised close to 1800 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Postumus.

The hoard comprised a small earthenware vessel containing 100 'small bronzes' (radiates) of which 86 were identified by the finder: Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274).
'The coins were dug up close to 1 another in 1936 during a follow-up investigation on the outer terrain h8 of the pillar temple. They appear to originally belong together.'
336 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Trajan (AD 98).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. VI

summary: 300 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Postumus (AD 260-269) found in a ceramic vessel; silver w8: 82.0-764.7g.
185 silver coins (tetradrachms, denarius, shekels) found with a ceramic vessel next to another 1 (Qumran 1955 A) and not far from Qumran 1955 C.
10 Iron Age coins found at Ashdown Forest, Sussex. 9 of them are now in the British Musem.

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other 1s exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: 403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Probus (AD 276-282).
A hoard of Roman aurei and their imitations was discovered in an earthen pot: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
1587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

During the excavation of a rural Roman bath-house, 10 coins were discovered in the ashes of the praefurnium. The b1s of a 12 year old child were found in the same place. TAF suggests that the coins were a purse loss or a funerary deposit.
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 2 antoniniani, Gordian III and Philip the Arab.
Excavation of the Celtic Oppidum. In the layers dating from the time of Augustus, 4 Turonos Cantorix coins were found that could be a hoard, a purse or a deposition.
Around 20 coins, 10 are known: Claudius II – Valens (AD 364-378).
539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
47 silver coins: 4 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Caracalla-Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 70.4-108.5 g.
162 silver coins: Republican denarii, imperial denarii; including 1 of Juba II, 1 Eastern Celts and 2 'animae': Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
(c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver w8: c. 367.1-588.9 g.
2 ceramic vessels with around 500 coins: Elagabalus (Aquilia Severa) to Carinus (AD 283-285). Hobbs estimates the w8 of 63.5-843.8g.

A hoard of at least 23 coins (denarii and aurei, ranging from the Republic to Vespasian), found during the construction of the city hospital in 1910, in cellar 12. 18 coins are now in the Mainz museum, at least 5 aurei of Nero were lost.
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
The hoard comprised 117 nummi dated between AD 312-317 and AD 361-363. More coins to be identified.
8 solidi of Honorius (AD 395-423); gold w8: 35.6g.
14 nummi: 12 nummi, 2 imitations House of Theodosius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1992-235

summary: 14 nummi from the Tetrarchy (Diocletian to Constantius I), found in Mainz-Bretzenheim between 1910 and 1923.
The hoard comprised 6 nummi of Constantine I, found in grave 4 of the east cemetery in Thessaloniki.

7teen coins apparently within a flint container. The publication by Burnett and Cowell (1988, 4-6) includes metal analyses of all 7teen coins. Note that Sills (2003, 363 no. 27) has modified the classes of some of the Gallo-Belgic E staters. Sills (ibid., 157, no. 94) also suggests that 2 Gallo-Belgic Ab1 class 5 staters recorded in trade in 1992, and said to have been found "within 15 miles of Henley on Thames" (217), might be strays from this hoard."
Originally were 196 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 coins were recovered: Claudius II (Divus) - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-392).
disposition: Câmara Municipal de Ribeira de Pena, Portugal

summary: 14 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 12 nummi: Gallienus (Salonina) – Valentinian I (AD 364-367).
The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Aurelian. It is suggested that the coins were the con10ts of a purse or part of a larger, scattered hoard.
19 nummi found inside the place for the handle of the mobile side of a st1 hand-mill: Constans - Valentinian II (AD 378-383).
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found 2 gold fingerings.
2 aurei of Nero, same type (AD 64-65).
The hoard comprised 5 silver denarii from Septimius Severus to Elagabalus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 9.2g.
3 solidi of Valentinian II (2) and Arcadius (AD 383-388); gold w8: 13.35g.

The hoard comprised 28 nummi of the House of Constantine and was found in a Roman mausoleum in the cemetery of Cherchell (AD 333-335). Found togethare with an entirely preserved lamp and a fragment of a lamp.
4 late antique bronze coins found in excavations of the Propsteikirche St. Mariä Himmelfahrt in Jülich. They derive from a destruction layer located beneath a furnace.
1300 republican and imperial denarii, ending with issues of Augustus and Tiberius (AD 14-37).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver w8: 54.9-502.2+

The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Anto9 family (including Faustina I and II) and 1 depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a 4th century nummus, but reverse types of the Anto9 period also depict the wolf. The 3 coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Deultum: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv. no. ?XXV

summary: Over 1000 denarii found in a forest. From only 5 of them are know the issuers: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together with the hoard were found: 5 pearls, 1 amber piece, a silver plate and a spring from a crossbow brooch.

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Anto9 period, n1 later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
Circa 15 kg of silver/bronze coins from Valerian I to Constantine I. Dispersed
The hoard comprises 12 provincial bronzes of Augustus found stacked together.

The hoard comprised an urn containing 218 (or 318) Roman silver coins, both denarii and antoniniani (radiates). A silver statue depicting a 'wise old man' was also discovered at the same findspot a little later. The hoard was found by a farmer called Filliol while working in his field; silver w8: c.60.4-563.7g.
67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver w8: 95.2-182.9 g.
370 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
Initially, there were 1500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found 1 gold and 2 silver ingots.

The hoard comprised more than 212 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Postumus. All the coins with clear reverses of Postumus were from his 1st issue at Trier, suggesting a tpq of AD 260 to 261. However, 16 of the coins of Postumus were described as having 'diverse' reverses so we cannot be exactly certain of this date.
Hoard 17 coins: 2 aurei, 15 denarii: Nero - Domitian (AD 88-89).

During excavation of a ditch in front of the Spickelstraße house 3 a hoard of denarii, ranging from Nero to Alexander Severus, was unearthed in 1958, from which 640 specimens were salvaged and could have been transferred to the Kemp10 Heimatmuseum. It is not sure that all coins are preserved. 2 antoniniani are also listed.
140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 175.6-362.9 g.
4teen staters and 2 silver units.

On Friday, August 3, some workmen digging in a chalk-pit, at Paulsgrove, on Portsdown Hill, found a skeleton in the chalk, in the left hand of which were 20-2 Roman third brass coins. Many of the coins were too corroded to be legible. They were all third brass, and some were of the reigns of Valens and Valentinianus. 1, very small, was of Theodosius.

(1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver w8: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel
disposition: Muzeul Na'ional al Unirii Alba Iulia, Romania

find_spot_name: POMPEII VI, 7 - VIA DI MERCURIO, ALL'ALTEZZA DELLA CASA DEI DIOSCURI B
summary: 2 uncertain silver coins, 4 uncertain bronze coins and an uncertain group of bronze coins fused together found with a skeleton and gold jewelry in regio VI, insula 7, on the via di Mercurio near Casa dei Dioscuri.
1600 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised 3 asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
(c. 400) 322 antoniniani/radiates: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (AD 257-258); silver w8: 87.9 - 401.5g+
disposition: National Museum Ljubljana, Slovenia (227 coins); Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (95 coins); dispersed

summary: 1100 antoniniani discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.
Unknown number of coins. 14 provincial bronze coins entered museum collection in Nesebar: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla. Mints: Augusta Traiana, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Serdica, Anchialus
disposition: History Museum, Nesebar, Bulgaria; inv.no. XI

summary: 8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
8 Alexandrian bronzes: Claudius I 2, Vespasian 6. Probably part of the El-Hiba 43, found during excavations.
3510 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius: Philip I - Aurelianus (AD 270-275)
316 coins: Philip I - Constantius II (AD 337-361). There are some doubts whether there were other coins added at the core of this hoard.
A list of coins not securely belonging to the hoard. Nr. 3-4 are badly preserved, thus a clear determination is not possible.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: 74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 348 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 347 nummi dated between AD 278-282 and AD 321-324 and 2 later coins dated between AD 351-361.
5 denarii found on a field: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).

Found during the British Museum Snettisham excavations in 1991. De Jersey (2015) writes: "Hoard N is described (Stead 1995, 53) as "a collection of 6 Gallo-Belgic A and C staters almost certainly from a scattered hoard". 2 more coins were found nearby.
325 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 323 nummi: Divus Claudius II - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised 110 Roman bronze coins from Augustus to Gordian III with a tpq of AD 239.

24 mostly later Roman coins were given to the state museum collection in 1966, which supposedly were found at Steinkirchen. Find-site particulars and circumstances of the find were not ascertained. This could be a hoard or single finds.

4 gold coins found in a grave: Tiberius, Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian. Together were found 5 staters of Colchida, 3 denarii of Augustus; 51 Parthian drachms: Orode II 47, Artaban I 1, Sinatruces 1, Phraates III 1, Phraates IV 1 and a gold bracelet.
At 3 m from the findspot of MORCHAIN 1, 7 coins: 1 double sestertius, 2 sestertii, 3 asses, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Postumus (AD 264-265).
The coins were found together in 1882 in St. Paulin.
18 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 5.8-21.5 g.
60 denarii: Galba/Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A scattered hoard of Gallo-Belgic and early South Thames gold staters. No further information available.
The Musée de Rouen has preserved 25 coins from this find, initially, it consisted of 33 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 87 studied: Republic - Titus (AD 81).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 15 gold coins and 2 pieces of jewelry found within a small area over a period of 150 years.
167 silver coins: 97 denarii, 70 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Diocletian (AD 295).
disposition: formerly Regional museum Tiel (destroyed during WWII)

summary: Originally 44 coins, 41 pieces recovered: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
(40) 20 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver w8: c.14.6-84.0 g.
disposition: Collection Derjicke, Iddergem, Belgium (20 coins), in 1965

summary: The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.

7 Claudian copper alloy coins said to have been found 'together' in mud from the river Colne at Colchester, possiby in the Sheepen area. No further details of the context are known. The hoard was seen at a coin fair and reported by Kenyon (Crummy 1987, 75).

6 Roman coins (Valentinian I) were found on the h8 of the Schönebecker Sand, 1 km above Vegesack during excavation of the Weser in a depth of 8 meters. The historical museum and municipal museum preserved 3 of them. The latter were stolen in 1919.
5 asses of Augustus (15 BC).
A small deposit of 6 bronze coins of the House of Vespasian found in a villa: 1 as Vespasian, 2 asses Vespasian for Titus (Caesar), 2 sestertii Titus, 1 as Domitian (AD 82).
Unknown originally number of coins. Owing to some short notes, 10 denarii were identified: Republic 3, Augustus 1, Galba 1, Vespasian 2, Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) 2, Titus 1.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 17 pieces are in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 16324-16340

summary: 45 nummi found together in a layer of ashes from a domestic building: Constans - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Convento dos Lóios, Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal

summary: 160 staters were found within a "restricted area" of a single field, near a fording point across the River Brit (TAR 2003, 151 no. 352). The coins are nominally described as base silver, although some might more accurately be described as bronze.
4643 nummi to FEL TEMP REPARATIO (348 - 2 coins) and associated pottery. Addenda of 10 and 16 nummi found during subsequent excavation.
26 number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Only 1 coin of Salonina is known (AD 253-260). Hobbs estimates a w8: 33.1-66.5 g.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 11 coins were registred in Janury 1978. According to the finder, the coins were issued between "+- 104 - 4".
The hoard comprised 66 sestertii from Domitian to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 195 to 196. It was found with a small statue of Mercury.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: At least 453 coins found by a boy in a ploughed field at Pertlow Farm, Aylesbury, ca. 1937-1939, ending before AD 375. The hoard was dispersed, but lists of 2 lots of coins exist, 1 of 36 small AE coins, from Constantius II to Valentinian II, and the other of 417 coins (1 ant. and 416 AE). It was noted that n1 of theses coins was clipped.

Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver w8: 2577.8-6108.2
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Nationale de France

summary: A person engaged in digging near the entrenchments which surround the castle at Bourn, lately discovered a small urn, containing upwards of 6ty Roman coins. 1 of them is an aureus of Nero; the others are denarii and sestertii of Constantine, Augustus and Maximilian [sic]." The account of the emperors represented in the hoard, and the denominations included are unlikely.

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii menti1d that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. 1 denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
1898 coins: 2 denarii, 1895 antoniniani (radiates), 1 nummus: Valerian I - Tetrarchy I (AD 296-297).
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: 15 denarii from a public building: Republic - Trajan (AD 100).

7 coins: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii; 1 medallion of bronze and gold and silver jewelry were found within a child grave: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
31 coins: 1 antoninianus, 30 nummi: Gallienus - Valens (AD 367-378).
2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: 1892 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-261).

A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and 1 Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
30 bronze coins found during a digging near a modern house: Antoninus Pius - Costantius II (AD 355-361).
Group of 3 coins: Tiberius 1 as, Claudius I 2 asses (AD 41-54).
disposition: Regional museum, Kolín, Czech Republic (2 coins)

summary: Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).
(5000+) 14 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274)
30 nummi of Constantine I (AD 306-337) found near the foundation of the Tower of Pisa.

8een Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). 2 additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a 10-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.
Circa 300 denarii and 6 aurei were discovered on the Anselmi proprty. Today, are known only 20 denarii and 2 aurei: Republic - Augustus (29-27 BC).
1 silver stater and 13 bronze staters, reportedly found at Breakheart Bottom in 1991.
6 aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
1124 denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: 125 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 3 pieces belonged to Galba and 1 to Titus.

56 bronzes of Postumus. Only 26 were considered worth preserving. The coins were acquired by the musée de Douai under inventory no. 6271. The dating in AD 270-271 is based on the abbreviation PIAV (vonius), nomen of Victorinus, on 1 of the coins.

The hoard comprised 16 barbarous radiates, all of Tetricus I and Tericus II, and 3 fragments of a copper-alloy statue. They have been interpreted as the con10ts of a purse, although no traces of 1 were found.
A hoard of Roman denarii found with a ceramic vessel and spread in more lots. 121 coins are known: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 23357); Archaeological Museum, Warsaw, Poland (inv.no. 27); Gorodetsky Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (until 1917)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 2000 and 3000 coins. The hoard was immediately dispersed but contained at least 20 radiates of Gallienus and Postumus.
21 denarii: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 233-235).

Roman coin hoard: 9 3rd-4th century coins fused together. The coins have been burnt, with some charcoal adhering to the corrosion products. The coins are visible in 2 stacks, 1 of the stacks has considerably more damage due to burning. 4 coins are clearly visible in 1 stack, with 1 face exposed. No detail is visible on the exposed coin face - there is possibly a radiate crown, however this is uncertain due to the level of corrosion. The exposed coin has a diameter of 13.24mm. The amount of coins on the second stack is more difficult to assertain due to the fused and melted condition. This area appears to have 4 coins stacked on top of each other with corrosion products inbetween, a further coin joins the 2 stacks together. The remaining area of corrosion contains fragments of coins, however due to the burnt condition it is unclear whether these are part of the coins listed above, or are additional coins. It weighs 12.74 grams.
49 solidi found with a lead vessel: Valentinian III (Galla Placidia) - Zeno (AD 474-491); gold w8: 218.05g. Found with orfevery artefacts.

3 denarii found a little distance away from 10 later denarii dating to around AD 198-201. The earliest coin is a Roman Republican denarius dating to 49 BC. Whilst these are commonly found in hoards dating up to the early second century, they would not be expected to be found in a hoard this late. It is therefore suggested that the 3 coins up to AD 69 should be considered as a separate deposit (hoard A).
A scattered hoard of 23 radiates (Salonina to Victorinus) found within the remains of an enclosed Romano-British farmstead.
Unknown initial number of coins. 5 nummi kept in a private collection: Valentinian I - Valens (AD 367-375).

The hoard was found in 2 ceramic vessels hidden under some large st1s. It comprised more than 8500 bronze coins of which 7978 (Hucher) or 8117 (Lallemand) radiates and copies were identified. Callu estimated that 5.2% of the coins were imitations. The hoard was found during st1 quarrying under some large st1s: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver w8: 1517.4-14518.3
c. 200 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 'Probably a whole hoard, offered for sale in Belgium.'
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.
56 gold and silver coins., 15 coins were recovered: Augustus, Tiberius, Gaius and Claudius I (AD 44).
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (14 coins, in 1845).

summary: The hoard was found in 1906 after a farmer discovered some coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus and Claudius II at the same findspot where 2 years previously 100 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus and Tetricus I and II had been found. As a result, Vigneron-Jousselandière excavated the findspot, discovering 7 silver ligula and a ceramic vessel containing approximately 3500 antoniniani (radiates). At the middle of the vessel was a radiate of Philip I, 39 worn denarii, 1 aureus of Postumus and a gold finger ring. The ligulae or spoons, the finger ring, the denarii, the aureus of Postumus and 450 radiates were acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. Vigneron-Jousselandière possessed 2651 radiates (in 1907).
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.

Unknown originally number of coins found with a linen or leather bag placed in a bronze vessel. Only 12 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Aurelian - Carus/Carinus (AD 283-285). Probably, part of the hoard VALHASCOS 1880-1890.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: Unknown initial number number of coins. T. Gerasimov mentions 12 silver coins: 3 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.

A hoard of 1985 denarii (Nero-Julia Mamaea); 310 drachms of Arabia (242 of which depict Arabia and 68 show a camel, some overstruck on Nabataean kings); 1 Caesarean drachm (Domitian); 31 tetradrachms of Antioch (Nero-Hadrian); 2 Lycian drachms (Trajan); 2 Amisus drachms (Hadrian), found in a village near Amman.
disposition: American Numismatic Society (2333, 2321 of which are still listed in ANS records), American University in Beirut (17)

summary: 3 denarii: C. Cornelius Blasio, Gargonius/Ogulnius/Vergilius and Vespasian, found near the protestant cemetery. Uncertain whether the coins were found together.
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca (inv. nos. 63–1906)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 'approximately 300 coins dating to the 3rd century AD, not otherwise described' (TAF).
61 coins found during fieldwalking and research at the place: 59 antoniniani, 2 denarii: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).
15 nummi found as a heap: Constantius II - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-403).
1 multiple of 3 aurei Carinus for Magnia Urbica; 1 silver medallion Valerian I and Gallienus for Valerian II (Caesar).
5 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.

Various parcels of coins started to appear on the market in late 1996, allegedly from Great Waltham or Great Dunmow. These included groups of worn Gallo-Belgic A staters and quarter staters, along with a significant quantity of British A staters including previously unrecorded varieties. A parcel of 10 staters (consisting of 7 ABC 2430, 2 ABC 2424 and 1 ABC 2427), said to have been found at Great Waltham in August 1998, was declared and reported in TAR 1997-98, 26 no. 110.

A hoard of approx. 400 Roman Imperial denarii from 1st-2nd AD and other late Roman – early Great Migration period silver, bronze and gold items were found by a treasure hunter at the end of July 2021 and then its photos were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters Violity. According to the finder, the coins and items were found together. 4 gold pelta-shaped pendants with zoomorphic ornaments, 4 gold leaf-shaped pendants (same type from Brangstrup hoard, Denmark), 24 silver temporal rings, 3 silver axe-shaped pendants with rings, silver shield-shaped pendant, 5 different types of plate pendants, plough-shaped pendant with ring, silver neck ring, silver and bronze buckle, fragments of silver brooch (?), and others.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver w8: 198.8-366.5 g.
Hoard of 5 kilos of coins (c. 16.500 coins), among 2 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - House of Theodosius (AD 388-423).
10 nummi found near a "crumbling piece of fabric": Constantius II 5, Julian II (Caesar) 3, Valentinian I 1, Valens I (AD 367-375).
The hoard comprised more than 1755 silver tetradrachms and 2 weighed lumps (20.646 kg and 578.48 g-approximately 40 coins) dating to the early first century BC.
25 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 23 republican denarii, 1 denarius Augustus, 1 drachm Archaelaus IV of Cappadocia.

A hoard of 7 aurei, 95 denarii, 206 antoniniani, together with 14 others (1 denarius and 13 antoniniani) which were reported as from the same hoard, all found on the Sully Moors by a labourer digging building foundations. 2 of the antoniniani of Trajan Decius were overstruck on denarii of Geta and Maximinus. 1 of the gold coins of Diocletian was a double aureus. The number of extra coins reported as having belonged to the hoard was given as 15, but only 14 were listed.
disposition: British Museum (gold rings; 5 of the gold coins); 297 coins in NMW, Cardiff

summary: 63 denarii foud by metal detecting: 53 republican, 6 serrati, 1 imitation, 3 augustan denarii (19 BC).
103 denarii, among which 1 imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).
3 staters of Armorican type found on the same beach over a period of time.
315 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2319/1-315

summary: 7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
6 denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
357 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 97.4-445.3 g.
disposition: Collezioni Governative del Medagliere Milanese, Italy (in 1923).

summary: A hoard of 480 Icenian gold and silver coins and Roman denarii found near the middle of the Roman Field on the eastern outskirts of the 4th-century settlement in 1959. The pot is a butt beaker with a pedestal base, 8¼ in. high. Externally and internally the colour is a sandy brown with a dark fabric. Horizontal grooves frame faint vertical combings between these lines. This form is frequently found at Colchester and is regarded as pre-invasion in date.

A hoard of 23 copper coins, all of which appear to be Assur Class 3 (SC imitative coinage, blank obverse and inverted SC on reverse). Only 2 coins are preserved today, but the other were photographed. They were found on the floor of House Y (north of the palace) and could have constituted a purse at the moment of the Sasanian conquest.
Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani were found in unknown circumstances. 18 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
A hoard of Gallo-Belgic coins found on the beach at Clacton in 1898, the bulk of which was in the Evans collection.

212 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); gold w8: 724.3-734.3g. The archives of the Cabinet des Médailles preserve the list of 102 aurei sent by the in10dant Lescalopier and the register 48 bis, of the same Cabinet allows identifying 22 pieces on the lot of 110 addressed by the bishop and the chapter of Troyes to Cardinal Fleury to be presented to the King. Research carried out in the Marne and Aube archives by MM. Gandilbon and Waquet, unfortunately, did not reveal the full list of the 110 pieces.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised at least 1183 radiates from Gordian III to Saloninus with a tpq. of AD 260.

A hoard of 10 Roman coins, found within a vessel (not preserved), found in the village of Kry1ri (close to Kavala): 7 late Roman coins and 2 provincial 1s from Philippi (from the time of Nero or Claudius: AMNG III,2, pl. XX, 10, RPC I, 1651).
A large quantity of nummi of the Constantinian period was found on Fleischstrasse. Uncertain whether it belongs to a destroyed hoard.
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 7.9-46.6 g.
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver w8: 203.3-1735.5g.
2500-3000 denarii. 250 pieces were bought by the National Museum in Sofia: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A hoard comprising 25000 coins including coins dating from the reign of Gallienus through to Diocletian.
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.
135 sestertii found in a cooking pot covered by a plate: Domitian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).
7 denarii, 1 sestertius, and 2 asses (Republic to Trajan) found together beneath the concrete floor of the room in a charcoal layer contemporary with the initial timber structure.
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: A gold solidus of Valentinian I and 2 of Valens found 2½ miles S.E. of Melton-Mowbray, by a labouring man employed in working the st1 of the country, together with 2 small brass coins, 1 of which is indecipherable, and the other is of the Emperor Allectus.
The hoard was found in "Perron" locality, in a vase. It comprised 1200 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Hoard of 58 denarii: 34 republican denarii, 24 imperial denarii: Republic - Augustus (9-8 BC).
A small hoard of 8 (?) gold British Iron Age coins found at Yarmouth, in the Isle of Wight in 1867.
Hoard of 152 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus (15-3 BC).

306 coins: 255 antoniniani (radiates), 50 denarii, 1 sestertius: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together, were found jewelry: 2 silver rings, 1 pair of gold earrings and 1 gold children’s earring.

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
2 lots of nummi (49, 35). No further information. Unpublished.
An urn of antoniniani (radiates) found between Sizzano and Fara. Only 2 coins are known of Philip I and Claudius II, as being donated to the museum in Fara.
disposition: Museo dal Sig. Luigi Spagnolini di Fara (on the May 10, 1886; donation record no. 723 (3)

summary: 9 coins, all contemporary types dating to AD 330s with no copies, frags. of poss. 2 more coins present. Found within small irregular pit 1029, prob. placed in a wooden bucket, as there were also 2 iron hoops. Coins within arc of the 2 hoops, which were both at same h8, plus a conc. some frags. of copper alloy sheet & iron, poss. from a stud.

29 imperial denarii (Augustus to Vespasian), 30 uncertain denarii and 163 uncertain bronze coins found with silver tableware in regio VI, insula 7, cubiculum south of Tuscan atrium of building 20 (house).
17 bronze coins (Constantine I - sons of Constantine) found in Hauen, on the Pilsum-Greetsiel road, during gardening works in a flower bed. The coins were strewn on a surface of 3 x 5m in 2 places.
Over 30000 coins - 50 kilos - found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius II - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
1008 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
2 solidi of Leo I (AD 462-466). Probably, a much larger hoard as there was some information on more solidi found by locals at the same site in the previous years.
The hoard was found near "domaine des Colliers". It comprised 61 nummi coins from the First Tetrachy to Constantine I (AD 306-337). Only 54 are now recorded.
The hoard comprised 525 nummi from the House of Constantine.

A 4th century gold hoard which was sold on the art market in 1970. 390 solidi and a gold necklace of 5 pendants and 6 spacers (only 4 are known) and clasp; and a gold bracelet (559 g): Constantius II - Theodosius I (AD 388). These are assumed to have been found in Sidi Bu Saïd.
disposition: Cleveland Museum of Art, USA (octagonal pendant, 6 spacers); Dumbarton Oaks, Byzantine Collection, USA (1 hexangonal pendant, 1 circular pendant); The British Museum, London, UK (1 hexagonal pendant); Louvre Museum, Paris, France (1 circular pendant)

summary: A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain.
