Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are menti1d. About 50 of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The 3 last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.

In 1981 a hoard of 159 Antoniniani of the last third of the third century (Gallienus - Diocletian, and Gallic Empire) was unearthed during excavations of the Institute for Pre- and Early history of the University of Johannes Gu10berg at Mainz. The hoard was found in a cellar.
List of coins, from the Roman-Germanic Museum in Köln, not yet registered with the museum, coming from the hoard on Stephan street..
Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: 15 AE to AD 195.
"A probably small scattered Valentinianic hoard of 10 coins was found in Mound 1" (Minnitt 2007, 731). See report by Minnitt in Somerset Levels Papers 13, 1987.
Hoard of circa 100 denarii. 18 coins were documented: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192). W8: 29.86.

3044 coins: 3029 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii, 1 provincial coin: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 274-275). "The bulk of the hoard was formed in 273; several pieces, if not intrusions, were added in 285." (Harl, 79, n. 11).
9 nummi found in a sandpit: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 388-393).
A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
Around 60-80 kilos of coins found in 2 vessels. 2830 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 99 solidi, dated between AD 344-351 and AD 395-402, placed within a millst1.

The hoard comprised 100 coins 'une centaine'. Gricourt only saw 3 coins from the find. They were antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip and Herennia Etruscilla. A pharmacist from Somain discovered the hoard which was immediately dispersed.

3 Roman gold coins and jewellery, found at Sweetbriar Road petrol station, while digging hole for storage tank. Information via A Gregory (Norfolk Archaeological Unit) but material not seen at Norwich Castle Museum.
76 silver coins: 54 denarii, 22 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found during landscaping and construction work at the 10nis Club, Cherchell.

14 bronze provincial coins from Antioch in a st1 mug: Domitian - Trajan. The mug was purchased at the market (!). Said to be from Bethany, but seems more like a hoard from northern Syria, according to Butcher.
NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late 9teenth century.

The hoard comprised several hundred coins of which only 150 were catalogued. They included a dupondius of Marcus Aurelius, a denarius of Plautilla, a few denarii and radiates of Caracalla, Geta, Elagabalus and Maximinus, numerous radiates of Gordian III, as well as Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Aemilian, Valerian I and II, Saloninus, Salonina, numerous examples of Gallienus, and some of Postumus.
74 nummi: Diocletian - Constantine I (AD 313-317).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing several hundred bronze coins from Trajan to Antoninus Pius.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
This appears to be part of a larger hoard and should not be confused with other hoards from Bavay which were composed of bronze issues. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 10.5-82.7g.
1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.

Unknown initial number of coins. The hoard comprised 1068 denarii and 2 asses dating from Nero to Balbinus and Pupienus with a tpq of AD 239. The hoard has a silver w8 of between 1496.9g and 3341.1 g.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
Over 1500 coins were discovered at the Roman villa. Only 790 antoniniani (radiates) were studied: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
18 coins found while digging the foundation for a new house: Q. Minucius Thermus – Gratian (AD 375-383). The republican denarius may be an intruder!
circa 1500 bronze coins of the Late Empire found in amphora. No further information
16 antoniniani (radiates) found together buried in an unpafved floor of 1 of the rooms of the Roman villa: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).
disposition: Laboratório de Conservação e Restauro (Direcção Regional da Cultura do Alentejo), Portugal

summary: 53 large Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii?): Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A group of 9 copper alloy Flavian coins found together during the excavation by Surrey Archaeological Society of a new circular temple a short distance from square temple complex robbed for several years by metal detectorists. The group was found "just within the wall line of the Phase 4 temple and within" it (context 48) (Williams 2007, 171). The temple was fully excavated. In his report on the Roman coins, Abdy (ibid. p.228) notes that "the 2 Domitianic asses are of the AD 86-7 shipment" and the hoard is therefore likely to be later than this.Other coins from the excavation are likely to be part of the same dispersed depositional activity on the site covered by record IARCH-ABD376Interim note: Howe, T., Jackson, G., Mal1y, C. & Saich, D. 2000. Archaeology in Surrey 1998-9. Surrey Arch. Coll. 87: 185.

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
Discovered at a place with Roman structures. Some doubts whether it is actually a hoard. 8 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Aureus of Trajan Decius found together with and a denarius imitation.

The hoard comprised a greyware cup containing between 8000 and 9000 nummi of the House of Constantine. They include GLORIA EXERCITVS nummi of Constantius II as Caesar and VRBS ROMA and CONSTANTINOPOLIS issues. The mints of Trier and Lyon are menti1d.
Hoard of 1000 nummi (AE4). No further information.
1385 coins: sestertii, dupondi, asses, 1 semis, 1 triens, 4 quadrante, 1 sextans, 1 bronze of Ptolemy II, 1 bronze minted at Amestratus (Mistretta) up to Vespasian (AD 78).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Italy

summary: A group of 14 Roman provincial bronzes of Pontic cities (Zela, Amasia, Comana, Sebastopolis), now in the Ankara museum, and judging from its composition, probably found nearby Zela. All coins were minted in the year 205/206, under Septimius Severus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 5.3-26.2 g.
Uknown number of coins. Coins documented: Gallienus 1, 7 nummi: Gratian, Valentinian II, Magnus Maximus, Theodosius, Arcadius, Honorius.
54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
`3 aurei and 1 other' seen in ca. 1935
53 denarii (mostly Republican, up to Tiberius), found in a small earthenware container on Mathildenterrasse (now Kupferbergterrasse).
40 asses and sestertii. 18 coins entered the collection Gerville: 1 Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius, 16 Postumus.

A scattered hoard of at least 409 coins (and up to 488) found in a layer of rubbly dark soil (context 4030) above in situ deposits of aisled Building 12 in the Dorset County Hospital / Hascombe Court excavations of 2001-2002.
Hoard of 13 silver coins found by chance: 12 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Septimius Severus, all minted in Caesarea Cappadociae.
758 imperial and provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 42288-46046

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. G. Dembski expresses his doubts about the cois issued before the reform of AD 348 being part of the hoard: Antoninus Pius - Gratian (AD 367-383).

The hoard comprised 71 Iron Age coins and 1 obol from Massalia. It was characterised as 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.859/1 to 72

The coins came into view in section A-B in a 30cm deep destroyed layer of the used stratum of the residential house, north of the Mithraeum. Not only the find circumstances, but also the collocation suggests a small hoard find.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn, Germany (inv. no. F 8125a)

summary: IARCH record for a fused lump of denarii, of which 3 could be identified as issues of Severus Alexander, The others (3 and a fragment) could not be identified due to the condition of the coins. Possibly burnt as they are deformed into a fused mass (total wt. = 14.01g).For further details and images see YORYM-6C737B
980 antoniniani (radiates) found in 2 lots, in 1962, 1980, in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 272).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Bibliotheque Nationale de France, Paris

summary: De Jersey described the circumstances of recovery of hoards B and C, which became mixed prior to recording. It is therefore uncertain which coins were associated with the torcs (here attached to hoard B) and buried in a box or boxes. Initially identified as 116 coins, the hoard has been subject to reexamination by D Holman, who has increased the minimum number of coins to 155 by joining fragments (PAS).
19 nummi found in a storage room in east of the Neon Library: House of Valentinian - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402).
(102) 101 silver coins: 24 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 131.2-264.8 g.
68 coins: 7 aurei, 14 republican denarii, 2 republican asses, 11 imperial asses, 33 bronzes of Paestum: Republic - Vespasian (AD 69-79). Found together with gems and other artefacts.
65 Iron Age Chute staters, found in a flint module in 1927.
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 10 denarii of Augustus 'of the same type' (2 BC - AD 11) were found during military diggings. They entered the private collection of I.I. Fediya.
A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
5 aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.
102 coins: 80 antoniniani, 22 denari: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 'several hundred', '75kg' or 'approximately 3000 sestertii from Domitian to Maximinus I Thrax. The entire hoard was quickly dispersed.
Unknown number of silver coins. 3 of them are kept in the Museum of Cultural History Stralsund: Antoninus Pius denarius, Philip I antoniniani (radiates) (AD 248).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (3 coins)

summary: 1 Iron age silver stater, 2 miliarenses, 82 siliquae and 1 unidentified bronze coin to AD 402 together with pot fragments and 3 sheets of rolled lead. The Iron Age silver stater (uninscribed South-Western Durotriges) and the bronze coin are probably a stray finds.
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: 12 late Roman coins found during archaeological excavations: Constantius II - Theodosius I (AD 335-388).
The hoard comprised 30 electrum staters.
67 silver coins: 63 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Direction des antiquités historiques, Paris, France

summary: 18 silver coins found in a small ceramic beaker: 5 republican denarii, 2 imperial denarii, 6 republican quinarii, 5 imperial quinarii (1 plated): Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 12).
A small hoard recorded only by Chadburn (2006, Appendix H, hoard 4), combining normal face/horse units with 1 ANTED unit. No further details of the discovery are known.

A hoard of 15000 - 20000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: Building in the garden of 22 Crouch Street excav in 1935. Opposite S end of an apsidal ended building was a pit 6-7 ft. deep, 3 ft in diameter. Remains of wood at bottom showed it had been shuttered to hold back soft sand. It was most probably a well, though there was no peaty sludge at bottom. The con10ts of the pit were remarkable. Scattered throughout filling, but with earliest examples near bottom, were c. 132 coins of Trajan to Theodosius, plus 39 barbarous issues. Hull (1958, 246) considered these votive deposits in a well, as they were spread throughout fill, but with earliest near bottom. There was also a human skull & thigh b1, a silver ring & a silver armlet, iron stylus, knife, bowl & nails, painted wall plaster, a piece of marble, pottery frags. incl. fine wares, & bird b1s.
102 coins: 5 antoniniani, 23 sestertii, 74 bronze (sestertii?): Domitian - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 4.0-12.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Bruxelles, Belgium (102 coins)

summary: Although only 40 aurei are known, there is evidence that originally there were more, including aurei of the emperors Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Hadrian and Septimius Severus (Mira 1997, 121). Gold w8: 313.1-340.4g.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 34 nummi: Diocletian - Arcadius (297-402).
18 coins, antoniniani (radiates) and nummi found lying together.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn, Germany (inv. no. F 7953a)

summary: Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).

The hoard comprised 100 bronze Iron Age coins. Some 'moins frustes' were acquired by the Musée de Châteaubriant. A silver alloy stater was found at the same findspot by a child in May 1926 and is likely to be part of the same hoard. The hoard was found under a chestnut tree in a quarry.
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).

A Roman hoard was found and dispersed, in recent years in Nembro. Some bronze coins of the 3rd century were seen. It is an Antoninianus (radiate) from Salamina (sic!) and dupondii of Claudius II and Aurelian (determination of E. Arslan). Soprin10denza Archeologica della Lombardia (7 coins).
The hoard comprised 50 aurei dating to the reign of Nero and Vespasian. Only 2 coins are known are the moment.
2 medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were 7 bronze tintinnabula, 1 patera, and 2 iron objects.
A hoard of 628 denarii (Republic- Domitian, including 1 Juba I), found in a jar by metal-detector users at a commercial rally on ploughed land in the parish of Askerswell, West Dorset.
6.7 kg of antoniniani, of which 2125 pieces entered the museums in Sofia and Vidin: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1079 (1990 coins); National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 8130-8264; 8679-8696 (153 coins)

summary: A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during 6 trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The hoard comprised 9 coins from the Roman period.
1267 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Trajan to Philip I (AD 247-248) found with 2 ceramic vessels.
A hoard of 30 AR Cappadocian drachms of Ariarathanes IV to Ariarathanes X and 1 drachm of Alexander I Balas found before 1994.
Roman provincial bronzes of Celsa, Turiaso, Calagurris, Cascantum and Graccurris. Age Augustan-Tiberian.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 2 denarii to Augustus
Hoard of 96 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
(500-600) 142 denarii: Vespasian - Balbinus (AD 238); silver w8: 771.6-1621.0 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coin); collection L. Renard-Grenson (113 coins), Liège, Belgium; private collection (22 coins).

summary: 21 kilos (c. 70000 coins): Aurelian - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-423).

Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).
350 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only coin of Julia Maesa is known.
The hoard comprised a large ceramic vessel containing 14 first and second century AD coins.
During the construction of a spinning factory in 1852 a hoard consisting of gold and silver coins, ranging from Nero to Severus Alexander, was unearthed. Only 27 specimens were documented.
2 solidi in the name of Anastasius (AD 491-518) found on the same field; gold w8: 8.78 g.
4 coins of which 1 provincial bronze 1 of Caracalla.
18 nummi of Valentinian I and 2 crossbow bronze brooches were found together in a courtyard (AD 364-375).
32 silver and provincial bronze coins: 5 antoniniani, 12 denarii, 15 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 26.1-38 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIX

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL I
summary: A person found a large hoard in 1895 during excavation works for a new parish office on the north side of Marienplatz, next to a dismantled corner house, on a bricked road at the parish house of St. Maria im Kapitol. The coins were situated partly in several amphorae, part in a wooden cask from molded wood remains, and there were also rings. The coins were oxidized together in a large clump. Immediately after the discovery of the hoard the coins were acquired by a museum. The record identifies 600 Roman specimens from St. Maria im Kapitol purchased in 1895 by S. Job. The museum must have acquired altogether approx. 628 specimens.

In 1837, 143 denarii and antoniniani were found on a field (Mühlen) next to the lime kiln, during excavation of an old boundary st1. No trace of a container was seen. Of these 143 coins, only 32 (Tiberius - Severus Alexander) have been described.
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Hadrianopolis found in the dirt when digging a sewer: Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 618, 624, 628, 632, 635, 639, 642, 645, 648, 654, 657, 684, 694

summary: Bizeul described 5 antoniniani (radiates) found in Quénet which may be part of a larger hoard or perhaps the con10ts of a purse.

In October 1987 members of the Andover Metal Detecting Club found 142 staters in 2 distinct clusters, approximately 55 m apart, 1 containing 58 coins and the other 84 (Haselgrove 1989, 13, 14). Each hoard - and it seems almost certain to be 2 separate deposits, rather than a scattered single hoard - contained a mixture of Gallo-Belgic E and British B (Chute) staters.
disposition: Museum of the Iron Age, Andover (part); Unknown (part)

summary: The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 or 3 ceramic urns filled with Roman coins, weighing approximately 5 kilos or perhaps 1200 coins. Although the containers were broken up and the hoard dispersed, 762 coins were recovered in the days following the hoard's discovery, including 10 from the presumed findspot. They were all radiates from Gordian III to Claudius II and Postumus.
A hoard of 78 Roman silver coins (Vespasian - Commodus, Constantius II, and Julian, some of which were imitations), found in a pot in a garden in Laatzen.
A hoard of 23 late Roman coins (Constantius II to Gratian), found during the excavations of the Roman road fort (Straßenburgus).

126 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (Aelia Flacilla) (AD 379-386) Mints: Londinium 1, Treveri 39, Lugdunum 13, Arelate 7, Aquileia 1, Roma 6, Heraclea 2, Constantinopolis 3, Alexandria 2, unidentified 28.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (126 coins)

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 25 pieces are known: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: 44 late Roman nummi (Constantius II to Theodosius I) and 1 local 3rd c. Palmyrene coin, found in the cella of the temple of Allat in a broken vessel that had been thrown on the floor with fragments of the cult statue found immediately above it. This hoard has been interpreted as an offering dating from the time preceding the destruction of the temple under Theodosius I.
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.

Bean (2000, 279 no. 33) provides the only published account of this undeclared find, made in the autumn of 1991 and initially said to have come from Hatfield in Hertfordshire, but subsequently relocated to "near Reading". He suggests that it contained c.90 coins, almost all of Verica.
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 34 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus; Silver w8: 33.8g.

HER record of 5 clipped siliquae "and some copper alloy coins" found at a rally in 1993 and noted as a possible hoard. This hoard does not seem to have been recorded elsewere from the limited information available.

When the new construction of Hofscheuer, Südallee 73, was created in 1900 a person noticed a Roman brick wall of large size. Whether this part - maybe the other specimens - originally belonged to a hoard find cannot be further ascertained. Inventory entries 00152a-c read: a) 129 small bronzes, very poorly preserved and not identifiable in their present condition, but appear to be largely of the Valentinian period. 20 pieces are available. b) 26 smaller bronzes of the Valentinian period with the reverse Securitas rei publicae and a Victoria running to the left. 25 pieces are available. c) 30 small bronzes of the Valentinian period with the reverse Gloria romanorum, depicting the emperor oppressing a barbarian. All preserved.
Over 200 solidi found with a small red ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were recovered: Gratian - Honorius (AD 393-395)
disposition: The National History Museum of Moldova, Kishinev (13 coins) - 1952

summary: The coins were found in the Danube in a ford between Scheer and Ennetach.
370 coins: 12 denarii, 358 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
142 bronze coins (sestertii, antoniniani?): Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver w8: 27.9-59.7g.
3 radiates and 1263 nummi to AD 293 - AD 317
Unknown initial number of coins. 81 antoniniani (radiates) are available: Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 18.5-80.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. XVII, XXXIV; History Museum, Sliven, Bulgaria (3 coins); History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1066 /0-12/

summary: Around 1910 a hoard with 423 Antoniniani was salvaged during excavation of a building pit. The find spot ('auf den Kästrich') could not be further circumscribed, so that it is uncertain whether the deposit was found inside or outside of the legionary camp. The find is said to have been found with leather remnants in an earthenware container.
The hoard comprised 40 coins of Tetricus I and II and were found alongside a toilet set, a glass vessel and a necklace in a female tomb dating to the first quarter of the 4th century AD.

A hoard of 331+ coins (324 post-Diocletianic reform nummi, 1 Aurelian radiate, 6 Roman provincial coins) found in Verroia. These 331 coins are only a minor part of the total hoard, estimated between 1/3 to 1/5. The hoard was split for sale by antiquities dealers.
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 78.0-122.8 g.
3 kilograms of coins. 154 entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 28.3-191.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1118-1133

summary: Over 1100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 720 coins are kept in the National History Museum in Budapest, Hungary: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: National History Museum, Budapest, Hungary (720 coins)

summary: (c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
Unknown initial number of coins. 815 silver coins found with a metal bucket: Julia Domna to Philip I; silver w8: 1019.3-2117.9g
disposition: National History of Antiquities Bucharest, Romania (815 coins) - 1886

summary: 129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
16 denarii: Republic – Augustus (12 BC).
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation, Deva, Romania (inv.nos. 11892-11907)

summary: Uknown originally number of coins. 854 pieces were recovered: Nero - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de La Rioja, Spain

summary: 27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.
797 silver coins: 641 denarii, 156 antoniniani (radiates): Vitellius - Philip I (AD 244-245).
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver w8: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
9 asses of Augustus (16 BC-AD 14).
C. Hipolito stated that the hoard contained 100 bronzes. The 5 asses of Claudius I and the dupondius of Claudius I for Antonia are the only 1 recorded.
c. 120-150 aurei: Julius Caesar - Domitian (AD 81-96).
38 nummi found burned and solded. 3 nummi seem to belong to Constantine I, 1 of them possible of Constantine II (Caesar).
(300) 229 coins: 1 sestertius, 228 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 64.2-669.9 g.
Hoard of circa 20 coins. Only 2 Republican denarii of C. Rennius were recovered.
62 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253).

The hoard comprised a black or greyware vessel containing 114 electrum staters (Collin and Aubin give a total of 170). 60 of the coins were studied by Dain in 1971. The hoard was discovered at eye level in small niche in a wall, while trying to create a window in the wall.
The hoard comprised at least 12 Tyrian Shekels (126/125 BC- AD 69/70) and shekels of the First Jewish Revolt.
disposition: A. Reifenberg, on loan to the Israel Museum

summary: 18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(5-6 kg) 2000 coins. Identified 341 silver coins: 1 denarius, 340 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 259); silver w8: 2500.2 - 4759.1 g+.
disposition: Archeological Museum Zagreb (?980 coins); P. Broz collection Zagreb (83 coins), Croatia; dispersed - 1981

summary: 600 imperial and provincial bronzes found in a ceramic vessel during excavation work. Dr. Harlanov has examined 384 pieces: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.
The hoard was found under a large st1 and comprised 'a certain number of bronze coins' dating to the late third and 4th century AD.
Few hundreds denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Only 16 pieces recovered: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver w8: 28.8-66.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2146-2154

summary: The hoard comprised 21 Iron Age coins and 4 obols from Massalia. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.679 to 76.701
The hoard comprised approximately 1200 nummi of Maximian I and Constantius I Chlorus. The hoard was found in a fissure in the rock in a quarry when a worker broke off a block of st1.
(54) 21 coins mixture of silver and bronze denominations: Caracalla - Constantine I (AD 324-326).
(c. 2898) 1902 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6406 - M IV 7503 (1098 coins); M IV 7507-8345 (839); History Museum, Vratsa; inv.nos. 8750-8839

summary: The hoard comprised between 1400 and 1500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
(c.3.500-5000) 61 antoniniani: Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 721.1-4999.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (2 kg), including the ceramic vessel

summary: 16 provincial bronze coins minted in Bizya: Geta 1, 15 Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (11 coins)

summary: 3 AR, 85 AE. Some foundation deposits under floor of piscina from the reconstruction and enlargement of Sarapeum.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 90 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2145-2230

summary: Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: 25 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Maximianus I (AD 285-286); silver w8: 4.6-6.8g.
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
A hoard of 1545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.
Circa 2000 coins, only 3 known: 2 of Severus Alexander, 1 of Philip I
The hoard comprised at least 82 coins with a tpq of AD 434 to 435. No further information was given about the composition of the hoard.
The hoard comprised at least 39 electrum staters and 175 electrum quarter staters attributed to the Iron Age Amorican tribe Osismii.
201 solidi: Valentinian II - Valentinian III (AD 425-455). Together was found a fragment from a golden bracelet.
disposition: Hermitage, St. Petersburg, Russia (53 coins); collection I.I. Tolstoi (12 coins); University of Kharkov, Ukraine (34 coins); State Historical Museum, Moscow, Russia (102 solidi)

summary: Circa 150 silver coins. N. Moushmov studied 28: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The find consists of 10 late Roman bronze coins (Tetricus, and other Gallic emperors), found in the area of the 'Kulturhaus am Hexenturm'

6 coins found grouped on the chest area of an inhumation in the Butt Road Roman cemetery in Colchester (Grave 431, C1653). The coins are 3 Fel Temp FH copies and 3 Magnentian copies. Thought not to have been in a container due to pattern of scatter.
933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).
The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
52 silver coins: 51 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found with a ceramic jug: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver w8: 75.9-163.6g.
Possible hoard of 7 silver coins and 27 bronze coins. Late Republic - Philippus I (AD 247).

A hoard found in woodland area of Grunertshofener in 1943. The find consists of 17 denarii and 1 bronze coin, ranging from the Republic to Titus Caesar. The 16 specimens itemized in FMRD were submitted to the Prehistoric Collection of Munich.
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
19 coins of different bronze denominations scattered on an area of 20 sqcm: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
395 silver coins: 280 antoniniani, 115 denarii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
17 provincial bronze coins of Caracalla found in a ceramic vessel: Serdica 13, Deultum 2, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1.
The 6 antoniniani (radiates) were interpreted as representing a purse hoard or being part of a larger deposit.
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-54).
Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: The coins were found in a st1 sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.
The hoard comprised 2186 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and 'other emperors of the same century.'
Silted-up stream palaeochannel contained over 30 Iron Age coins, incl. gold stater of Tasciovanus.

The hoard comprised approximately 600 silver coins (denarii and radiates). The antoniniani (radiates) were described as being of 'large and medium module' according to Bocquillet. There were 38 different types from Commodus to Postumus Found during embankment works for the Château-l'Abbaye road.

IARCH record for a hoard of 8 milarenses and 45 siliquae found in 2 batches in 2014. For further details see GLO-9D7F36. The 9 uncertain siliquae are fragments.R. Abdy (unpublished catalogue) writes: "The latest coin is not fully legible but probably takes the hoard just into the joint reign of Honorius and Arcadius. If so this sole specimen would place Thruxton near the beginning of the sizable body of British siliqua hoards, which end with the period 395-402. Furthermore, the siliquae in this hoard are virtually unclipped ('clipping factor 1' just possible on 1 specimen) and this, together with the presence of miliarenses alongside the siliquae, supports an earlier date for the deposition of the hoard, before the AD 395-402 coinage had much chance to spread into the circulation."
2484 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in an underground room during excavations of a house.

The precise find location and circumstances of the find are unknown. The hoard is believed to have consisted of several kilos of bronze coins, covering the time from Postumus to Constantine I. Only a set of 274 antoniniani of Victorinus is known in details, which made it into the possession of R. Weiller.
2 iron age coins found together.
Unpublished hoard of 14 bronze coins of Augustus.
disposition: Formerly Archaeological Museum, Zadar, Croatia (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 72 Provincial bronzes, 70 of Gallienus from Lacedaemon, 1 of Septimius Severus from Gytheion and 1 of Caracalla from Mantineia.
9 asses of Augustus (AD 9-14).
A small group of staters of Verica and Tincomarus reportedly found together and recorded by a private collector in May 2005.
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
1103 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 296) found in a disintegrated cloth bag in an underground room during excavations of a house.
140 provincial bronze coins of Serdica, Marcianopolis, Odessoss, Nicopolis ad Istrum, Anchialus, Tomis and Pautalia. No further information.

A hoard of approximately 1000 coins, of which only 249 were identified by E. Tordeaux. The closing date for the hoard is based on the assumption that the coins seen were representative of the whole Silver: c.1000 (249) coins; silver w8: c.1250.6-2598.9g.
A small quantity of north-eastern coinage, possibly a hoard; the stater seems rather out of place.

The hoard comprised a plaque, a finger ring and some unstruck coin flans as well as 14 Republican denarii, Imperial denarii and some dupondii and asses. A dupondius or as of Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius was also found, but it is not clear whether it formed part of the hoard.
Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian found in a grave with a skeleton (AD 270-275).
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
14 Roman bronze coins and 1 autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 80 Roman coins were found in the soil of the basement of a house in Kronhofstraße during building works. Given the large chronological range of the coins (Republic to Late Empire!), this might be an assemblage of a modern collection rather than a hoard.
In 2005 a series of finds were reported to the PAS by the widow of the finder. Among them were 3 Iron Age staters which may have formed all or part of a hoard. No further detail is known.
27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

“Several hundred Roman coins”. Unearthed while building the Galle Face battery in 1887. “8 coins, some of the reign of Honorius, found on the Galle Face”, were purchased by the Colombo Museum (CAR Museum 1887). The identifiable coin types (based on Still 1907) Roman Empire: House of Constantine I: Gloria exercitus (1 standard); House of Theodosius I: salus reipublicae victory/captive); concordia augg; virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors).
1803 nummi: Galerius - Constantius II (AD 355-361)

Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.
It comprised c. 150 sestertii. 145 had been studied from Trajan to Gordian III.

A hoard of 745 coins of Bosporan kings, Teiranes, Theothorses, Rhadamasades and Rhescuporis VI (AD 276-323) was found within a courtyard of a domestic building. The coins were grouped in rolls, each of them was separately wrapped. Some of the coins present 'tamga' symbols.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprises 232 cast denarii: a rejected series of coins depicting emperors from Vespasian to Elagabalus with a tpq of AD 218-222 or soon after.
disposition: National Union Musem, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 7438-7673)

summary: 1204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: 38 denarii: Republic - Augustus ( 15-13 BC).
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
25 Roman coins of the "Anto9s". Considered as possible funerary offering. No further details.
17 bronze coins in a glass container: Antoninus Pius, Constantine I.
It comprised 613 nummi, possible to have been found in 2 ceramic vessels.
44 denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Found together with a silver brooch dated between the end of the 4th century beginning of the 5th century AD.
Group of nummi: Constantine I (Crispus Caesar) - Valentinian I/Valentinian II (AD 364-392).
22 antoniniani were discovered during archaeological excavations in 1 room: Trajan Decius - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

The hoard 'comprised 80 gold coins dating to the 4th or fifth centuries AD. A later find in 1861, apparently in the same spot, located another 18 solidi, mixed with Medieval florins' The coins were discovered on 2 occasions. In 1844 (or 1846) 80 gold coins were discovered after a landslide near the Customs post. In 1861, a further 18 solidi were found, apparently at the same spot. Gold w8: c.404.95g
disposition: Musée de Dieppe, France (three coins, stolenin 1904)

summary: In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).
53 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 156-157).
disposition: Zemaljski muzej Bosne i Hercegovine (National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Sarajevo (32 coins) - 1981

summary: The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.

Found by labourers while ploughing a field near Ibikon. The hoard consisted of 10 silver coins and 169 aes coins, in a pot. The writ10 sources name Maximinus Thrax as latest reign represented. Today only 44 aes coins are preserved: 33 coins in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, and 11 coins in the Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich. The latest coin preserved dates from Commodus (SFI 1707-5.1) Another 12 coins, now in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, might be part of the same hoard (SFI 1707-5.2). The latest coin of this lot dates from Gordian III.
disposition: Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug; Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich

summary: Around 100 gold coins of Constantine I/Constantius II and the House of Valentinian were found in the river Moselle. In the Moselle Towards the end of April 1958, having taken gravel from the bed of the Moselle between Ahn and Machtum, a dredger belonging to the company Hein de Machtum, brought in his load many currencies of Roman gold. They are pieces of: 321 1/2, 1 and 1/2 solidi, struck almost exclusively by the effigies of the emperors Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian, and preserved at the corner of the coin. The coins were discovered scattered in the gravel, especially on the site of the aforementi1d company located at the place called "Kommert" near Machtum and the depot of the Bridges and Chaussees located at a place called "Banzelt" near Roodt / Syr , where a truck had deposited 2 loads of this "enriched" gravel. Several pieces, especially the multiples, had more or less suffered from their passage through the crusher. No trace of a vessel was found, nor any piece of silver or bronze. It is impossible to estimate accurately the number of pieces found, but the information available to us suggests that it must have been more than a hundred. Coins entered private collections or were sold abroad. 2 pieces were acquired by the Cabinet of Medals of the Museum of History and Art, Luxbg. (Nos 24 and 29). The absence in this treasure of the coinage of Valentinian II, raised to the rank of Auguste on November 22, 375, and associated with his half-brother Gratien in the government of the western part of the empire, is explained by the fact by Pearce, that Valentinian II does not take part in the first emulation of the period 375-378, of which date the most recent pieces of the treasure. Among the solidi and multiples are several unpublished pieces and some minor variations. This treasure, flowing with a ship from Treves, represents, in our opinion, some of the donativa lavished by Gratien on the occasion of the sumptuous fetes celebrated during his decennalia (376/377).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1993-200; private collection

summary: During excavations of an enclosure by the Museum of London, a group of 7 barbarous minims were found in a pit. Another pit contained a possible metalwork hoard. (Information from HER).
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
Unknown initial number of coins. 86 silver coins seen: 58 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 117.6-231 g.

The hoard comprised 9 gold coins: 1 multiple of 6 1/2 aurei, 8 aurei: Trajan (Plotina) - Florian (AD 276). Together were found jewelry: small gold male bust, 3 old bracelets, 3 gold armillae, rolled gold band, jet (or black glass paste) bracelet, black material bracelet, 6 small jet (or black glass paste) pieces, bronze pin.

A hoard of at least 24 gold and silver coins from the time of Constantine was found during repair work on the entrenchment by the Neutor city gate in 1635. This city gate was located at the end of Neustrasse, before being destroyed in 1877.
Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).
25 bronze coins: 3 antoniniani (radiates), 22 nummi: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Caracalla Augustus) – Theodosius I (Arcadius Augustus) (AD 388-395). Some of the coins may be intruders.
disposition: Regional Museum, Hradec Králové, Czech Republic (inv.no. N 3685-3709)

summary: A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have 1 fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's con10ts.

The hoard comprised a black pot containing between 500 and 600 Iron Age coins and approximately 120 Republican coins. The most frequent legends on the Iron Age coins were ABVDOS, ANDECOMBO, ANORBO/DVBNO, ATISIOS, ARIVOS/SANTONOS, AVLIRCO, ATEVLA/VLATOS, Q.DOCI SAMF, DVBNOCOV/DVBNOREX, DURAT/IVLIOS, DVRNACVS (?), EPAD, LITA, MEDIOMA, NINNO, COIOS/ORCETIRIX, POTTINA, SOLIMA, TOGI/TOCIR, TVRONOS, VIIPOTAL The hoard was found in a field east of the village of La Jante.
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 2000 coins from Probus to Gratian. Unfortunately, the exact composition of the hoard is not known.

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which 2 imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of 1 massive silver buckle for a sword belt and 2 buckles for a girdle. The find also contains 8y-4 silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: A summary of the coins in this hoard exists, but gives family names rather than identifications for Republican denarii. The hoard was discovered in a crevice in the rocks amongst a mass of carbonised material.
42 coins found in a 2 sqm area on a floor from the gate tower no. 1:
A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus - Postumus), found while extracting peat in the moor.
66 solidi: Theodosius II - Basiliscus (AD 475-476).

A hoard of more than 100 solidi, apparently, all of Honorius was found during the construction of the Bank of Algeria building in Cherchell. Although the hoard was immediately dispersed. 23 solidi were seen and described by P. Salama
disposition: Musée d'Alger (16 coins); in Cherchell Collection Louis (6 coins); Collection Albitre (1 coin).

summary: 530 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Mints: until AD 253 Rome (except for 1 Volusian from Antioch); after 253: 72 Rome, 40 Cologne, 1 Milan, 2 Viminacium, 45 unidentified and for Postumus, 334 Cologne and 7 imitations. Silver: 580 coins; Silver w8: 145.0-295.5 g.
3 solidi (Honorius and Arcadius) and 1 silver ingot, found while digging the foundations for a new office in the Tower of London, in 1777.
16 denarii found in a trench: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: A hoard of 6 provincial coins minted in Alexandria (Claudius II - Aurelian), found in or near Ipswich in 1922.

Found whilst digging a ditch in the Saint-Louis or Quatre-Acres cemetery (the ancient cemetery z1). The hoard was not found in a burial context. 662 bronze coins: sestertii, and dupondii or asses: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
A small hoard probably of 4 or 5 Atrebatic (British Qc) quarter staters, recorded at the British Museum.

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.

Evans (1890, 485, repeated by Allen 1960a, 207) recorded several potins found at Bardwell, of his pl. H.8 type (cl. II). 3 coins can still be traced. As Haselgrove (1987, 283 no. 40) has pointed out, there is a Romano-British fort and settlement here and the coins could well be multiple site finds.
62 flat linear potins found during an excavation, scattered at the east end of an elongated pit.
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).
1726 coins found in a bronze vessel: 3 denarii, 1723 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 293-294); w8: 5650 kilos.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: 301 Roman nummi: House of Constantine I - Marcian (AD 450-4557). Supposedly given to the Colombo Museum in 1935

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 14 denarii are known: Republic – Augustus (20-16 BC).

Gallwey described 29886 coins which he considered to represent 2/3rds or 3/4s of the total found. Originally, the latest coin in the hoard was stated to be an issue of Gallienus' Zoo dating to the period AD 267 to 268. However, a revision states that it is actually an issue of Gallienus from the mint of Siscia dating to AD 268 Silver: c.40000 (29858) coins.
(8-10 kg) 36 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carinus, Magna Urbica, Numerian, Diocletian, Numerian (AD 293-294)
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver w8: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
c. 4000 (2244) antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 720.1-1079.9g.
83 nummi: Constantius II - Leo I (AD 457-474).
26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver w8: 35.5-53.2 g.

Several reports mention several silver coins (probably a hoard) ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found on the Flürener Heide, on a sand hill, close to Diersfordt, Flüren. The coins have been dispersed.
Unknown quantity of provincial bronze coins. 2 pieces of Caracalla minted in Serdica are known
'Some years before 1882, on a Gallo-Roman site, a ceramic vessel containing 30 gold coins mixed with copper obols' was found.
On the site of the Roman theatre, a hoard of 24 sestertii wrapped in cloth was found .
Around 1460 denarii - a number established based on an average w8 of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a cremation burial dated to the beginning of the 1st century AD by its grave goods.
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver w8: 57.8-100.7g
The hoard comprised approximately 300 radiates of which 64 survive.
Around 60 denarii found in a small ceramic vessel. 28 pieces entered the museum collection in Nova Zagora: Augustus 20, Tiberius 8 (AD 14-37).
disposition: History Museum, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1176/1-28; clay pot (inv.no. A-6371

summary: A small deposit of 10 coins: 9 sestertii, 1 antoninanus (radiate): Vespasian - Carus/Carinus for Magnia Urbica (283-285). The last coin, possible, intruder.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 27 coins provide information on issuers: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
7 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in a building from the military vicus.
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the 6teenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 200 Iron Age coins in a good state of preservation. A second hoard of 110 (or 200?) coins, also in a ceramic vessel was found during the construction of the Maison de Gaburos. The hoard was found by a farmer, working in a field covered in brick and st1s. Probably, there is only 1 hoard.

47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Ol10 by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.

73 coins (44 denarii, 3 aurei and 23 bronze coins), ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander, found together over time within the foundation walls of a Roman building located in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Eining. The earlier finds had been dispersed, but most of them could be traced in FMRD.
35 nummi of the House of Constantine and House of Valentinian (AD 367-378).
Hoard of 1000 silver coins: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). 8 coins are documented.
8 coins: 1 antoninianus, 7 nummi: Tetrarchy (AD 303-304) Mints: Londinium 1, Lugdunum 2, Treveri 3, Ticinum 2
Group of 7 coins reported in HER as a hoard, including denarii of Augustus and Tiberius. No further information. The source is given as Devizes Museum Daybook 783.

A hoard of about 80 antoniniani was discovered by treasure hunters in the late 2010s between the villages of Stanislavchyk and Bud’ky in Vinnytsia region. It is known that the hoard contained coins of Gordian III.
The exact composition of the hoard remains very unclear. It certainly included 50-60 Gallo-Belgic uninscribed gold staters, found between 1997 and 1999.
Unknown number of denarii. 4 coin were identified as Augustus' issues minted in Lugdunum (2 BC - AD 4).

A hoard of Iron Age coins and 2 as of Claudius I, found while digging gravel. Evans lists 107 silver units of the Iceni, consisting of 29 uninscribed and 78 inscribed, plus 2 asses (originally classified as dupondii) of Claudius (AD 41-4). 53 Icenian coins from the hoard can still be identified today.
2382 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 644.1-2976.5 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (110 coins and fragments and casts); collection Meire, in 1950

summary: A hoard of approximately 30000 'large and small bronzes', probably radiates and nummi. There were however, 2 large silver coins described as 'grand module' which have been interpreted as medallions: Valerian I - Constantine I.
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Anto9 dynasty. Only 4 coins are documented.

17 radiates found assoc. with remains of a ceramic container & human infant b1s in fill of a ditch. Poss. a foundation deposit under a timber building. 2 bronze scrap frags. & a bronze hook also menti1d, but not clear if assoc.
3 coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised 12 antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.

The hoard comprised 1 antonininiani (Tetricus I ) and 65 nummi ending in issues dating to the period AD 378 to 402. Found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, in the entrance room, to the right of the door to the cult room, in the demolition layer; ritual deposit? Originally stored in a container of perishable material, no traces detected. – The lot was not detected in situ ("... a surgi sous la pioche d'un ouvrier ..."). As many other coins were found in this layer, it is possible that some coins from the surroundings were attributed err1ously to this deposition.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. 1 of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the 2 Anto9s, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.

„It is only stated that the coins were examined by the Archaeological Department, Colombo. The whereabouts of this hoard is unknown; it was neither recorded in the Department’s inventory nor available for study in 1978.”

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot 9 more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold 1 by 1 at the Violity auction.
Report on file at HER of a fused group of 4 or 5 radiates or nummi reported along with other objects. No further detail visible on X-ray.

The hoard comprised 2769 coins including a plated copy of a denarius of Severus Alexander and radiates from Valerian to Probus. It was found concealed in a broken ceramic vessel covered with a schist slab in a cavity in the southern wall of Building E (V) of a Gallo-Roman villa. Elements of the hoard were found on 2 occasions. First, in August 1983 and then in 1984 when further excavation of the site took place. Severus Alexander (plated denarius); Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1984-72

summary: The hoard comprised 1 radiate of Claudius II and 38 Provincial coins of the early third century AD, found in a grave (Grave Θ) in Amphipolis in 1976
Hoard of 11 denarii.
90 silver coins: 23 denarii, 67 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 125.5-252.4 g.
1071 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1065 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 267); silver w8: 290.7-2781.5g
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology Tulcea, Romania (1971)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian I, Philip I 2.
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
14 nummi the time of Constantine I (AD 333-335) found stuck to each other.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology, Coin Room, Bucharest, Romania

summary: A hoard of 13 provincial coins, found in grave T207 of the Roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. fig. 23α and 23β. They comprised 6 pseudo-autonomous coins of Philippi (dated to the time of Claudius or Nero), 6 provincial coins of Amphipolis (Domitian) and 1 uncertain coin.
40 sestertii discovered at 1.40 m depth. Among them 2 of Commodus and 7 or 8 of Postumus (AD 260-268?). No further information.
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.

The hoard comprised '1000s of Roman coins dating to the period AD 290 to 310 from the mints of London, Lyon, Trier, Rome and Carthage.' The plow originally brought 250 coins to the surface and subsequent archaeological investigation discovered 3 amphorae containing the coins.
2 coins of Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius and 1 of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
The hoard comprised 7 bronzes coins from the reign of Nero, dated between AD 67-68, which may have belonged to a Roman soldier during the First Jewish War.
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: 10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 20.8-37 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2247

summary: 55 silver coins, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, found during construction work.

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
Around 300 bronze coins found in 2 ceramic vessel at the bottom of a dam: Claudius I - Gratian (AD 367-383).
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Anto9 coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.

The coins were dug out during excavation for the construction of St. Paulus elementary school, on Zuckerbergstrasse. A Roman street was cut into (a decumanus) as well as the remains of a residential development.

The hoard was found within the cella of a Gallo-Roman 'fanum' or shrine. It comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 49 nummi of Constantine I, Crispus, Constantine II, House of Constantine Constantinoplis and Roma issues, Constans, Constantius II and Magnentius.

Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

The find consists of 15 Roman bronze coins (incl. 2 provincial coins) and 3 Danish coins (these were not part of the Roman hoard!), which were found during plowing works in the vicinity of the Neuwerk farm, on the road of Kappeln towards Schleswig.

The hoard comprised a greyware ceramic vessel containing 6000 coins from Valerian I to Probus. The last coin is of Probus, Lyon mint, AD 281 (Bastien type 347 or 348). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1161.2g and 6865.6g.
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: The hoard comprised 70-80 Tyrian tetradrachms, deposited in the early part of the first century BC.
31 silver coins: 8 small silver Celtic (1 Karlstein type; 7 Magdalensberg/Gurina type), Republic: 16 denarii, 2 denarii serati, 2 quinarii; 3 imperial denarii: Celtic - Augustus (AD 2-14).

The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Probus and was found while enlarging a cellar in a house. It was originally stated that the hoard was found in a small silver vessel. However, TAF questions the metallic composition of the vessel.
Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: 50 gold coins: 1 aureus, 1 multiple 1 1/4 solidus 48 solidii: Maximian I - Constantius II (AD 337-343); gold w8: 225.62g; silver: 9 ingots; silver w8: c. 2647.24g
disposition: Schatzkammer und Zentralarchiv des Deutschen Ordens, Vienna

summary: 39 nummi: Constantine I 30, Licinius I 9 (AD 321-324).
700 coins found with a ceramic vessel near a wall: Probus - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
Hoard of 194 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus (13 BC).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 130 silver coins are known: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 129 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
300 denarii: Augustus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
A widely scattered hoard of 82 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of more than a decade.

A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the con10ts of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
20 AR denarii to AD 37.
Hoard of 9 aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria (2 coins)

summary: 500 sestertii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 226).
A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
The hoard comprised 70 nummi, of which 18 were cleaned, dated between AD 330-335 and AD 351-361.
A hoard of 2079 nummi found in a small jar. The coins run from Constantine I to Arcadius and Honorius. 978 of them were illegible.
disposition: Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology, UCL (at least part)

summary: The hoard was found in an iron box deposited under a mosaic depicting Bacchic themes and contained 40 coins of Gordian III to Postumus. The denominations of the coins were not specified.
2 double-pierced gold coins, an aureus of Septimius Severus (AD 203), and its imitation were reported from a village.
60 silver coins: 2 denarii, 58 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
A hacksilver hoard composed of assorted silver fragments, 21 gold solidi, ranging from Magnentius to Constantine III. Some of the silver fragments form a large decorated plate.
773 nummi found with a st1 box: Constans - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
Over 500 aurei: Trajan to Geta Gold: c.500 coins; gold w8: 3200.8-3599.2g.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Severus Alexander.
Originally, over 100 denarii, only 34 were studied: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 51 nummi: AD 318/320 - 330/335

Metal hoard/deposition, silver, bronze, iron, carefully stored in a cavity, in a small room close to the southern porticus. Bronze vessels, iron tools, jewellery and coins stored together between 2 bronze vessels. The hoard comprised 59 (62 ?) coins including 4 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 50 asses and 1 dupondius or as terminating in issues of AD 249-51 and including many pre-103 AD coins: these were not taken from normal coin circulation in mid-3rd cent., but carefully selected.

The hoard was found in a wooden box measuring 30cm by 30cm which was hidden in a cavity under a large st1. It comprised 6 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip, Gallienus and Divus Valerian II (AD 253-260).

35 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). There is no certainty that this was the total number of the m1tary group. The owner could have retrieved part of the coins, as well as the following agricultural works, probably, led to the finding of other pieces.
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania

summary: 12 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and ending ca. AD 255, found on the Zugerberg.
disposition: Amt für Denkmalpflege und Archäologie, Zug

summary: 6 solidi: 3 Honorius minted in Mediolanum (1) and Ravenna(2); 3 Arcadius minted in Mediolanum (AD 395-423); gold w8: 26.7g.

75 coins: 73 antoniniani, 1 as, 1 as/dupondius found in a house at an altar, ranging from Domitian/Hadrian to Carinus for Numerian (Augustus) (AD 283-284). The specimens listed here follow Marion's publication, but Thouvenot's inventory differs slightly in that he records 2 specimens of RIC Gallienus 178, only single specimens of RIC 207 and 28, he omits RIC 36, 45/6 and 1 illegible specimen for Claudius Gothicus, but instead gives 2 examples of RIC 48 and another illegible type, and he also mistakes RIC 705 (Antoninus Pius) for a silver coin.
Hoard unearthed by a labourer working in his garden. The coins were contained in a pot.
(260) 257 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel covered with a silver plate and comprised 73 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) vfrom Vespasian to Valerian I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 55.4g and 208.8g.
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
310 antoniniani (radiates) found wrapped in a piece of cloth and placed in 2 ceramic vessels: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274). The Tetricus I coins are imitations.
8 coins found in a cave: Antoninus Pius - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II); silver w8: 4.1-13.9g.
The hoard comprised 224 coins from Nerva to Aurelian. This included 28 sestertii from Nerva to Septimius Severus, 1 worn dupondius or as and 95 radiates from Gordian III to Victorinus and Aurelian.
24 silver coins found in a st1 quarry: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2424-2446 (24 coins)

summary: 232 Iron Age coins, found in a field. It is not sure that all the coins belonged to the same deposit. The site si considered as the location of a Romano-British temple with an earlier, Iron Age phase.
(303) 292 silver coins: 240 denarii, 52 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver w8: 380.4-892.2 g.

More than 200 Roman silver and bronze coins were found in 1880, in the barn of the house no. 20 in Ronsberg. 61 were identified in the Munich state coin collection and 6 are listed in FMRD; the imperial series ended with Severus Alexander.
2944 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.

The hoard was found deposited in an old wall and comprised 838 antoniniani (radiates). Hucher compiled a catalogue of 810 coins: Trajan Decius - Postumus (AD 260-269). Hucher acquired 351 coins for the Musée du Mans (Manuscript of entries 1863-1909, p. 4 and 5) and the Hospice kept 487 coins.Silver w8: 227.2-1046.5 g.
(+100) 122 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251); silver w8: 34.5-314.1g.
Hoard of 126 siliquae Constantius II (AD 337-361); silver w8: 397.74g.
disposition: National History Museum of Modolva, Chișinău (125 coins) - 1951; one returned to the finder; inv.nos. 2545; 950-1076

summary: 26 coins found together at the archaeological site: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 25 nummi: Divus Claudius II - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
"A considerable large quantity" of coins of "middle bronzes", all of Postumus (AD 260-268). 4

A small hoard of 4 gold coins of Arcadius and Honorius found with a gold ring outside the east wall of the temple, during the excavation of the Romano-Celtic Temple inside the Iron Age hill fort of Maiden Castle.
37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver w8: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: The hoard comprised several vessels containing 1000s of Roman coins. Labourers working on an English army camp in 1939 or 1940 discovered this hoard.
50 Roman imperial coins, only 10 are known: Augustus - Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120189: 1-17

summary: 30 coins, 27 described, found inside a rich grave. Includes 1 2nd. c. denarius and 1 ‘Dortmund’ copy. tpq c.430 Silver: 1, 21 coins; Silver w8: 29.42g+
(500-600) 120 republican denarii (tpq 36 BC).

In 1968 a person came upon a hexagonal water tank with a circuit and a cellar on the east side of Neumarkt during the construction of a railway entry. 34 coins lay in the infilling of a pit under the cellar between porphyry and marble remnants. The pot/jar found probably served as a m1y bank.
Hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 30 coins were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293)
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
The hoard was discovered after 1863 in the rubble from the excavation of the bathhouse. It comprises 21 aurei, ranging from Nero to Trajan.
The hoard (a sanctuary box) comprised c. 38 Celtic and Roman bronze coins, from Augustus to Domitian (AD 81-96).
15 nummi found 'more or less stuck to each other'. Some of the coins belonged to Constantius II (Augustus).
184 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. The large number belong to thee issues of Gratian with the reverse type REPARATIO REIPVB, ending with issues of Honorius.

According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).
2 lots of nummi (59, 25). No further information. Unpublished.
7 gold coins: 4 solidi, 3 tremisses, all of Zeno (AD 474-491);gold w8: 22.3g. Found with jewelry in a grave.
159 solidi ranging from Gratian to Honorius, AD 406.
5-6 silver and bronze coins. Among them 1 piece of Antoninus Pius.

Between 25000-30000 coins found in 2 bronze vessels: 8 or 10 aurei from Hadrian to Severus Alexander; 5 bronze coins (Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander, Philip II, Postumus); 1 bronze medallion of Severus Alexander (with Julia Mamaea); 25000-30000 silver and billon coins from Claudius (I/II?) to Postumus; gold w8: c. 64.8 g; Silver: c.25-30000 coins; Silver w8: c.7427.6-71498.9. Together were found jewelry: 30 gold and silver rings; 2 or 3 pairs of gold earrings; a pair of bracelets, 2 styla, 30 silver spoons; a gold necklace (?).
15 coins: 3 denarii, 5 antoniniani. 7 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 10.9-17.1 g.

In 1979 Philip Kinns saw in the Herakleion Museum a coin from the ΜΥΩΝΙΔΗΣ+tripod issue of Rhodes (43/42 BC until some time during the reign of Augustus) which had apparently been found at Axos with a coin of Augustus or Caligula.
