The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: 1 Iron Age gold stater and 37 denarii to 47. The gold stater was found about 7.5m from the main scatter of coins but in the same field
386 denarii: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 231).

A hoard of at least 375 coins - Tetradrachms, drachms, cistophori, denarii: Macedonian, Seleucian, Phenician, Parthian, Armenian, Pontic, Cappadocian, from Pergamon, Ephesus and Roman), ranging from 220-163 to 36-34 BC. 195 coins were well documented.
4th century.Small hoard of Roman coins found in 1978 in building beside Ermine Street in Area II of excavs of Roman settlement. Most coins in a heap with few scattered more widely.
Unknown initial number of coins. 100 denarii: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv. nos. 49.717-49.816

summary: 2 solidi of Valentinian I minted in Antioch (AD 364-367), same type. Published as single finds.
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 90 coins are kept in the collection of the National History Museum in Bucharest: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
27 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 35.6-71.4 g.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
Unknown initial number of coins bronze vessel. 2090 silver coins: 2076 denarii, 13 antoniniani , 1 provincial: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver w8: 2891.3-6458.6 g.
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (2064 coins), National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania (15 coins), Victor Bratu Collection Bucharest (11 coins)

summary: 100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
96 nummi found in a cave: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico, Etnográfico e Histórico Vasco, Bilbao, Spain

summary: 3598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
3918 antoniniani of the second half of the 3rd century AD found on the territory of the village. No further information.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing a silver finger ring with blue glass setting depicting a figure left and 380 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus. 267 examples were catalogued by Pinsard. A closing date of AD 268 is given by a APOLLINI CONS AVG reverse of Gallienus and 7 coins of Postumus with ORIENS AVG with P in the field reverses.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 27 silver coins and 93 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Postumus. D. Hollard expresses some doubts about the hoard ending with coins of Postumus.
This hoard of 20 3 coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
(128) 126 siliquae: Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: National Museum of Ethnography and Natural History, Chișinău, Moldova; inv.nos. 2.545/AR 950-1.075 (coins), 2.545/A 35/1 (vessel)

summary: Hoard of 60 denarii of Augustus minted in Lugdunum (2 BC - AD 4).
A small amphora containing 2850 nummi of the first Tetrarchy up to Constantine I and Licinius.
4 asses found during excavations: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45373-45376

summary: The hoard comprised 31 Roman Provincial coins from Nicopolis from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus, found south of Nicopolis, at Agios Phaneromenes Vathi (Αγιας Φανερωμενης Βαθυ), where 1 of the 3 harbours of the city was located. The coins were found in 2 lots (of 5 and 26 coins), recovered at a few days interval, and both hidden under a tile.
2 solidi of Theodosius II minted in Constantinople (AD 441-450).
88 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 379-383). Mints after AD 364: Treveri 1, Lugdunum 17, Arelate 25, Aquileia 9, Roma 4, Siscia 7, unidentified: 11
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (88 coins).

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 bronze coins dating from Seleucid period to the House of Theodosius (AD 379-455). Only 159 of these coins are preserved by the IAA and recorded at the level of the coin.
11 denarii, the latest 1 of Tiberius. No further information.
5 gold coins (Nero and Titus) closely packed together in the clay floor of an early structure, at Vagniacae (Springhead).

251 coins in the NUMIS database as being considered the hoard discovered at Rossum in 1895. The structure of this discovery may raise some doubts whether is a hoard or there are contaminations with single finds, too.

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel placed within a pit lined with 4 tiles. It comprised approximately 4000 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Tetricus I and II. Issues of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. A small portion of the hoard including 103 coins were catalogued.
193 nummi found in an ox b1: Constans - Valentinian III (AD 425-455).

This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a 4th century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only 30 years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of 1 originated from the same mint - Rome".
The hoard comprised 8 Continental Iron Age silver coins.

In 1955 an earthenware container with 7 antoniniani and 888 nummi (Tacitus - Constantine I, AD 318) was found within remains of a Roman occupation layer, during excavation of a dung pit on the site of Winger street.
5 aurei: 2 republican, 3 imperial: Republic - Augustus (AD -11-10).
The hoard is comprised of 131 republican and imperial denarii, ending with Augustus' coins (AD 29-27 BC).
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a st1. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the anto9 dynasty.
50 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
3256 coins, mainly antoniniani radiates, together with nummi and an argenteus found in a ceramic vessel: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetrarchy (AD 285-298).

'The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel filled with approximately 40 gold, silver and bronze coins with portraits of Trajan, Claudius II and Probus. The composition of this hoard is thought to be suspect.' The hoard was found in a small valley on the Guillet property.
Before 1889, 8 coins were found in a garden in Campbon. These included 1 radiate of Tacitus and 2 of Probus. They may represent a portion of a larger hoard.
73 denarii: Republic - Augustus (AD 2 Bc - AD 4).

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in 1 small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
Circa 100 Celtic staters. The coins were sold as soon as they were found.
A widely-scattered hoard of 37 staters of Addedomaros, discovered by 8 or more detectorists in repeated visits to the site.
Silver: 1000+ (83) antoniniani/radiates: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 271.0-1249.0 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (978 coins); dispersed

summary: 610 nummi considered as 'residual coins': Claudius I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

(1200) 290 denarii: Otho - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). Found together with: 1 gold torque of twisted wire, 2 silver torques, 2 silver bracelets, 10 silver appliques, 1 silver brooch, 1 silver ring with inscription.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXXXIX (1934)

summary: 18 (?) silver coins, found 1925 on the street 'Am Römerwall'. 21 coins are menti1d in the inventory of the Altermusmuseum, but the coins are now lost.
A hoard of 260 provincial bronze coins (Domitian - Gallus, including 1 from the First Jewish Revolt), found at Dura Europos, in L8 W102, the street along the wall near the main Gate.
173 nummi of the Tetrarchy.

In 1904, Ali Farah, of the Eastern Telegraph Company, Aden, donated 3 gold coins to the British Museum: 1 Aksumite coin ofEbana, 1 imitation of a solidus of Constantius II, and a solidus of Constantius II minted in Arles.

Found during construction work for a water pipe, in a pot, around 1900 (but certainly before 8 April 1909 when some coins of the hoard were sold to the Rosgar10museum in Konstanz). The indications on the numbers lack precision: 4.5 kg (including pot?), over 1000 coins. The coins were dispersed and sold to different parties. Today 255 coins are preserved or identified: 224 are in the Rosgar10museum in Konstanz (where they were kept until 1991 separately in an envelope with the note of the year 1909, then integrated in the coin collection without noting the findspot; now identified via the similar incrustations), and 2 coins in the Thurgauisches Historisches Museum in Frauenfeld. The allegedly 27 coins in the Heimatmuseum Kreuzlingen could not be retrieved (NB: The 7 coins published in 1998 as part of the hoard are rather to be linked to a local coin find in Kreuzlingen). 3 coins date to the period 315-316, the rest to the period 318-324 (House of Constantine); ca. 80% Treveri, many die links between the coins.
disposition: Rosgarten Museum Konstanz (253 ex.); Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (2 ex.); the others lost

summary: 249 coins : 1 antoninianus (radiate), 248 nummi found in the Odeion's cavea: Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) - Theodosius II (AD 408 423). No traces of a container.

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.

A hoard containing 3 silver finger rings, 4 silver spoons, 2 solidus of Eugenius, 206 siliquae and 1 half–siliqua of emperors from Constantius II to Honorius, discovered on a ploughed field at Burgate, Suffolk, between 1991 and 2006. A least 27 of the siliquae were clipped. Since the publication in CHRB X, 18 additional siliquae have been reported from this hoard, see TAR reports. A further 20 siliquae and 1 solidus were found in 1997 and are included in the PAS dataset.
disposition: Ipswich Museum (part); Diss Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Hoard of 56 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 55 nummi: Claudius II - Constans (AD 346-350) found at the site was a Gallo-Roman villa.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel or a leather pouch containing 166 coins of Magnentius and Decentius.

The hoard was 1 of 2 Iron Age hoards found in La Châtaigneraie around 1901. It is difficult to establish which coins belonged to which find. M. Roy of La Rochelle acquired nearly all the coins of 1 hoard, amounting to 43 coins. Only 1 was gold. Vallette notes a find of 30 Iron Age electrum coins found in the 'ancient rocks of Moulins.' Does this statement related to the first or second find? The hoard was found during quarrying.
(116) 101 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIV

summary: Hoard of 32 silver coins: 9 imitations of Thasian tetradrachm, 30 republican denarii, 1 imperial: L. Thorius Balbus - Augustus (AD 19-4 BC). '1 of the Thasian barbarous imitations has the head of Roma l. and letter X behind the goddess, clearly copied from an obverse of 2nd c. BC’ RRD; another bears a punch-mark –anchor, the emblem of Apollonia Pontica. Apparently, all the coins are worn, but the imitations are almost uncirculated.' (Paunov)
4 silver denarii to Tiberius and 4 Icenian silver units found in a small concentration in February and March 1995.

The 32 coins were reportedly found together decades ago in the Nennslingen part of the Weissenburg Forest. A more precise find location cannot be determined, though it must be within the limes border. Coins range from Augustus to Theodosius I. It is uncertain whether this is a hoard.
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: 782 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 294-306).
Initial quantity of silver coins: 13 kg, Studied: 9 kg (Gerov, B.) = 1790 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 2238.1-4652.9 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 843-856 (1716 coins, stolen 1407)

summary: A hoard of c. 7000 late third-century radiates.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei from Antoninus Pius to Marcus Aurelius.
Over 2500 coins were discovered. 2527 coins were studied: Claudius II - Constantine I (tpq AD 323-324).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France (2,492 coins); lot sold on eBay (35 coins).

summary: 55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found 1 meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, 1 hoard.
64 denarii found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman Villa: Republic - Augustus (Lugdunum, 2 BC - 4 AD).
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver w8: 194 g.
2 solidi (Valentinian I), found in the neighbourhood of Croydon.
Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
c. 100 antoniniani: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
“300” coins of unknown type (Roman?). No details were reported.
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the con10ts of a purse lost when the building was demolished.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Imperial coins of Severus Alexander, found in grave 6 of the east cemetery in Thessaloniki.
31 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 29 nummi: Claudius II - Theodosius I (AD 381-383).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: 73 nummi of the House of Constantine. No further details.
4 coins (Divus Claudius II - Arcadius / Honorius), found on Fehmarn in 1899. A hoard?
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 25 silver coins of Juba II and Ptolemy (AD 18).

10 solidi found in an area with 3 Iron Age houses. The first 7 coins, FP 5142, were found within 15x35 meters. In spite of the relatively large distance between the coins they are probably a ploughed-up hoard. No denarii have been found yet at this site.
10 solidi found in a domestic building: Constantius II - Honorius (AD 402-406).

73 Icenian Iron Age coins and 14 Roman denarii found on a string of small sand islands surrounded by black peat, over a number of years. It is however difficult to give a precise breakdown of all the coins found at Joist Fen, or their relationship with each other.

35 coins (3 sestertii, 9 radiates and 23 Provincial coins from Athens. The Athenian coins range from the time of Augustus to Gallienus), that were part of a larger find made in the region of Corinth (?). Its composition is similar to the hoards from Eleusis.
Hoard of 608 denarii: 1 republican, 607 imperials: Republic - Trajan (AD 98-117). Only 173 coins were studied.
11 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2206

summary: The hoard comprised a 'crock filled with 400 coins of early emperors and empresses' Found in a ravine leading to Janval.

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The m1y consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. 2 pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
46 nummi found scattered near a tile kiln, on its eastern corner, in a debris layer Constantius II - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-383).`
Probably, 2 solidi of Valentinian III (AD 425-430).

Hoard of 386 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found jewelry: 30 silver rings with pearls, 1 silver twisted bracelet, silver large rings/bracelets, 20 amber perls, silver ring with 1 coin of Constantius II (!) mounted.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 08 comprises 6 Iron Age coins.
535 nummi of which 58 were cleaned: House of Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-423).

6 copper alloy coins found during excavations at the long barrow known as Giant's Cave, in Luckington. Their association together is uncertain but they may relate to ritual deposition at the site. It is also notable that sherds of over 100 third and 4th century vessels were found.

2 wooden caskets (wooden has vanished) comprising coins and jewelry were found at 50 cm 1 from the other in a pithos pit in the citadel of Artezia. The first casket contains 146 coins: 145 bronze staters: autonomous issues and Bosporan kings and 1 denarius of Tiberius. Together, there had been a variety of items of jewelry: 1 thin annular bracelet made of twisted silver, 3 large penannular bronze bracelets – some twisted and some smooth (silver hairpins fused with 1 of them), a string of hollow bronze beads cylindrical in shape, a necklace of very large paste and glass eye-beads, a thin and flat bronze mirror round in shape, a large bronze ring which had lost its oval inlay; a small silver earring; a fragment of an iron ring (?) and part of a badly corroded thin-walled bronze item (clasp?).
The hoard comprised 4 coins of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) and 2 unidentified coins.

Grave find consisting of 25 coins: 1 local Alexander's imitation, 2 Parthian drachms of Sinatruces I, 1 drachm of Phraates III, 9 drachms of Orodes II, 1 drachm of Phraates IV, 10 denarii of Augustus and 1 denarius of Tiberius.
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 6 bronze countermarked coins deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136). Dated based on a countermark with Hadrian's head
24 nummi found 10 m from CONIMBRIGA 1967-1968 hoard: Constantine I (Divus) - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 393-395).

The hoard was found at a very shallow depth placed under or on a flat, square st1. It comprised a vessel containing 3369 coins. J. Chappée bought the hoard and compiled a catalogue of 3075 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations. M. Amandry undertook a new study of the hoard in 1983 and compiled a catalogue of 3052 coins. It is this catalogue which is recorded in our database. Silver w8: 784.8-3627.8g.

The hoard comprised a bronze statuette and approximately 300 silver coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus. The coins were bought by the Abbot Carlier, curate of Bavay. The statuette was acquired by the Museum of Douai where it remained until 1944 when it was destroyed in a fire.
Around 800 denarii of wchich 189 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Due to the common find spot, 30-50 cm under the lower edge of the walled threshold, the supposition is that the coins represent a small deliberately concealed stock of cash.
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
A hoard of over 2000 Thurrock type potins found by a metal detectorist at the edge of quarry hollow. The hoard was used by Van Arsdell as the basis of his typology for the 'Thurrock' type potin.

A group of copper alloy coins found in a garden, some of which were reported as having been in a leather wallet. Aspects of the find give cause to suspect that this may have been buried in modern times but it is included here as it has been published as a Roman hoard elsewhere.
The hoard comprised a cylindrical bronze vessel containing 66 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Victorinus. 2 coins, Gratian and Valentinian II are also menti1d, intruders?
4116 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 bronzes: Greek - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 284-295). Acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
disposition: 185 were sent to Macalister. The rest is partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford (Milne)

summary: The coins were found in a thick burnt layer above the furnace. This circumstance as the find spot east of the theater wall points to a correlation with the destruction of the residential area.
The hoard comprised a small red ceramic vessel with a lid containing approximately 150 coins of the second and third century AD. It was probably a hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates).
32 silver coins: 24 antoniniani (radiates), 8 denarii: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
96 silver coins: 33 denarii, 63 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver w8: 128.2-226.5 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, 96 coins

summary: Group of 6 coins: aureus of Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I), aureus of Postumus and 4 denarii of Augustus found in grave no. 8.

The hoard comprised 40 sestertii and dupondii or asses from Trajan to Gordian III. They were accompanied by a small copper-alloy figurine. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard in a semi-circular niche hollowed out of the rock.
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver w8: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
119 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 307). Part of the Seltz hoard.

N 9159 "The only 'find' was a collection of 15 Roman coins of small value, all belonging to the reign of Constantine the Great. They were discovered about 8een inches below the surface of the ground, and immediately over the wide trench menti1d above. It is interesting to note that from the position in which they were discovered, it would seem that the trench had been filled up and the surface grass grown at the time when they were lost." J. Healy, in Journal of Royal Soc. Ant. of Ireland, XXX (1900), 176 "It has now transpired that the hoard was put there a day or 2 before for them [i.e. the excavators] to find." (J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 59f., no. 73, "Reign of Constantine I"). Uncertain location? Uncertain find?
1069 silver coins found with a ceramic cooking pot: Republic - Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Rome, Italy

summary: 61 coins: 1 gold, 48 bronze, 12 nummi: Magnentius (AD 351-353)
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (12 coins); Cabinet des Medailles, Bruxelles, Belgium

summary: 500-560 billon coins originally - mostly Marius, Postumus, and Victorinus, closing with 2 coins from 267. Also including coins of Claudius, Tetricus, Gordian III, Trebonianus Gallus; silver w8: c.136.0-624.0g.
The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: The hoard comprised 27+ silver coins, consisting of Tyrian shekels, Antiochene tetradrachms, and shekels of the First Jewish Revolt.

The hoard was found in 2 boxes next to a lead coffin in a Gallo-Roman cemetery. The boxes contained masses of radiates and included amongst them, issues of Postumus and Tetricus I. Found in a sandpit.

The hoard was found in the foundations of a 15th century house and comprised a small deposit of 3rd century coins. J. Chappée told Blanchet there were 10 coins: Victorinus 2, Tetricus I 3, Tetricus II 5.
5 nummi: Valentinian I - Gratian (AD 375-383) Mints: Lugdunum 2, Roma 1, Arelate 2

A hoard of ca. 150 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Septimius Severus), found in Winnefeld while planting trees. 133 coins were acquired by the museum in Hannover, 117 of which can still be traced. Several coins are badly preserved and identifications are 10tative.
4 coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Private collection, loan Drents Museum Assen

summary: 2 silver units of ANTED corroded together. No further details known.
19 coins: 17 antoniniani (radiates), 2 nummi: Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 306-337).

HER record for MOLAS excavations in 2002-3 at 21 Lime Street has the following: "A brickearth demolition layer at the top of the dumping sequence, which may have also served as a floor slab, produced a hoard of 10 silver denarii and some silver plated copies, including rare Republican forgeries, dated to AD 70 or later". No further details found.
A hoard of 6000+ AE of Apamea (56.5 kg) found in a pithos dating to the mid first century BCE.
IARCH record of a hoard of 11 sestertii from Devon. For details see DEV-37EC41.

A small scattered hoard which has generated considerable confusion in the literature. 7 Iron Age coins were acquired by the Hampshire County Museum Service, but the hoard might have contained more coins.
Scarce Information on a hoard, in which circa 20 antoniniani depict portarits of 7 emeperors between AD 238-268 from Gordian III to Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Museum of Sain-Sulpice, France, but no records of them in the registers.

summary: Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: 39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
357 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius, ranging from Caracalla to Aemilian (AD 253); silver w8: 448.5-804.5 g.
disposition: Archives de la Commission d'assistance publique (358 coins); private collection (3 coins); Musée communal de Bruxelles"

summary: 4928 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi: Claudius II - Constantine I (AD 306-337).
Approximately 50 sestertii dating to the 2nd and 3rd century, terminating with issues of Trajan Decius
131 coins, 125 menti1d in the catalogue: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 2 denarii, 2 asses, 115 nummi: Claudius I – Thedosius I (AD 379-395).

3 accounts of the discovery exist, but all give different details and there is no other contemporary authority which could be used. Both brass coins (possibly including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina) and minimi were found in 1869 and have been assumed to be part of 1 and the same hoard. The 3 accounts of the range of the first brass gave either Severus Alexander, Gallienus or Maximian as the last emperor represented, and it is now impossible to be certain which account is correct. In 1935, C.H.V. Sutherland examined 105 radiate minims from this hoard. These proved to be exactly similar to the 317 radiate minims which were acquired by Sir Arthur Evans at Bristol some years before, along with 6 regular antoniniani (NC, 1934, 92-103) [no. 804]. Dr. Sutherland therefore concluded that these 317 and 105 radiate minims all came from the Whitchurch hoard. The 6 regular antoniniani may or may not have come from the same find. They were of Victorinus (3) and Tetricus II (3). With the 317 minims, were a rough lump of copper and a piece of sheet metal. The 422 minims copied the following prototypes: Gallic Empire types (249), types of Claudius II (23), miscellaneous types (150). The large brass may have been collected together, to be melted down to make into radiate minims.
This hoard is incomplet. Only 12 (of 80) denarii of Augustus studied, although is has been assumed that the coins were all issues of Augustus in Lugdunum (2 BC - AD 4) of RIC 207.
3 Late Roman coins (Constantine I - Constantius II), found in 1914 and now lost.
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 35 coins entered the museum collection in Varna: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver w8: 45.1-89.6 g.

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold w8 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The con10t: 2 crosses; 3 chains; a brooch; 6ty-8 pendants and 6ty-4 grains of necklace; 4teen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Anto9s mainly, and 2 bracteates.
Unknown initial number of coins. 169 (but there is evidence only on 161 coins) bronze coins were studied: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 266-267).

HER record of a hoard of 120 4th century nummi, "bronze coins of Constantine I, and Helena". The source is given as Devizes Museum daybook, 1903. This hoard does not appear to be recorded elsewhere, although it could possibly be related to the pot from the same parish in Devizes Museum.

The hoard comprised a total of 130 coins including 6 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius and 124 Roman Provincial coins from Athens dating to Periods V and VI (Hadrian to Gallienus). This hoard is linked to the invasion of the Goths in AD 267. It was found 300 m north of the archaeological site of Eleusis.
Unknown originally number of coins 'a handful of Roman coins'. Only 2 nummi of Magnentius are known.
The hoard comprised 19 bronze prutot and lepton of John Hyrcanus I and John Hyrcanus II.
The find comprised numerous (1000-2000) copies of radiates of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Grave 1012 contained an adult female skeleton, buried with 2 bracelets and 10 mid-4th-century coins dated between A.D. 337 and 364, possibly a purse group.
18 provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. 16 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2677, 16 coins

summary: Hoard of over 5000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 235 were documented: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). W8: 597.2g (196 coins).
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (collection Iversen); University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (36 coins)

summary: 2 Gallo-Belgic coins found 4 feet apart on west bank of Thames between Putney Bridge and Barn Elms, perhaps deposited together.
197 Late Roman coins from the period AD 330 to 348, with 1 earlier coin (AD 307-8), found next to the furnace of a Roman building.
2 solidi - Valentinian I, Theodosius I - found at the same spot, different years.
11 coins discovered in a burial consisting in 1 denarius of Augustus, 5 drachms of Gotarzes II, 1 aureus of Commodus, and 4 aurei of Caracalla.
3 Gallo-Belgic E staters and a quarter stater of Vosenos.
140 republican and imperial denarii ending with Domitian's issues (Caesar or Augustus?). Found with a ceramic vessel.
8 coins: 5 double sestertii, 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 261-269).
200 gold staters of the Bosporan kings found on the banks of the Mortvyy D1ts River: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
200 "disks" of republican pieces. Possible, among them, issues of Julius Caesar, P. Crassus. Possible a denarius of Augustus minted in Emerita Augusta.
116 coins: 1 antoninianus, 115 nummi found in a ditch under a st1, 200 m from the auxiliary fort: Gallienus (sole) - House of Constantine I (AD 337-340).
65 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257); silver w8: 82.6-167.6 g.
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.

5 kg of silver coins with issuers from Nero to Severus Alexander. Only 1350 were recovered, among which: 233 Septimius Severus, 71 Caracalla, 5 Elagabalus, 5 Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver w8: 1764.3-3938.9 g.
379 denarii from Republic to Augustus, including 4 coins of Juba I and 12 imitations.
A dolium with 35 kilos of coins - 20-25000 pieces. Only 35 coins were recovered: Trajan (!, probably an intruder), Gallienus - Theodosius I/Aracdius (AD 383-395).
disposition: Museu Etnológico e Arqueológico de Cucujães; Colecção do Mosteiro de Singeverga, Portugal

summary: 542 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 541 nummi, found with a bronze pitcher (Blechkanne), only 38 coins can be entered at the coin data level: Aurelian - Tetrarchy (AD 300-303).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici della Lombardia

summary: 575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
114 nummi from Constantine I to House of Theodosius (AD 395-423).
The hoard comprised approximately 20 bronze coins from the second and third centuries AD.

20 siliqua found in an early medieval burial (Alemannic) and re-used as jewellery. All coins pierced close to the rim, attached as pairs by small metal rings to a belt, combined with other items (glass bead, amber bead, shell, 2 bronze rings).
±100 Republican and Imperial denarii ending with Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 410 bronze coins. Desjobert gave a description of 4 sestertii from the hoard which were in the Abbot Gilbert and Abbot Lottin Collections. Legeay noted that the emperors Augustus, Vespasian, Marcus Aurelius, Antoninus Pius and Postumus. This information was not repeated by Leadru.
The hoard comprised an amphora containing between 6000 and 7000 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and II. Only 5 coins were identified more closely.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (1 Antoninus Pius), Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous Commodus), found in grave 4 in Sevasti.

The hoard comprised 4 bronze coins of Mattathias Antigonus (40-37 BC). 'This small hoard consists of 4 bronze coins found accreted together, due to the corrosion that covered them' (Farhi and Melamed 2014, 110)
The hoard comprised 21 denarii from Vitellius to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 201 to 206. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 39.6-60.8 g.
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Republican to AD 193-221 Silver: 527 coins; Silver w8: 966.2-1890.2g
50 Roman bronze coins. No information whether were found as a hoard.
At the beginning of the 20th c., a hoard of 12 bronze coins and 3 denarii was found while extracting gravel. Probably 1st-2nd c. AD.
50 silver coins. 15 pieces were seen: 5 antoniniani, 10 denarii; silver w8: 65.2-131.5 g.
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).

The hoard comprised a black coarseware vessel containing several 100 electrum staters. A mention of a second discovery of 20 staters at the same site is probably an error. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard at the bottom of the garden of the ancient Commandery of Saint-Thomas.

Found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, sector NW, niveau de fréquentation (found in 1994, 69 coins) and above in the demolition layer (found in 1993, 4 coins). Hoard, most probably packed in a container of perishable material, no traces found; 73 aes coins, Nero (?) to Philip I, mostly sestertii with a few dupondii and asses.

summary: 54 denarii: 51 republican, 3 imperials: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: County Museum Zalău, Romania; inv.no. CC 677/1997

summary: (104) 98 provincial bronze coins up to Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 400 silver coins to Gordian III or Gallienus with a tpq of AD 244/268.
10 coins found at Schrotzbug, which is a medieval castle on the Schienerberg: 1 dupondius, 2 aurei and 7 denarii, ranging from Titus Caesar to Severus Alexander.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
27 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 34.3-69.1 g

Ceramic vessel containing 610 Roman provincial bronze coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 235-238). Minted mostly in Tomis (today, Constanța, Romania). Other mint, identified so far, Deultum; At the bottom of container, iron carpentry tools: penknife, clamping clamp, ax/chisel, wood gripper, bolt.

summary: The hoard comprised 59 coins, including 1 denarius of Maximinus and 58 Roman Provincial coins, found in a grave on the north side of the hill of the « Παλαιόν Ηρώον ». The coins of the Koinon are inscribed ΚΟΙΝΟΝ ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ and ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ ΟΜΟΝΟΙΑ.
A small ceramic vessel with 6 silver coins: 2 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver w8: c. 576.7-1295.1g.

A small hoard of 30 coins, ranging from Gallienus to Diocletian, discovered on the site of a Romano-British villa, on a rough st1 pathway next to a building. The building had been in use from the middle of the third century, and was demolished soon after 367.
200+ sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised approximately 1400 radiates from Gallienus to Tacitus Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 337g and 1084g.
The hoard was found north of the village, in 3 ceramic vessels. It comprised c. 500 bronze coins. 180 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
27 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I of which 23 imitations
Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: 86 of various denominations - sestertii, asses, antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Quintillus (AD 270).

A probable hoard of 3 sestertii and 1 1 denarius (Vespasian and Hadrian) found among charcoal and other occupation refuse in Room 25. Their date range suggests a hoard, but this cannot be said for certain as their exact depositional context was not recorded.
The hoard comprised a small black ceramic vessel closed with a stopper and containing 54 Republican and early Imperial denarii.

6 aes coins (Augustus - Severus Alexander), found approx. 1 km southeast of Meyendorf in the middle of the 19th c., on the premises of an orchard near Stangenberg. The group also comprised 1 modern cast sestertius, and a modern belt closure, which casts some doubt on the authenticity of the find.

77 Republican denarii, 12 uncertain Republican denarii, 1 Imperial aureus (Titus under Vespasian), 12 Imperial denarii (Augustus and Vespasian) and 7 Imperial AE (Galba and Vespasian) found with a skeleton in regio IX, insula 14, second atrium north of west wing of building 2.4 (house).
Unknown initial number of coins. 11 silver coins in the Museum of Ruse: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 16.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1495 (initially, 12 coins, after robbery only 8)

summary: Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: The hoard comprised 'a black coarseware vessel containing 32 electrum staters and some Republican and imperial coins in quite a good state of preservation.' The hoard was found by quarry workers in a quarry

Over 4500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.

Hoard of circa 6000 siliquae (11.5 kilos). 3 lots from this hoard are known, comprising 536 coins: Constantius II (98); Julian (24); Jovian (20); Procopius (9); Valentinian I (128); Valens (157); Gratian (17); uncertain (92).
2 aurei of Nero (AD 54-68).
Hoard of antoniniani (radiates) and denarii. 128 coins were kept in the museum in Modena in 1829: Maximinus I Thrax (Diva Paulina) - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
5 Antoniniani found together on the 'Tokenberg', in Göstrup-Hüt10hau. These may be part of a larger find.
Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
698 nummi of the 4th century AD found with a ceramic vessel ('oletta'). Probably, part of the hoard SIRACUSA 1896 B. Work in progress.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.no.: 16514)

summary: Originally, around 50 denarii. Only 10 are recorded: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
15-20 provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: 247 antoniniani (radiates): Gordiasn III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
196 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valentinian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver w8: 245.0g.
4 Iron Age East Anglian silver units (1 of which was a plated copy with a copper alloy core).
The hoard comprised 25 nummi from the House of Constantine to the House of Valentinian I (AD 364-388).
35 nummi found together in a domus: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
238 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Lcenturyarden (218 coins), Drents Museum, Assen (20 coins). 1 coin lost. FML

summary: A hoard of no less than 27 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the village of Filiopil in the Vinnytsia region. The hoard was found at the foot of a medieval earthen defense structure. The coins were collected from an area of 30x30 m. After the first search, 37 coins were found, and it is likely that other treasure hunters have subsequently searched the site. The finder reports that the coins were well preserved, with bronze oxides. In total I have been informed of finds of denarii from the time of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Clodius Albinus. The photos I received from the finder show images of 10 coins (Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Clodius Albinus, Septimius Severus). The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
The hoard comprised 16 nummi from Diocletian to Constantine I and was probably the con10ts of a purse.
2 Gallo-Belgic C staters recorded in trade, possibly a small hoard.
Circa 780 broze coins, 778 studied: 776 imperial bronzes, 1 dupondius/as, 1 provincial coin (koinon of Cyprus): Vespasian to Philip I.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: 7 solidi: Valentinian I - Constantine III (AD 407-411); gold w8: 31.15 g.

Over 60 gold coins. Found in a jar during construction of industrial compound 250 m from the mound of Kinet Höyük, apparently in the same place as the KINET HÖYÜK 1999. Intercepted by police during dispersal.
10 silver coins: 9 denarii, 1 antoniniani(radiate) (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: Hoard of nummi found within the ruins of a fortress. Only 3 coins are known: Maximian I, Maximinus II Daia, Licinius I as they entered the private collection A.N.Simonov.
(circa 80) 26 silver coins: 3 denarii, 23 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania;

summary: The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: The hoard was discovered by workmen and comprised gold and silver coins, jewellery and silverware. Many of the coins and medallions were stolen shortly after the discovery of the hoard (Bastien and Metzger 1977, 9). The catalogue was constructed using material from private collections and archives, a catalogue created by R. Ratto in 1923, photographic plates taken by E. Bourgey, publications of A. Baldwin, numerous scholarly articles and sales catalogues. Of a total of approximately 700 specimens, 472 coins have been catalogued. The silver vase in which the coins were found is missing 'On discovery, the find was placed in a bucket and much of it was stolen by the workmen in the course of the following night. As the result of a legal action, the workmen gave back a number of coins and jewels, but retained the greater part, in particular, the gold multiples which they sold in Belgium…they spread the rumour that some gold medallions had been melted down and destroyed' (Bastien and Metzger 1977, 214)
A poorly-recorded hoard of early north-east coast staters.
The hoard comprised a large cup containing 635 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 332 were identified. Silver w8: 172.4-792.8g.
(3500-3600) 3106 antoniniani: Trebonianus Gallus - Tacitus (AD 276); silver w8: c.640.1-4436.6 g
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard comprised 2 solidi of Constantine I and Magnentius, found at the St-Luzisteig pass, ca. 1863.
Between 80 and 100 solidi: Theodosius II - Justin I (AD 518-522).

'Between the paving and the vegetal mantle, there is a level of about 15 cm where they were found… a series of coins from the 4th century AD. They were located close to each other....some 30 coins were found, of which only 6 have come into our possession.'
200-300 denarii of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD found in unknown circumstances. No further information.

The hoard comprised a mass of coins which were concreted together. It is estimated that there were as many as 5000. However, only 130 examples were cleaned. These were found to be of the emperors Gallienus and Probus.
84 antoniniani (radiates) from the area of Lisbon: Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: The British Museum (?), London, United Kingdom

summary: The coins were found in a purse in Grave 144 and comprised 8 nummi from Gratian to Arcadius.
8 coins of Tetricus I, including some imitations, located in the museum of Bad Dürkheim and allegedly found 1854 in an urn. This could be a hoard, or part of 1, or a grave find.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
During a rescue excavation, 13 coins were found close to each other or even glued: Celtoiberic - Valens (AD 364-375).
76 denarii: 75 republican, 1 imperial: Augustus (AD 8).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 69154...76545

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. Among them those of Tetricus I, Constantine I, Constantine II, Constantius II for Constantius III Gallus (AD 352-354).
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.
A rather confused record of a series of finds, totalling 62 Iron Age staters found in a field. 4 Roman silver coins also menti1d as stray finds in 1996
437 antoniniani (radiates) in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Musées royauc d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: Grup of 2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver w8: 5.52 g.
5 late Roman solidi, stacked on top of each other and placed inside a massive gold wire. The total w8 in gold of the ensemble is 93 g.
The hoard contains 21 gold solidi struck in Antioch and ranging in date from Valentinian I to Valentinian II.
1173 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 317.7-1465.3g.
66 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver w8: 94.0-193.2 g.

In 1966 evidence of another coin hoard from Eining was made public. The coins were found between 1958 and 1965. The hoard included at least 20 denarii, ranging from Trajan to Maximinus. It is probably not complete.
The hoard comprised a large number of denarii and radiates, although only 160 were recorded and were issues from Septimius Severus to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 50.3g to 413.7g.
313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

A hoard of 'some 700 Roman copper coins' of the time of Constantine I, said to have been found in a box during building work, excavating the the site of a new hotel in Tavistock Square, Bloomsbury. 667 were listed by H. Mattingly, with rulers and mints. It is said that the hoard included also a base denarius of Lucius Verus, and a billon antoninus of Claudius II (JRS, XIV (1924), 229f.).
2830 silver coins: 2827 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 2 drachms: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 196-197); silver w8: before restoration: 9290g; after restoration: 9075.17g
disposition: History Museum ”Iulian Antonescu” Bacau, Bacau County, Romania

summary: The hoard was found during excavations directed by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques de Poitou-Charentes on the site of the Trésorerie Générale: Claudius II (Divus) - House of Constantine I (AD 347-348).
500 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Tetrarchy - Honorius (AD 395-423). Only 54 could be identified.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Provinciale di Salerno, Italy (inv.nos. 17329-17382

summary: 5 nummi: Constantine I - Constans (AD 348-350).
250 silver coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 314.2-735.8g
20 nummi found near the hillfort of A Peneda: Claudius II - Valentinian II (AD 383-392).

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: The coins were found in a double-burial amongst numerous other grave goods. It has been interpreted as a Burgundian grave dating to the period AD 457 to 461. Gold: 1, 2 coins; Gold w8: 7.45g; Silver: 2 coins; Silver w8: 2.54g
disposition: Cl. Côte Collection (1912) (solidus, tremisses Valentinian III and Majorian, two earrings)

summary: 2 aurei found within the modern prison ground, all in the same year. They are presented as single finds in bibliography: Tiberius, Domitian.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
(3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii from Vespasian to Commodus, 1 dupondius of Caracalla and 281 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 351.8g to 729.5g
8 solidi, among: 1 Constantine III, 1 Joannes, 3 Valentinian III (AD 425-455); gold w8: 22.25 g.
7 nummi found in a wooden box in a cave with other artefacts: Constantius II (AD 337-361).

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.
450 denarii: Republic - Augustus (27 BC -AD 14.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Cividale, Italy

summary: A hoard of unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A hoard found at Middle Farm, Cople, Bedfordshire in 2004 (2 solidi, 5 siliquae) and 2005 (10 siliquae). A solidus of Honorius, found before 1899 in a field, is presumably to be associated with this hoard. Coins range from Valens to Arcadius and Honorius, with the latest coins dating to AD 394-402.
23 nummi found in a pit under the floor of a domestic building, range: Constans - Theodosius II (AD 408-450). Possible, part of the hoard Termini Imerse 1984 B.
disposition: Museo Civico "B. Romano" Comune di Termini Imerese

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 2 asses are known: Nero, Gordian III.
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a) 1 or more aurei. Coutil states that there were 6. B) approximately 1600 silver and billon coins, almost all being radiates. C) 3 ogold pendants (?) 'coulants' were also recovered. The hoard was sold at auction in May 1880. According to Angérard, the State (the Cabinet des Médailles?) acquired the aureus of Faustina. The Musée d'Évreux has 63 coins from the assemblage and Louviers, 43 (including issues of Valerian, Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Claudius II). Gold: 6? (1) coins; Gold w8: 19.3; Silver: 2, 1343 coins; Silver w8: 365.8-3493.2
The hoard comprised 14 silver Iron Age coins.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen; Inventory: III, 2, p. 48, no. 1871 (1893) and IV, no. 4554 (1931)

summary: Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and 4 rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: The hoard comprised 'a bucketful of Roman coins, fused together with corrosion products. Cochet estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard was more than 300. The coins were antoniniani (radiates) of the third century depicting 10 emperors until Tacitus and Probus.
disposition: Musées d’Angers, France; Accession Register III, p. 37, no. 42 (3.11.1876)

summary: 61 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A hoard of around 1200 imperial denarii was found while metal detecting. The coins were placed in 3 pitchers.
2 Gallo-Belgic staters recorded in trade, reportedly found on the same site, in 1991 and 1992. Possibly a small hoard.
5 denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).

In 1946 during peat digging the find was discovered in a marsh, between St. Annen and Lunden. The find consisted of a wooden box (not preserved) containing a small silver vessel (destroyed) with 9 pearls, 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius, rolls of 23 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Caracalla), and 2 small bronze rings.
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgar10bridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. 1 of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. 1 coin was lost.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
The hoard comprised between 1121 and 1123 bronze coins dating to the 4th century AD.
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: The hoard comprised 6 bronze coins struck in Caesarea Maritima from the reign of Nero (AD 54-68) and 1 autonomous coin struck in Dora.
The hoard comprised 3700 bronze coins dated between AD 316 and AD 361.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (1,172- IAA nos. 23066-23418 and nos. 30278-31050)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 4 coins provided some data: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius, Elagabalus, Maximinus I Thrax, Gallienus (sole reign).
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
1049 bronze coins found in 3 ceramic vessels placed 1 next to the other: 1045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: 26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

summary: The hoard comprised 34 silver coins, placed 1 on top of the other and identified as staters of Coriosolites of Classes I, II and II (BN 6634; 6598 and 6614) Found by a labourer breaking rocks. Bought 20.11.1908.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 268 handed to the National Museum in Bucharest: Nero - Marcus Aurelius. 1 denarius may depict Julia Domna?
disposition: National Museum of History, Bucharest, Romania; Museum of History and Archaeology, Piatra Neamț, Romania (the vessel)

summary: 772 nummi: Constantine I - Valentinian II (AD 375-378), found with a ceramic vessel during ploughing. w8 1.55 kg (before cleaning).

1043 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 285-286). The emperors represented include: Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Divus Claudius II, 'Imp. Gallo', Aurelian and Probus. However, the original number of coins was ca. 3.840.
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Spain

summary: 60 silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel while planting a vineyard. 44 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Republic - Claudius I (AD 41-54).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (24 coins)

summary: Hoard from the excavated Town House at Colliton Park, Dorchester (excavated 1937-8 and published in Durham and Fulford 2014, 59). 9 coins were found near the East door of room 13, building 182. However in revaluation (ibid) these were thought to be a residual scatter. In his report, Reece (same volume p.103) notes the presence of this hoard and 5 others identified by Mark Corney (2 first to third century and 3 Theodosian). However his report does not attribute these hoard coins to particular hoards and they are therefore difficult to reconstruct.The latest coin in this hoard was of Crispus AD 317-326, though the hoard coins from this hoard do not appear to be in Reece's catalogue.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 400 large and small bronze coins nearly all of the Late Empire.

The hoard comprised 2 copper-alloy urns containing 515 Roman coins (denarii, antoniniani (radiates) and bronzes). The majority of the coins were well preserved. The division of the coins between the 2 urns was not recorded. The hoard was found while extracting limest1. Vespasian - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
Unknown originally number of coins. 49 denarii recovered: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223); silver w8: 70.2-143.0 g.
1600 nummi: Carinus - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388). Found in a ciste made of bricks and covered with a slab.
The hoard comprised 658 silver coins (denarii, a few antoniniani and 1 drachm from Caesarea in Cappadocia) from Republican issues of Mark Antony to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Zürich, Fundmünzenbearbeitungsstelle, Münzkabinett der Stadt Winterthur

summary: HER has a record of "a hoard of 22 antoniniani of the period AD259-273" in Swindon Museum.
The hoard comprised more than 6000 radiates from Julia Domna to Postumus, the most numerous being of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Found by a workman on the land of B. Flamand

The hoard comprised 29 coins, ranging from Hellenistic times (?) to Philip. This includes coins of Athens and Cnossus, as well as Roman sestertii, dupondii and asses. Hadrian, Severus Alexander and Gordian III are also menti1d. The hoard was found beneath the foundations of a building, under a slab of st1.
The hoard comprised 1 ceramic jug and 2 urns (?) containing 90 kg of coins. 2777 antoniniani are known: Divus Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Circonscription archéologique de la ville de Souk Ahras

summary: 103 coins: 7 antoniniani, 96 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 17

summary: De Jersey lists a possible scattered hoard but notes "the presence of several later, inscribed coins might indicate several episodes of deposition, or the exis10ce of some sort of temple site".

find_spot_name: POMPEII VI, 17, PORTA DI ERCOLANO C
summary: 106 Republican and Imperial aurei and denarii found near the Porta Ercolano.
483 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (unknown number)

summary: 277 antoniniani (radiates) + 28 imitations antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation denarius: Valerian I and Gallienus for Saloninus (Caesar) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
disposition: Musées royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: Hoard of 25 coins of the Bosporan kings: Cotys III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
The hoard was found under a doorstep and comprised approximately 400 gold coins of the Early Empire. They were immediately sold and no catalogue was made.
256 bronze coins: 1 Greek, 1 provincial 254 nummi: House of Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 402-450).
199 Roman imperial large bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928a.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included 1 denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: Hoard of 74 denarii found near a Dacian settlement: Republic – Augustus (2 BC – AD 4).
191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?
6 uncertain AR, 1 Imperial AE (Vespasian) and 15 uncertain AE found with a skeleton and a bracelet in regio VI, insula 1, north of peristyle of building 7 (house).

273 mostly Late Roman Coins ranging from Celtic (30-5 BC) to Honorius (393-423). A nucleus of Late Roman nummi can be easily distinguished, probably consisting of several hoards, all determined as far as possible.
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
160 nummi of the 4th century AD. Possible, part of the hoard SIRACUSA 1896 A. Work in progress.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.no.: 16535)

summary: 16 bronze coins were bought by the museum: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. XXV

summary: 526 nummi: Constantius II - Valens (AD 364-378). No further details
disposition: Accademia di Sant’Anselmo di Aosta, Italy

summary: "The 10ant of 1 of the gardens dug up, within the last few years, at least 5 hundred Roman coins. They are a "denarius of Valentinian, and small brass of Tetricus, Carausius (?), Magnentius, and Constantine". The large number of coins found suggest that they did come from a scattered hoard. The coins of Tetricus must have been antoniniani, those of Carausius? probably so.
6 nummi recovered after a flood: Constantine I 2, Constantine II/Constantius II 1, Cionstantius III Gallus 1, Valentinian I 1 (AD 364-375).
Found in a ceramic vessel, 120 coins: 66 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 147.7-320.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2442, 120 coins

summary: (ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: A fused mass of 6 staters, evidently fiercely burnt, weighing 32.92 g. The coins at each end are readily identifiable as a biga stater of Cunobelin and a stater of Tasciovanos; the 4 in the middle remain unidentified, although they are presumably of the same types.
360 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 200-201).
The hoard comprised 5 sestertii with a TPQ of AD 97.

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are 2 lists of coins for the hoard; 1 lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
A possible hoard found during the agricultural works. Sestertius of Tiberius and nummi from Constantine I to Honorius/Theodosius II (AD 408-423).

Hoard of around 4000 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 166 pieces were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 292-293). Not clear whether the coins of the Tetrarchs include also nummi or only antoniniani (radiates).
The hoard comprised 120 4th century nummi from a variety of mints, found inside a st1 cavity in a Roman house.
5 denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.

Landron estimated that there were 35642 coins in the hoard, whereas Blomme suggested a total of 57775. Leclercq dates the hoard to the end of the Gallic Wars. Found by 2 agricultural workers while emptying a manure pit on the farm of Mme Revel de Saint-Mart. The hoard was dispersed. The curate of Ledringhem took 200 of the coins. A. Preux of Douai took others and 150 were sold in 1853.
The hoard comprised 117 bronze coins dated between Ptolemy I (323-283/2 BC) and Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
73 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos.1538-1610 (73 coins, 69 have been stolen)

summary: The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.
Circa 100 silver coins. Y. Youroukova have seen 30: 10 denarii, 20 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised 1 bronze vessel containing 7150 radiates from Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus and Probus. It must be linked to the treasure LA VINEUSE II
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 250 Roman coins of Gallienus, Saloninus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian.

A hoard of 10 denarii (Septimius Severus - Alexander Severus) discovered during groundwork for the continuation of Harthauser Street into wooded area in southern Harlaching. The coins lay close to the remains of a skeleton.

A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other 1s exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised 273 sestertii from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus.
Hoard of over 1000 coins of the time of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
38 imitation antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I found under the granite foundations of a central building from the fort.
411 coins. 254 studied: 1 Greek bronze coin, 2 denarii, 9 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze, 241 nummi: Greek - Theodosius II (AD 402-450).
disposition: National Museum of History, Belgrade, Serbia

summary: 400 nummi, almost all of the Constantinian period were found with a ceramic vessel.
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 5 coins are documented: Domitian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Philip I (AD ).
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 319 bronze prutot of the Hasmonaean kings.
disposition: Palestine Exploration Fund; Jerusalem (Department of Antiquities)

summary: The hoard comprised a jar containing more than 7000 denarii and some radiates. Some contemporary reports suggest that there were as many as 12000 coins. Hugon suggested that the gaps in types and paucity of the latest issues and the presence almost exclusively of denarii indicated that the hoard was sorted by type and denomination and that originally there may have been further jars. Indeed, in 1943, a further vessel containing 28 denarii was found at the same findspot and is considered to be part of the same hoard.

The hoard comprised an 'earthenware vase containing 47 silver Baiocasses staters.' 37 coins were donated to the Musée de Rouen (Inventory III, 2, p. 157, Inv. 2638). A further 10 were deposited in 1939 with the Musée Biochet de Caudebec-en-Caux. These were destroyed during the 2nd World War.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France (37 coins) (Inventory III, 2, p. 157, Inv. 2638). Musée Biochet de Caudebec-en-Caux, France (10 cois; lost during WWII)

summary: (700-800) denarii and antoniniani. 251 coins are kept in the museum in Isperih: Galba - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Unknown initial number of coins. 5 coins are known: 1 Greek coin, 3 denarii, 2 plated denarii: 2nd c. BC - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205). It may be a votive offering as suggested by some scholars based on the findspot.

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Hoard of 300 republican denarii. Partially recovered. Latest issue: 43-42 BC.
67 nummi found scattered on very small area of a preafurnium: House of Constantine - House of Valentinian (AD 364-375)

De Jersey (2015) writes: "Iron Age gold coins - principally Gallo-Belgic E staters - have been recorded from the cliff and/or beach between Weybourne and Sheringham for 1 hundred and 50 years or more, and consequently the reconstruction of exactly what has been found is complicated." He gives a detailed discussion of discoveries from 1847 onwards in the area and the difficulties in assessing whether the various finds come from 1 or more deposits. The PAS listing is taken from his summary. The finds also include a fragment of a tubular torc.
A hoard of 58 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Edessa, Dium and the koinon of Macedonia), from the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, found in the northern room of SW section of Building IX in Palatiano.
More than 200 nummi comprising issues of Constantine I, Constans, Constantius II, Valentinian I and Valentinian II.
The hoard comprised approximately 300 'small bronze' Roman coins, probably radiates. Only 1 coin was described, a radiate of Probus with a MARS VICTOR reverse.

There are 2 different notes regarding hoards found in this area in the 1880s. The author argues that the notes relate to the same hoard. A) A bronze vase containing silver coins of the third century AD was found in Sardoal. 12 of these coins were acquired by the Ethnographic Museum. B) The Ethnographic Museum in Abrantes acquired 190 silver coins dating to the third century AD, which formed part of a hoard found in Sardoal in the 1880s.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. There is some information on 7 coins: 1 denarius, 6 antoniniani: Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)
11 bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Before 1933, 20 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Victorinus and Claudius II were discovered in the Corgnac, now a suburb of Limoges.
562 coins, mostly denarii, 1 aureus (Galba) and some antoninianii, ranging from the late Republic to Severus Alexander, found in Baden-Baden, auf dem Quettich. No further informations given in FMRD.
19 silver coins: 18 denarii of Augustus, 1 republican quinarius (19-18 BC).
Hoard of 191 coins: 190 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 Roman provincial coin (Ephesus) found as a pile on the caldarium's floor: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 272).
Hoard of 500-1000 denarii: Second Triumvirate - Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
The hoard comprised 30 nummi dated between AD 330-335 and AD 341-346.
The hoard comprised close to 8000 nummi of the House of Constantine, including SOLI INVICTO, PROVIDENTIAE CAESARVM NOSTRORVM, GLORIA EXERCITVS, VRBS ROMA and PIETAS PVBLICA and PAX ROMANA.
The hoard comprised an unknown amount of jewellery and 93 solidi terminating in issues of Anastasius (AD 491-492).
disposition: J. Aubry in 1958; nowadays; location unknown

summary: 3 aurei: Trajan, Septimius Severus, Caracalla (AD 213).
37 nummi: Constantine I - Arcadius (297-393).
Votive offering at the entrance in the cave - 15 coins. Group of single coin finds with portraits of several emperors from Augustus to Arcadius (AD 383-408).
100 nummi, most of them from the time of Constantine I. Uncertain, whether they were all found together
38 coins: 16 denarii and 22 bronze coins found together in a tavern in the 19th century. Only 12 denarii could be re-identified:
disposition: Il Medagliere del Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Italy

summary: A hoard of 13+ drachms of reduced w8, struck by Rhodes in the late 1st c. BC. The find spot is given as Rhodes (?) in CH II, but Marmaris in CH VII.

During ancient excavations on a Roman iron production site, a hoard of 110 official and local imitation radiates was found. The coins ranged from issues of Valerian I to Tetricus I and II, with a single outlier of Marcus Aurelius.

Penhallurick (2009, 182) notes the find of 2 illegible "second brass" of Vespasian found at "a depth of 8 feet (grave 15 J5) together with some cow b1s, lying in an ancient trench" in Penzance cemetery. Presumably therefore found together and a small in10tional deposit.
6 Iron Age staters found in 1851.
A hoard of 15 Roman bronzer coins, allegedly found in the vicinity of Bad Pyrmont in 1935. FMRD considers that the list of coins ressembles more that of a private collection, than a hoard.
6 solidi found between 1788 and 1887 within the same village. Probably belonging to a larger hoard: Valentinian III 2, Theodosius II 2, Leo I 1, Libius Severus 1 (AD 461-465).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elbląg (Elbing) (until 1944)

summary: The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 270 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Aurelian. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 73.9g and 336.5g
A hoard of 170 Gallo-Belgic staters and 3 quarter-staters found between October 1990 and March 1991.
