1 denarius (Mark Antony), 9 gold staters of Cunobelin and 1 copper-alloy brooch.

The hoard comprised a 427 coins of Constantine I and his sons. Close by, 166 coins dating to the period AD 320-335 were also found. Although originally interpreted as site finds, it is possible that they represent a further portion of this hoard. A lot of coins from this hoard is preserved in the Musée de Laval (Mayenne) with the label 'Jublains Hoard'.
2 aurei of Vespasian and Trajan, probably, found in Braga.
21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III
71 nummi ending with issues of the House of Constantine I (AD 337-340). No further information.

A hoard found during road work. Some coins were dispersed, and the total of coins recovered was 447, made up of 3 gold solidi, 12 miliarensia, and 432 silver siliquae. No trace of the container which held the hoard was found despite careful search.

Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: 24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver w8: 10.25 g.
The hoard comprised between 30 and 40 electrum staters of Type LT XIII, 4395, weighing between 6.5g and 6.8g. There is no suggestion that a Namnète stater found in Savenay is part of this hoard.
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.
3000 coins: Septimius Severus – Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (unknown number of coins)

summary: 96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: Hoard of 118 denarii: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found a pair of gold earrings, a silver belt buckle with a massive "proboscis" detached from the pin. Owing to the presence of this silver belt buckle the hoard is dated to the late 4th - early 5th century AD.
8 radiates declared Treasure Trove in 1980, otherwise unpublished. Not part of the Sprotbrough 1980 hoard.
Uknown originally number of coins. Only 5 nummi are known: Licinius I, Constantine I (Crispus (Caesar), Constantine II, Constantius II, Valens.
A hoard of 866 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Elagabalus, and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia, found during blasting at a quarry near Obererbach in 1944.

The group of coins comprised about 55 coins, with at least 1 gold coin and 32-37 identifiable nummi dated to the 4th century AD. "About 50-5 coins were found, of which some 30-2 were legible and could be attributed to definite rulers, the remainder being all late 4th century AE 3 or 4. The earliest of the legible 1s is a gold coin of Valens, in almost mint condition" (Iliffe 1934, 81). The deposition date was placed at c. AD 396, based on the types represented, "at a time when the 'Gloria Romanorum' was still the main type in circulation and the 'Virtus Exerciti' had just begun to come in" (ibid, 83).

IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 6 denarii. Other coins have been recorded from the immediate area but they were not considered to be part of this hoard. For full details and images see SOM-D0A907.
The hoard comprised 21 sestertii and 2 dupondii or asses from Trajan to Severus Alexander. It was found on an ancient floor surface in the corner of a room during archaeological excavations.
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
An undeclared hoard of perhaps 25 or 30 Iron Age staters, dispersed in trade, consisting mainly in staters of Dubnovellaunos, V169/ABC 303.
3 imperial AE (Nero, Galba and Vespasian) found in regio IX, insula 11, fallen from a rack on top of amphorae leaning against wall E of building 2 (thermopolium).
Around 1200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.

Snettisham hoards B and C were initially discovered by a tractor driver in November 1948. When the finds were collected, the 2 hoards became mixed. The 12 coins from hoard B listed here, however, were not discovered until the excavation which was directed by Clarke in December 1948. The torcs listed here may have been associated with hoard B or C.

Circa 500 silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver gilded bracelets and 3 silver rings. 50 antoniniani are kept in the History Museum in Lom: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; (50 coins, 1 bracelet, 3 rings)

summary: A hoard of 47 bronzes, found in 1 of the buildings of Area 2 (on the floor of courtyard 6) during the Hatra excavations. Most of them were imitative SC coins (Hatra), with radiate head and eagle types, and some were 'senatorial dupondii' cut in half. It is unclear what is meant with 'senatorial dupondii', but these could be either provincial or imitative coinages.
13 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 11 nummi: Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (393-395). Found on the decumanus. Uncertain whether they were found together. (Chico provides a list of 12 only).
disposition: Museo Monográfico de Itálica, Santiponce, Spain

summary: 1602 silver coins: denarii, quinarii, antoniniani (radiates), drachm: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A possibly large number (1700?) of Roman coins were found at Cadnam, in the Forest, contained in a thumb pot. This included coins of Tetricus (I or II?).
200 antoniniani and nummi. Only 3 coins of Valerian I for Gallienus, Licinius I and Valentinian II were noticed.
In 1835, a hoard of 12000 coins was found there. Hundreds of antoniniani (radiates) of the Gallic emperors were discovered in 1852.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 10 pieces were seen: Philip I, Otacilia, Trajan Decius.
Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius: 350 silver coins; silver w8: 352.8-905.2g.
4-5000 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II found in a ceramic vessel (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 35 aurei from Tiberius to Claudius, including commemorative issues for Drusus the Elder and Antonia.
7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: Unknown number of solidi found with lead recipient. 9 coins were recovered: Leo I - Anastasius (AD ; Gold w8: 40.05g;
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale della Valle Camonica, Italy (inv.nos. 53257-53265)

summary: Assemblage of 25 copper alloy coins from the Ancaster area donated to the British Museum by the finder in 2008. The group could be considered to be a hoard, containing Magnentian coins that have been cut to make smaller coins and contemporary copies of FEL TEMP fallen horseman type. However the group includes a cut Valentinianic coin and a possible Theodosian coin. Given the lack of contextual information available it is difficult to say which of these coins constitute a hoard.
The hoard was found on 2 February 1985 - initially 1 coin and then another 30-2 about 15 cm deeper, with the remains of a pottery vessel.
2 aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
Hoard of around 1600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
A large hoard of Chute staters found by metal detectors over several visits, with a brief mention by Haselgrove (1978, 24).

A hoard of 6 nummi, comprising 4 FEL TEMP REPARATIO types of various sizes, 1 of Valens, and 1 possible Magnentian imitation, found in deposits overlying the natatio fountain house during consolidation works. The coins were fused together and could not be identified with any greater precision.
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except 1 note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).
14 Iron Age silver coins found over a period of several years

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest 1s date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins

The hoard comprised 1 bronze coin struck under the reign of Ptolemy IX (115-104/1 BC) and further 259 Roman imperial bronze denominations ranging from Constantine the Great to that of Julian II (AD 335-363).
1 imperial denarius (Nero), 4 uncertain denarii and an uncertain group of imperial bronze coins fused together found with 5 skeletons and a gold ring in regio VI, insula 6, building 1 (house).
6 denarii: Caesar - Domitianus (AD 81).

The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.

Mattingly (2000, 20) lists 3 other poss. hoards from Frocester. These included 2 4th C coins found in contact on the pebble/gravel surface under Building E (hoard 4 - check). CK 512. CK523a - to check

Several thousand Roman coins reported to have been found in 1852. 32 coins, findspot menti1d "Malvaglia" and "Val di Blenio", entered the collection of the Antiquarische Gesellschaft Zürich (AGZ) and have now integrated the collections of the Schweizerisches Nationalmuseum, Zürich. They are probably part of this hoard (32 antoniniani, Aurelian to Diocletian).
disposition: Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (32 coins); the other ones are lost.

summary: Over 13 bronze coins. 15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 165 they are dated in the first half of the 1st century AD. No further information.
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver w8: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with b1s fragments and an oval whetst1.

From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.
29 bronze coins: 27 setertii, 1 dupondius, 1 dupondius/as: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Hoard of 1040 silver coins (?) found in a small ceramic vessel of which only 394 silver coins are known: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Museum, Panagyurishte; Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria

summary: Uncovered by workmen levelling a stretch of Offa's Dyke. At least 32 coins of the 1st-4th centuries along with an assemblage of small finds, a votive altar, and several probable cinerary urns. No further contextual information is available. Owing to their wide range, it is highly unlikely that the coins ever constituted a single hoard. 2 small hoards of the 1st-2nd and 3rd-4th centuries are possible, as is Guest and Wells' suggestion that the entire assemblage might represent a votive deposit that was built up over time.
An unknown original number of coins 513 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-259); silver w8: 639.3-1327.5 g.
The hoard of 17 aurei of Augustus was found during repairs to the paving of rue Saint-Esprit (actually rue Gondinet).
Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 26.6-117.8g.
38 aurei: Tiberius - Nero (AD 62-63).
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!
A hoard of 30 AE coins of Apamea, Cremna, Sagalassos, Aspendos, Perge and Galatia dating from the mid / late first century BC.
361 antoniniani/radiate: Gallienus - Tetrachy (AD 292-293)
Unknown number of solidi. 32 solidi were known: Theodosius II - Zeno (AD 476-491).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France (10 coins).

summary: 700 denarii found with more ceramic vessels following floods. Only 75 pieces were recorded: Republic - Claudius I (AD 41-45).
The hoard was found in a layer of carbonised material and ash. It comprised a group of 60 Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).

4th century. Coins 80, 83 & 84 - 3 coins found in small pit/posthole [148] outside doorway of House 1. No other finds from feature, & coins may have been deposited after removal of a post (pp. 360). These coins were approx. 20 years later in date than those used in house infill.
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 29 "aurei" (solidi) dating to the reign of Honorius and Theodosius II, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.
11 antoniniani (Gallienus - Divus Claudius, AD 270) found on the southwestern slope of the Sommerberg directly above Furtwangen.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
2329 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 289-290) found in a jar, buried beneath the doorway between a room and the courtyard, during excavations of a house.
16 silver coins: 4 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard was found in a niche in a wall structure and comprised an 'important assemblage of gold and silver Roman coins which were dispersed amongst the workmen. It appears that there were more than 2000 coins, mostly silver issues dating up to the reign of Septimius Severus. There were 2 aurei of Commodus mounted in jewellery. Comarmond notes 2 aurei of Nero and a gold quinarius of Commodus. Issues of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna were numerous and well-preserved, but there were no coins of Caracalla or Geta. There were also numerous items of gold jewellery, weighing a total of 741g, which the brother supervising the works managed to collect together. The jewellery was the subject of a detailed publication by Comarmond. The hoard was found by workmen digging foundation trenches for a new boarding school run by the Christian Brothers.
1504 almost exclusively nummi. 1476 nummi, 4 Naimana imitations, 1 Sapur II, and 85 fragments: Constantine I - Marcian (AD 450-457).
disposition: Archaeological Department, Colombo, on 14th October 1975 (Inv: Arch. Dept. 75/12)

summary: A hoard of 72-82 coins of Verica and 4-5 of Epaticcus. It difficult to establish exactly how many coins it may have contained.
4 Chute type staters (NC 166 (2006), 365 no. 1), found just within the Hampshire county boundary. No further details are known.
Hoard of 174 denarii. 53 coins are kept in the National Museum in Budapest, Hungary: Republic – Domitian (AD 81-96).
disposition: National Hungarian Museum, Budapest, Hungary (53 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised around 525 nummi from the House of Constantine.
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.

A small hoard of Iron Age gold coins, found on the beach in Folkest1 in ca. 1877. It has been argued that some coins found in the area in 1838, 1865, 1870 and in the late 1990's are strays from the same hoard.

An upturned bowl made of white metal under which coins lay. Some of the coins were bound together into 1 chunk by oxidation. 192 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 257). Together gold jewelry was found: 2 pinheads connected by a chain, a pendant decorated with base emeralds and an onyx cameo. Apparently, the jewelry had been in a now rotted wooden box. This assumption is supported by fittings found near the jewelry and a broken bronze key. The circumstances of discovery indicate that the casket was not originally buried.
6 coins: 5 denarii, 1 unknown denomination: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).Uncertain whether the cooins belong to a hoard or are single finds.
"Allegedly about 30000 Roman ‘third brass’. Doubtful. Confirmation required. 8000 pieces are supposedly stored at the Archaeological Department in Colombo." No further information.
disposition: Archaeological Department in Colombo, Sri Lanka (8,000 coins)

summary: 26 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXVI

summary: The hoard comprised 36 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) - of Gordian III to Postumus and 6 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Faustina II.

2 scattered hoards identified in villa excavated in 1950s. The site produced an unusual amount of coins (850). It is not clear from the published account how many belonged to each hoard. This hoard thought to be about 200 coins, with a large proportion of Fel Temp copies.

11 coins found over 3 private searches; 1 in 2009, 4 in 2011 and 6 in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.
Composed of 5 denarii of August and 3 republican denariii .
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 16 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal-detecting: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257). Unknown initial number of coins.
300 Republican denarii. All of them with the helmeted head of Rome on the obverse. Only 2 could be studied.
128 silver coins (antoniniani?): Balbinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
A hoard of more than 36 sestertii (Domitian - Julia Domna) found around 1860 on the promontory between the Krummen and Neuedorfer lake ('Scheersberg').

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.

The hoard comprised approximately 200 gold aurei. Some gold coins were found while the miller, Chereau was ploughing in the church's field. He then found quite a large quantity while digging in his field.
In 1785 2 late Roman gold coins of Valens were found on a field near Waldaschaffer lake. The find relates to a hoard or a part of 1.
5 coins found in a cist?: 4 Republican denarii; 1 as Tiberius. The imitation of a Postumus' denarius is, most likely, an intruder.
Originally, 74 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 68 pieces were available for study: Domitian - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
A small hoard of 12 silver denarii. 4 coins of Augustus were of the type Gaius and Lucius.
Hoard of a dozen or more kilos of silver coins. Only 15 denarii are known: Hadrian - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 193-217).

The alleged con10t of a purse comprises 36 mixed denominations (radiates and sestertii) from Trajan to Carinus. The purse was originally located over an aband1d hearth within a taberna in the eastern sector of the so called domus of Titus Macer. Coins originate from different layers; 2 late Roman bronze coins have to be regarded as instrusions while the connection of a very worn repubblican denarius with the purse is uncertain.
disposition: Aquileia, Archaeological National Museum; University of Padua, department of Cultural Heritage

summary: 24 nummi with a tpq AD 455.
The hoard comprised 6 shekels and 6 half shekels from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73), found in a bronze vessel.

The original find comprised 5578 coins, of which only 2330, including 7 ancient forgeries, were recovered by the authorities. These can divided into 2 lots; first, 1067 denarii from Vespasian to Macrinus/Elagabalus (217/22), second, 1263 antoniniani from Severus Alexander to Gallienus (260/8).
300 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 130 coins were recovered: Vespasian - QuintillusI (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being 2 sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
7 Jewish coin, including 3 of the first uprising (AD 67-70).
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Anto9s and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.

The hoard comprised hundreds of nummi of which only 36 were studied: Maxentius 31, Constantine I 5 (AD 313-314). Mints according to Callu: 2 Lugdunum, 8 Rome, 5 Ostia, 3 Ticinum, 3 Aquileia, 4 Carthage.
The hoard comprised 88 nummi of Licinius I, Constantine I and his family with a tpq of between AD 330 and 337.
The hoard comprised a silver patera on which were placed 23 denarii or antoniniani (radiates)(?) of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1 Nero, 2 Vespasian, and 2 uncertain AE found in the Villa Diomede.
676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 113 coins were recovered: Republic – Augustus (18 BC).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (100 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania (13 coins)

summary: 42 denarii found by metal detecting near the Dacian citadel: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Muzeul Judeţean de Istorie şi Artă Zalău, Romania

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani. Dr. Harlanov examined 15 pieces: Caracalla 1, Gordian III 13, Philip I 1; silver w8: 20.1-37.6 g.
27 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 siliqua, 25 nummi found with a bronze saucepan; Valerian I (VDivus Valerian II) - Constantine I. Suspicious case.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico e Histórico de A Coruña, Spain

summary: 30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 39.0-70.0 g.

The hoard comprised a cylindrical copper-alloy vessel containing 450 bronze coins, of which the majority were sestertii. Not all the coins were identified but those that were dated from the reign of Domitian to that of Severus Alexander.
The hoard was found in the northeast part of the Roman fort during an excavation campaign in 1983. It comprised 4 aurei and 70 denarii, ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
ARCH record for 5 Iron Age gold staters.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and 1 more denarius found in 2009. Most likely 1 owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: 2 denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.
132 nummi: Magnentius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
64 nummi found inside the cave of Abauntz, apparently with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 388-392). Together were found a bronze ring and an iron hoe.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain

summary: A hoard of 24 provincial coins (ranging from Antoninus Pius to Geta) and 5 antoniniani (Gallienus) were found in a small pocket behind the stage of the theatre in Corinth, at the level of the marble pavement.

The hoard comprised approximately 1200 sestertii 'of 25 emperors, caesars and empresses' from Vespasian to Gordian III, mostly in a corroded or worn condition. There was also a single unworn bronze of Postumus
The hoard comprised approximately 400 silver coins of Augustus, all in mint condition.
A series of 20 Iron Age staters, found over a period of several years in a field. The last 3 staters found in 2012 are not listed in de Jersey.

In January 2022, 2 detectorists each independently found a golden aureus on the same plot of land in the municipality of Sittard-Geleen. The coins were subsequently reported to PAN by both finders. Rumor has it that some additional gold coins may have been found at this site, but this is uncertain. In April 2022, 1 of the detectorists found another aureus. The 3 coins are: Vespasian, Titus and Trajan.
A hoard of 13+ Roman coins (Caracalla - Gallienus), found after 1850 during house construction in Cottbus.

Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).
A hoard of 6 provincial coins of Philippi, found in grave T23 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL VII
summary: In the inventory from 1899 5 coins are situated with the find location of Cologne, which based on their type might belong to the hoard.
852 coins: 824 antoniniani (radiates), 28 nummi: Gallienus - Constantius II-Valentinian III (AD 337-455).
25 nummi found in of the rooms of the bath complex: Valentinianus I - Honorius (AD 395-423). Dembski offers information on 24 coins.
Large hoard of Roman denarii found in 2 ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.

A hoard of 3119 mostly late Roman coins, found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888 and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1920. The hoard comprised 2 Greek coins, 2 Roman provincial coins, 2245 late Roman imperial coins, 3 small lead disks, and 870 cast imitations.

The hoard comprised 1953 bronze coins in a broken cooking pot was unearthed adjacent to the northwestern entrance of the synagogue, in the western corridor (Bijovsky 1998, 77). The very poor state of conservation has allowed only 380 coins to be documented. The range: 103-76 BC to AD
83 eastern antoniniani (radiates) ranging in date from the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian.
Unknown originally number of coins. 8 silver coins: House of Constantine I (AD 330-347)
disposition: National Museum Prague, Czech Republic (5 coins) 1981

summary: Large hoard found while ploughing. Only 13 antoniniani identified: Caracalla 7, Philip I 6.

The hoard comprised a total of 44 coins including 28 denarii of Vespasian, Domitian, Nerva and mostly Trajan; and 16 Roman Provincial bronzes of Thessalonica (pseudo-autonomous and provincial), found in a grave in Thessalonica.
It comprises 15 Visigothic 'wreath' solidi of Valentinian III (AD 439-455) found in a lead roll.
Con10ts of a little purse. 6 denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: 375 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 38 sestertii were recovered: Domitian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including 1 of Antoninus Pius.
Large quantity of roman provincial bronze coins near the river Duero. Only 6 pieces are recorded: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-37).

The hoard consists of a series of finds of Durotrigan coinage from a field south-east of Maiden Castle, recovered over the course of 12 years or more. The nominal total of coins is 113. The actual number of coins in the original deposit may have been significantly higher.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 05 comprises 394 Iron Age coins and 1 Roman denarius.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: Hoard of 86 coins: 82 republican and imperial denarii, 3 drachms of Dyrrhachium, 1 unidentified bronze coins: Republic - Augustus (29-27 BC).
Hoard of 68 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 pieces were recorded: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
25 silver coins: 2 republican denarii, 21 imperial denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Group of 16 bronze coins found in Pit 637, in farmyard area N of Building 2. No evidence of a container, but pit also contained 1 kg of animal b1, large quantity of 4th C pottery, representing at least 6 diff. vessels; & a zoomorphic brooch. Coins from Constantine II to Constantius II, or AD 321-364.
1500-1700 nummi probably held in a textile container as some fibers survived. 612 coins have been studied so far: Gallienus - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Municipal Abade Pedrosa, Santo Tirso, Portugal

summary: Unknown number of nummi of the House of Constantine I. Only 5 nummi have been seen in a private collection in Soest (1867>
8 bronze coins found in a grave, range: 3rd c. BC - early 4th c. AD.

HER record of a hoard of 190 coins found with a ceramic pot base in High Wycombe under the roots of a tree. Described variously as having a date range AD 240-400 and "of approximately early 4th century date". Dr. Cathy King studied the hoard at the Ashmolean and concluded that it was "problematic" because "some of the mid 4th century coins present never turn up in British hoards" and it had similarities with material more common in early fifth century Egypt. The finder had some archaeological experience and was not using a metal detector.
While ploughing, a ceramic vessel with 13 antoniniani of Aurelian was found.
26 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 254). With silver jewelry.
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
2 solidi: Marcian, Zeno, (AD 474-491).

Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. The hoard comprised 1 small provincial bronze coin of Trajan (18 mm), 2629 late Roman coins and 369 cast imitations.

Around 5000 antoniniani (radiates), 13.5 kg. The majority of coins belonged to Tetricus I and Tetricus II. Other issuers: Gallienus, Salonina, Victorinus, Postumus, Marius, Cludius II, Quintillus, Quintillus (Divus Cludius II), Aurelian.

The hoard was found in a container beneath an altar to the goddess Fontana and comprised numerous bronze and brass issues which were deposited in the Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa. The coins appear to be the offerings of devotees. Only 4 of the coins have been described and these were in a poor state of preservation.
disposition: Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa., Lisboa.

summary: 180 solidi (only 179 mention on Salama's list): Theodosius II - Anastasius (AD 495) and 1 gold ring. Found in the 'Bâtiment à auges' on the northern façade of the basilica.
disposition: Musée d'Alger (176 coins, Registre d'entrées, no 1222, March 1924); Musée de Djémila, Algeria (vanished between 1956-1962)

summary: The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). 1 nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: 14 solidi: Arcadius - Leo I (AD 462-466).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1371-1384

summary: A hoard of approx. 5200 coins, found in a garden close to the station of the railway Cleve - Köln. The hoard was dispersed, though a list of 1203 coins was made and 55 coins are in the museum in Trier. The FMRD list therefore encompassed 1225 entries.

The hoard comprised 500 denarii from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). The catalogue states that the coins were divided into '2 lots, 1 comprising 446 coins'. However, the summary adds up to a total of 500 coins.

1 denarius and 903 radiates (Maximinus I to Victorinus) found by a metal detectorist at Craig-y-Saeson Farm. Decayed fragments of a possible pewter container were found alongside the coins. No more precise depositional or contextual information is available. 8 coins are counterfeit. 7 are of Postumus, whose coinage in now recognised to have been promptly imitated. The other, of Philip I, is a compe10t creation of good w8, but stands out on account of its style
disposition: National Museum Cardiff (103); Newport Museum (40); private collections (761)

summary: 18 nummi of the Constantine I and his family (AD 330-335?).

Over 120 silver coins. Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I (Marcia Otacilia, Philip II), Trajan Decius and Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla). 3 coins were bought by the Coin Room of the National History Museum in Bucharest.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (3 coins)

summary: A hoard of possibly 35+ late Roman gold coins, including at least 5 medallions (Honorius, Galla Placidia), as well as solidi of 'Constantine', 'Valentinian', Valens, Gratian, Arcadius, Honorius, Johannes and 'other emperor and empresses at that time'. The medallions were encased in frames and attached to a gold necklace. Bracelets are also reported of.
disposition: Numismatic National Collection (2 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris (2 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel covered with a tile. It comprised 12 very worn 'large bronzes' of the High Empire (Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander etc) and approximately 400 denarii and radiates including issues of Severus Alexander (1 or 2), Maximinus, Gordian III (numerous), Philip, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian II and Salonina. The majority of the coins were very corroded. The coins were accompanied by 7 gold intaglio finger rings and 2 gold necklaces, 1 set with emeralds and the other lozengiform blue st1s.
800 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further Information.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 5000 bronze coins. They were bought by M. Molchnet who stated that they included coins of Postumus, Victorinus, and a very large number of coins of Tetricus I. The hoard was found by a farmer, leveling of the ground surface in a barn.
Found in a pitcher, the coins were placed in a textile bag. 936 coins: 14 denarii, 922 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Institut national de recherches archéologiques préventives, Paris, France

summary: 1 solidus of Leo I and 15 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 457-474); gold w8: 4.26 g.; silver w8: 38.50 g.
21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.

300 nummi hidden under a slab of slate, compact and without any remains of fabric or leather: Valentinian I - Honorius (AD 395-423). Most of the types are: REPARATIO REIPVB; GLORIA ROMANORVM; SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE; RESTITVTOR REIP.
25 denarii found on the east wing of the north facing gate: Galba - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 214).
The hoard comprised 20 large bronze coins of Mattathias Antigonus (TJC 36c).
Unknown number of initial coins. 8 denarii donated to the museum in Tulcea: Nero - Domitian (AD 88/89).
disposition: Danube Delta Museum, Tulcea, Romania; (8 coins)

summary: The coins were found in a destruction layer, scattered on the floor of a room alongside agricultural implements. It comprised 17 sestertii and 5 asses and 1 nummus, dating from Republic through to a nummus of Constantius II for Julian II (Caesar).

Probably, over 1000-1500 silver coins because of the container: a bucket. Only 45 are recovered: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235). The latest coins is a plated ”barbarous” imitation of a Commodus denarius. Most of the coins were sold in batches of 100 pieces each, at the fair in the nearby commune of Puiești. According to the authors, this hoard is the very same with the 1s of Tutova, Cetățuia and Băcești. (see Munteanu, L. and Popușoi, E., The Roman coin hoard from Iezer, p. 3)
disposition: Museum “Vasile Pârvan”, Bârlad, Romania (inv. nos. VPMB B/317-368)

summary: Hoard of 279 silver coins from the Republic to Domitian, was found together with silver objects by a local man on his field.
disposition: National Museum in Belgrade [76 coins]; National Museum in Požarevac [203 coins - since stolen]

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 225 coins were known: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.

A very large hoard of approximately 25 or 30000 coins (Severus Alexander - Gallic Empire, probably Victorinus), found in Friedrich-Wilhelm-Strasse. The coins were dispersed. 907 of them are listed in FMRD, in 6 different lists according to the place where the coins are kept today: 1) 595 coins in the RLMT Trier (FMRD 30643) 2) 54 coins in the RLMT Trier, with mention 'probably from that hoard' (FMRD 30644) 3) 41 coins bought by the RLMT Trier in 1925 from a private collector (FMRD 30645) 4) 30 coins in the RGM Köln (FMRD 30646) 5) 1 coin in private coll. (FMRD 30647) 6) 186 coins bought by the archaeological Museum in Zagreb in 1906/7 (FMRD 30648)
disposition: RLMT Trier; RGM Köln; private collection Lückger, Germany; Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia

summary: A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are menti1d. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are menti1d; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals in10ded for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius 2 or 3 Faustinas and 1 Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."
Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
101 coins: 16 denarii, 85 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8 122.1-240.8 g.
disposition: Regional Historical Museum, Vidin, Bulgaria; inv.no. 591

summary: 3 Iron Age coins (1 gold quarter stater of Cunobelin and 2 fragments of silver units of Amminus) and 6 Roman denarii (3 Republican, 2 Flavian and 1 unidentified fragment).
Unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 nummi are now known: Constantine I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-392)
disposition: Serviço de Arqueologia da Câmara Municipal de Vila do Conde, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1000 coins 'nearly all with the bust of Augustus' and bearing the reverse type LAETITIA AVG. As the LAETITIA AVG reverse type is most common on issues of Gordian III, under the Gallic Emperors and under Probus, it is likely that the coins were radiates dating to the third century AD.

26 coins which were found in a sandhole at Cholmondeston, not far from the Watfield Pavement. Most of them were judged to be coins of Constans, having the legend FEL TEMP REPARATIO, and on the obverse of some D N CONSTANTIVS P F AVG.
1172 nummi: Constantine I - Flavius Victor (AD 388-392).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Ferrara, Italy

summary: 162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
The hoard comprised a coarseware urn containing 1806 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Allectus.
(200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 63 bronze prutahs of John Hyrcanus II.

Hoard recovered during archaeological excavations at the site of Catcote undertaken by Tees Archaeology. Originally, 18 coins were reported from the hoard, but post-excavation review of the document uncovered 3 additional coins from the same context. 21 nummi to AD 348.
A small hoard of Iron Age coins from Alfriston, but it exact composition remains subject to discussions.
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 9 pieces entered the museum collection in Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
34 sestertii: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
14528 nummi deposited in a cooking pot: 321-324 - 337-341. Work in progress
50 coins found between the pillars of the hypocaust in 1 of the buildings of the civilian city of Carnuntum: 3 argentei, 47 nummi of the 1st Tetrarchy (AD 305).
1.616 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel which were deposit as a foundation offering beneath the theater orchestra: Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).

Found during the excavation of a inhumation cemetery in a leather purse hanging by the belt (possibly Frankish?). All coins are nummi of the Constantine I and his family members. Although it is said that there 11 coins were found, only 10 are menti1d.
6 silver coins: 3 denarii, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247) found during excavations
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45361-45365, 52259

summary: 5 solidi found with ceramic vessel sherds: Leo I - Basiliscus (AD 475-476); gold w8: 22.25g.
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: 12 nummi found with a jug: House of Constantine I - Zeno (AD 474-491).

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)
6 6 coins found near a tuff spring (votive offering?). 2 of the coins were halved: Augustus: 1 dupondius, 2 asses, 2 halved asses; Claudius I 1 As (AD 41-50).
A hoard of 6 aurei and 27 silver punch-marked coins.
c. 5500-6000), there is some information on 530 coins, and only 70 can be precisely identified: Constantius II - House of Valentinian I (AD 367-375).
disposition: Library of the Romanian Academy, (31 coins); Municipal Museum, (91 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, (400 coins mixed ); 3000 coins in a private collection in Caracal, today lost

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 18 coins are kept in the Hungarian National Museum in Budapest: Augustus – Gordian III (AD 243-244)
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 7 of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
28 antoniniani found during a fieldwalking: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256).

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: Around 25 kg = 7656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

32 coins were found in the Eastern buildings of the Temple at Pagan's Hill, most of which were found in robbers' spoil or under the rubble spread to the East. This includes 13 coins (2 radiates and 11 4th c. small bronzes) from a scattered hoard found under the rubble outside the outer wall.
4-5 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 2 coins are known: Gordian III, Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar).
The hoard(?) comprised a concentration of 15 nummi, dated between AD 316 and 329.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 260 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 2449-251)
500 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: c. 625.6-1298.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1918

summary: The coins were found in a cremation burial, mixed in with the cremated b1 and ash. The coins comprised an as of Vespasian and 12 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Philip I.
62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).

6 coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate). The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from 5 small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are 4 large serving platters; 1 of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, 2 large situlas 1 of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (1 of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)
The coins (at least 5) were found in 1830 on the premises of Proitzschenberg, near the 'Lehmmauer'.
5 gold coins: 3 aurei, 2 solidi: Tetrarchy - Constantine I/Constantine II (AD 317-340).
7 denarii discovered together in the Dacian fortress: Republic 6, Vespasian 1 (AD 70).
disposition: Eastern Carpathian Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (inv. nos. 16036–16042)

summary: 9 solidi (Valentinian I - Valentinian II) and 1 cen10ionalis (AE 3) of Jovian, found in the garden of the school and a neighbouring property in Eidinghausen-Hahnenkamp.

Cotton and Wood (1996, 26 nos 37-8) record 2 or possibly 3 cast bronze coins found downstream of Chiswick Eyot. 1 of them may be a Massiliot bronze prototype; the second is a class IL (ABC 171) flat linear type.
The hoard comprised Parthian silver tetradrachms, found by treasure hunters among 'ruins' at Akura, 50km east of Byblos. 29 specimens (Artabanus II to Volagases I) were seen on the market in Beirut.
The hoard was discovered in 2013 within the boundaries of Vaukavyski County. Consisted of at least 140 denarii (Nerva-Commodus). The circumstances and exact location of the find are unknown.
112 coins: imperial and provincial: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver w8: 217.0-343.5g.
Around 300 solidi. Only 12 coins are documented: Honorius - Valentinian III (AD 441-455).
(235?) 232 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus – Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Union National Museum, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 1787-3408)

summary: 14 silver coins, 13 known: 12 antoniniani (radiates) 1 denarius: Septimius Severus - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver w8: 4.2-33.3 g.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 33 aurei, 1 gold necklace, 2 bracelets and 1 gold ingot. The aurei range in date from Marcus Aurelius as Caesar to Diocletian. Hobbs estimates a gold w8 of c. 171.6-221.5g.
A hoard of 28 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I, discovered in an earthenware container at a field in Met10bach.
Unknown number of denarii were found in unknown circumstances. 18 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
4 coins (Claudius II - Tetricus), found in a garden in Gehrden.

A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver w8: 71.8-592.1
Several hundred Roman coins. "Except for 9 pieces that went to the museum in Sigiriya, the whereabouts of the rest of the hoard are unknown."
A siliqua of Honorius, from the mint of Trier, now in the BM, was found in the earth filling of a window-box of a flat in St. Pancras, together with 6 other siliquae of Valens, Maximus, and Arcadius.
3 coins: 1 denarius Antoninus Pius, 2 aurei Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Collection de Pitteurs, Budingen, Belgium, in 1850

summary: Hoard of 52 denarii found at the site: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Among them, issues of Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, Augustus, Tiberius.
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) from Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II.
40 imperial and provincial bronze coins in the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13629/1-22; 13634/1-18 (40 coins)

summary: 110 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Dispersed.
(50+) 9 staters; 1 ring and 2 torcs (75-57 BC). Uniface, "scyphate," made of an alloy of gold and silver. Highly stylized and abstract galloping horse. Tribes of the Morini and the Nervii.
disposition: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA ( 9 coins and torques)

summary: 9 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
4 provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.
These coins were found on several occasions between 1875 and 1885, but appear to represent a hoard. The hoard was found in a field.
6 Republican coins and 1 unidentified coin, found during metal detecting in Hou10.

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: 5 bronze coins found 1 next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
A hoard found in a pot in a late Roman pit. The pit was later truncated by a Roman rubbish pit containing metalworking debris.
The hoard comprised 'approximately 120 Roman bronzes, principally sestertii, of which many were very crudely manufactured 'trés frustes'.
23 solidi, 3 milarenses and 23 siliquae, ranging from Constantius II to Libius Severus, with 1 Republican denarius, found in a field, south-west of the village of Patching, West Sussex.
A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.
158 coins: 7 denarii, 151 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21275-21281 (7 denarii); inv.nos. 5224-5376 (151 coins)

summary: 16 silver coins: 2 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
12 denarii (Trajan - Caracalla) were registered at the Landesmuseum Hannover in 1916, as having been found together at Klein-Hesebeck. The coins are now lost.

A total of 255 coins were found at Langwood Hill, Chatteris. Many of these were bronze coins ranging from the 1st to the 4th centuries AD. Of the remaining 1 gold and 30 silver coins, 23 were declared Treasure Trove and seem to represent 1 or more hoards, although their exact composition remains unclear. These 23 coins consists mainly in Icenian silver and Roman denarii (Republic to Tiberius).

1918 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian - Victorinus (AD 271); mints: 1006 Rome, 787 Mediolanum, 122 Cologne, 1 Siscia, 1 Viminacium, 1 Antioch: Valerian I and Gallienus - Cludius II/Victorinus (AD 268-271); silver w8: 518.8-2396.6 g.
130 silver coins: 109 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-246); silver w8: 187.6-294.9 g
4 burned antoniniani (radiates). Only 1 coin, antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III (AD 241-243) was identified.

111 coins confiscated in 1981. The find encompassed 69 provincial coins from Thessalonica (Commodus - Philip II), 14 from Pella (Caracalla - Otacilia Severa), 6 from Edessa (Caracalla - Gordian III), 3 from Dion (Elagabalus - Maximinus); 1 from Stobi (Septimius Severus), 9 from the Koinon of Macedonia, 5 uncertain 1s of 'Greek cities', 4 imperial coins (Vespasian - Maximinus).
5 Celtic coins: 4 staters, 1 quarter stater.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 150 nummi, mostly from the mint of Trier dating to the period AD 323/4 and AD 347/348.
Unknown originally number of coins, but for certain, a large number. Only 4 siliquae were documented.
disposition: Muzeul Național de Istorie a Moldovei, Chișinău (inv.nos. FB-13135 – FB-13138)

summary: c. 600 silver coins found with a bronze vessel (urna aerea): Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II.
HER record of a small hoard of 33 nummi ending with Gratian, found by the side of the road in Hambledon before 1942. Probably Valentinianic?
Hoard of 1000 silver coins. Only 11 available for study: 10 denarii, 1 drachm: Republic - Augustus (19-8 BC).
The hoard comprised 60 silver Iron Age coins within a hollowed out st1. Found during road construction. The Musée de Rouen acquired 16 coins from this hoard.
2 solidi (Magnus Maximus and Honorius). The discovery of 2 solidi, struck within 20 years of each other, in the same field suggests strongly that this is likely to be a small hoard.
53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.
At the site of a newly constructed school building in 1957 3 denarii (Septimius Severus - Caracalla) were found in the topmost burnt layer below a st1 of a Roman wall.
Approximately 130 silver coins, the majority of which were denarii, of which only a small proportion were identified.

6 coins were found during an excavation by the University of Leicester Archaeological Services (ULAS) on the 18th April 2012. All 6 coins are British Iron Age silver coins of the North Eastern regional series, which was produced in Lincolnshire and neighbouring counties from about 60/50 BC.

The hoard comprised 2 vessels containing 3080 coins. Cousin mentions 3074 coins, but the list of reverses that he gives has a total of 3071 and the total by emperor is 3084. He also described reverse types but does not match them with their obverses. The last coins are 115 SAECVLI FELICITAS issues of Postumus (Elmer 593). It was found within 7 or 8 metres of Hoard ÉTAPLES 1840 1 during archaeological excavations directed by L. Cousin.

The hoard comprised 72 'bronze denarii of the late Empire', possibly to be identified as either radiates or nummi. They were found in association with a bronze lamp and a large number of ceramic vessels.

It is not certain whether there were 1 or 2 hoards. The hoard(s) seems to have comprised between 100000 and 380000 coins: Mark Antony - Maximinus I Thrax. 2 hoards were found in a short period of time, 40 m from 1 another in January 1936 in March 1936.
disposition: National Museum, Niš (3,941); National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (3,123); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia (4,096); National Museum, Ljubljana, Slovenia (c. 830); National Museum, Prague, Czechia (15,000); Šipuš collection (64 coins);

summary: The hoard comprised a redware vessel containing 2 gold bracelets, a gold brooch, 150 Republican denarii and some 1st century coins, including 2 denarii of Domitian.
16 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: The hoard was found in a small earthenware pot with a corroded iron cover. It comprised 2 gold Continental Iron Age coins and 21 aurei of Julius Caesar and Augustus.
73 nummi found in the "House of the 2 hoards": Constantine I (Constantine II Caesar) - Theodosius I (Arcadius) (AD 388-395).
3 provincial coins (Edessa, Thessalonica) found in a grave in Europos (Kilkis).

20313 nummi of the Tetrarchy before and after the reduction of Maxentius divided by mints. Before the reduction (3168 coins): Gaul 132, Rome 661, Carthage 2002, Ticinum/Aquileia 373; after reduction (171455 coins): Rome 8002, Ostia 5190; Carthage 1099, Ticinum/Aquileia 825, Balkans and East 196, uncertain 1833 (AD 310-311).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.

72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in 2 concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. 2 further coins were found nearby.

A hoard of 3 solidi (Honorius), 33 miliarenses, 1166 siliquae and 1 nummus, found close to the Roman villa of Stanchester. A denarius of Hadrian (0.99g fragment) was found at the same time but it is uncertain whether it is part of the hoard.
Circa of 1000 republican and Augustean denarii. 126 coins were recorded.

The hoard comprised at least 30 sestertii, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Claudius II with a tpq of AD 268 to 270. The coins were discovered as an oxidised lump and were found in close proximity to a silver finger intaglio ring with chalchedon setting.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1100 antoniani (radiates) from Valerian to Diocletian and Maximian I. Those of Saloninus, Salonina, Tacitus, Numerian, Carinus and Constantius I were quite numerous; those of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Aurelian, Probus, Maximian I and Diocletian were quite abundant; those of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 131.1g and 1248.9g.
1486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.

8 detectorists from the Stour Valley Search and Recovery Club found 9 Chute (ABC 746) staters on 22 September 200 and a further 6 on 24 November 2001. A 6teenth coin of the same type was discovered in the same area on 23 February 2002 (TAR 2001, 90 no. 176), and 2 more in April 2005 (NC 169 (2009), 331 no. 1; PATAR 2008, 186 no. 462).
A possible hoard (or part of a hoard) of 40 sestertii from Trajan to Valerian I (AD 253-254)?
1100 solidi, of which 840 recovered. 423 coins were studied: Theodosius I - Valentinian III (AD 425-455); gold w8: c. 4950g.
disposition: Museo Archeologico di Siracusa, Italyn (423 coins)

summary: Hoard of 5700 aurei, most of them belonging to Augustus.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 6ty-3 coins were seen in the collection of the Friends of sciences Society Collection in Poznań: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Friends of sciences Society Collection, Poznań, Poland (63 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 35 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.1146.1 to 27
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: (c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: 2154 silver coins: 45 denarii, 2109 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260); + 6669 provincial bronzes: 3600 Callatis, 3000 Tomis, 6 Histria, 5 Odessos, 21 Marcianopolis, 13 Nicopolis, 8 Hdrianopolis, 6 Anchialos, 3 Dionysopolis, 3 Mesembria, 1 Pautalia, 1 Bizantion, 1 Augusta Traiana, 1 Nicaea.

2 silver units of EISV found in the same field in 1990 and 1998 and recorded with the CCI. E. Ghey notes: Penhallurick (2009, 104-109) lists a variety of coins metal detected from the same field and immediately surrounding area between 1990 and 1998. It is difficult to disentangle separate hoards from what we now know is settlement evidence. However these 2 Iron Age coins have been considered here separately as a hoard due to the unusual nature of this find.

Originally 487 silver coins, 404 were studied: 1 Iberian denarius CESE; 79 Iberian denarii BOLSCAN; 261 Republican denarii, 63 denarii of Augustus (2 BC - AD 4). 20 Celto-Iberian denarii and 10 Augustan denarii and have countermarks.

543 denarii (of which 5 plated) found with a pitcher: Nero - Macrinus (AD 218); 1768 g. The mints of Alexandria, Antioch and Emesa are represented by 1 copy each, while the 1 from Laodicea by a total of 12 coins.
1498 coins: 9 antoniniani (radiates), 1489 nummi found in a corner of a dwelling: Claudius II - Thedosius II (AD 423-425).
242 tinned bronze nummi from the time of the Tetrarchy (Diocletian - Constantine I), buried in rouleaux between the bricks of the floor of a Roman house at the back of the temple.
The hoard comprised around 851 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC)

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.

The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Anto9 bronzes. It was found during 3 archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.
The Mossop Archive at the CCI includes undated polaroids from Seaby's of a group of 8 cast bronze coins described as 'Ancient British tin m1y found in Kingston-upon-Thames'.
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
21 silver coins: 9 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 256/00)

summary: 3 lots of coins bought from local people in Ihnasyah by Currelly, but considered to be 1 hoard given their similar patina. The find comprised 6476 nummi from the period AD 320-347/348. It might also have included 1 Alexandrian provincial bronze of Domitian, 1 Alexandrian tetradrachm of Philip I and Claudius II, as well as 1 mamluk dirham of Al-Nasir Nasir ad-Din Hassan (AD 1347-1351/1354-1361). These coins were not listed by Noeske in his catalogue.
The hoard comprised 29 nummi of the House of Constantine along with numerous items of jewellery including a glass 'medallion.' The hoard was found in a tomb in a late Roman cemetery.
8 asses: Republic - Augustus (10-6 BC).

1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver w8: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: 10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 3.7-11.5g.
907 aurei, but only 857 have been identified. They were found by accident. There were also 10 'restored' coins of Trajan. Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-207)
Hoard of 166 denarii (512.94 gr.) found stack together: Vespasian - Septimius Severus. It was found within the settlement of Chernyakov culture.
15 asses: Nero (AD 66-68).
2596 denarii (among: 1 plated, 47 'barbarous'): Republic - Caracalla (AD 214).
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of 228 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic pitcher. 225 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270); silver w8: 61.5-279.0 g.
disposition: Direzione generale per le Antichità e le Belle Arti, Torino, Italy (in 1904).

summary: The hoard comprised 292 denarii from Domitian to Maximinus (AD 238).
22 nummi from the time of Constantine I and Constantius II found 1923 'Am Fort Josef', in front of the hospital.

8 coins: 7 aurei: Nero - Vespasian (AD 74). Found together with a Celtic coin. No further information on this coin. The site is located near Nijmegen, on the other side of the Rhine. The coins were found at a depth of 1 and a half meters in the infill of a residual channel (stream gully) near Lent.

Cotton and Wood (1996, 25 no. 35) record a 'multiple find of potins discovered 'off the downstream tip of Isleworth Eyot on the Middlesex foreshore of the Thames' in 1976-77. At least 20-5 coins were recovered from a spine of gravel running out from the north-east side of the Eyot, most of them apparently below the low water mark.
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.
41 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274) found in a savings box.
81 imitations of solidi: Zeno - Justin I (AD 518-527); gold w8: 360.45g.

IARCH record for a hoard of 206 Constantinian nummi. For full details and images see DENO-6F8801.Found whilst metal detecting on ploughed land up to 8 inches down. Coins were found scattered over 30-40 metres with most within a 15 metres area. The coins were possibly contained in a pot as suggested by just 1 undiagnostic rim sherd from the same findspot, though this was uncertain.Unpublished catalogue by V. Drost.
The hoard comprised 1 tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus and 21 posthumous tetradrachms of Philip Philadelphus, found in the environs of Aleppo.
298 provincial bronze coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement: Commodus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria, inv.no. 3634 (262 coins - 218 were stolen)

summary: On discovery, most of the find was melted down and therefore it is difficult to establish the exact con10t of the deposit. It is reputed to have included 30000 gold and silver coins. Buried around AD 260. Together were found 8 silver statuettes and 1 silver plate remain from the original treasure.
disposition: Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, The British Museum, London, United Kingdom; Musée des ursulines à Mâcon (copies of the statuettes)

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel while ploughing. 32 pieces (denarii, antoniniani, provincial bronzes) entered the museum collection in Shumen: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1507-1537, 1546

summary: The hoard comprised 3 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 29.116 a to c

Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissi1r, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors).

During groundwork a coin hoard of 310 coins was unearthed near the Roman fort of Gunzenhausen. It comprised 308 denarii and 2 antoninianii, ranging from Commodus to Gordian III. Note that FMRD lists 310 coins, but in the summary only gives 309.
The hoard comprised 35 gold coins dated between the reigns of Valentinian I (AD 364-375) and Anastasius I (AD 491-518).

The hoard is thought to have comprised at least 600 coins but only 229 were recovered from the finders. The coins are described as being 'di grande modulo' and this has been interpreted as sestertii: Vespasian/Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found during the construction of a house for Corrado Tedeschi di Modica.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (31 coins)

summary: 25 coins found in small ceramic pitcher: 2 denarii, 18 antoniniani, 4 provincial bronze medallions, 1 provincial bronze coin: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.

Details from HER: 2 coins: 1 of Claudius II Gothicus (AD 268-270), Providentia type; & a local copy (c. AD 270) of Pax Aug type of Tetricus II, with radiate head on obverse.Present location unknown.YAJ 1975, 46: 4.
An unsatisfactory record of what seems to have been a substantial find of North Thames gold and silver" found by illicit detecting in 1993-4.
The hoard comprised 786 or 802 sestertii from Hadrian to Hostilian (or Gallienus, see bibliography).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 100 and 120 aurei (or more than 150 coins according to Godard-Faultrier). Most publications state that the latest coin is an aureus of Augustus. The aureus of Nero may be an intruder or an isolated find. The hoard was found by a miller, J. Alleaume
11 denarii from Lucius Verus to Elagabalus/Severus Alexander (1 denarius of Julia Soaemias is a hybrid with a reverse of Severus Alexander). Found during the excavation of the cathedral apse

A hoard of at least 70 Roman Imperial denarii was discovered in 2018 (?) in the vicinity of Fastiv. Information about the hoard on the treasure hunting forum Violity was posted on 16 December 2018, probably by its finder, who also provided 1 general photo of the deposit. The coins were fused into 1 large ingot and had traces of heavy exposure to fire. 3 coins were found separately. A silver item in the form of a ring-bent bar measuring ca. 2.5x3 cm (possibly a clasp from the pouch in which the treasure was hidden). There were also small fragments of pottery nearby, whose relation to the hoard is not clear. Judging by the photos posted on the forum, the hoard was sold at the Violity auction. The further fate of the deposit is unknown.
The hoard comprised either 1200 bronze and silver coins of the Tetrarchy or 1500 of the House of Constantine Gratian and Theodosius I found in a copper alloy vessel.

Marks Tey (1843) hoard would seem to have contained an unusually long span of coinage: from a late Whaddon Chase type, perhaps of the 40s BC, through Addedomaros, Dubnovellaunos and into the early first century AD with Cunobelin. This seems a little unlikely, and 1 must wonder whether there are multiple deposits involved here.
IARCH record for a hoard of 5 denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.
332 silver coins: 45 denarii, 287 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 383-758.6 g. Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum, vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M II 3011-3330 (320 coins)

summary: Around 300 nummi were found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 coins were recovered, all from the time of Constantine I.

The hoard comprised more than 35000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape F10i Punta. The hoard was found on a shipwreck (Syrna I) and has been interpreted as carrying wages or m1y for military expenses. The hoard was first found by a sponge diver, rescue excavations followed in 2002.

A hoard of 124 coins, comprising tetradrachms (Philip I - Gallus), denarii (Domitian - Alexander Severus, 1 quinarius (Caracalla) and 1 provincial bronze coin (Gordian III & Abgar), found at Dura in G1, during the season 1936–7. No container was reported.
74 nummi of the House of Theodosius I found in a layer of ashes in a Roman villa.
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Among them issues of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I. 11 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3902-3912 (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 150 silver coins of the same type as found at Vouillé (Picton 'drachms' depicting horseman and fleuron).
17 coins: imitation antoniniani (radiates), nummi: Tetricus I - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402).
6 sestertii recorded with the PAS, 3 further from excavation of the site (see Amber Valley barbarous radiate hoard). Not classed as Treasure.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the m1tary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.
40 denarii and 30 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Commodus (Crispina).

3 solidi found through detector surveys. These solidi may be part of a hoard destroyed by ploughing, as the solidi were found within 1x8 m. This same field has also yielded 10 denarii spread over a larger area.

520 silver coins found with a lead recipient: 513 republican denarii, 2 imperial denarii, 1 republican quinarius, 4 drachms: Republic and early Imperial denarii terminating in issues of Augustus dating to 29 BC.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia, Italy

summary: 377 nummi: Tetrarchy (AD 284-310).
Hoard of circa 200 coins. Only 17 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259).
7 antoniniani (4 copies) Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (11 coins); collection Vandermaelen (2 coins and the shards from vessel), in 1851

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat st1. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some b1s. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat st1 in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of 1 coin each in gold, silver and bronze.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). 2 other coins, 1 bronze and 1 bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
The hoard comprised a matt white ceramic vessel containing 205 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus. The hoard was placed under some tiles.
Circa 50 argentei, +800 nummi: Diocletian - Constantius I (AD 305-306).
56 denarii: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 214); silver w8: 87.8-167.0g.
disposition: Voralberg Museum, Bregenz, (initial 51 coins, in 1977 46); Private collection, Innsbruck (1 coin), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian II with a tpq of AD 258. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 65g.

A hoard of 68 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Titus to Trajan Decius. The exact provenance is unclear, but coins were found in Ladenburg. Only 2 thirds of the coins could be traced in the collections of the Baden-Baden museum.
56 denarii found in the Seaside baths complex. Only 31 have survived: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-205).

A hoard of 788 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), denarii (Julia Mamaea) and antoniniani (Caracalla - Gallienus) found during the excavations at Dura Europos, in a jar under the embankment beside the Palmyra Gate.
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.

Originally were 500 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 120 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Clodius Albinus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Until AD 253, Mints represented: Rome, except 2 from Laodicea for Septimius Severus and Geta; 2 from Antioch for Elagabalus and Philip I; 2 from Viminiacum for Treboninanus Gallus and 2 from Milan for 'les divi'; after AD 253: 1 Rome, 9 Cologne, 1 Viminiacum, 1 Milan, 1 2nd eastern Mint and 1 uncertain. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 698.4-1425.8g
(c. 2000) (133, 46) coins: Republic ?, Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver w8: c.528.6-2441.5 g.
(9.5 kg; 2358 coins) 2317 silver coins: Nero - Trajan Decius (AD 250); silver w8: 2671.9-6683.8 g
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; 2024 coins; inv. nos. 125- 282; 921 1-630

summary: 3 bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
2 nummi of Magnentius/Decentius (AD 350-353).
A hoard of 84 "bronze coins dating to circa AD 350-360" found near the bath house of the Castle Hill villa complex during excavations in 1988-1989.See also IARCH-62F9DD
17 antoniniani (radiates); Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown number of denarii. 933 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Silistra: Nero - M. Aurelius (AD 162-163).
