Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888 and first published in 1938. 1120 late Roman coins, 4 casts imitations and 2 lead disks. All except 2 coins, were halved or even quartered. The 2 coins that were not halved are: an imitation of type Copy G and a barbarous SALVS.
8 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1482 (8 coins)

summary: 6 coins found as a roll were discovered in a pit within a Roman building: 1 antoninianus, 5 nummi: Aurelian - Valens (AD 364-378).
1446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: It is alleged that more than 3 kg of coins were found. 34 denarii: Galba - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver w8: 67.2-111.4 g.
(?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
(147) 142 bronze coins: 1 as, 141 provincial: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 22

summary: A small hoard of 31 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan – Commodus (AD 193-211) was found by treasure hunter in January 2022, possibly in Kharkiv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Vasiliy Kopat'ko (Василий Копатько). The conditions of hoard finding are unknown, but judging by the photos from the post on Facebook, it was found in the forest. Since the hoard was discovered in winter under snow cover, it is possible that not all coins were found.
14 silver and bronze coins of unknown denominations: Republic - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 145-176).
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
186 nummi from the time of Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
Hoard of 200 coins, 134 were studied: Gallienus - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.
89 coins found spread close to each other in a domestic building: Celtoiberic - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
A hoard of ca. 800 silver and 20 bronze coins, found in a pot while ploughing a field (at Hermendonk?, not far from Wach10donk). The coins are not preserved, but a list of emperors exists.
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver w8: 584.0-1024.5 g.

M. Poilly donated a lot of 173 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) to the Societé archéologique de l'Orléanais' which were found 'in the environs of Dieppe': Maximinus I Thrax - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 44.4-232.4 g.

Between 400 and 1200 solidi ranging from Constantine I (and not Valentinian I as previously assumed) to Valentinian III and Theodosius II, next to 8 silver and 13 bronze coins, ranging from the 1st c. to the mid 4th c. AD, all found 1764 on a field of the abbey of Hagenbusch, south of Xan10 (in today's Hochbruch area of the city). A list of ca. 210 coins was established in 1765 and subsequently published by Iluk in 1987. 6 of these coins are now in the Berlin museum. – The summary list of coins given here is based on Kent 1994 and the information published by Dahmen - Kosanke in 2021.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin (6 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in 2 lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A coin hoard comprising 44 Iron Age staters of the 'Norfolk Wolf' Uninscribed Icenian JB type. These were found scattered in what appear to have been 2 groups over a relatively small area, the first group in November 2012 and the second around March 2013. If 2 hoards were concealed, however, these must surely be 2 part of 1 main deposit; the 2 groups of coins share die-links as well as being of the same type. (PAS).
At least 50 coins of the late Roman Empire were found in a sandy stream bank while excavated in a former 13th century church. No details on the hoard composition.
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Anto9s' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.

Approximately 300 hundred Iron Age coins, collected from the coast over a number of years. On the basis of the CCI records, the assemblage is dominated by early South Thames quarter staters (some 96 coins, or 32%) and quarter staters of Tincomarus (90 coins, 30%), with rather lower quantities of quarter staters of Verica (28, or 9.6%). Gallo-Belgic quarters and the digamma type (ABC 1028, 1031), possibly of Commios, make up the bulk of the remainder (17 coins, 5.7%, and 19 coins, 6.3%, respectively). There is a wide spread in date here, suggesting multiple deposits over a long period of time, presumably from the mid-first century BC onwards. (de Jersey).

20 6 coins (aurei and their imitations) were accessi1d from 11 persons under treasure trove legislation. They constituted a part of the hoard which contained also jewellery and was found in the land owned by private individuals. Some of the imitations are mould-linked.
A hoard of 62 denarii (Republic - Augustus), found in 1882 during drainage work in a moor in Niederlangen.

140 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius), were found in a pit filled with burnt destruction rubble in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort. The vast majority of the coins shows no signs of circulation.
13 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191-192).

A hoard of 116 coins found over a period of several years in a field, including 3 Iron Age coins, 87 Republican denarii and 26 Imperial denarii up to Claudius I. Other finds were restricted to post-medieval metalwork, prehistoric flints and a single Romano-British brooch, a Colchester derivative of rear-hook type belonging to the mid first century AD.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
31 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 272-273) found in a pottery jar during excavations beneath the floor in room of a house.
The hoard comprised 3 denarii and 610 radiates from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1756.6 and 16896.9 g.
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.
The hoard was found in an iron cooking pot or 'marmite' and comprised an uncertain number of silver coins and some jewellery, such as 'large finger rings'.

The hoard was found in a large ceramic vessel. Within the vessel were 5 corroded blocks of coins, each coated with very hard clay. 2 thirds of the hoard was cleaned (except for 2 blocks weighing 5.5kg) and it appears that there were approximately 1500 coins (bronzes and radiates). Between 200 and 250 coins were of the emperors between Augustus and Gallienus. The others were of Aurelian, Probus and Diocletian. The hoard was found by a farm labourer.
115 antoniniani: Caracalla to Trajan Decius. Found in 2 separate but homogeneous groups. Silver: 115 coins; Silver w8: 145.1-297.6g
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 174 were studied: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 211-217)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 587 (72 coins)

summary: Found during excavations, in a quarter to the north-east of Insula 1, in tomb 1, a cremation burial; 3 coins corroded by fire.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 15 were recuperated and 11 documented. Multiples of solidi, 1 aureus and 1 fraction: Carinus - Constantine I (AD 328-329).
556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver w8: 1694g.
337 antoniniani, "almost all of them bearing the portraits of Claudius II and Tetricus I" (AD 271-274).
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 8 pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 2 solidi: Valens, Honorius for Arcadius (AD 395-402).
20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).
Hoard of more than 1000 coins of the Early empire found under a slab in a cave. The coins were sold by the finder. Few of them were in the museum of Cagliari in 1858.
A hoard of 1 solidus and 85 siliquae, up to Honorius, AD 402, found in 2001, 2002, 2007, 2010, 2011 and 2013.

1000 solidi of the 5th century AD were found in a ceramic vessel with lid. Based on some photos and press release information pieces of Honorius, Valentinian III, Libius Severus, Anthemius and Leo I are among the coins (AD 472-474). Together were found jewelry and fragments of gold artefacts, probably to be reused.
11 antoniniani of Philip I found in a small ceramic vessel (AD 244-249)

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
The hoard comprised 9 bronze coins dated to the reign of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 2 vessels filled with bronze coins (between 1200 and 1500 coins according to Grille; more than 1200 according to Godard (1851); approximately 600 according to Martin; hundreds according to Godard (1863). The hoard was found by farmers on the Coin des Pierres Blanches farm.
60 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: 110.9-175.9g
(55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 21.6-34.1 g.
4957 radiates to Probus (AD 279), found in a jar, 10 miles south of Oxford. The hoard contained a second specimen of a coin of Domitianus (Domitian II), a Gallic usurper under Aurelian.

2 antoniniani (radiates) of the brothers Macrianus II and Quietus, placed on either side of the head of the deceased, and a coin (pierced) of Caracalla minted at Paphos, placed over the chest. Burial cave.
78 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: About 200 silver and bronze coins.
Found during excavations in the pars urbana of the Roman villa rustica of Osterfingen, below an ash layer. 18 sestertii, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander, Maximinus Thrax.
(700) 160 silver coins: Trajan - Valerian I/ Gallienus (AD 253-268). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring.
35 antoniniani (radiates), 28 seen: Marius - Tetricus (AD 271-274); silver w8: c.10.5 g.

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. 3 publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. 1 further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
2 denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius.
Around 2500 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1800 coins were recovered: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 859.1-1804.1g.

A small hoard of 45 radiates in a pot dating "to within a few years of AD 280" (Pastscape 343603) found during archaeological excavations of a Roman settlement in the Weedon Road area by Northamptonshire's Archaeological Unit in the 1970s.
Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.

In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver w8: 40.1g
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 2 nummi are known: Constantine I, Constantius II (Constantius III Gallus Caesar).
112 (102 AR, 8 AE, 2 Uncertain) coins from the Republic to Augustus.
125 nummi from the reign of Constantine I (AD 330-337). Unknown findspot.
Group of 22 coins: 21 antoniniani radiates of Claudius II (Divus) and 1 nummus of Valentinian II.
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with 1 swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
3 Macedonian coins (Pella, and 2 from Thessalonica, time of Augustus), allegedly found in the garden of a house in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1923.
more than 1000 nummi, mostly of the types Reparatio Reipub e Gloria Romanorum: AD 379-381 - Arcadius (AD 395-402).

On 18 March 2018, photos of 5 Roman provincial bronze coins Prusias ad Hypion: Macrinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244) with countermarks were published on the Ukrainian forum Violity. According to the finder, they were found at the same site on the territory of Khmelnytskyi region. Given the close chronology of the coins and the fact that they were issued by 1 mint, most likely it was a hoard. Coins: Macrinus (1), Maximunus Trax (2), Maximunus Trax (Maxim) (1), Gordian III (1).

The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including 2 coins of Juba II, 1 of Nero, 1 of Galba, 9teen of Vespasian, 7 of Titus, 20-3 of Domitian, 3 of Nerva, 40-8 of Trajan and 10 of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified 2 of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes 10 extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: 1 Republican denarius, 1 denarius of Vespasian, 2 denarii of Domitian, 5 denarii of Trajan and 1 Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the 9 latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.

A 'placed deposit' in context 201/206 which included 3 coins, a gold stater of Tasciovanus, a silver North-Eastern half-unit and a copper alloy unit of Cunobelin. The non-coin objects consisted of contained 2 iron spearheads, a sherd of Roman glass and a fragment of copper alloy sheet. This deposit is difficult to date from the artefacts but falls within the Roman period, possibly the first century AD.
57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
(250) 238 nummi: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 312-337) Mints: Treveri 59; Lugdunum 116; Londinium 12 (1 Imitation); Roma 11; Ticinum 24; Aquileia 4; Siscia 4; Carthago 7, 1 uncertain.
disposition: Museum d'Aix-les-Bains, France (187 coins); collection Duc (40 coins); collection Lagier-Bruno (12 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 180 Provincial bronzes from Nicopolis, found next to a small countryside road, at Phloriada-Valtos, Plakanida, at the border of Aetolia and Acarnania. The list given here follows Calomino.
A scattered hoard with a complexe record, containing a minimum of perhaps 10 or 11 staters of Cunobelin, together with an aureus of Augustus.
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
10 cistophori: 2 Mark Antony, 8 Augustus (19-18 BC). Found with a small ceramic vessel.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 900 silver coins (denarii). The older coins show wear patterns consis10t with long circulation, while the more recent issues were in mint condition: Hadrian (Sabina Augusta) - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

An explosive blast occurred at a rocky knoll of Ringsberg, which was detonated for the extraction of hydraulic building material. An undetermined number of silver coins was ejected with the rocky material. The coins appeared situated in various small cavities of Jurassic rock and were probably concealed there. The find belongs to the denarii hoards from the Alemanni of the first half of the third century. 7 coins were described, nothing is known of the others.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A find, comprising 1 aureus and 7 denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Anto9 period.
67 silver coins: 21 antoniniani (radiates), 46 denarii: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: The hoard comprised 81 bronze coins dated between AD 341-346 and AD 383-395.

4 coins: 1 denarius, 2 plated coins, 1 bronze coin: Tiberius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 6.1-7.4 g. Found together with silver inscribed objects (patera, 2 rings), 2 statuettes, 3 hair-pins.
disposition: Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: (?) 8 nummi: House of Constantine I (AD 337-341).

The hoard contains 40-50 coins and a decorated ring. They include over 12 electrum staters and 5 electrum quarter staters attributed to the Gallic Osismii tribe. 2 uncertain Osismii coins, 2 Coriosolitae billon staters and 12 petit billons armoricains were also recorded.
disposition: Archaeologists from Rennes: Harscouet of Kavel, Bezier and Moucoude; (the coins); Laurence de la Barre, lawyer from Morlaix (the ring)

summary: 399 silver coins: 245 republican, 22 serrati, 4 republican quinarii, 128 imperial denarii: Republic - Gaius (AD 37-38).
disposition: The casts of these coins are in the Musée d'Archéologie de Lons-le-Saunier, France. Since December 7, 1960, 240 coins are kept in the same museum.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 12 bronze coins were examined: 3 double sestertii, 8 sestertii, 1 as: Titus - Postumus (AD 264-265).
Found in a cup (that was discarded), the hoard was recorded 10 years after being found. 8 coins to the coin level. 2 copies; 5 nummi Silver: 1, 2 coins; Silver w8: 2.95g
Hallaton: hoard associated with the helmet from context 74. It comprises 434 Iron Age coins and 7 Roman denarii.
19 coins: 15 denarii, 3 quinarii, 1 aureus: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
200 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Maximian I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-423).
Around 60 coins, 41 pieces are known: Vespasian – Theodosius II (AD 408-450).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic; Collection Červinkova

summary: The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: Report ca. 20 of Iron Age silver coins found in the 1840's, at Tollard Royal. 1 of them is probably is probably SCBI 24, no. 909, in Salisbury Museum.
263 coins found in a beaker covered by a plate: 1 denarius, 125 antoniniani (radiates), 3 double sestertii, 1 sestertius, 134 nummi: Trajan - Constantine I (AD 317).
174 coins: 32 antoniniani (radiates), 142 nummi: Gallienus - Theodosius I (Honorius) (AD 393-395).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: The hoard was concealed under 3 st1 slabs. There was no evidence of a container.

475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: Details from Pastscape: "111 Roman coins were found at Witham Friary when draining a field belonging to Mr James Croom. They were well preserved, about the sizes of shillings and 6pences, and all but 1 were found in a round hole covered by a flat st1, about 12 inches below the surface. Some pieces of Roman ware were found at the same time....The collection was dispersed, but 6 siliquae, Julian II - Magnus Maximus (AD 360-388), were bought by J W Singer, the Frome brass founder, and are now in Somerset County Museum. Taunton Museum supposedly have no record of these coins, but the Ashmolean Museum have a bronze fibula with Roman coins of c. A.D. 390, at Witham, in 1867. A late 4th century hoard."
4 solidi: Theodosius II - Glycerius (AD 473-474); gold w8: 17.8 g. Found at different times but in same field

The hoard comprised a total of 1133 coins, including 1031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
Over 100 nummi: Constantius I - House of Theodosius I (AD 395-402)

559 denarii - 1607.31 g found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). ToOn the same field were found a rectangular bronze pendants and 1 of gold and a brooch. Uncertain whether these artefacts are connected to the hoard.
45 nummi: Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 309-313).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel within the remains of a wooden box, half-filled with ash. The coins are described as '130 gold coins of Constantine, all with the same reverse type.' TAF questions whether they were really gold coins.

A set of 7 gold pendants made of solidi from the Constantinian period was found by a treasure hunter near Bronnaja Hara village in the spring of 2018. The 6 coins available for study were struck between the years 335 and 347. All of them had fluted suspension loops attached, uniform in type, and pointing to the integral rather than combined nature of the set. The coin-pendants could either be a hoard or a part of a funeral assemblage.
53 silver coins found with a purse in the fortress wall: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 1229-1238

summary: This hoard of 43 aurei, ranging from Nero to Marcus Aurelius, was discovered in June 2000 during the archaeological excavation at Plantation Place, Fenchurch Street, in the City of London. The coins were discovered in situ within a uniform context of silty brick-earth with organic inclusions. The absence of coins of Commodus suggests a deposition date probably no later than AD 180.
During archaeological excavations, 11 burned bronze coins were found on the south-east corner of the basilica: 1 Rome, 10 provincial: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 238-244)

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Anto9 dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
820 coins of which 818 are preserved, all imitation of antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Claudius II (Divus), Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Badajoz, Spain

summary: Circa 20 sestertii of Gordian III (AD 238-244) found in a layer of ashes.

21 provincial asses of Tiberius: 20 Segobriga, 1 Turiaso.

The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
A hoard of 543 Roman coins from the time of Constantine I, found in 2 small vessels hidden in a house with a mosaic floor.

find_spot_name: JERUSALEM - WESTERN AND SOUTHERN WALLS 1975 A
summary: The hoard comprised 34 bronze coins deposited during the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-72).

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, 5 of the 9 coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.

20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them 2 imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).

During the excavation of the Roman villa at Andover, in the east wing of the villa, a large urn of the ordinary black ware, was found. It was buried upright in the ground, and covered with a large flanged tile, which had been crushed down into the mouth of the jar, by pressure from above, probably by the plough. 6 small bronze Roman coins were found in it. This seems to be the villa at Clanville. "Small bronze" might suggest a third to 4th century hoard
The hoard comprised 2 sestertii, 2 asses, radiates and nummi from Trajan to the House of Valentinian (AD 364-378); silver w8: 3.8g-10.7 g.

The hoard comprised an offering of vessels to Minerva including silver and bronze objects and numerous bronze coins dating from the reign of Tiberius all the way through to Constantine I. The hoard was found by a farmer planting a vineyard. The hoard is preserved as the Notre-Dame-d'Allençon hoard in the Musée du Louvre, Paris
disposition: Louvre Museum, Paris; Archaeological Museum of St. Jean, Angers, France

summary: The hoard comprised approx. 2500 sestertii, ranging from the 1st to the 3rd century AD, finishing under Gallienus, and found in a burial in Akriai, near Gytheion.

252 silver coins with now description, 4 gold coins: Maximian I aureus, Severus II aureus, Valentinian I solidus pendant (AD 367-375). An aureus of Nero as a pendant. Together with the coins were also found 2 gold coins (1 lunula).

summary: Hoard of circa 350 coins. 285 were seen: 284 antoniniani (radiates), 1 aureus: Claudius II - Diocletian (AD 284-294); gold w8: 5.34g; Silver: 284 coins; silver w8: 51.2-90.8 g.

Excavations in advance of A435 Norton Lenchwick bypass, now part of A46. In Area C3, rectangular st1 Building i was aligned E-W & 15 x 7m in size, with clay bonded walls with loosely dressed faces. Inside Building i there was a large deep cess pit 329, into which st1 slab floor partly subsided, but it was not clear if this was from an early phase of building, or a phase pre-dating it. There was a soil-filled hollow to E. To S was Building j, of aisled posthole construction & timber form, at least 16 x 6m in size, with a central drain gullly. These 2 structures may have been agric. buildings assoc. with a larger complex - Building j could have been a byre. During excav., however, controlled metal detecting & archaeol. recording around the 2 buildings plotted concs. of coins & brooches, with a particular focus on the NE corner of Building i, but also with groups to the N 7 SE; & to the E of Building j. The coins & brooches were sometimes individual but also in groups of c. 10-16 coins, which in several cases were spatially close to brooch finds. The coins & brooches were sometimes in soil layers, sometimes in very shallow 'scoops' in underlying natural subsoil. Some brooches were broken, others complete; & between Buildings i & j were 2 human skull frags.Mays, M. 2000. Roman coins. In S.C. Palmer Archaeological Excavations in the Arrow Valley, Warwickshire. Birmingham & Warwickshire Archaeol. Soc/ Highways Agency, pp. 84-87, 126-134.
23 coins: 22 denarii, 1 as (Augustus - Caracalla/Elagabalus) (AD 210-222). The last coin is a hybrid Caracalla/Elagabalus.

Over 747 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a pile on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.

summary: A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with 3 silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The con10t of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.

140 antoniniani were found on the bottom of a ceramic vessel by the excavation team of the University of Milan. Based on preliminary information drawn from the web, coins in this hoard date to the reign of Gallienus (AD 260-268).

Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).

The hoard comprised 69 Iron Age Continental bronzes and Roman coins. The Iron Age coins were Ambiens bronzes of Scheers types 59, 80, 96, 104, 105, 143, 163 and 217, a bronze of Scheers type 170 attributed to Viromanduens, another with the legend VANDIILOS attributed to Bituriges, 1 with the legend SEGISV (BN 4628) and 16 with the legend GERMANVS INDVTILLI L. The Roman coins included plated Republican denarius, a cut dupondius from Nemausus, 3 worn cut asses, 4 asses of Augustus, 1 quadrans and 1 as of a type depicting the altar of Lyon of either Augustus or Tiberius, 2 quadrantes of Tiberius and 2 of Claudius.

The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the 9teenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.

summary: Unknown initial coin number. 28 coins studied from a private collection: Valerian I - Gallienus (sole) (AD 265-266).

A hoard of Iron Age staters found in Climping, at a rally in 2000 during which a Roman denarii hoard was found as well, and then in 2002. The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel with leather bags originally containing more than 2650 Roman gold coins. Of these, 2518 have been recorded. In 1963 a hoard of 4th-century Roman bronze coins said to have been originally found near Izmir in the vicinity of Smyrna in Turkey found its way to Germany in 2 portions. 1 part, consisting of 1186 coins, was acquired by the Prähistorische Staatssammlung München; a second portion, consisting of 1052 pieces, was listed by Drs. H.-J. Kellner and B. Overbeck before the sale of the coins by the late Heinrich Pilartz. The details of a further 9 coins in a "private collection were supplied by H.-J. Kellner. The hoard consists of the nummi of the joint reigns of Constantius II, first with Constantius Gallus (A.D. 351-354) and then with Julian as Caesar (A.D. 355-361), with the addition of quite a small amount of earlier coinage Galerius, Constantine I. The 3 coins 1, 1 of Valentinian I, and 2 of Honorius are clearly intruders in the hoard.
disposition: Prähistorische Staatssammlung München, Germany (1,186 coins); private collection (9 coins)

Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.

In addition, a bronze coin of Anastasius was also recorded, probably an intruder. The closing date is given as 393 or 395, or according to J. Lafaurie between 402 and 408).

Boissel, the coins were principally nummi of the m1tary reform and some fractions (1/48th of a pound) from Trier, London and Lyon. HER report of a hoard found in 1976 and sold in trade, reported by a dealer in 2002. "The hoard was examined by Malcolm Lyne who produced a report. 48 dupondii and sestertii were identified. They had been found in a truncated Rowlands Castle grey ware jar dating from the third century. [The dealer] believed that the sestertii and dupondii had been accompanied by an uncertain number of antonianii of Galienus, Victorinus, Claudius II, Tetricus I and II and Quintillus. These had been retained by the landowner".
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 7.3 to 19.6 g.

A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.

Given the uncertainty about the origins of the hoard (found by a shepherd boy in a flint?), and in particular its possible confusion with Farley Heath, the reconstruction presented here must be treated with some caution (de Jersey). 18 coins, out of a possible total of 40 (?).
140 nummi found with a cooking pot: Gratian - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).

A report on a hoard of Roman denarii (Vespasian - Septimius Severus), found in the forest of Cowie, 3 miles north of St1haven, about 1 ½ miles from the Roman camp of Raedykes, in 1843. 9 of these denarii were apparently presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland (3, with names of emperors), the British Museum (3 with names of emperors), and the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle (3, but without names of emperors), but could not be located. The coins presented to the BM, and to the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle, were described as having been "found at Blackburn of Muchalls in the County of Kincardine, in 1843".
The original total number of coins in the hoard is not known, although 14 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Originally were 420 silver coins. 274 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 273 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 259-268).
disposition: Town Museum Koprivnica, Croatia (274 coins); partly dispersed - 1982

summary: The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for st1. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.

The hoard comprised approximately 200 gold aurei dating to the Julio-Claudian period.They were found in association with sherds of pottery suggesting they were originally deposited in a ceramic container. It appears that they were not all catalogued although Ponton d'Amécourt examined a lot of 30 coins. M. Brun found the hoard in an area of hard and resistant ground, while working in his fields.
860 billon tetradrachms: Marcus Aurelius - Claudius II (AD 268-269) found during excavations beneath the floor of an underground room of a house.
disposition: 849 in Ann Arbor. The rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver w8: 135.15 g.

3997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in 2 stages: 939 in 1965, 3058 in 1970. In total: 3663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).

A hoard of 26 solidi and ca. 304 siliquae, found with 2 gold rings in 1824 in 2 pots, 1 for the silver coins, 1 for the gold coins and the gold rings. 2 bronze coins recorded at the time may have come from a Romano-British habitation site in the neighbourhood. The list given by O'Neil in 1933 includes 26 solidi and 296 siliquae.
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The earliest source to mention the circumstances of the find appears to be the Carlyon-Britton sale catalogue (Sotheby, 17 November 1913), at lots 24, 37 and 49, all of which are described as "Found in a tumulus at Cackham Farm, West Wittering, about 1840". Haselgrove (1984, 297) has suggested that the tumulus "was probably a sand dune or clearance", and he includes the Cackham Farm finds among the larger assemblage from Selsey (267). While it is possible that Carlyon-Britton had some particular knowledge of the circumstances of discovery, the record is too vague to be of much value now (de Jersey).

16 Roman coins (including 4 sestertii and 2 asses, and some silver coins) found in a jug in a quarry, along the road from Mangelhausen to Kirschhof in a quarry. Find possibly identical to the 1 described under Kirschhof (CHRE ID 16732).
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."
1 kilo of silver coins found with a Dacian ceramic vessel. Only 8 denarii were recovered: Republic 7, Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) 1.
disposition: Eastern Carpathian Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (inv.nos. 16023-16033)

summary: 130 nummi found with a metallic vessel: Gallienus - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 383-408).
disposition: Museu Regional de Oliveira de Azeméis, Portugal

summary: 4-500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel. 29 coins were studied: Vespasian (Titus Caesar) – Philip I.
Amongst 76 coins found in the Musée d'Ernée with the label 'Jublain 1937', are 14 which appear to represent a hoard.

A hoard of 144 coins (mostly 4th century AD) were discovered during the excavation of a wine cellar in De-Nys-Strasse in a burnt layer of 50cm thickness, deep in a Roman well with other things. The coins show burn marks and are badly preserved.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: Child's burial, found by the local teacher; among grave goods 3 coins to the left of the body, Augustus, Tiberius and Claudius I. No details given on the metal, so probably Aes.
23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274; silver w8: 0.4-0.6g.
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
Over 1000 coins, believed to be of the House of Theodosius (AD 388-423).
Hoard of 867 nummi of the House of Constantine I of which 864 are imitations of various mints issues (AD 347-348).
66 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 47 antoniniani (radiates), 19 nummi: Gallienus - Magnentius (AD 350-353).
disposition: The Karl Ernst Osthaus Museum in Hagen (impossible to identify them)

summary: c. 150 denarii: Republic, Augustus, Tiberius, Nero-Domitian
disposition: National Museum Belgrade, Serbia (104 coins); dispersed 1981

summary: 84 nummi found spread on the pavement of a room: Constantius II -Avitus (AD 455-456).
Unknown number of silver coins. 19 antoniniani are known: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2729

summary: 3 denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.

The coin hoard was discovered during the third season of excavations, where archaeologists unearthed an amphora containing 80 copper staters, whilst researching evidence of a destruction layer caused by fire from the 6th century AD. A closer inspection of the coins reveals that they are mainly copper staters of the Bosporan kings of the late 3rd – early 4th century AD.
3000 bronze Alexandrian coins, 'mostly drachms', 1st century and early 2nd century. Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina m1taria".

In 1880 a hoard weighing 10 kilos was discovered. In 1883, other 500 silver coins were discovered in the same village. In 1971, 6 coins from 1 of the lots were available for study: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I/Trajan Decius (AD 244-251).
disposition: Museum of History, Reșița, Romania (6 coins)

summary: 41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
186 coins: 185 antoniniani (radiates), 1 billon Alexandrian drachm: Gallienus - Maximian I. Circumstances of find not known.
34 aurei found with a ceramic vessel and jewelry: from Nero to Trajan Decius (Hostilian). Includes a medallion of Gallienus; gold w8: 238.2-255.2 g.

There seems to be confusion in the record between a hoard of 16 second century coins associated with a ceramic vessel given to the BM by Franks and said to be found in a garden of a house in Albert Drive in Wimbledon and a hoard of 8 "early brass" coins found in excavations at Caesar's Camp on Wimbledon Common in a ceramic vesssel. The hoard was said also to contain a bronze ingot fragment. This record refers to the Caesar's Camp hoard.
43 nummi; Licinius I - Constantine I (AD 318). Mints: 2 Londinium, 41 Arelate
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: 20 antoniniani. No further information .
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 coins in the museum of Lovech. No further information.
The hoard was found inside a textile bag placed within a ceramic vessel and comprised approximately 300 silver coins, apparently all antoniniani (radiates). The hoard has a tpq of AD 261.
A hoard of 14 (or 15?) denarii (Republic - Augustus), found in Haltern during the 1925-28 excavations. The precise find spot can not be ascertained any more. The coins are now lost.

A hoard of denarii was found approx. 0.7 km northwest of Ausleben, on the Ausleber Hoch (alt. 135 m) in a probable neolithic grave mound. 142 coins (Otho-Commodus) were described, but the total amount of coins is unknown.
4370 coins found in a cooking pot with graffiti (ME X): 4 denarii, 4366 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: Centre archéologique de la Mayenne, Jublains, France

summary: Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded 3 hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All 3, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.

70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: 52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
The hoard comprised 6 gold coins from AD 337-350 to AD 527-565.
Circa 200 denarii fopund in a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 196-211).
disposition: Until 1944 part of the hoard was kept in the museum in Szczecin, another part was kept in the museum in Reskow, the rest in a private collection. Nowadays, 161 pieces are in the Straslund Museum of Cultural History Germany) and 14 empty envelopes

summary: Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: 101 coins found in a vineyard. 86 are documented by D. Chico. The structure of this discovery raises some suspicions: Gaius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
27 denarii found with a jug covered by a st1: 24 republican, 3 imperial of Augustus (25-23 BC). With 3 bracelets and 1 jewelry fragmented, also of silver.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (23 coins); the British Museum (4 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 3 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II, placed in a pile in the foundations of the wall of a Gallo-Roman villa. It has been interpreted by TAF as a foundation deposit.

12 coins, presented to Gunnersbury Museum by a Major Salter, were said to have been found "wrapped in sacking" in Gunnersbury Lane. The sacking was not preserved and the coins were subsequently stolen.

In the summer of 1959, during excavations on a pre-Roman and Romano-British site on the east bank of the Avon at Armsley in the parish of Godshill, Hants, a small hoard of 4 Durotrigic coins was discovered together with a bronze fibula of La Tène III type. No further details of the context of the "hoard", or its precise association with the fibula are given. The 3 staters are described (Shortt 1960, 1) as "showing evident signs of silver plating.
Funerary deposit near skeleton (viaticum): 40 coins: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 33 nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 310-313). Found together with 2 finger rings.

Brick fragments were recorded under the inventory number 10202 in 1884, which number was located on a box with uniform well-preserved late Roman coins; only Nr. 28 derives from a heavily worn stamp. The composition of the series clearly suggests a hoard find, at least starting from Nr. 2, Victorinus.
A mixed hoard of circa 250 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) dating from Septimus Severus to Valerian I (AD 253-259).
9 sestertii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 181).
Unknown Initial number of coins. 12 quadrantes of Trajan are kept in the National History Museum in Sofia.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 40771-40781 (12 quadrans)

summary: 223 silver coins (tetradrachms, denarius, shekels) found with a ceramic vessel next to another 1 (Qumran 1953 B) and not far from Qumran 1953 C.

7 coins discovered outside Vaenor in 1945, 4 of which were either lost or too worn to permit identification. The 3 surviving coins are all nummi of Maximinus II Daia (A.D. 305-313), Maxentius (306-312), and Constantine I (307-337).

The hoard comprised 16 coins from Tiberius to Claudius II and were found along with the remains of a coarseware pottery urn. TAF interprets the assemblage as being successive votive offerings rather than a hoard. The coins were found at the entrance to a cave.
140 provincial bronze coins, possible kept in a leather bag. 110 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 00518/1-110

summary: The hoard was found placed on a masonry slab and comprised a sestertius of Hadrian and 21 double sestertii of Postumus, including 4 imitations.
2 sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
(?) 17 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Julia Domna, Gordian III, Valerian I, Gallienus, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
43 nummi found in the heating system of room F of the pratorium: House of Constantine I - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 3750 coins, mostly Syrian tetradrachms ranging from Caracalla to Volusian, some antoniniani and a few denarii, found in a destruction layer in the 'Poseidon villa' in Zeugma.

A hoard of 162 provincial coins, 27 of which were illegible. The remaining 1s were: 134 coins from Sinope (Antoninus Pius - Valerian & Gallienus) and 1 from Trapezus (Gordian III). The hoard was found in a burnt and shattered container in the remains of a Roman villa, on the northern side of the Sinope peninsula.

In 1999, the numismatics department of the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts acquired 197 nummi, which were part of the hoard discovered near the village Molochne of the Saki region of the Republic of Crimea, probably in 1989-1990. Unfortunately, the circumstances of the discovery are still unclear. Constantine I - Constans and Constantius II (AD 347-348).
disposition: The Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts, Moscow, Russia (197 coins)

summary: 244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
6 coins found in associated with box fittings "of a type of10 associated with casket burials" (Crummy 1987, 75) from Culver Street site J (insula 34) in Colchester.
5 or 6 silver denarii. The coins were originally corroded together. 3 coins were separated, leaving a stack of either 2 or 3 denarii.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver w8: c. 28.0-124.0 g.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins dated between AD 225-253.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins dated between AD 378 and AD 388.
50 denarii of the House of Vespasian (AD 69-96).

The second hoard find from Kirchgasse contained also folles from the middle Constantinian time, in addition apparently to a Divus Claudius specimen. Only 6 coins are known, but the hoard might well have contained many more.
"A hoard of 147 copper alloy late Roman coins, deposited between AD 379-388. A large flint nodule was placed on top."
Hoard of 13-15 coins, antoniniani (radiates) and nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Victorinus - Honorius (AD 395-423).
disposition: Vytautas the Great War Museum, Kaunas, Lithuania (inv.nos. 2215A-2227A)

summary: This hoard of 1648 gold coins was found at the periphery of the ancient site. It comprised 2 parts: 102 solidi belonging to the joint reign of Valentinian I and Valens, almost exclusively from eastern mints (AD 364-67); 1545 solidi and 1 semissis belonging to the time of Theodosius, Arcadius and Honorius, with mints mainly from southern Gaul and Italy, including some Visigothic mints (AD 379-421).
disposition: Musée National du Bardo, Tunis, Tunisia

summary: 3 Gallo-Belgic staters reportedly found together early in 1992. Sills (2003, 364 no. 29) notes that they might conceivably be strays from the Harpsden Wood hoard (de Jersey 215).
In 1931 the discovery of 14 late Roman coins (Tetrarchy - Gratian) is reported during building work.

The hoard was found along with several inhumation burials and the foundations of buildings and comprised a mass of 80kg of Roman coins. The successive editions of the museum catalogue have varied catalogues for this hoard. For example, the catalogue of 1856 notes 35 coins for Otacilia Severa and Trajan Decius; the catalogue of 1903 mentions 3 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius (possibly site finds?) and 'small bronzes' of Philip and Maximian Herculeus. The mention of Maximian, 60 years after the discovery of the hoard is considered by TAF to be suspect. The hoard was found during dredging and ground levelling work, along with inhumation burials and building foundations. Silver: c.25000-30000 (39, 2) coins; Silver w8: -
60 sestertii of Trajan (AD 98-117).
340 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210).
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver w8: 78.54 g.
3 bronze coins: 2 sestertii of Hadrian, 1 double sestertius of Postumus (AD 264-265) found in a layer of ashes in a cellar of a Roman building.
51 coins: 50 sestertii and 1 as with 2 fibulae found in a looted Roman building
17 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 186-187)
disposition: Collection L. Eloy, Namur, Belgium (14 coins), in 1966

summary: A hoard of 18 Late Roman coins (AD 378-383), found near the NW corner of city wall. 3 further coins were found close to this group, and may or may not belong to it (1 of them has an earlier date: Constantius II, AD 347-348).
11 solidi of which only 4 identified: Theodosius II 3, Valentinian III (AD 445); gold w8: 48.95 g.
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: The hoard comprised both coins and other objects, including numerous items of personal adornment in precious metals as well as tableware and other vessels. 1 of the vessels contained approximately 395 denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Saloninus (and Valerian II?) while in the hoard as a whole, there were approximately 1080 bronze coins, nearly all sestertii, but with the exception of 12 dupondii and asses. The bronze coins range in date from Domitian (1 example) through to Trajan Decius. Tes10oire-Lafayette noted that issues of Gordian III were particularly prominent in the hoard, that Severus Alexander was also well-represented and that issues of Gallienus and his family made up a large proportion of the radiates in the hoard. The hoard was found when the landowner, M. Charles demolished well-built foundations in his field which were hindering cultivation. Silver: c.395 coins;
disposition: Societé de la Diana, Montbrison, France

summary: 2 Cheriton staters were found by Mr Brian Radford, near Fareham, in February 2006. They were stolen from Westbury Manor Museum, Fareham, on 29 April 2010, and unfortunately no images appear to exist.
17 sestertii found with a large black urn. The earliest coin belongs to Gaius, the latest 1 to Titus (AD 80-81).
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
(2000) 27 nummi: Constantius II, Constans, Vetranio (AD 350).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest (28 coins), in 1904

summary: Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver w8: 965.17 g.

The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and 4 barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: A hoard of 768 nummi (first Tetrarchy, AD 295-305), originally wrapped in a linen cloth, found in the barracks of the Roman fort of Vemania. The hoard was buried in early AD 305, Garbsch / Kos, pp. 70-1. N.B. Though the number of coins catalogued is 768, the total number of coins is menti1d several times as 771 in the publication of Garbsch / Kos.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 350 silver coins, 'nearly all debased coins.' The coins included issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Geta, Plautilla, Macrinus, Diadumenian, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Maximus, Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius and Herennia Etruscilla. Piette mentions a coin of Diocletian but this is an error for Diadumenian.

Gold hoard of aurei, solidi and multiple of solidi: Tetrarchy - Constantius II-Magnentius (AD 353). The hoard, which according to some sources contained around 70-80 coins and a large amount of gold jewellery, was embezzled by the finders immediately after its discovery, divided and scattered in the trade.6 AV mults. assumed to be 2x; 32 AV sol. tpq c.353 Gold: 6, 32 coins; Gold w8: c.195.8g+;

The hoard was found inside a vessel, apparently made of iron. The total number of coins found seems to be 90, although some reports detail at least 107. The coins were all bronze issues measuring between 25 and 35mm in diameter: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Monedas conservadas en el Museo Arqueologico, Etnografico e Historico, Vasco, Spain (5 coins)

summary: About 40000 antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found in 3 vessels: Septimius Severus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised 1 vessel containing a harness fitting and 800 copper-alloy and silver coins of Commodus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Albinus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Plautilla, Geta, Macrinus, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Orbiana, Gordian I, Pulpienus, Balbinus, Gordianus III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa and Herennius Etruscus.
1764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with 2 ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised 2118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: 4 denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely
Circa 585 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 176.4-730.3g.
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); w8, c. 80 g.
40-8 Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
19 nummi of the House of Constantine found in a grave
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 02 comprises 163 Iron Age coins.
137 silver coins: 112 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Clodius Albinus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 176.8-335.2 g.

Originally this hoard consisted of approx. 10000 mostly bronze (some exceptions) coins but only a fraction have been recorded. The Cabinet of Medailles due Musee d'Histoire et d'Art has the following coins listed here. Others are in Trier, although it no longer is possible to determine which 1s these are. 4 arg., 74 nummi copies, 2439 nummi Silver: 2, 4 coins; Silver w8: c.13.4g

find_spot_name: OPLONTIS - VILLA B, SKELETON 27, ON THE CHEST
summary: 123 coins found on the chest of the skeleton no. 27: 89 aurei, 34 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 78-79).
125 nummi: Tetrarchy - Valens (AD 364-378).
A hoard of 107 provincial bronze coins (of which 74 were identifiable), found in the Roman barracks at Dura Europos.
4 gold coins found in a female grave: Septimius Severus 2, Philip I and Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised a gold necklace and 20 copper-alloy coins from Commodus and Caracalla. The archive report questions whether this deposit represents a horad but does not provide any further explanation.
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: Hoard of 700 silver coins. 578 pieces were recovered: 577 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Pokrajinski muzej, Celje, Slovenia (578 coins); dispersed

summary: A hoard of 15 aurei (Tiberius to Domitian under Vespasian) and 133 denarii (Republic to Domitian), found on several occasions between 1981 and 2003, widely scattered, as a result of deep ploughing, over a considerable area.
Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
329 nummi found with a ceramic vessel in the Christian necropolis of Tarraco. The most recent coins has been dated between AD 342-348.
3 solidi: 2 Valentinian I, 1 Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).

In 1838, dredging works along a length of river measuring approxiamtely 100 metres, brought to light numerous Roman coins in mint condition (between 15000 and 20000 approximately). They ended with issues of Tiberius. The assemblage was found during dredging works of a stretch of river measuring approximately 100 metres in length, at the confluence of the River Achenau and 10u.
15 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 161-180). Only 7 denarii are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia, 7 coins; dispersed

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL II
summary: An investigation of several specimens, in total a thousand pieces, took place in the Cologne museum. The 85 listed coins are derived from this number. It is unknown whether the coins arrived inside the museum only for examination, or whether the coins remained there in their entirety or a part of them

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 249.6-505.0 g.
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.
The hoard, discovered 1 year after MAGNY-COURS 2008, comprised 466 antoniniani (radiates) and 366 heavy nummii.
161 coins: 19 denarii and antoniniani, 142 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 4428-4588

summary: (1313) 995 nummi: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 375-378).
Originally 200 denarii, at least 10 were recorded: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Around 200 denarii. 7 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235) are known..
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Circa 200 nummi went to a private collector: Constans - Honorius (AD 395-423).
85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).

12 coins found together in a pit that served as a cellar to an agricultural building. Probably were kept in a leather or fabric purse: 1 bronze medallion, 7 sestertii, 4 dupondii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 240).
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were menti1d.
297 nummi with a tpq around AD 375

During various excavations at the Neolithic site (from 1842 to 1969) 25 Roman coins - ranging from Domitian to Arcadius - were found together with other artefacts (rings, brooches). Among coins were, 8 gold pieces presented here: Tetrarchy - Theodosius I. Also 3 uniface gold medallions of the House of Constantine were found (see Objects). All the coins and artefacts are considered to be votive offerings (Bland/Loriot 2010, 99).

Around 1860 a forest warden delivered, among other coins, 6 denarii that lay in rolls, stuck together in a bundle. 7 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Caracalla, were listed among the single finds made in Dambach in 1901 and could be identical with the find made ca. 1860.
339 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan Decius - Carinus (AD 284-285); silver w8: 62.1-422.8g.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt, Austria (64 coisn); various private collections

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins. 40 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen. No further information.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12347/1-40 (40 coins)

summary: Record of a partial hoard of Tetrarchic nummi, found by looters at Çanakçılar, a farmstead above Filyos, and purchased by a local businessman. This partial hoard consists of 433 coins dating from AD 294 to 306. The complete hoard is estimated at approximately 1400 coins.

77 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 76 nummi, 2nd century AD, House of Constantine I, House of Valentinianus I (AD 367-375). The hoard was found in a leather purse together with 3 bronze rings. The purse was discovered between the legs of a Skeleton in a grave beside a knife. 7 more coins were found in the same grave displaey near the left leg (see VRON 1).
3762 coins found with an amphora: Gallienus - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
A hoard of gold and copper coins found in a vessel. Only 10 solidi are known: Honorius - Theodosius II (AD 424-425).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Sofia, Bulgaria; 10 solidi; inv.no. 865-874

summary: 17 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 21

summary: The hoard contains in total 18 coins. 1 antoninianus, 17 denarii. Coins of Septimius Severus, Julia Mamea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I (AD 244-246).
40 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
Originally, 201 silver coins. 190 silver coins are documented: Hadrian - Carus (AD 282-285). The half follis of Justin I/Justinian I is, most likely, an intruder.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 165 (190 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in burial 403 in a Roman cemetery and comprised 'a purse containing 5 sestertii, as well as 70 coins of Tetricus, Licinius, etc.'

Nearly 300 Roman coins of the houses of Constantine I and Theodosius I (AD 408-423). The identifiable coin types (based on Still 1907): Crispus (Caesar); gloria exercitus (1 standard); vot xx mult xxx; vict aug; victoriae dd auggq nn (2 victories); vot xx mult xxx; Constantius II: fel temp reparatio (falling horseman); spes reipublice; House of Theodosius I: gloria Romanorum (emperor, captive); salus reipublicae (victory, captive); vot x mult xx; vot x mult xx; vot v; gloria Romanorum (emperor on horseback); virtus exerciti (emperor, victory); virtus exerciti (emperor, victory); concordia augg (Constantinopolis); urbs roma felix; gloria Romanorum (3 emperors); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors).

A hoard found in 1854, including 1505 siliquae, ranging from Constantius II to Constantine III and 1 miliarensis of Jovian. Many coins were clipped. A further 195 siliquae (Valens, Gratian and Honorius) are said to have been subsequently found near the same place. These are listed here as well.
disposition: The British Museum; Belfast Museum (21 coins)

summary: 39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.
During the digging of a ditch 3 asses were found placed in a small amphora which was placed in a bigger 1: Sextus Pompeius as, Augustus as, Philip I as,
The hoard comprised 7 badly corroded Late Roman bronze coins roughly dated between AD 378-383 and AD 455-465.
23 denarii found with a m1y-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: (c. 100) 81: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver w8: 51.3-104.7 g.
14 nummi: Valens - Magnus Maximus/Flavius Victor (AD 3787-388). In a destruction layer of a Roman house.
60 sestertii of Claudius I, all of the same type (RIC 96) found under a slab.
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.
4 republican Denarii, 1 imperial AR, 8 imperial AE (Galba and Vespasian) and 4 uncertain AR found in regio IX, insula 9, entrance of building F (house).

The hoard comprised 6 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.748 to 76.753
110 silver Roman denarii recovered by excavation by the FLO and WYAS after initial detector find. For full details and images see SWYOR-810366. Unpublished catalogue by R. Abdy and V. Drost.
123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.
3 denarii found during excavations in a field near an archaeological site, prior to the construction of a water treatment plant.
2 aurei - Tiberius, Claudius I - found in a grave.

1 republican Denarius, 4 imperial Sestertii (Nero, Galba and Vespasian), 4 uncertain imperial AE and 1 uncertain AR found in regio IX, insula 11, fallen from a rack on top of amphorae leaning against wall E of building 2 (thermopolium).

The circumstances of discovery of this hoard are unknown. Some of the coins were in the Védie Collection. Évreux museum had 1 gold stater (LT 7017) with the same provenance, but it is not clear whether it was from this hoard.
Over 9 nummi found in a garden. Among them 1 coin of Constantius II and 1 of the House of Theodosius I (AD 379-423).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (inv.no. H5-H5-255.040-255.648)

summary: A hoard of 30 or 40 coins, packed in clay in the form of rouleau. 8 of them were of Trajan. The others are of Trajan, Tiberius.
Originally, circa 1000 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 37 are known: Constantine I - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).
disposition: Museo Provincial and Museo Diocesano de Lugo, Spain

summary: Unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins are known: Antoninus Pius 2, 1 of the Faustinas 1, Lucilla 1.
5 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (tpq AD 302-303) discovered in a grave from a necropolis.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

37 aurei were found in 1957, digging the trench for the foundations of a bungalow. There was no trace of a container. The coins were probably packed in rolls and wrapped in cloth which had perished. 34 were published in 1959, and a further 3 coins sent to the British Museum in 1965.
15 sestertii found close to each other on a narrow space in the eastern necropolis of the Augusta Emerita: Domitian
disposition: Consorcio de la Ciudad Monumental de Mérida, Spain

summary: 1 aureus of Vespasian, 63 uncertain AR, 28 uncertain AE found in regio VI, insula 10, atrium of building 2 (house)
3 Roman hoards found in St1a. This hoard comprises 47 denarii, ending with Severus Alexander.
61 Celtic gold coins of the 1st century A.D. found in a field at Farmborough, near Bath.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: A case of folded copper sheets was unearthed at a rustic villa while building barracks in 1937. It contained 12 coins (Crispina - Magnus Maximus).

2 solidi found in 1899 and 1909 on the same field. The loops of these coins are identical to the 1 from the coin from EJSTRUP MARK, and the 3 may have belonged to the same ensemble. Other coins were reported found «previously» on the same field.

The hoard was found in a vessel in a villa (?). The vessel contained about 200 nummi from Constantine II to Valens, as well as 2 radiates of Trajan Decius and Gallienus and a larger bronze of Constantine I.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.

Hoard from the initial phase of excavations at Bat10 Hanger Roman villa, directed by J. Magilton. Currently in preparation for publication. Details from M. Lyne (pers. comm.). The site consists of a Roman villa and aisled building, with occupation into the fifth century.
160 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Sold to a British private collector.

summary: 1444 solidi: Honorius - Valentinian III (AD 441-450); gold w8: 6446 g.
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest (1437 coins), Inv.no. 28/1964.1-1437; Józó Erzsébet (2 coins); János Tornyai Museum, Hódmezővásárhely, Hungary (5 coins)

summary: A hoard of 60 late Roman coins (Constantin I - Constantius II) found during excavations made before the construction of a new Merkur store Am Spielhof. The coins had been burnt and are poorly preserved. Deposition possibly connected with the incursion of the Juthungen in AD 357.
(ca. 2000) 489 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver w8: c. 2801.7-6258.3 g.
1170 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1159 coins were recovered: 1158 denarii 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver w8: c. 2142.4-3660.8 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie Piatra-Neamţ, Romania (inv.nos. P 706-1865 MAPN; P 105 MAPN)

summary: 76 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Gallinus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a disintegrated cloth bag at floor level in room during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold w8: 7.1-7.2 g; silver w8: 17.2-22.6 g.

The 29 coins are derived from a closed room of the residential house, north of Mithraeum. They lay dispersed in the sandy earth on the usage h8 of the building. It concerns also marginally a unified deposited find.
242 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 67.7-626.9 g.
25 silver denarii were found along with a considerable amount of human b1, interpreted as being an indicator of a battlefield site.
Around 200 denarii. Only 60 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only 3 readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
9 coins of the Bosporans kings: Eupator, Sauromates II.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins and 1 bronze coin dated to the second century AD.
50 bronze coins were discovered in Roux, but only 9 were preserved, ranging in date from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for 1 Lycian drachm of Trajan.

Chappée and the Vicomte d'Elbenne bought 2 lots of coins (approximately 2000) which were sold as part of a hoard weighing 20kg. They were found in a ceramic urn in a field next to the station in Sillé-le-Guillaume or in Rouessé-Vassé or in Mayenne (Voutré or Sainte-Suzanne). The Musée du Mans has preserved a manuscript note related to a lot of 583 coins weighing 1453g and quantifying these coins by emperor: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard was found in a grave or tomb, amongst the b1s and comprised 11 Roman sestertii. The hoard was found in a barnyard.
5989 Roman denarii (Augustus - Septimius Severus, AD 209) and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Antoninus Pius) were uncovered, hidden under the floor of a house.

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
31 denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

The hoard comprised a grey ware vessel containing 9065 small bronzes, weighing 25kg. The coins included issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Several months later, the same finder discovered a second vessel filled with approximately 4000 coins. According to Etoc-Demazy, 4/5ths of the first hoard was acquired by the Musée du Mans. In 1981, a lot of 181 coins was sold at the Hotel Drouot which may have been part of the second hoard.
356 silver coins: 294 denarii, 62 antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver w8: 490.5-1026.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania (348 coins), County Museum Tg. Jiu, Romania (8 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.
Over 100 aurei. 94 aurei documented: Tiberius - Domitian (AD 88-94).
200 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1 nummus wasd seen in 1933 by Dr. F. Hantmann.
