A Clacton type quarter stater shown to the British Museum in June 1996 was reported to be 1 of 3 found at St Lawrence Bay. No further details available.
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only 2 pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.

2901 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 379-395). It must be noticed the absence of the coins of the House of Valentinian I. The mints: Ambianum 1, Treveri 1, Lugdunum 3, Arelate 6, Roma 53, Aquileia 91, Siscia 509, Sirmium 715, Thessalonica 440, Heraclea 143, Constantinopolis 247, Nicomedia 86, Cyzicus 146, Antioch 29, Alexandria 3, uncertain mint 418, barbarous 10
disposition: Museum of the Highland Banat, Reșița, Romania

summary: 154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: “some half a dozen Roman third brass coins”.
32 denarii: Republic - Titus (AD 80).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain (28 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 32 coins, including 2 denarii and 30 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Maesa to Postumus. It is suggested that they were originally stored in a box.
76 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates), 25 sestertii; silver w8: 16.5-147.8 g.
6 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring and a bracelet: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
74 silver coins. No further information
269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
6 billon coins of Alexandria found in a grave: Probus - Maximian I (AD 293).
36 Roman coins found together with a statuette "having a ring at the top of the head". No further details
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel filled with between 60 and 80 Roman bronze coins of unknown date. The hoard was found at the top of a ditch on at a tree nursery.
2666 coins (21.735 kilos). 1333 coins were available for cataloguing: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 303).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche del Comune di Milano (inv.nos. M 0.9.38196-M 0.9.39528)

summary: The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing 4066 radiates of Postumus, Macrianus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian and Tacitus.

The hoard comprised 159 coins: 55 Syrian tetradrachms (Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus) and 104 antoniniani (Trebonianus Gallus to Maximian), found in a pot in an underground beneath a church in Iafa, near Nazareth.
The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.
It comprised 187 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
A small number of solidi, found close to Deudesfeld 'Auf der Steinmauer'. 3 solidi are host in the Landesmuseum in Trier: Constans, Constantius II (2).
(2820) 2819 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.no. 1867

summary: 80 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (AD 293-305).
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
3 coins, of which 1 aureus of Trajan (AD 114-117).
The hoard comprised 11 sestertii: Hadrian-Philip I (117-246 AD).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: 18 gold staters, 138 silver staters, 1 thin silver coin, 7 copper alloy coins of the Roman period, 2 silver ingots, 1 copper alloy ingot, 5 sherds of Iron Age pottery and 1 copper alloy unidentified object.
11 burned antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 2 lots of 8 (24.09g) and 3 (8.83g) coins.
33 denarii found in a pit under a slab in a Roman house: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-15).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Santa Tecla, Pontevedra, Spain

summary: A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).
3 gold coins (Vespasian, Titus and Domitian), found in 1725, below Alton Castle.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 third century antoniniani (radiates.) The hoard was discovered by a farmer while cutting back an oak tree.
A hoard of 45 antoniniani found in the burial of a soldier killed during the siege for Dura Europos in 256/7.
Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina m1taria".
24 antoniniani (radiates) and 42 imitations found in the basement of a Roman villa: Gallienus - Maximian I (AD 285-291).
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat st1.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1200 antoniniani (radiates). The following emperors were represented: Valerian, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus and Claudius II. It also included a radiate of Macrianus (SOLI INVICTO) and 3 of Postumus (CONCORD EQVIT; MONETA AVG; and P M TR P COS II P P). The last coin is a DIVO CLAVDIO radiate with eagle reverse.

4 copper alloy coins (1 provincial coin from Antioch and 3 local SC imitations produced in Hatra), acquired from locals at Hatra, during the Assur excavations by the Deutsche Orient-Gesellschaft, 1903–1913. These coins could be a hoard or single finds.
21 denarii and 28 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 1 denarius Maximinus I Thrax, 3 antoniniani : 1 Caracalla, 2 Gordian III.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2591

summary: 572 silver coins: 22 denarii, 550 antoniniani (radiates): M. Aurelius (Lucilla) - Postumus (AD 268); silver w8: 180.5-1484.6 g. Found together with Gold jewelry: 1 necklace, 2 rings, 2 sets of earrings
20 denarii of similar types with the coins in the hoard POMPEI I, IX, 1 - Casa di Cerere. No further details. Ending with coins of Vespasian ?
159 denarii: 151 republican, 7 imitations; 1 imperial denarius of Severus Alexander. Uncertain whether the Severus Alexander coin belongs to thee hoard.
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest (20 coins: today, 9 denarii and 6 imitations are preserved)

summary: There is an account of Borlase receiving 4 radiates from the Rector of Lanreath that were found at the unidentified place of "Carlean" in 1785. The findspot was described as "near the northern extremity of [the earthwork known as] the Giant's-hedge, not far from Ethy", at Lerryn creek, on the Eastern banks of the River Fawy". Penhallurick suggests that Carlean is a misreading of Collon.
6 sestertii: Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander 2, Julia Mammea, Maximinus I Thrax, Paulin (Diva) brought together with other Roman materials: glass urns, bricks.
2 hoards not entirely recovered. 1 contained 7 coins: Salonina, Tacitus, Probus (5).
The central site of Sorte Muld at Bornholm has produced a large number of coins, of which 292 are interpreted as belonging to 1 original deposition.
Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. 2 dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.

In 1996 the Manor House Museum, Bury St Edmunds, purchased 6 staters, a quarter stater and a broken silver unit which had been found by Mr R. Nobbs on a site at Little Saxham, between January 1990 and May 1995. An additional stater from the same site, found in 1996, was acquired in November 1997. The 7 staters are likely to have originated in a single deposit, while the silver unit (ANTED(I), 0.47 g) and the quarter stater (Irstead type, ABC 1480, 1.01 g) were some distance away and thus perhaps not associated with the hoard (Talbot and Leins 2010, 12). (de Jersey).
disposition: Manor House Museum, Bury St Edmunds

summary: 162 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'
42 silver coins: 2 denarii, 40 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
51 nummi of Constantius II (AD 337-361). No further details.
6 Roman denarii up to AD 4 and 1 Iron Age potin, associated with a 1st c. AD brooch.
8 denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. 1 additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
2 solidi (Eugenius and Arcadius) and 7 siliquae (all of AD 394-402). All the coins were found together within an area defined by using a radius of 14 metres.
265 coins: 264 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

A hoard of originally more than 200 antoniniani of which 147 were split up between different museums and a private owner. 116 of these were published in detail by Laser in 1972 (114 of these could be documented de visu by M. Schlapke in 2015) and FMRD gives a full list of all 147 coins. Unfortunately, the FMRD list is faulty. The mistakes are difficult to correct, as the coins are not all accessible any more today. As a result, all coins ever documented have been listed here, with 3 FMRD entries having their quantity set to 'zero' (0), as no matching coin exists among the 1s seen by M. Schlapke. Surviving coins range from Valerian to Postumus. No trace of a container could be seen.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens (96 coins); Sondershausen, Schlossmuseum (8 coins); Gotha, Stiftung Schloss Friedenstein, Münzkabinett (31 coins, which cannot be identified any more within the collection) and 12 coins in private hands

summary: 10 provincial bronze coins. 1 of Septimius Severus, 1 of Caracalla, minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
2 aurei: Augustus, Tiberius. No description. The coins are considered as single finds by Callu-Loriot. However, same year of finding same findspot close chronological range.
24 solidi: Nepos - Anastasius (AD 491-518); gold w8: 106.8 g. Only 1 coin of Zeno was identified.
A hoard of 7 gold Iron Age and 28 silver Roman coins found during a metal detecting rally in 2014. The latest Iron Age coins date to c. AD 20-50 and the latest Roman coins are of Tiberius.
19 antoniniani (radiates) of the period Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259); silver w8: 5.6-13.4 g.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least 2 separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.

28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).

214 coins were discovered during the emergency excavations. Around 60-70 nummi were found with sherds of late terra sigillata and considered as a possible hoard: Constantine I - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-387).
A hoard of 402 silver coins: 31 tetradrachms (Marcus Aurelius - Macrinus), 370 denarii (Nero - Caracalla) and 1 tridrachm (Trajan) found in 2 jars at Dura Europos.
7 coins found at 30 cm deep: 2 sestertii, 5 asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: The hoard comprised 18 antoniniani (radiates) from trebonianus Gallus for Volusian to Postumus with the most recent issue a SAECVLI FELICITAS reverse type (Elmer 593).
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 57 bronzes dating to the second and third century AD. Sherds of pottery were recovered at the same time as the hoard suggesting that it was originally stored in a vessel. The hoard was discovered in a molehill. Although menti1d in numerous publications, it has never been studied in any detail. It was kept by the Club archéologique d'Auzances.

A small hoard of 13 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Maximin I Thrax (AD 235-238) was discovered in October 2018 in Crimea, probably in its eastern part. Information about the find and a general photo of the coins were published on 21 October 2018 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder himself identified the coins as “purse of denarii”. The coins have a very good preservation. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

Within circular st1 Late Roman shrine in layer of brown sandy loam were 8 coins, 2 fibulae & a penannular brooch, though these were earlier in date. Curated? Immediately above the building in the topsoil, controlled metal detecting in 1982 recovered a further 9 coins, 7 iron spearheads & 3 iron sockets, & pottery. Some/all of these finds may be additional items from hoard in pit, dispersed slightly by medieval/early modern ploughing.
A find of 8 coins of Faustina II, made in the area of Panagia Vrontou in Salamina.
Few hundred silver coins (?), kept in a wooden box similar to a casket, covered with amber lumps at the top (?). The hoard was probably found in a swampy meadow.
The hoard comprised 10 Roman Imperial 'bronze' (i.e. antoniniani?) coins, found in a Roman bath house in the southern part of ancient Pella. The latest were of Aurelian, Florian and Probus.
The hoard comprised 12 Celtic Iron Age bronze coins.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy spoon and 147 copper-alloy coins from Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Julia Mamaea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip II.
Originally 400 coins found with a bronze vessel, mostly sold to a jeweller. Only 41 were described: Republic - Nerva (AD 97).
6 Republican denarii, 1 quinarius of Augustus, and 1 denarius of Vespasian found in a piece of canvas in regio VI, insula 15, building 20 (house)

The total number of coins found is estimated at approximately 5000, of which only a small proportion were identified as issues of a particular emperor. The emperors represented were: Gallienus, Claudius II, Severina, Quintillus and Aurelian. The coins were of base silver and were therefore sold.
A hoard of Roman gold coins, imitations and beads was found by brick makers: Augustus - Nero (AD 61-62).
The Kirchgasse 62 find includes 100-200 coins, ranging from Gallienus to the time of Constantine I. Of these, 70 have been described.
2 aurei of Domitian and Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
5 coins found in room 3 of the House of 4 Season: Commodus 1 denarius, Septimius Severus 1 denarius, Caracalla 1 denarius, Julia Mamaea 1 sestertius, Maximinus I Trax 1 sestertius.

A hoard of 97 tetradrachms (Nero–Severus Alexander), 25 denarii, and 1 antoninianus, found in a trench excavation at Gindaros. As no further excavations were d1 araound that trench, the archaeological context remains so far uncertain.
1424 Tetrarchic nummi (c. AD 295-310) inside a broken greyware container found during the archaeological monitoring of the installation of a gas pipeline.
651 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from M. Antony to Philip I, found in a Roman cellar south-west of the Roman fort.

Votive deposit comprising 3 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.317 a to c
6 coins: 4 bronze republican (!), 1 denarius Nero, 1 antoninianus (radiate) Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised 7 iron or copper-alloy boxes filled with silver or small bronze coins of Gallienus, Claudius II, Tacitus, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian. Sirand acquired 6 antoniniani (radiates) from the hoard and noted that there were also silver vessels.
17 coins (denarii) found by a farmer on a field, ranging from the Republic to Titus (AD 79).

3 4th C. coins (1 of House of Constantine I AD 335-47, 2 uncertain AE, found in single homogenous fill of 'working hollow', assoc. with poss. hearth/fire pit. Also late 4th C pottery. Poss. a small purse hoard, but not found in a tight group.
The hoard comprised 75 nummi from the early part of the 4th century AD.
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); w8: 6100 kg.
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only 2 pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).

Unknown number of nummi of the first and second Tetrarchy. 10 pieces are known from public auctions: Diocletian - Constantine I (AD 307 and post). Mints: Treveri 4, Lugdunum 3, Ticinum 1, Serdica 1, Cyzicus 1
(50) 48 nummi House of Constantine I (AD 334-335)
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (48 coins)

summary: 4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: A hoard of Gallo-Belgic E staters found by the Sedgeford Historical and Archaeological Research Project. The hoard was partly contained within a bovine front right humerus.
4 antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
3 drachms of the Parthian king Gotarzes II (AD 40-51) and 16 denarii of Augustus (2 BC - AD 4) were found during excavations.
30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: 18 silver coins: 4 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Claudius II (AD 268-270). Together were found jewelry: 2 silver bracelets, 1 gold pendant, 3 gold rings, 1 gold earring and fragments of silver earrings.
disposition: Museo di Antichità di Torino, Italy

summary: 700-750 bronze coins. 483 provide some information and 273 can be entered at the coin data level: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

1 coin is a Western uninscribed gold quarter stater of a type produced in the Gloucestershire-Worcestershire-Oxfordshire area between about 40 and 10 BC. The other is an Eastern gold quarter stater of Cunobelin struck in about AD 10-40.

Hoard of 82 Republican and imperial denarii (including 16 of Augustus) found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus? (27 BC-AD 14). Found together with jewellery.
The hoard had been discovered in İncilipınar vicinity of Göktepe village, Muğla, during a topsoil excavation in 1983. It contains 202 pieces of well preserved Roman folles (nummi).

45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'

Treasure with jewelry. 29 coins: 2 aurei, 27 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 92). Found together with an embossed gold foil diadem, 2 partiti1d earrings, 2 earrings with insectiform or endomorphic decoration, 2 rings with semi-precious st1s.
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; 2 Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in 4 bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)
1745 small flan bronze coins: Hellenistic (Lipara) - Leo I (AD 457-474).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the fill of a Roman well in a previously unknown area of the vicus and comprised 54 radiates from Gallienus (sole reign) to Tetricus II with a tpq of AD 274. The coins were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1990ss-100/10

summary: 32 silver drachms and 15 half-drachms of the Lycian League deposited c. 15 BCE.
disposition: British Museum, American Numismatic Society, Commerce

summary: The hoard was found in a copper-alloy bucket or situla and comprised 76 sestertii, 4 dupondii or asses and 1 radiate from the Flavian period to Gordian III and 65 bronzes of Postumus. These included 7 doubles sestertii from the mint of Cologne, 17 'large bronzes' from an uncertain mint, 23 'middle bronzes' of which many were cast and 18 bronzes of a size and w8 which would suggest that they were imitations.
1032 nummi of Constantius II, Gratianus, Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Magnus Maximus, Arcadius, Honorius were found near the porta principalis dextra of the fort (AD c. 400).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: The hoard comprised over 300 bronze coins dated between the 4th and fifth centuries AD.

In 1837 6 silver coins and 1 copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The 6 silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.
505 antoniniani (radiates), of which 358 are catalogued: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (AD 290).
disposition: Castello del Buonconsiglio di Trento, Italy (358 coins); Museo di Riva, Italy (126 coins, stolen)

summary: 5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the 30 tyrants' (AD 260-274).

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL XII
summary: Around 600 coins from the Maria im Kapitol hoard were acquired in 1902 by K. Hallama.

The hoard comprised 885 coins, including 576 antoniniani (radiates) and 309 nummi. Not all coins were catalogued. The hoard was offered for sale on the Antiquities Market and is thought to have come from the Ankara area.
9 coins: 2 republican denarii 4 sestertii, 2 asses, 1 bronze coin. Among them issues Claudius I and Vespasian.
249 nummi: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 317).
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia del Piemonte, Torino (197 coins); Municipio di Scarnaﬁgi (52 coins)

summary: 55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal

27 coins found together in a roll (un petit rouleau de monnaies soudées ensemble par l'oxydation) next to the wall of the temple of Zeus, in Salamis. 26 silver issues of Cyprus (Vespasian to Titus) and 1 bronze coin (Berytus).
Original hoard contained about 66 coins, of which 17 are extant. Found 'in a mound of broken flints'.
40 nummi that may have been found together. No further details
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 14 coins provided information on the issuers: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Hoard of 80 denarii. 19 coins were documented: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
5 sestertii Augustus (15 BC) - imitations
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
It comprised c. 100 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). Only 30 are now recorded: 29 sestertii, 1 as.
A hoard of uncertain size, of which only 7 coins are known from Postumus (Elmer 131, 314, 335, 565, 566, 593) to Victorinus (Elmer 683).
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).

The total number of coins originally found is unknown. There are 2 catalogues which slightly vary in the numbers of coins present. The 1 in May 1968 is entered here: Claudius II (Divus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
20 coins: Antoninus Pius - Constans (AD 337-341). Some authors consider these coins as single coin finds (Chico 2000, 352).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico Provincial de Ourense, Spain

summary: Hoard of gold jewellrey and votive plates. From the 9 votive plates, 4 of them have stamped on the golden foil aurei of Diocletianus (2 plates) and Constantius I (1 plate) and 1 with an uncertain portrait, still 1 of the tetrarchs.
Originally 460 coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates), of which 459 were documented: Titus - Valerian I (AD 253-259).

The hoard (56 nummi, from the time of Constantine I, with 1 antoninianus of Trajan Decius) was discovered in 1905 on a field, next to the road leaving Immendingen going to Möhringen. The pot, in which in which the coins were located, was lost immediately, the coins are now lost too.

The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing 60 silver and billon coins. Joullietton noted the presence of coins of Otacilia Severa ('some'), Gallienus, Saloninus and Postumus ('a large number') of which many possessed the reverse type HERC DEVSONIENSI (E. 316) The hoard was found by a farmer cutting down a cherry tree in his garden.
Hoard of sestertii found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) (AD 197-211).
disposition: History National Museum, Vilnius, (inv.no. NL 24/1-49); Town museum Rokiskis (1 coin), Lithuania

summary: 26 denarii of Augustus, all of RIC type 264 (29-27 BC).
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).

At Nettleton, during the excavation of the West Lodge, Building XVIII, 2 groups of coins have been listed separately as they seem to belong to hoards or deposits. Both groups belong to the middle and end of the 4th century. The second group (group B) only became apparent during the identification of the coins and is almost certainly too small since no coin was included unless it had all the necessary characteristics (e.g. lack of wear on these coins of Valentinian I and his co-rulers). Group B probably ends with coins of 378-83, though it is just possible that these are intrusive. This will affect the date of the deposit very little, however, for the group could have been formed and buried any time up to c. 388 when the issues of the House of Theodosius came into Britain in large numbers.
15 Roman imperial bronze coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Constantius II (AD 331-367). A lamp was found with the coins.Some doubts were issued on this discovery.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120191: 1-15

summary: A hoard of siliquae, found in a leather purse in 1838. 62 of them were sold by Seaby's in 1945. The record mentions that "2 small leather purses were found in the Turbary last year, which soon fell to dust on exposure to the air; 1 contained silver coins of the later Emperors, and the other the smallest size copper of the same era, both so much clipped that but few of the inscriptions are left."
Hoard of circa 86-87 aurei found with a ceramic vessel with a graffiti "IRENE": Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Hoard from the Roman villa at Chesters.What is menti1d in Garrett & Harris 1938 and shown on a plan (p. 97, fig. 1) is a small group of coins associated with a 'hole in upper flagged floor' in Room I. This hole was 'filled with various debris, amongst which coarse pottery, pseudo-samian ware, late coins (Decentius, Constantius II, barbarous, & minimi), twisted copper bracelet wire etc'. Also 2 glass beads.
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 240) minted in Rome and a further 1 from the mint in Viminacium (Trajan Decius, AD 251).
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Hoard of 700 imperial bronze coins in the museum of Cagliari.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: 2 radiates (Gallienus and Victorinus) found along with a gold ring beneath a st1 in the valley side around Blaen-cwm-Pennant near Llangynog. No other information is available.
43433 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 274-275); silver w8: 11726.9-54290.3 g

Found during uprooting an old tree, in a pot. The early reports give varying dates of discovery (1809 or 1810), numbers of coins (2000 or 4000 coins) and lists of emperors represented. Probably a 3rd century hoard of debased radiates, Tetricus/Quintillus/Claudius II/Gallienus, mixed later with some other coins. Today, only 7 coins preserved: 6 antoniniani of Gallienus and 1 nummus (aes III) of Valens.
disposition: Bernisches Historisches Museum (6 ex.); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (1 ex.); the rest lost

summary: 8 nummi of House of Valentinian I (AD 364-375).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: Unknown Initial number of coins. 16 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 11 provincial: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 21 were kept in the museum of Elbing: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii: Mark Antony - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elblag (former Town Museum Elbing) in 1903.

summary: A hoard of 387 antoniniani of Probus found during the excavations of the Roman fort of Vemania.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 2598 bronze coins found with a linen bag: Victorinus - Arcadius-Honorius (AD 402-408).
Unknown initial number of bronze coins. 24 pieces are kept in museum of Lovech: 1 sestertius, 23 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
The coins were 'found in a lead cremation urn containing human b1s and comprised 40 copper coins of Tiberius and 3 silver pieces.'

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA MT
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area MT, scattered hoard of 87 Theodosian coins, & 1 of Honorius from disturbed layers used to backfill medieval pit 21. Deposition date of AD 402 or later (though single Honorius could be intrusive).
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
Gold: 99 solidi: Gratian - Valentinian II (AD 388-392); Gold w8: 440.55g
51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.
118 nummi (folles) of the Tetrarchy found with a ceramic vessel.

4teen coins, including 2 Late Roman gold coins: 1 solidus of Theodosius II minted in Constantinopolis 408–420 and a tremissis (cross within wreath). "These coins are known only from a marginal, hand-writ10 note on p. 44 of Biddell’s CCC, referring to the solidus of Theodosius II and including the following description: “ex 14 coins sent by AGA [Assistant Government Agent] Matara 4.IX.35 1 has R(e)v(erse) wreath. Cross within. Below wreath letters. If COMOB †___† Avitus 455–456 †___† too Honoria ex RSM but leg(end) SALV...IE cf Aelia Galla Placidia C.11ex RA(venna) but leg(end) Salus reipublicae”.
89 denarii found with a jug: 1 Celto-Iberic, 68 republican, 20 imperial of Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: Museu d'Arqueologia de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: A hoard of 4 provincial coins of Philippi, found under the orchestra of the theatre.
147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).
8 denarii: Augustus 6, Tiberius 2 (AD 14-37).
The hoard (a purse?) comprised 8 coins of Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Quintillus.

The hoard comprised 2 ceramic urns that contained more than 100kg of Roman coins (according to Payan-Dumoulin) or 40kg (according to Vallentin) equating to approximately 12000 coins. Only 4685 coins, all radiates, were catalogued: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 3241.0-14999.1 g.

in 1852 on a hoard was dug out on a hill in a peat deposit of the Landstuhl municipality, on the island called Krimm. 11 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, Geta - Philip) were published, but it remains unclear if this is the entire find or not.
108 bronze coins of Postumus: double sestertii, sestertii, imitations (AD 267-269).

During excavations conducted in the city of Arykanda in 2011, a hoard consisting of 259 coins, was found at the site called TK3. Only 218 of these 259 coins could be identified. 41 of these coins could not be identified due to their poor condition. 4 of these 218 identifiable coins date from the first century B.C., while 214 of them date from between the years 305-457 A.D. Most of these coins date from between years 395 and 423 A.D. Mints (Table 4): Aquileia (1), Siscia (1), Thessalonice (3) Heraclea (2), Constantinople (4), Nicomedia (2), Cyzicus (14), Antioch (32), uncertain (200).
5 nummi: Constantine II (Caesar) 2, Constantius II (Caesar) 1, Constans (Caesar) 1, Urbs Roma 1 (AD 335-337) Mints: Treveri 3, Lugdunum 1, Arelate 1
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (5 coins).

summary: Aucti1d at Dorotheum in 2003, 68 nummi found near a well: Constans 55, Constantius II 13 (AD 350-351).

The hoard comprised 19 aurei, from Nero to Vespasian, no container(s) reported. It was found in the Forum of Martigny during excavations directed by Albert Naef. 14 coins found Dec. 22, 1896, in room/shop 37 to the north-east of the forum; 5 coins found (or reported) the next day, localisation not explicit (room/shop 36?).
disposition: Musées cantonaux du Valais, Cabinet cantonal de numismatique, Sion

summary: 2634 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Carus (AD 283).
26 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 294-307).
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.
The 22 late Roman and Byzantine gold coins were found in 1897 and 1898 in the field during quarrying, approx. 10 cm under the surface, between 2 flat st1s without trace of the container.

Circa 450 bronze coins were found under an old tree. The majority of coins belonging to the emperors of the latest quarter of the 4th century AD and are AE2 denominations. 5 earlier and late Chers1sus issues, 5 provincial coins and 1 nummus of Galerius were also among the coins.
Around 100 denarii, among them, 1 of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver w8: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.

A pursefind (Börsenfund) consisting of 5 bronze coins of Vespasian, found in a post hole (Pos10bau IV) surrounding a Roman settlement or camp (HA 101) at Steinstraß, on the area of the open pit mine of Hambach (Braunkohletagebau Hambach), on the Roman road Cologne - Jülich.
171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: Hoard of 2000 nummi (32) ending with issues of Constantine I (AD 306-337)
1 denarius and 2 aes (Republic to Trajan) found in the earliest level of occupation in Room 3.
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn filled with approximately 400 Roman sestertii 'dating to the era of the 12 Caesars.'

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 12 kg of small bronze Roman coins dating to the 4th century, equating to 3700 pieces. They were very corroded. Rulers represented include Constantine I (numerous), Helena, Fausta, Crispus (very numerous and mostly well preserved), Constantius II Caesar (numerous), Constantine II Caesar (more numerous than Crispus and Constantius II). Ducrocq estimated the date of deposition to be around AD 330 The hoard was found by a farmer.
130 siliquae of Constantius II minted in Sirmium. Found together with fragments from 1 or more silver vessels and a silver belt buckle.

Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver w8: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
21 antoniniani: Valerian I - Gallienus (AD 2659-268). Found in a ceramic jug with 1 handle.
disposition: National Bank of Romania, Numismatic Collection, Bucharest

summary: 38 bronze coins "in northwest by the heating system bordering the narrow room in the incendiary and debris layer above the st1 floor. They possibly form a small hoard; the composition also speaks for it."

A hoard 'buried right before the accession of Diocletian'. It consists of large brozes, especially those of Postumus, middle bronzes and circa 1200 small bronzes, 5 gold rings and a pendant necklace ".
2 solidi: Theodosius I, Zeno (barbarous style) found in a Merovingian grave.
disposition: Museum für Vor- und Frühgeschichte, Berlin (IIb 3130e, IIb 31330f; vanished in 1945)

summary: The hoard comprised '40 Gallic gold coins in the form of buttons with representations of crescents and horses'. These appear to be staters of a uniface type attributed to Ambiens.
The hoard comprised 2 black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).
7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans: Mark Antony - Vespasian (AD 76).
A purse of 14 provincial coins from Athens (period VB, VC and VI), found on the floor of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
3 imperial AE (Tiberius) and 3 uncertain imperial As found in regio IX, insula 11, dolium of the counter of building 2 (thermopolium).
A big vessel full of Roman imperial coins, bronzes and antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
(7 kg) 3488 coins: antoniniani and nummi: Trebonianus Gallus - Valentinian II (AD 375-378)
In 1873, Alph. Frappier gavie to the Société de statistique des Deux-Sèvres, 37 silver Roman coins which were said to come from a hoard found in the region.
453 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 307). Part of the Seltz hoard.
disposition: Musée Préhistorique et Gallo-Romain de Strasbourg (453 coins)

summary: 240 denarii (Commodus - Gordian III) were found during renovations of a house in 1933. The coins were to the Ingolstadt museum but lost in 1945.
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
The known part of the hoard comprised 15 silver coins from the first century AD, ending with coins of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73).
disposition: The Reuben and Edith Hecht Museum

summary: The hoard comprised 2432 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 256. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 3513.1-7304.9g
206 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).

5 denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1000 3rd century antoniniani (radiates), including an example of Gordian I or II.
4 denarii, 2 sestertii, and 1 dupondius/as (Vespasian to Septimius Severus) found in Room 18.
The hoard comprised 246 nummii found with a carbonised leather bag: Aurelian - Constantius II (AD 337-361). Not a hoard buried in purpose but a 'wallet' lost in a fire.

76 silver coins found in a building near the principia of the legionary fortress: 35 miliarenses, 41 siliquae: Constantine II, Constans, Constantius II, Vetranio, Constantius III Gallus, (AD 352-354); silver w8: 260.8-305.2g.
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 19 antoniniani found during archaeological excavations: Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus
The hoard comprised 1 or 2 vessels filled with silver and billon coinage of different sizes of which 1 was of Gallienus and 1 Postumus'
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 8000 well-preserved antoniniani (radiates) depicting 28 emperors from Gallienus to Maximian I (AD 285-293).

149 Roman provincial silver and bronze coins found with a bag during archaeological excavations: 10 silver coins (4 didrachms, 6 drachms) of Caesarea in Cappadocia, ranging from Hadrian to Septimius Severus; 139 bronze provincial coins of Trapezus, ranging from Commodus (?, or Septimius Severus?) to Philip I (certainly AD 244/5, as this is the last time Trapezus produces coins). Authors disagree on the identification of the coins of Trapezus. These are badly preserved and were never published in detail. The list given here follows Kropotkin, as given in Depeyrot's translation. Golenko has a slightly different breakdown, including the mention of 4 coins of Clodius Albinus, allegedly from Trapezus. Kapanadze and Golenko also list 7 coins of Commodus, though these were grouped with Septimius Severus as uncertain by Kropotkin. The list provided in Tsotelia / Depeyrot 2010 does not offer further clarifications.

63 silver and gold coins discovered in a burial consisting in 5 imitations of Alexander III, of Alexander staters, 51 Parthian drachms: Artabanus I or II? 2, Sinatruces 1, Phraates III 1; Mithridates III 3; Orodes II 43, Phraates IV 1; 2 drachms of Polemon I of Pontus; a denarius of Augustus; 4 aurei: aureus of Tiberius, aureus of Nero, aureus of Vitellius, and aureus of Vespasian.
300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla) (AD 193).
5 denarii, with no certainty whether they were found together.
A small hoard of 9 south-western (Durotrigan) staters.
A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.

The hoard comprised 75 gold coins. The best specimens were bought by Huppy and Raineville and after his death passed to de Rohant and de la Hayette. Gold: 75 coins; Gold w8: 333.75g. Part of the hoard VILLERS-L'HÔPITAL 1643?
disposition: Huppy, Raineville, de Rohant, de la Hayette

summary: 28 nummi: Constantine I (Crispus) - Arcadius (AD 383-408) Mints: Treveri 3, Lugdunum 2, Arelate 2, Aquileia 2, Roma 1, unidentified 13

The finder of the first coin, a stater of Cunobelin stated that the first coin had been found barely beneath the surface, in early 1971. On 27 January 1973 he and his detecting partner searched the same spot again, and found the 11 additional coins - another 7 staters of Cunobelin and 4 of Tasciovanos - up to 30 m apart and from just below the surface to about 25 cm deep. The site was said to have been disturbed by roadworks and/or the planting of a hedge, which may well have scattered the hoard.

25 coins of AD 260-290 from Poverest Road West site, thought by R. Reece to be a scattered hoard. Majority (21) found scattered on surface of an upper metalling deposit (Feature 8), other 4 were from deposits above metalling & may have been derived from it. Some tile frags. among st1s of metalled surface, & RB pottery, a bronze stud, iron nails & 2 glass beads.Philp, B. and Keller, P. 1995. The Roman Site at Fordcroft, Orpington. West Wickham: Kent Archaeological Rescue Unit, pp. 15, 28-29.
Circa 50 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
150 nummi of GENIO POPVLI ROMANI type of 3 different module sizes.
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).

The hoard comprised somewhere between 10000 and 32000 pieces, with an approximation of 15000 being the most likely. 4473 of the coins were recorded. 4471 of these belong to the Tetrarchy, 1 is dated AD 314/315. The hoard also contained a provincial coin issued in Nysa (Lydia) for Valerian.
3 aurei part of a chain, 2 mounted in pendants: Valerian I (2), Valerianus II Caesar) (AD 255-256)
67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Hoard of an unknown originally number of nummi found with a ceramic vessel. Only 3 coins are presented: Magnus Maximus 2, Theodosius I.
1200 imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268).

A hoard of 30 coins (2 uncertain, 1 Imperial Roman; 27 provincial coins: Dion, Odessa, Pella, Koinon of Macedonia, Thessalonica, Cassandrea), found in a grave in Sindos in 1981, ending with coins of Philip.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).
210 nummi of the Constantine's I family and Licinius I.
7499 bronze coins: 7486 sestertii, from Augustus to Valerian I (AD 255-256). 158 kg.
Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.
The original number of coins in the hoard was not ascertained and only the 2 Lycian drachmas were acquired.
180 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Silver w8 of 170 denarii: 503.35g.

80 bronze coins were bought by M. Alexandrov: 1 sestertius, 79 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum 38, Marcianopolis 30, Hadranopolis 4, Anchialus 2, Deultum 2, Augusta Traiana 1, Pautalia 1, Nicomedia 1.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 927-991

summary: The hoard comprised about 600 bronzes of Postumus.
+1000 silver coins, according to Gerov, B. 640 studied: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 800.6-1662.9 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria

summary: 43 coins, part of a larger hoard: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

On several occasions between 1845 and 1971, numerous wooden ex-votos were found at the source of the Roches, along with Continental Iron Age and Roman coins. The finds from 1850 included coins of Constans, Constantine and Maximinus. According to Henry and Gonod, there were also coins of Claudius, Vespasian and Titus. Rescue excavations in 1970 to 1971 recovered 11 Continental Iron Age coins, 47 coins of Octavian, 6 of Augustus, 2 semisses of Augustus or Tiberius, 1 as of Tiberius, 1 dupondius and 3 asses of Nero and numerous unidentified coins.
A hoard of more than 14 solidi dating from Constantius II to Theodosius I (Arcadius I) (AD 383-388).

The hoard comprised between 250 and 300 Iron Age bronze coins. 4 coins were identified by a Parisian expert called Feuardent as issues attributed to the Bituriges Cubi. A further 14 were of the same type (Obv: Head right; Rev: Horse, most of10 right, surmounted by a bird(?) and with an annelet or trilobe under). All coins weighed between 6.25g and 7.1g. The hoard was found during the construction of the road from Vaulry to Mas (Section C, parcelle 706). The coins were dispersed quickly.

(+250) 243 Celtic and Roman republican silver coins. 37 Celtic coins of the horseman type and inscriptions DORNACOS/AVSCROS and DVRNACVS/DONNVS. 206 Roman republican coins: 195 denarii, 11 quinarii: 211 BC - 27 BC.
disposition: Musée archéologie nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (Inv.no. 1153-1355 - Roman coins; inv.no. 1356-1392 - Celtic coins)

summary: (318?) 286 silver coins: 38 denarii, 248 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 259-268)
The hoard was found in an inhumation grave dated to the 4th century AD by its grave goods.
161 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic – Augustus (12 BC).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Apparently more than 500 coins in this hoard.
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
6 or possibly 7 aurei ranging from Nero (either 3 or 4 aurei) to Domitian, found on the farm at Brooholm.
Uncertain findingspot, presumably from the Shumen's area, as it was part of the Dr. Vasssil Haralanov collection: Republic - Augustus (19-18 BC)
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Shumen,Bulgaria (former Dr. Vasssil Haralanov collection; inv.nos. 203- 284)

summary: 58 tetradrachms of Alexandria, 1 bronze coin: Vespasian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 294-295). Found in a heap beneath the floor of a passageway during excavations of a house.
disposition: 57 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel, which was recovered in fragments and comprised 228 denarii. Part of the hoard (estimated at 58 coins) was sold but the landowner kept 200 or 201 denarii from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
About 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Bizya were found in a ceramic vessel. No further information.
(235) 234 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Philip I; silver w8: 294.1-665.3 g.
2 solidi of Valentinian II.
Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
15 nummi Tetrarchy (AD 294-305).
British gold coins and Roman denarii found in a field, opposite Lightcliffe Chapel, in a Roman vessel, between the years 1828 and 1831.
disposition: British Museum (part); Leeds Museum (part); York Museum (part)

summary: Hoard consisting of 36 solidi found 1850-1851. The last coins belong to Anastasius, but 1 of them is an imitation, which explains the tpq of AD 576.
At least 6 Gallo-Belgic E staters discovered over a period of a year or more by a single detectorist and described as having been found "a few hundred yards apart".
Large hoard. Only 25 silver coins are known: 9 denarii, 19 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver w8: 32.6-59 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3343

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 40 electrum staters. The hoard was found while digging the foundations for a new church. The majority were sold to a jeweller and dispersed. The Musée de Niort acquired some examples.
1776 denarii (5.5 kg): Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Most likely were kept in a wooden box, as 8 silver rivets "have been discovered at the site".
40-7ound with a ceramic vessel. 45 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 211-217).
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, 3 pieces of Pertinax
1424 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I/Licinius I - Gratian (AD 375-383).

A hoard of Roman bronze coins, next to a few gold 1s, found during the construction of the railrepair workshop in Neustadt. It was acquired by the museum in 3 successive lots (A-C: 26 coins, 5 coins, 1 coin).

c. 80 kg; 12000 nummi of the Tetrarchy. 5032 nummi are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana. 448 coins were presented in a catalogue by A. Jelocnik: Aurelian - Tetrarchy/Maxentius (AD 310).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5,032 coins; the rest was sold in Trieste, Italy.

summary: A hoard of 1167 denarii and 2 antoniniani found in the south-wester of the Hungerbergacker property during spring 1937. FMRD associates the deposition of the hoard with the Alamannic invasions of Raetia in AD 233 and the assemblage is notable for the high proportion of eastern mints. Coins range from the late Republic to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum Straubing (ca. half of the coins)

summary: Hoard found during railway construction work, in a copper-alloy vessel (not preserved). Mainly Tetricus or Tetricus imitations (N. Dürr, Beobachtungen zur römischen Münzprägung. JbHMB 1953, p. 34, mentions Bonosus - this is wrong!). More than 5000 coins. 5% of these were coins of Claudius II (mainly Consecration issues, mostly of barbaric fabric).

Initially 805 antoniniani (radiates). 786 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 268). It included issues from the mint of Siscia, but the number is not given. Data for other mints was not recorded.

32 gold IA British Q staters. Other coins reported at the same time included a plated silver unit of Eppillus (CCI 07.0882), an early uninscribed southern silver unit (precise type uncertain), and 2 denarii (1 plated) of Tiberius. De Jersey has not included them in the hoard, but they are listed here.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); River and Rowing Museum, Henley (part)

summary: 2 solidi of Honorius (AD 393-423); gold w8: 8.9g.
Since 2001 a number of die-linked Cheriton staters have appeared in the trade, reportedly from a hoard found near Wickham, north of Portsmouth. The total of coins in the find is unknown.
A hoard of a certain size was found in 1885 in Sandbruch. 29 coins (Magnentius - Constantius II) of this hoard are now in the Museum in Mainz.
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5000 and 9000). Only 1 piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.
1401 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Remains of a wealthy residential development was unearthed during excavation for the new synagogue. In the process 11 Roman bronze coins were found (2 großerz of Antoninus Pius, 2 mittelerz of Commodus, and klenerz from the father Tetricus).

2 different accounts exist regarding the composition of this hoard both given by M. Guéroult. In Version A, all coins were found in the bottom of the pit at a depth of 19 metres, spread over an area measuring 1 metre by 5 metres. 31 examples were identified. In Version B, the hoard was found in a greyware vessel, buried at a depth of 10m and containing approximately 200 bronzes, of which 15 were identified. It is possible that these 2 accounts represent 2 lots from the same hoard and therefore the coins have been summarised together, with a note made of whether they are menti1d in Account A or Account B. The hoard was found by workers extracting st1 from a large pit measuring 160 metres in circumference.
Initially 857 coins, only 168 silver coins are known, and jewelry found with a : Vespasian - Aurelian (Severina) (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Civico, Lodi, Italy (nowadays, 168 coins, 1 brooch and 1 silver ring); Biblioteca Laudense, Lodi, Italy

summary: A hoard of about 160 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The finder reported to me that the coins were found within a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture. No other additional information about the circumstances of the find or the composition of the hoard.
Unknown originally number of coins. 21 denarii were recovered: 18 republic, 3 Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology, Iași, Romania (inv. no. 70 051)

summary: Hoard of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 78 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Severus Alexander - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2072

summary: Record from Guildford Museum (noted on Pastscape) of a find of 9 nummi "of Diocletian, Maximian and Constatius I, dating overall AD 286-310" found as a group. A report on the coins is held by Guildford Museum (not consulted).
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.
508 bronze nummi to AD 347 to 348 in a pot.
30 imperial bronze coins: Augustus, Agrippa, Vespasian, Domitian (AD 81-96).
An undeclared hoard of 13 Corieltavian staters, said to have been found in August 2006 and recorded by a private collector.
645 denarii, 1 gold necklace and other artefacts. 154 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: 29 antoniniani, 125 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. IX

summary: The hoard comprised 60 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II.

820 denarii and antoninani: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); 640 provincial bronzes. 500 provincial coins were minted in Tomis (144 types described in detail) for issuers from Septimius Severus to Philip I. Other types were menti1d only if they were new in 1893 publication from the catalogue by Mionnet

104 silver coins from Mark Antony to Caracalla (AD 215): 103 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found spread in a debris layer in the southwest tower of the city wall. The layer was brought to level the floor after the AD 365 earthquake.

At least 4 Irstead quarter staters formerly owned by Henry Mossop were said to have been found at Cherry Hinton, 3 of which (nos 1, 3 and 4 below; Haselgrove 1989, 24) came from the same source. No further information is available on the circumstances of their discovery.
1088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9221-10309

summary: The hoard comprised a small copper-alloy vessel containing 7 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations of Tetricus I. It was found hidden under a large st1 slab.
The hoard comprised 1 as of Domitian and 2 dupondii of Trajan.
86 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 108.1-222.5 g.
498 solidi found with a ceramic vessel: Honorius - Romulus Augustulus (AD 476).

10 Roman bronze coins (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, an As of the early third century AD and a hummus of Constantius II), found by a quarryman, probably on Whita Hill. Apart from the last 4th-century coin, this is a fairly homogeneous group, but surprising as a hoard.
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with 2 golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of 1 aureus and 13 denarii found near Overley Hill, to the east of Wrekin, Shropshire, ranging from the Republican period to Vespasian, AD 79.
The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
13 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 216); silver w8: 24.9-37.2g.
Unknown circumstances of finding. 4 solidi: Honorius 1, Theodosius II 3 (AD 441-450); gold w8: 17.8g.
disposition: Musée National du Bardo, Tunis, Tunisia

summary: A hoard of 358 tetradrachms (Septimius Severus - Philip II), denarii (Crispina - Gordian III) and antoniniani (Julia Donna - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in a common-ware jar near the citadel.
5 staters of Dubnovellaunos found in a radius of c.75 m on land near Maldon.
320 Roman coins. No further information.
The hoard comprised 110 denarii: Vespasian-Severus Alexander (AD 222-235 AD).
26 solidi and 3 siliquae, ranging from Julian II to Valentinian II, found near to the Horkstow Villa. N1 of the siliquae was clipped.
2 clipped solidi - Anastasius, Justin I, found in a grave of Princess Ruru dated in AD 550.
A hoard of 4 siliquae of Theodosius, Marcian and Leo I (AD 457-474).
300 gold and bronze coins of Sauromates I (ad 93-123).
'The coins lay next to 1 another on the southern exterior of the perimeter under the wall terrace of the pillar temple. They apparently form a small hoard.'

150 bronze coins of the Lower Empire (for the most part illegible, the faces and figures sufficiently plain), found in 1815, during the demolition of a tumulus. A farmer in the neighbourhood had 2 or 3 of gold, though the Crispus coin (CRISPVS NOB CAES/VOT XX 2 Victories) is actually an AE issue.
An amphora with 2 antoniniani and 7 nummi ranging from Tacitus to the first Tetrarchy found on the seabed.
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
1361 coins: 451 antoniniani (radiates), 909 denarii, 1 as: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258). Found with a limest1 mortarium.
The hoard comprised 105 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 bronze issues and was apparently deposited c. AD 263. No reasons are given for this date for deposition.
131 Roman nummi and 1 Naimana imitation: House of Theodosius - Theodosius II (AD 425-435). Supposedly given to the Colombo Museum in 1935.
A small hoard found early in 2004, with 2 Gallo-Belgic E staters and 4 British QB staters. 5 staters found in 2013-2014 are thought to be part of this hoard as well.

The hoard was found in a cave shelter and comprised numerous ancient objects including pottery vessels, hipposandals and a sestertius of Hadrian, a dupondius of Antoninus Pius and a worn coin of another emperor, possibly Macrinus.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 2 silver bracelets, 2 gold finger rings and 197 radiates from Gordian III, Philip, Philip II, Otacillia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Saloninus.
17 bronze coins with the latest issues of Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, 2 coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
19 gold medallions, a gold chain with 52 pendant amulets, 24 gold foil rings, a disk-shaped pendant, a ring, the fragment of a bracelet, and a pendant in the shape of a human figure.
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna, Austria; Hungarian National Museum, Budapest

summary: 2 wooden caskets (wooden has vanished) comprising coins and jewelry were found at 50 cm 1 from the other in a pithos pit in the citadel of Artezia. Inside the casket were 99 Bosporan bronze coins, which had most probably initially been placed in a small purse made of cloth or leather. The coins were thoroughly arranged in rouleaus. In the casket, there was also a large gold ring with which a small pile of 9 silver Roman denarii had fused. Under the ring in the cluster of coins, an iron knife had been found with a bronze ring, which had stuck to its blade when oxidization had taken place. Further finds had been 7 small trilobate iron-tanged arrowheads and 1 bronze bilobate socketed arrowhead dating from the Hellenistic period. Several bronze bracelets were found in the casket, made from thin wire which had collapsed in pieces; an elegant bronze ring; a spring-clasp earring made of poor-quality silver; 2 curved bronze strap buckles with a protruding tongue; a curved strap fas10er with 2 rivets on a rectangular plate, a small bronze ring, a silver buckle, bronze pincers, the fragmentary remains of a bow-shaped fibula with a broad back-plate and a fragment of a thin-walled convex plaque made of bronze. On the bottom of the casket between the coins and the jewelry items there lay on its side a figured 2-sided glass unguentarium. On top of the coins and jewelry there lay 2 large hollow silver anklets, and inside these, there was a necklace made of large eye-beads, an astragal, a large b1 pendant-cum-talisman triangular in shape, and also a small bronze amulet made of 2 pipes soldered together, which collapsed in part when it was being cleaned. On the casket, 2 small 1-handled jugs made from blue and white and greenish-yellow transparent glass had been standing in situ. While the hoard was being cleaned fragments of another glass vessel had also been found and 2 narrow-necked thin-walled unguentaria as well.

A hoard of Roman coins, contained in an earthenware vessel, was discovered about 1902 while digging for gravel (shale) for the parapets of local roads on the rock. 6 of the coins were of Constantine the Great (310-15 A.D.)
Ove 42 bronze coins. Only 6 coins were recovered and studied. tHey were all struck for Gaius with the same coin dies. All 6 pieces are imitations, possible from a local mint.
14 sestertii: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
An inhabitant of Lusignan found the hoard while digging.
The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel holding approximately 300 'small bronzes' (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 263).
7 bronze coins finds found in excavations: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 59/1-5

summary: It comprised 48 Kg of coins, in 3 earthen pots. The hoard was divided in several lots including 1 of 758 coins for P. Chenu. After some studies, this lot comprised 795 coins, from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 284-305).
12 provincial coins ranging from Commodus to Philip (Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedononia) found in grave 8 in Meth1.
26 antoniniani found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma' with a small ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
232 Imperial AE found in the Villa Diomede. Among the issuers Galba and Vespasian.

In 1953 a hoard was salvaged between Jahn and Gerhart-Hauptmannstraße. Only part of the hoard could be saved. Coins include 87 denarii, sestertius and dupondii, ranging from Nero (?) to Severus Alexander.

Funerary deposit of 5 denarii in a Late Roman grave: Trajan - Commodus (AD 192). In the same grave were found: a bronze brooch, an iron brooch, an iron bracket, 1 thorn, an iron firesteel and 2 knives.
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: 7 nummi displayed as funerary offering near the skeleton: House of Constantine I t- House of Valentinian I (AD 367-375).
Initially were found 81 coins. 44 coins: 1 cistophorus, 1 sestertius, 9 asses, 33 unknown bronze denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Arheoloski Muzej Istre, Pula, Croatia (44 coins); othewise dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.
A roll of 8 corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
3 coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trus2rthy and the coins are not preserved.
636 nummi of the House of Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 328-329).
3 Gallo-Belgic C staters believed to have been found together.
53 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 223).
5 burned nummi of the 4th century, 1 issue by Gratian (Siscia, AD 367-375).
