disposition: Regional Museum of History, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 13

summary: The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.
4 coins, probably part of a larger find: Probus antoninianus (radiate), Constantine I nummus, Valentinian I nummus, uncertain bronze (AD 364-367).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic and collection E. Štorcha.

summary: 9 kg of bronze coins found in ceramic vessels while ploughing. 1076 coins are kept in the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 7670-8441 (772 coins); inv.no. 8/1-45 - Harlanov collection

summary: 10 denarii: Domitian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised c. 200 antoniniani (radiates) (tpq AD 274).
At least 4 denarii found on a field: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I).
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates). Only 12 were identified, all being of Valerian I.
152 nummi: Constantius II, Constantius II Gallus (Caesar), Julian II (Caesar). Together were found 2 bronze rings.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Adria, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 28 4th century nummi from a variety of mints, found in a vase.

A hoard of at least 120 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 and early 2018, possibly in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the first 52 coins were published on September 19, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. The circumstances of the find, described by the finder, are not completely clear. From the description it follows that he collected the coins in 1 field (ploughed hoard?), but later reported that bronze “military” brooches (Almgren VII type?), glass beads, many fragments of grey pottery were also found here. Probably, the hoard was discovered on the territory of the settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture or near it, and the hoard also included some coins from the settlement. The treasure hunter collected coins in several batches: mid-September 2017 – 52 denarii; by December 2017 – plus another 20-30 coins; by early February 2018 – 21 more coins; and by the end of February 2018 – plus 30 coins (i.e., at least 120-130 coins in total). Almost immediately after the coins were published, the finder was selling them on Violity auction.
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised over 1000 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. 640 coins have been seen: Titus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The coins (130 nummi from the time of Constantine I) were found in 1901 in Breisach, close to the Radbrunnen. The coins were described, but are now lost.

1300 antoniniani (radiates). "Due to the poor state of preservation of the radiates hidden in Varzi, which were completely covered by corrosive elements… The first group of 95 radiates were restored between 2020 and 2021 […] The issuing authorities are Gallienus (3%), Claudius II (64%), Quintillus (8%) and Aurelianus (3%). The remaining part (22%) consists of unidentifiable specimens. Only 43 radiates can be attributed (for now) to a specific mint: the majority to the Siscia 1 (86%), followed by Rome (11%) and Mediolanum (3%)."
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio, Pavia, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 300 coins of which 50 were Augustan asses of the altar of Lyon type.
369 bronze coins: 368 sestertii, 1 as: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-261).
(160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver w8: 181.8-353.2 g.
A hoard of late Roman coins comprising 19 gold solidi, 114 silver siliquae and 2 copper-alloy radiates. The silver coins are all clipped.
A hoard of 50 coins found in a Roman building: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 4 denarii, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 24 provincial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

1 sestertius (Lucilla) and 29 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Julia Mamaea. The sestertius was not menti1d in FMRD. No trace of container was found, although it could have been made of organic material.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens

summary: A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in 3 videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including 1 broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, 1 of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.

The hoard comprised a ceramic lamp containing 3 coins including a quinarius of Faustina II and 2 4th century nummi. TAF interprets this assemblage as being funerary in nature as it was found during the excavation of a tumulus.
24 silver coins: 3 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Caracalla - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2372

summary: A hoard of 12 provincial coins of Gordian III and Tranquillina (Thessalonica and Edessa), found during the excavations of a farmhouse in ancient Lete (preceding the construction of the Egnatia motorway) and linked to the Gothic invasions of the middle of the 3rd c. AD.
4 denarii to Titus found by a metal detectorist near the fort of Brecon Gaer
The assemblage contained between 200 and 300 bronze coins. Blanchet interpreted this assemblage as a votive deposit.
Unknown number of solidi. 23 have been described: Valentinian I - Zeno (AD 474-476).
37 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No details on the structure.
The hoard comprised fragments of a greyware vessel containing 90 sestertii from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 261.
On 4th April, 1950, between 346 and 369 coins and pieces of pottery were dug up by workmen at Acacia Avenue, Laleham Road, Sunbury.
67 potin coins. These could be were Massiliot issues or more plausibly Kentish derivatives.
1055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: (36) 34 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip (AD 244-249).
56 antoniniani (radiates) found on the western wing of the cryptopórtico of the forum of Conimbriga: Gallienus (sole) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

The hoard comprised a redware ceramic vessel containing more than 200 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which 185 were catalogued by A. Dubiez: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 251.6-568.4g.
disposition: A denarius of Macrinus was acquired for the Claudius Côte Collection in Lyon.

summary: 104 denarii: 99 republican, 5 of Augustus (AD 19-18 BC).

296 AE radiates to AD 286. The coins were 1.5ft below the plough soil with no visible signs of a container. A circular, corroded stud with a narrow band and possible inscription was also discovered with the hoard. This is believed to be Medieval or post-Medieval and, as such, is not considered part of the hoard. A farthing (Seaby, 3992) was also found with the coins during conservation.Addenda of 618 coins found in 2104 added here.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver w8: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: 70 coins: 35 sestertii, 27 dupondii, 8 asses hidden in the wall of a Roman building: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 8 silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver w8: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal b1s.
2 aurei found in a lead sarcophagus: Trajan Decius, Tacitus (AD 275-276).
(c. 1000) 995 silver coins: 203 denarii, 792 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 1277.0-2659.3 g.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly 1 hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and 1 of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.
2 aureii of Vespasian from a lost hoard of 70-100 aureii, all of Vespasian
The hoard comprised 9 nummi of the House of Constantine with a tpq of AD 309 to 315. It was found on the banks of the River Danube.
The hoard comprised 252 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Quietus with a tpq of AD 260. It was found in 2 ceramic vessels.

On December 1978, a hoard of 47 Roman silver siliquae was found on Gallows Hill, Thetford. The coins were found in a compact mass. Subsequently, 27 more siliquae were found (20 found in August 1981, and another group of 7 found in July 1982), bringing the total to 74, ranging from Constantius II to Magnus Maximus. About 450 m. from the findspot of the siliquae hoard, the Thetford treasure of gold and silver jewellery and silver spoons was found in 1979.
10 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Claudius II to Probus (276-282) found in a grave.
3 solidi (Gratian, Theodosius I and Valentinian II), found in July 2005.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 01 comprises 262 coins, including Iron Age, Roman Republican and Roman Imperial coins.
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).
77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver w8: 31.3-136.1 g.
Hoard of more than 4000 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) sestertius - Honorius.
6442 silver coins: 6395 denarii, 47 antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); w8 of 21 kg.
1 barbarous imitation of a Roman gold coin found in a grave together with a denarius of Augustus coin of Caius and Lucius and a plausible drachm of Gotarzes II.
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).

95 or 96 denarii were found near the Danube by the c frew of a ship. The coins were distrubuted to various person and melted down. There is some numismatic information on only 7 of the coins: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Commodus 1, Severus Alexander 4.; silver w8: 11.2-17.9g.
The hoard comprised 34 denarii ending with Tiberius.
Uknown originally number of coins. 443 pieces were recovered: Claudius II - Honorius (AD 395-408).
A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.
13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II part of a larger hoard?
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: Hoard of 1312 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found 2 impressive silver gilded brooches, a bronze ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: The hoard comprised 10 Imperial denarii. No further details were given regarding the composition of the hoard.
1 solidus and 8 siliquae, ranging from Julian to Gratian, found in September 2002, scattered over an area of some 30 yards square, during a metal detecting rally.
A hoard of 200 coins, 'mostly silver, 10 of gold, but only a brass of Domitian', found at Crown Inn, Trafford Street, in 1840.
The hoard comprised gold coins including 2 multiples of aurei of Gallienus and Constantine I.
Mint distribution is menti1d so can probably be entered at level of coin. Silver: 107, 28 coins; silver w8: 20.3-132.8g.
disposition: Société de recherches de l'Atrèbatie septentrionale

summary: Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: (100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver w8: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: 98 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria found with a ceramic vessel: Probus - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 291-292). Briefly examined by Martin Price.
The hoard comprised 49 sestertii from Trajan to Philip I and 2 Provincial bronzes from Patras (Caracalla).
The hoard comprised 1735 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC) from a shipwreck.
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
49 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 36 denarii, 13 quinarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

Building D was a st1-walled rectangular structure with an aisled area & a series of separate rooms, & a bath-suite.Room 21 was in the NE corner, and originally 11 ft long and 14 ft wide, with heavily robbed wals & an op. sig. concrete floor, replaced twice by similar floors. In use with the second of these floors was a large pit 3 ft 16 in. wide, 9 ft long & 1 ft 9 in deep, with sharp sides & a cleanish filling. This may have held some form of tank or container. In final phase of room the pit was filled in & covered with concrete to bring it to level of surrounding floor, & in this concrete was found a small hoard of 5 coins (AD 330-341).Stead, I.M 1976. The Roman villa at Winterton. In I.M. Stead Excavations at Winterton Roman Villa and Other Roman Sites in North Lincolnshire 1958-1967. DoE Archaeol. Reports 9. London: HMSO, pp. 46.
20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: 2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
156 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 143 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 8 asses; silver w8: 6.4-8.6g.
15 antoniniani found together: Gallienus - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
5 solidi: Constantine II - Arcadius (AD 383-408).

During agricultural works, followed by archaeological investigations 2 gold coins were found in a grave: solidus of Constantine I minted in Nicomedia (AD 324-325), and an imitation aureus of Numerian.

23 British Iron Age silver and debased silver coins found on farmland near Donhead St Andrew in Wiltshire in 2012. The coins were scattered over a small area within the plough-soil. During the same period, the finder uncovered a separate concentration of 3 Iron Age coins, around 65m from the first. The second group comprised 1 gold coin and 2 silver or debased silver coins. What were apparently 2 separate deposits could not be separated and have therefore been treated together by the PAS.
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.

The hoard comprised '93 or 99 Gaulish silver coins of 2 different dimensions, but of the same type.' It is likely that they were actually pale gold staters or quarter staters of type BN 6957-6961 and 6972-6979 attributed to Baiocasses. Found at the foot of a tree. 3 examples are accessi1d in the Musée de Rouen.
The hoard comprised 96 bronze coins from the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).

Within circular pit 1.22m diameter & 0.68m deep, in corner of Room 11 in 'Northern Group' of villa rooms, there were 3 small, coarse handmade cooking vessels, animal b1s & portions of skulls, with cut marks, iron knives, & 13 coins from Constantine II to Fel. Temp. Rep., with 1 of Tetricus II. Suggest pit filled in after AD 345-361. Pit occupied NW corner of back corridor before gravel floor of vestibule laid over it, in the 'Northern Group' of villa rooms.
Over 191 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: 1 Aurelian, 190 Probus (AD 276-282).
The coins were found during excavation work on Südbahnhof towards Leoplatz.
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 665 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 168.4-774.0 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (647 coins); Ilie Constantin private collection from Caracal, Romania (18 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a st1 conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.
5 nummi (c. AD 364-95) removed from the beach by mechanical excavator in 1988.

The hoard was found in a well under the Roman ramparts and comprised 18 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins were from the mint of Rome, with the exception of a denarius of Severus Alexander from Antioch and 2 denarius copies of Caracalla and Severus Alexander.

A Roman coin hoard was found in the field of a sexton containing more than 100 silver and copper coins, with most of the silver coins made of bad alloy. The sources mention coins of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Gallienus, Salonina, Aurelian and Probus. 4 coins are listed in FMRD, of which a description exists. It can be assumed that the hoard comprised mostly antoniniani of the middle of the third century AD and was buried between 276 and 284 A.D.
19 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 18 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 352-361). Found in the House with the median apsis.
Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.

Roll of 12 silver coins, dating to the Roman Republic and Augustus, found during excavations. Roman Republic: 1 half victoriatus, 6 denarii and 2 quinarii; Augustus: 2 denarii and 1 quinarius. The total sum equals 150 asses.
63 denarii found with pot sherds: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Septimius Severus (AD 198-200). Found on the same field as GANDARVE 1927 by the same finder.
4 solidi of Honorius found over a period of a year.
Found by a fisherman amongst rocks off the coast of Ambleteuse. Silver: ? (137) coins; Silver w8: ? (24.8-43.8g)
disposition: Boulogne (statue, cup, spoons); The British Museum (ewer)

summary: 763 coins found with a bronze jug. It comprises mainly nummi of Constantius II and his caesares. The earliest coin is a denarius of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I. The latest coin is a nummus of Julian II (AD 361-363).
24 silver found in a ceramic vessel: 18 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 34.1-63.8 g.
At least 140 solidi and 1 aureus (Gordian III), found in 2 lots (1822 and 1838), but certainly belonging to the same hoard. Tpq of AD 430/445.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin (76 coins); Archäologisches Institut der Georg-August-Universität Göttingen (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a finger ring with an intaglio depicting Mercury, a worn dupondius, 64 denarii and 75 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus. The objects and coins were enclosed in a leather bag which had been placed in a small recess in the foundations of a third-century building.
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Approximately 500 sestertii from Flavian issues to Valerian I found during the construction and landscaping of the military stadium in Cherchell. The hoard was dispersed immediately after discovery, with many being sold to Italian collectors, but some of the coins were acquired by the Collection Bouchereau in Algiers.
144 coins: 4 aurei, 140 antoniniani: Gordian III - Philip I; gold w8: 17.6 g; silver w8: 175.0 g. Together with a silver brooch.
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).
A hoard of 50 + large bronze coins of Ephesus, with some of Smyrna and 1 of Colophon dating to the 2nd century AD.
122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
About 20 antoniniani (radiates) found during prospections. Only 10 of them were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus or Gallienus (sole reign) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
5000 antoniniani (radiates) found with more ceramic pots. Only 2249 were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 272).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa; Museu Municipal do Bombarral; Museu Municipal Pedro Nunes, Alcácer do Sal, Portugal; private collection, Barcelona, Spain

summary: Hallaton: Hoard from context 75 which forms a separate group from the helmet pit. It comprises 702 Iron Age coins and 19 Roman denarii.
41 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 41 imitations in an alloy of copper and lead: 1 Valerian I, 40 Gallienus (AD 257-258).
85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).

Fused hoard, possibly the result of burning; leaving a distorted mass of what once had been 4 or more coins. Traces of a Roman style bust can be seen on the top layer - possibly a late Roman effigy but this remains subjective. Total w8 is 9.21g so each coin must average 2.30g or less depending on quantity.

1500 bronze coins (“oboli”) - nummi. “The Roman coins range from Diocletianus to Theodosius II, and there were also 18 Naimana imitations. This list is confused however by Codrington’s final sen10ce: “Some of these came from Mr. Trefusis’ fi nd on Shakerley estate”. Pearson, relying on the observation that the busts (in how many cases?) on the coins were facing the wrong direction (i. e. the left), declared all these coins to be imitations.”
A hoard of 8 bronze coins from the Severan time (after AD 192), found in grave 27A in the western cemetery of Pella.

1 of 3 coin hoards found in a villa on 8een Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD (see Robertson nos. 649 and 888). 67 coins, ranging from Valerian I to Allectus, placed in a cist dug in the earth together with animal b1s, pieces of coarse pottery, and a blue bead, nearly the size of a walnut.
The hoard comprised a shipwreck assemblage of 1500 bronze coins from the reign of Constantius II.
The hoard comprised 'a large number of bronze coins, apparently in gold or silver. 4teen were identified as issues of Aurelian.
15 nummi: House of Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402). In a glass jar from a destruction layer of a Roman house.
87 silver coins found in the "Ancient theater": Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
5 aurei (Nero - Domitian) found during the excavation of the legionary fortress in Caerleon. The aureus of Titus has M engraved on obv.

At least 3000 denarii were found in ceramic vessel (2 of silver and 1 of bronze, at least). A gold medallion of Jovian. Together were found silver plates. It is not clear whether there were 1 or 2 hoards discovered. The denarii run from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (Byzantine vessels, Med); Shevchenko Museum, Lvov (362 den.); Ukrainian National Museum, Lvov (61)

summary: The hoard comprised 327 sestertii and 3 dupondii from Galba to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 233.

Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.
34 British coins declared Treasure in 1983 with group I.
53 solidi found on the seabed: Valentinian I - Honorius (AD 395-423). Probably, it was kept in a wooden chest.
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
A hoard of 936 nummi (Tetrarchy), found 2 hours west of Oraio.

The hoard comprised 11 sestertii from Domitian to Balbinus. The coins in the hoard were stacked on top of each other and corroded together, forming a cylindrical shape. It appears they were originally in a small bag or pouch which has not been preserved.
110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: Group of 2 dupondii: Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II (Diva) (AD 175-180).

26 gold solidi and 4 silver siliquae, ranging from Valens to Honorius, with an addenda of a further solidus of Arcadius (394-5), found in 2012, about 12 miles south–west of Norwich. The coins were found scattered over an area measuring about 30 m by 20 m. J A Davies, CHRB X, p. 468.
Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a 7 year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
60 denarii (Nero to Domitian), but only 1 is known and recorded.

A find of 43 Roman bronze coins, ranging from Agrippa to Domitian, associated with 18 Ancient British coins of the 'Hod Hill' type (Durotrigan, uninscribed) in an earthenware vessel found is Timsbury, in 1907. The find included several Claudian copies (3 of which are now in the BM). The coins were 1 "first brass", 42 "middle brass", and 18 Ancient British AE: AE Ancient British 18 Agrippa 3 Claudius 24 Nero 9 Vespasian 4 Domitian 3 61 (Sir) John Evans, in NC, 1908, 80 NC, 1908, Proc., 11, stated that "the imperial bronze coins ex10ded from Agrippa to Domitian, the latest being struck circa AD 90 [sic]." F.A. Walters, in NC, 1907, 360, said the hoard contained "several of these rather barbarously executed coins of Claudius." Cp. D. Allen, Problems of the Iron Age in Southern Britain (1961), 244
11 Republican denarii and 6 Imperial denarii (Augustus and Vespasian) found in regio VI, insula 2, building 4 (house).
2 gold coins of Valentinian III: 1 solidus, 1 half solidus (semissis) (AD 435-445).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML 349) in private collection

summary: Hoard originally with 50 coins from the reign of Claudius I. Only 4 coins were studied.
52 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 269). 1 Denarius.
2 solidi apparently found in the same garden: Leo I, Libius Severus. A solidus of Justinian I is not certain as is belonging to the same find as it is menti1d "Guéret surroundings".

10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.
The hoard comprised 7 denarii from the Republic to Domitian.

1022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second 1 it was pre10ded to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just 1 hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: 241 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 67.4-624.3 g.

Hoard consisting of 14 gold coins, a gold mouth piece of a sword scabbard, a couple of gold spiral rings, a whole and a fragment of a gold bar found 1839. The hoards ends with coins of Zeno (AD 476-491), but as it contains imitation solidi, its tpq is set to AD 500.
Hoard of 100-200 of Republican denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Together was found some silver jewelrey.
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Some information on 4 of them: Vespasian 2, Faustina I/II, Julia Domna (AD 196-217).

2 denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. 1 might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.
The hoard comprised approximately 100 'small bronzes' - 'radiates' of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II The hoard was found in the Reverchon quarry
Unknown number of denarii. V. Haralanov studied 52 pieces: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown number of bronze coins. 387 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Marcus Aurelius - Gallienus (AD 260-268). 13 coins are countermarked.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 23101-23493
